webTitle: FA Cup: Everton see light at the end of the tunnel

fields.headline: Everton see light at the end of the tunnel
fields.standfirst: Old Merseyside foes primed for family tie
fields.trailText: Everton v TranmerePreview Two almost incestuously intertwined Merseyside foes are primed for a family tie.
fields.body:
The working relationship between Everton and the gods of sporting fate has been so strained in recent seasons that the belief inside Goodison Park was that the club's FA Cup fourth-round opponents were bound to be Manchester United.

The pessimists in blue also assumed it would not just be United, but United at Old Trafford, probably on an afternoon when David Beckham decided to slip in a football match between film premieres and awards ceremonies.

But for once the balls fell kindly, if mischievously. No, not the great United but instead the worthy Rovers from Tranmere, Everton's near neighbours from just across the water.

Those with only a peripheral knowledge of the two clubs' recent history and their almost incestuous intertwining could be forgiven for regarding tomorrow's meeting as nothing more than a parochial spat, aristocrats against alleycats. Not so.

For one thing there is the Peter Johnson factor. Johnson, the food magnate dubbed Hamperman by more vindictive Everton fans, was chairman at Goodison until December 1998 when he was swept from power by the will of the people and carried back whence he came - Tranmere's Prenton Park - on a tide of savage condemnation.

Despite having sold Everton's talisman Duncan Ferguson without first having the courtesy to inform his manager Walter Smith, Johnson seemed surprised by the ferocity of the backlash. He has not set foot inside Goodison since and will not be present tomorrow when the two clubs that touched his heart and emptied his wallet contest an FA Cup tie for the first time since 1968.

His girlfriend of some years will be there, though, for Lorraine Rogers is the Tranmere chairman. A former merchant banker with a penchant for fine hats, she has successfully redefined Tranmere's financial infrastructure and is making a good fist of disproving the traditional, if tired, theory that women are incapable of thriving in what is avowedly a man's world.

With average home attendances of less than 8,000 Tranmere are always more likely to be in the red than pink, so Rogers could be forgiven for undertaking a head-count at tomorrow's game.

"What we wanted was an away draw against a top Premiership club and that is what we got," said Tranmere's manager John Aldridge. "Hopefully the additional income we receive from this tie will perhaps help us bring in a new player or two."

The money will indeed be most welcome. With the house-full signs almost certain to go up outside Goodison, Tranmere can expect to collect in excess of £250,000 for their day trip through the tunnel to see how the other half lives.

From Everton's perspective, the FA Cup once again has a dual fascination. Not only does it offer a realistic, viable route towards something substantive and shiny, it is providing blessed relief from another forgettable league campaign.

Interestingly, perhaps significantly, Smith will be delighted to learn that there is a parallel to be drawn. Everton have been treading water at the Premiership's deep end for so long it is easy to forget that only six years ago Joe Royle's dogs of war swept through to the final - conceding only one goal en route - and emerged victorious against Manchester United.

That game was a less than appealing spectacle but, to re-emphasise the links between Liverpool L4 and Birkenhead, the man who scored the solitary goal was Paul Rideout, the nomadic striker who quit Everton for spells in China and the United States before returning to join, yes, Tranmere.

"It will be good to return to one of my former clubs," he said. "Financially the tie is wonderful for the club, but the players' priority is staying in the First Division."

When Rideout opts to reminisce about the good old days across the Mersey he is not a lone voice. Tranmere is also now home to Kevin Sheedy, Everton's midfielder of the 80s and Aldridge's current assistant, and the striker Stuart Barlow, the man they called Jigsaw because he fell to pieces in the box.

Everton's love affair with the FA Cup is often understated; they have reached the final five times in the past 17 seasons and no club has appeared in more semi-finals.

"The FA Cup has always had a very special place in the hearts of all Everton supporters," said the club's vice-chairman and majority shareholder, Bill Kenwright.

"Some people have been saying that, in recent seasons, the competition has lost some of its very special magic, its very special appeal, but not for us it hasn't."

webTitle: Ron Atkinson: Strachan deserves support and not derision

fields.headline: Strachan deserves support and not derision
fields.trailText: Gordon Strachan is facing his toughest test yet, but rounding on him is not the answer - especially when everyone shares responsibility.
fields.body:
I was horrified at the sight of Coventry fans remonstrating with Gordon Strachan after the 3-1 home defeat by Everton last Saturday. And the fact that the supporters are not the only ones making their feelings known is a sign of the problems at Highfield Road.

The way in which the chairman Bryan Richardson has stuck by Gordon is highly commendable but where I strongly disagree with Bryan, who is a personal friend, is in his decision to criticise the players publicly.

By doing that he may have alienated them. Bryan might say they couldn't do any worse, and he's certainly entitled to call the squad into a room to let them know what he thinks, particularly with the manager's permission. But I don't feel any good comes from mouthing off in public.

Sometimes that looks as if it's passing the buck, and the fact is that everyone shares responsibility. I'm sure Gordon knows he has to take as much blame as any of the players, given that he's responsible for choosing the team and the tactics, and the board have a share as well.

They may have been the people who decided Robbie Keane had to leave last summer. It may also be that Gary McAllister's contract should have been sorted out earlier to stop Liverpool taking him as a Bosman bargain. Whatever, the bottom line is that Coventry have gone rapidly backwards.

After having quite a decent season last year and finishing 14th, they have not properly replaced Keane and McAllister, the leading scorers last season who shared 23 of the club's 47 Premiership goals, or Noel Whelan, for whom I have the highest regard as a striker.

David Thompson from Liverpool looks a good prospect but Craig Bellamy has not yet justified his £6.5m price tag and players have been brought for £1m here and £500,000 there over recent seasons without making any great impact. I'm thinking of people such as Ysrael Zuniga, Ivan Guerrero and John Aloisi.

Lee Carsley, who joined for £2m last month, is a useful midfielder but the midfield area doesn't seem to be the main priority. The real problem is scoring goals and maybe that money should have been put towards bringing in someone such as Clinton Morrison or bringing back Darren Huckerby.

As it was, because Cédric Roussel didn't want to go to Wimbledon, Gordon couldn't sign John Hartson, although I'm not sure Hartson would be the answer, knowing how Gordon puts an emphasis on physical fitness and players who can train consistently.

As far as preparation goes, a change of environment or training might help. Concentrating on a livelier, lighter approach or going away somewhere might get a response, and every little helps because this is Gordon's biggest challenge.

I know Gordon well, having managed him at Manchester United and then signed him for Coventry in 1995 on the premise that he would have a couple of years learning the ropes and then succeed me.

The chairman asked me when I took the job if I would groom a young manager and it was between Gordon and Chrissie Waddle. Chrissie was a key player then at Sheffield Wednesday, whereas Gordon had been more or less told by Leeds that he had no playing future there.

I involved Gordon in everything, whether it was sitting in on transfer deals or having a considerable input in training. His biggest strength is his enthusiasm and his ability to work endless hours, but he now faces a test of his man-management skills more than anything.

Inevitably Gordon will be feeling the pressure and the strain but it's vital he doesn't go under because if the players see him do that their heads will drop. If they see him busy and enthusiastic, geeing them up, that will keep them going.

Unless it all affects his family overmuch I can't see Gordon quitting because he's a very proud man, and in any case it's by no means a lost cause. It's not as if Coventry are in the position Nottingham Forest were when I went there in 1998. They're very much in contact in the table and a lot of their players can draw on experience of how to get out of such situations.

What it will need, though, is a real togetherness from top to bottom. And that includes backing from the fans, who should remember that one of the best displays ever in a Coventry shirt was Gordon Strachan's at Tottenham in a game we won 3-1 in 1995 to stay up. I just hope he can have the same impact from the sidelines.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Clubs lose £40m a year to injury

fields.headline: Clubs lose £40m a year to injury
fields.standfirst: Wilkinson calls for a winter break and less time off in the summer
fields.trailText: Howard Wilkinson has called for a winter break and less time off in the summer in an attempt to reduce the annual £40m cost of injuries in English football.
fields.body:
Injuries to footballers in England cost the game £40m each season but more could be done to prevent them if players were better trained and coaches made more aware of sports medicine.

The most thorough survey yet of football injuries, published yesterday, found that at any one time 10% of a squad were unable to train because of injury, causing each player to miss an average of four games a season. With an annual wage bill of £400m, the survey estimates that 10% of this figure is the cost of injured players to the clubs.

The survey was carried out by the Football Association and involved an audit of players' injuries at 91 of the country's 92 league clubs, covering 2,376 professional players. The survey was compiled from July 1997 to the end of May 2000.

In all 6,030 injuries were reported, approximately two-thirds occurring during competitive matches and the remainder in training. It found that strains and sprains represent 69% of all injuries and that the peak time for injury was August, when the football season starts and many players have just returned from a long break.

Running accounted for 19% of all injuries, and 15% and 9% were the result of being tackled and tackling.

Those involved in the survey, organised by Alan Hodson, the FA's head of sports medicine, have called for better-trained coaches and for training to be modified so that the high level of injuries could be prevented. There was an average of 1.3 injuries per player per season.

Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, also called for the end-of-season break to be shortened so players sustain fewer injuries during the opening month of the season and in July, when the survey showed almost 500 players were lost to injury. He also said a shorter summer break should be combined with a midwinter break.

Wilkinson added: "Most players have a fairly long break between the end of the football season and the start of a new one. They come back after a long break to a period of hard work and then this is followed by competitive matches ... football should do something about trying to limit its long summer break, as they have done on the continent."

Hodson called for better training of coaches and improved training techniques. He said: "Club's training strategies have to take into account, how injuries can be reduced. With better training of coaches the situation is improving."

Premier League plans to make a Uefa coaching licence compulsory for all managers would also help increase awareness of sports medicine.

John Barnwell, the chief executive of the League Managers' Association, which supported the survey along with the Premier League and the Professional Footballers' Association, said: "The coaching licence includes modules about diet, players' health and other areas of physiology."

He added that the days of players being forced to play despite injury had long gone and that today's professionals were unlikely to suffer from arthritis and other ailments as many retired footballers currently do.

This view, however, is at odds with an article in the current issue of the British Journal of Sports Medicine, which alleges that managers and coaches are putting pressure on players to play through injuries and that club doctors and physiotherapists lack the independence to stand up to clubs.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Chesterfield under investigation
fields.trailText: Chesterfield, the leaders of the Third Division, may face expulsion from the Football League if an investigation uncovers financial irregularities.
fields.body:
Chesterfield, the leaders of the Third Division, may face expulsion from the Football League if an investigation uncovers financial irregularities.

A delegation from the FA and the Football League visited Saltergate yesterday after receiving complaints about the club's business practices since Darren Brown succeeded Norton Lea as chairman last May.

The FA refused to confirm the precise nature of the allegations but it is believed they centre on the alleged non-payment of gate receipts to Bristol City from the FA Cup first-round tie in November and delays in paying for Luke Beckett's £150,000 transfer from Chester City.

"If financial irregularities are proven, we have almost limitless powers," an FA spokesman said last night. "That could include banning the club from all competitions, demoting them or deducting league points. At this stage it's too early to say what could happen to Chesterfield but I can confirm they are under investigation after allegations of various incidents were brought to our attention."

Brown, a 29-year-old printer, is the youngest chairman in the league. His UK Sports Group also owns the Sheffield Sharks basketball team and the Sheffield Steelers and Hull Thunder ice hockey clubs.

Brown's ice hockey arm is also in trouble. Unpaid players in Sheffield and Hull plan to hold meetings today to decide whether to fulfil this weekend's fixtures. Hull have also been hit by the walkout of their Great Britain defenceman Stephen Cooper.

According to the Steelers' manager David Simms his players "are all unhappy, all a little bit miffed. Obviously they just want their pay and we've told them we will do whatever we can to ensure they have that prior to the game [v London]. There have been rumblings of no-pay no-play from a couple of politicians among the squad, but I don't think that will be an issue".

Simms claims the players have seen statements showing enough money is in the club's accounts to meet the unpaid wages. However, as of yesterday those accounts remained frozen after a winding-up order served recently by a finance company over a debt which has since been settled.

The Ice Hockey Players' Association claims that Hull players are owed a total of £27,800. Chesterfield have been late in paying their players on one occasion this season, when the club blamed a faulty fax machine. A deal to buy the local greyhound stadium and move the team away from Saltergate, which does not fulfil current safety requirements, fell through two months ago.

webTitle: £24m deal helps Chelsea eye up transfer targets

fields.headline: Chelsea sell shirt for £24m wish list
fields.trailText: Chelsea have identified the players they want for next season but have told fans not to expect an influx of Englishmen.
fields.body:
Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates announced yesterday that the club have identified the players they want for next season but told the fans not to expect an influx of Englishmen.

Chelsea's resources have been strengthened by the signing of a sponsorship deal with the Emirates airline worth £24m over the next four years, and the manager Claudio Ranieri has been promised funds as Bates looks to remain in "Europe's elite".

A list of transfer targets was drawn up at a board meeting on Wednesday night when a strategy for the next two years was planned. Although Bates refused to divulge names, he made it clear the club was likely to look abroad despite Ranieri's belief that his team needs an English spine.

"We want to sign the best players available irrespective of nationality," Bates said. "How many good English players are there, how many are available and thirdly how many Premiership clubs would be prepared to sell their top players to a competitor? We weren't prepared to sell [Tore Andre] Flo to Aston Villa for that reason, so we sold him to Rangers."

The new deal begins next season and represents a substantial increase on Chelsea's existing agreement with Autoglass, which was worth £6.5m over four years. Its value is dwarfed only by Manchester United's partnership with Vodafone, which yields about £30m over a similar period.

"It's all about resources in this day and age," said Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson. "Hopefully it will help us to continue to compete at the highest level for star players as well as up-and-coming youngsters."

Money will also go towards a new training ground and youth academy among other projects. The association with an overseas sponsor is appropriate at what Bates calls an "international club" and the chairman feels Chelsea are moving closer to their ultimate target. The £110m owed does not worry him, given gross assets of nearly £300m.

Meanwhile Chelsea have paid for Celestine Babayaro's flight to Nigeria for this weekend's World Cup qualifier against Sudan as a one-off "goodwill gesture". Babayaro had warned he would not play for his country again as he was owed expenses for past flights on international duty.

Martin Djetou, the £5m-rated France defender, may be on his way to Arsenal this summer after saying he will definitely be leaving Monaco. Arsène Wenger has been linked with the 26-year-old, who won a championship medal last year, as he seeks to replace his ageing defence.

Queens Park Rangers' chief scout and former manager Steve Burtenshaw is recovering in hospital after suffering a slight stroke on Tuesday.

Money will also go towards a new training ground and youth academy among other projects. The association with an overseas sponsor is appropriate at what Bates calls an "international club" and the chairman feels Chelsea are moving closer to their ultimate target. The £110m owed does not worry him, given gross assets of nearly £300m. Meanwhile Chelsea have paid for Celestine Babayaro's flight to Nigeria for this weekend's World Cup qualifier against Sudan as a one-off "goodwill gesture". Babayaro had warned he would not play for his country again as he was owed expenses for past flights on international duty. Martin Djetou, the £5m-rated France defender, may be on his way to Arsenal this summer after saying he will definitely be leaving Monaco. Arsène Wenger has been linked with the 26-year-old, who won a championship medal last year, as he seeks to replace his ageing defence. Queens Park Rangers' chief scout and former manager Steve Burtenshaw is recovering in hospital after suffering a slight stroke on Tuesday.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Jimmy Greaves: luxury goods
fields.trailText: The 1961 transfer of Jimmy Greaves from AC Milan to Spurs was almost scuppered by Treasury officials, according to official files made public for the first time today.
fields.body:
The 1961 transfer of Jimmy Greaves from AC Milan to Spurs was almost scuppered by Treasury officials, according to official files made public for the first time today.

The £99,999 deal for Greaves - a record signing by a English club at the time - risked falling foul of Britain's strict currency controls which limited the amount of money that could be taken out of the country.

The case even reached the Chancellor, Selwyn Lloyd, amid fears of an outcry from football fans if the deal was blocked. However, papers released to the Public Record Office show Treasury officials got round the rules to protect Britain's foreign currency reserves by arguing that Greaves should be treated as an "invisible" import, or "luxury goods".

William Clowser, an official in the Treasury, recommended that the Bank of England should approve the payment for Greaves. He wrote: "The transfer fee paid by one club to another for a player's release represents the means by which the paying club secures his services and skill, which are of course of little value except as a member of a football team."

"This is closely analogous to a royalty payment which might be made by an industrial concern for the use of a patent or know-how," he continued. "I have told the Bank that, on this justifiable analogy, they may approve the application if it should be made. We would no doubt run into trouble if it were refused."

Another official agreed with the argument that Greaves - the foremost English striker of his day - should effectively be counted as an "invisible" import, adding, with a phrase that is unlikely to appear in official correspondence today, "however Irish that may appear".

Not everybody was happy with the decision however. The Treasury received a number of letters complaining that one set of rules applied to famous footballers while another applied to ordinary members of the public who wanted to send money abroad.

Ian Lacey from Hove wrote angrily: "Is this person worth, in the national interest, the transfer of so many million lira from our reserves? I say no, especially as he is a spoilt puppy."

fields.headline: The batcave, and the evils of golf
fields.standfirst: Still in Sarawak, Sue heads for Sibu and then on to the Mulu National Park, where she gets her first taste of hostel living, and finds developers' plans definitely not to her taste
fields.trailText: Week 9: Sarawak, Malaysia Still in Sarawak, Sue heads for Sibu and then on to the Mulu National Park, where she gets her first taste of hostel living, and finds developers' plans definitely not to her taste
fields.body:
Another week in sunny Sarawak, this beautiful unspoilt area. My last afternoon in Kuching we rode out to a village with a longhouse. These are tribal, communal buildings built mostly of bamboo on stilts with living areas subdivided for families but the veranda, kitchen, store houses etc shared. This one was almost a village on stilts with 'streets' going off it. It was much more ramshackle than the small neat examples at the cultural village. There was now electricity, and you could glimpse the odd TV, but the water was still collected from the river beside. Some living areas were padlocked and an old woman making baskets said that many families had moved to the towns. I always feel somewhat uncomfortable on these occasions, the 'rich' tourist come to gawp at their way of life, but it was fascinating to see nonetheless.

So Saturday off to Sibu by bus, a long bumpy journey. Sibu is a busy port, the last place linking the China sea with the Batang Rejang river. Again I had arrived on the day that the huge pagoda temple, with magnificent views from the top, was closed. I spent the day wandering around the fascinating street markets. I confess to having problems with meals. There is an abundance of eating places but they do not have menus and they make the dishes up as they are asked for - difficult when you haven't a clue what anything is called and also have a dread of ending up with seafood of a 'slimy' nature. The market stalls are OK as you can point to things, but you then there's nowhere to eat it in the busy throng. I refuse to resort to the KFCs which are everywhere, and usually end up with noodles and something or other but never the same thing twice.

Next day another bus to Miri, an oil town that is the jumping off point for the Mulu National Park. On both buses I had been the only non-Malaysian. The buses stop every so often but nobody seemed able to tell me for how long so I hardly dared move away. When the drivers were ready it was one loud blast of the horn and away. No such thing as a head count. On the Miri bus I was sitting next to a Malaysian girl. We didn't talk, but I offered her one of my mangy biscuits which she refused. At the next stop when we got back on she had bought me some chopped local fruit and a bunch of rambutan, red horse chestnut-like things with a delicious lychee-like fruit inside. She had to show me how to open them, which is a two-handed twist around the middle. I was very touched by this act of kindness.

On the subject of fruit I had, in Kuching, sampled the local 'king of the fruits' durian, a huge very prickly thing the size and weight of a medicine ball, much revered and loved in Malaysia. It opened into segments of white gooey stuff like ice cream mixed with marshmallow which you scooped out and sort of sucked up. I had been warned it had a very strong smell but didn't expect it to taste as bad as it smelt and to linger with you for days to come. I will give this one a miss in future. Sorry. All other fruits are lovely and the selection makes Sainsbury's shelves seem boring and bare.

I had been emailed by Jeremy and Gay, who live in Miri. They collected me from my hotel and took me out for a meal and back to their bungalow for coffee and a quick read of my email. I love this interactive travelling - people are so kind. They have even offered me the use of their washing machine when I return from the park - an offer they may regret when I open my bag! I had a shock in their car when on the radio I heard Capital Radio! Apparently it was the favourite station of one of the Brunei royal family when in England so he had it beamed out to Brunei, just across the border from Miri.

Time for my second national park, Mulu. This park can only be reached by plane, so it was another new experience flying in a twin-engine Otter below the clouds with a wonderful view of the ground below. A few patches of land totally denuded by logging were a reminder of the conflicting demands on this land, rich in natural resources but with an economy devastated by the Asian financial crisis of a few years ago.

I had decided to forgo the extremely expensive travel agency tours, with prearranged trips and guides and play it by ear when I arrived. A very wise decision as it turned out as guides are totally unnecessary and the system of permits a lottery. This was my first real taste of hostel living - a different experience from the cheap hotels I had opted for so far. What you lose in privacy is gained in mixing easily with other travellers. In the three days I was there, two Canadians, two Americans, a Slovakian, two Swedes, a German and an assortment of English came and went, all (with one exception)very friendly and good fun.

That first night I had left a plastic bag of odds and ends of food beside my bed and was woken by loud rustling sounds from the bag. I froze but decided there was no way I could get back to sleep with my imagination running riot - cockroach? lizard? monkey? deadly snake? - the creatures were growing bigger by the second. Finding my torch I grabbed the bag, still rustling, flung it in the kitchen and closed the door. When I dared to look next morning what ever it was had long gone so I will never know.

Mulu park has the largest limestone cave system in the world. There are four show caves. Wednesday I set off for the Deer and Lang caves. With what appears to be becoming my usual timing I picked the day the generator broke down so the caves were not lit. Deer cave is huge, home to millions of bats. The towering walls and rock formations are all covered with a layer of guano. You had to be careful not to gape too much at the magnitude of the cave as the smell of ammonia was very powerful, or to not slip on the fine layer of droppings on the walkway. There was quite a lot of natural light here, but when I saw the pitch black entrance to Lang cave I decided my little torch was not up to the job. I sat on a rock and waited for someone else to arrive. First along were a group of about 10 young Malaysians sporting a good array of torches and flashlights. I showed them my torch and they immediately agreed I would be better off with them. In the cave the weird and beautiful rocks, stalagmites and stalactites were amazing. At times there was an Escher-like impossibility to their twists and turns.

I then parked myself at the bat observatory to await the nightly exit of the Two million or so bats from Deer cave, usually about 5.30, and was gradually joined by about 20 other people. By 6.45, no sign of a bat, it was getting dark and most people had gone. Five of us were determined to stick it out and were rewarded after 7pm by a couple of short strings and a doughnut or two of bats emerging. Whether they had missed their afternoon fix of electric light, or the rare lack of rain for two days upset them, or they knew that I had waited three hours with camera at the ready, I do not know. But whatever the reason, tonight was definitely not the night! That meant that the 45 minute walk back with a couple from KL had to be done by the light of my little torch. I also had the embarrassment of slipping on some wet leaves and landing heavily on my backside.

The next day most of the hostel were setting off for the three-day trek to the pinnacles. I had decided against this when a couple of the very fit young men said it was hard! That left me and superfit Canadian Dave, the postman who jogs his round. I asked if he minded if Sue, the not very fit netjetter, joined him on the 4km walk to the other caves. He gallantly said not at all. Wind Cave was another impressive display of nature being artistic in stone.

Clearwater Cave is 51km long with a stream going through it. At the end of the walkway, a few 100m in, I left Dave the jogging postman forging on into the unlit depths of the cave following the stream. I decided if he had not returned by midnight I would alert the authorities. A few ringits to a boatman saw me hitching a boat ride back, joining a rather bewildered family on their way back to the posh hotel further down the river from the park.(Dave did eventually return many hours later.)

That afternoon a few of us were invited to have coffee on the veranda of the house of one of the local Berawan tribe. We were told the story of the tribe's struggle to save their traditional lands from the loggers and developers. They had reluctantly agreed to have an area of their land declared the national park - Mulu, but then 20 acres more were 'sold' to developers with government and Japanese connections, for a pittance and the Royal Mulu Resort (the posh hotel) was built.

Since the early 1990s they have been trying to acquire another 250 acres to build a golf course. This and the extension of the tiny airport would involve the demolition of two huge limestone hills. The Berawan have resisted through the courts, saying this is Native Customary Rights land, and through a peaceful demonstration, where four were arrested. An arson attack on the parks generators also led to more arrests and alleged beatings. The dispute rumbles on in the courts, but we were shown the heavy machinery already active at the base of one of the hills. The locals try to enlist support from foreign visitors to the park. Unfortunately for them, the people who stay in the park - although the last people to want golf courses and monorails - are mostly backpackers, the people with money and clout stay in the Resort. It is a story repeated at many levels all over the world. I personally hope the Berawan retain their rights to decide the future of their land, but history and the way the modern world works are heavily against them. I consider myself fortunate to travel here now, what will 10 years bring?

I enjoyed Mulu very much but the only trails were to the caves and the Pinnacles. I would have enjoyed other half day walks if they had been available.

Last week I changed my tickets and extended my stay in Sarawak a few more days rather than rush everything. I'm off to the Niah national park on Sunday and then on to Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday. Can one become addicted to rainforests? I wonder how the peninsular will compare to Sarawak? I'll let you know over the next couple of weeks.

May I just wish my friend Philip a speedy recovery from his op? I tend to think of England as in suspended animation while I am away. It is strange to think of the lives of family, friends and work carrying on with all the usual twists and turns of life. I seem to be in philosophical mood this week!
Sue

webTitle: The hospitable Hindujas and the wooing of the Westminster classes

fields.headline: The hospitable Hindujas and the wooing of the Westminster classes
fields.standfirst:
The network Whitehall alarm as politicians check links with billionaires

Special report: Mandelson resignation
fields.trailText: William Hague, who yesterday intensified his attack on Tony Blair's links to Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja, faced embarrassment last night when it emerged that the billionaire brothers had thrown a party in his honour. Over samosas and bhajis the Tory leader rubbed shoulders with the cream of British Asian society in the penthouse of their British headquarters, New Zealand House off Piccadily.
fields.body:
William Hague, who yesterday intensified his attack on Tony Blair's links to Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja, faced embarrassment last night when it emerged that the billionaire brothers had thrown a party in his honour. Over samosas and bhajis the Tory leader rubbed shoulders with the cream of British Asian society in the penthouse of their British headquarters, New Zealand House off Piccadily.

Listed as a co-host was respected businesswoman Surina Narula, who last night told the Guardian that the Hindujas paid for the whole event, staged after Mr Hague became Tory leader, although the invitation carryied her name and those of other prominent Asian figures.

Mrs Narula, a Conservative party member, said: "It's a way of them [the Hindujas] getting to know William Hague and introducing them to their Asian friends, It was a two way thing, it was for the benefit of both sides. They do it out of the kindness of their heart, not for a political agenda. They do this to make friends."

Dinner

The brothers are known by friends by their initials, SP and GP. Businessman GK Noon, a Labour party member, also attended: "SP Hinduja made a speech welcoming Mr Hague. Well, if you invite someone for dinner, you have to praise them. The room was absolutely full, it was a lavish function."

Mr Noon added: "Mr Hague has enjoyed their hospitality. Having enjoyed himself the hospitality of the Hindujas, was there any rationale in attacking the way he did on Wednesday?"

A Tory insider present at the function said: "People were saying, why haven't they hosted it on their own? They did not want to identify themselves exclusively with the Tory party. It was them playing both sides, covering their options in case we got back in."

Last night a Conservative party spokesman, asked about the Hindujas' function in Hague's honour first replied: "Since William became leader in 1997, the Hindujas have not made any donations to the party." Pressed for an answer to the question actually asked, the spokesman said: "We're not in a position to deny or confirm that the Hindujas held functions in William Hague's honour."

The Tory insider remembered another example of the Hindujas' largesse to the party. When Margaret Thatcher was still prime minister the brothers attended a party ball: "A bottle of House of Commons whisky autographed by Margaret Thatcher was autioned off. They paid £25,000. They are teetotal and they returned it. Some saw this as being smug."

Details of the Hague bash emerged as panic gripped Whitehall last night as ministers and MPs trawled diaries and papers to clarify details of conversations and meetings with the billionaire brothers following Peter Mandelson's spectacular resignation after misleading Tony Blair about his interventions with the Home Office on behalf of SP. "We are getting some traffic with other departments. It is not the kind of stuff you can do in a couple of hours," said a senior civil servant.

The tentacles of the Hindujas have touched prominent figures in all the main parties, the brothers appearing to hedge their bets by consorting with Labour, Tory and Liberal Democrat politicians. About a dozen candidates at the last election, Labour and Tory, are rumoured at Westminster to have received donations from the brothers who are facing possible corruption charges in India over an arms scandal.

The minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, will be grilled by former Treasury solicitor Sir Anthony Hammond QC after he was named in the parliamentary written answer that triggered Mr Mandelson's downfall. Mr Vaz, Britain's most high-profile Asian politician, made "inquiries" about an application by SP and the Home Office refused to divulge details until the inquiry report is published later this year.

Mr Vaz yesterday would not answer detailed questions, but one report claimed he sent letters drafted by the Hindujas for his signature to Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson in October 1997. Last night a government department also said they believed that the Hindujas had staged a party when Mr Vaz became Europe minister at the Foreign Office.

A spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's department said, after checking Lord Irvine's diary: "The lord chancellor attended a function at New Zealand House on September 22 which we believe was hosted by the Hindujas to mark the appointment of the first British Asian minister of state in recent times, Keith Vaz."

Mr Vaz faces problems on a second front with Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards, expected to raise concerns that individuals who gave evidence to an inquiry into the minister received letters from the local Labour party challenging them to put up or shut up.

The minister strongly denies allegations from businessmen that he accepted money in exchange for exerting influence in a planning case in Leicester where he is an MP. Mr Vaz is said be a regular visitor to the 14th floor of New Zealand House, and one source said he is obsequious in the presence of SP and GP. Tony and a sari-clad Cherie Blair have attended a Diwali party hosted by the brothers in Alexandra Palace, north London. One picture of the event showed an anxious Mandelson hovering in the background.

Sources close to the minister confirmed he met the brothers at his office to discuss a multi-million pound joint project they are funding in India with Powergen.

Fear

"Stephen met the brothers to discuss the project at the department," the source said. "He also met them at a reception hosted by the brothers attended by 200 other people. All their discussions were about trade."

In a sign of the fear gripping Whitehall in the wake of Mr Mandelson's resignation, Mr Byers instructed officials to search hundreds of files to check exact details of contacts between his ministers and the brothers.

Sir Edward Heath, who acted as a referee on GP Hinduja's passport application form, ordered his staff to check his private papers to discover whether he has ever received money from the brothers.

Sir Edward has known the Hindujas for more than 20 years and recently served as a trustee of an academic institute at Cambridge founded by the brothers in memory of SP's only son, Dharam, who set fire to himself and his wife, an Anglo-Indian Catholic, in 1992. His death is a highly sensitive matter for SP after a coroner's report said that the family had objected to them living together.

Sir Edward also served as a trustee of the Dharam Hinduja Institute of Indic Research which carries out work on the Vedas, the most ancient of India's sacred texts.

A spokesman for the former prime minister said he did not believe that Sir Edward had received payments from the Hinduja brothers. "We have received odd presents of fruit but we will have to check if there was anything else," he said.

The Hinduja brothers did not limit their generosity to the two main parties. At least one of the brothers regularly attends the annual Liberal Democrat ball at the Dorchester hotel where tables cost thousands of pounds. Lord Razzall, the party's treasurer who is a close aide to the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy, said last night: "I have seen one or more of the Hinduja brothers at our annual balls. But they have not made any donations to the party."

"They put themselves about," said a party official. Sir Paddy Ashdown, the Lib Dems' former leader, met them "several times" at functions. But Sir Paddy insisted yesterday he did not call, write or lobby any civil servants or ministers about a passport for either of the brothers.

In the City, the secrecy surrounding the Hindujas' business affairs is increasingly the subject of speculation.Their battle to become British citizens appears to date from the first signs of trouble in India over allegations centring on £30m of kickbacks allegedly paid out by the Swedish arms firm Bofors to secure a £775m deal to provide howitzer guns to the Indian army in 1986. On January 22 1990 GP was named as a suspect in a report by police at India's central bureau of investigation.

Less than a month later, on February 21, both SP and GP applied for British naturalisation. The applications were turned down the following April. Both the brothers' spokesman and Home Office sources now say SP was turned down on residency grounds.

But no explanation has been given for the refusal of GP's application. Since 1983 the brothers have attracted controversy. One India expert who has followed their career in detail said: "It is unimaginable that MI6 and the Foreign Office would not have drawers of files on them."

Did GP seek his passport because of the storm brewing over Bofors? Is it coincidence that in 1991 an Indian CBI investigator arrived in London to make inquiries in connection with the controversy?

On March 5 1997 GP applied again. The naturalisation certificate was granted on November 4 1997. The speed with which the application went through was described as one expert as "remarkably quick".

SP then applied again on October 20 1998, gaining naturalisation on March 23 1999 - again a very speedy result.

webTitle: Liddell joins cabinet after Blair's choice is blocked

fields.headline: Liddell joins cabinet after Blair's choice is blocked
fields.trailText: Helen Liddell became the first woman secretary of state for Scotland in the notoriously male-dominated world of Scottish politics after Tony Blair's first choice of Brian Wilson was blocked by the devolved administration in Edinburgh, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Helen Liddell became the first woman secretary of state for Scotland in the notoriously male-dominated world of Scottish politics after Tony Blair's first choice of Brian Wilson was blocked by the devolved administration in Edinburgh, it emerged last night.

Though he has kept quiet in recent years, Mr Wilson - John Reid's deputy before Wednesday's mini-reshuffle - remains a gut anti-devolutionist, a view anathema to Henry McLeish, the new Scottish first minister.

Downing Street refused to confirm that Mr Wilson's promotion had been blocked, but it is understood from friends of Mr Wilson that Mr McLeish prevented him getting the post he expected. The politics behind the choice of Ms Liddell - who becomes the seventh woman in the cabinet - emerged as she spoke of being "overwhelmed and humbled" at becoming the first woman to hold a post she was tipped to get 20 months ago instead of Mr Reid.

The MP for Airdrie and Shotts, who entered Parliament in 1994 after winning the Monklands East byelection caused by John Smith's death, allied herself to her "old friend" Mr McLeish as she pledged to make devolution work. Insisting she had "fought all her life" for devolution, the former energy minister said: "I look forward to a very exciting time here in Scotland and I am very conscious that I have been given a huge privilege to play my part in building the new Scotland in the 21st century.

"The initiative taken in establishing the Scottish parliament is one of the most exciting constitutional developments in the European Union and I am delighted to have this opportunity to work with my old friend Henry McLeish to make sure that Scotland and all of the United Kingdom benefits to the full."

Once described as having "balls of steel" by the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, 50-year-old Mrs Liddell has held four ministerial posts since the 1997 election.

webTitle: Questions over choice of Reid for Ulster job

fields.headline: Questions over choice of Reid for Ulster job
fields.trailText: The Conservative party yesterday raised "serious questions" about the appointment of John Reid            as Northern Ireland secretary, saying the parliamentary commissioner for standards published            damning evidence about his behaviour only a month ago.
fields.body:
The Conservative party yesterday raised "serious questions" about the appointment of John Reid as Northern Ireland secretary, saying the parliamentary commissioner for standards published damning evidence about his behaviour only a month ago.

The commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, found that Mr Reid had in his previous post as Scottish secretary tried to frustrate her inquiry into the use of taxpayers' money for party political use by the Scottish Labour party by intimidating witnesses.

Tim Collins, the Conservative vice-chairman, said: "The Mandelson saga does show that the prime minister is an appalling judge of character. Given the mistake he has made in his choice of his past Northern Ireland secretary, it is all the more important that the next one should be seen to be a person of the highest possible character, especially given the sensitivities of the province at present."

The Scottish National party also criticised Mr Reid's appointment. Mike Russell, SNP education spokesman and formerly the party's election campaign manager, said: "Dr Reid is a politician who there are question marks over in terms of his ability to do straight dealing with people. That has never seemed to be his strong suit. I don't think the prime minister's judgment was good in terms of Mandelson, and I don't think it is good in terms of Reid."

Ms Filkin's investigation found that Mr Reid had sought to get a key witness to "agree a line which falls short of a full and comprehensive account of the events of which they had both knowledge". The witness, Alex Rowley, the former Scottish Labour general secretary, according to Ms Filkin, "felt under pressure from Mr Reid to say things to me which he does not wish to say and which he regards as not wholly accurate or even misleading".

After listening to secretly taped conversations between Mr Reid and Mr Rowley, she concluded that Mr Reid's conduct amounted "to an attempt to frustrate my investigation".

She also complained Mr Reid had tried to persaude Mr Rowley from giving evidence on oath.

Ms Filkin was examining allegations that work conducted on behalf of the Scottish Labour party by three researchers based in the Commons had been improperly funded by the taxpayer. One of the three researchers was Mr Reid's son Kevin.

Mr Reid claimed the allegations were baseless and driven by malice.

Ms Filkin upheld the complaint about improper funding, but the Commons standards and privileges committee rejected her conclusion.

Mr Reid has been seen as a safe pair of hands for Labour on TV, and is widely admired in parliament for his knowledge of defence and political philosophy.

webTitle: Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly

fields.headline: Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive has embarked on a collision course with Westminster after a parliamentary rebellion forced the first minister, Henry McLeish, to offer free long-term care for all Scotland's pensioners.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive has embarked on a collision course with Westminster after a parliamentary rebellion forced the first minister, Henry McLeish, to offer free long-term care for all Scotland's pensioners.

Minutes before a vote on the issue in the Scottish parliament yesterday, the executive announced a dramatic policy u-turn and said it would implement plans to fund long-term care for all pensioners.

Scottish pensioners will now get free personal care, including bathing, changing dressings and assistance with eating - services that pensioners in England and Wales will continue to pay for.

The government thought it had repaired its reputation with pensioners by promising to increase pensions faster than inflation this year, but the policy split between London and Edinburgh may make it harder for Labour to garner the grey vote at the forthcoming election.

The decision to implement the care package, at a cost of £110m a year, reverses the announcement by Mr McLeish just a day earlier when he had offered a scheme that stopped short of the universal free care recommended by the Sutherland royal commission.

Facing certain defeat after a stormy debate on the issue yesterday, the parliament minister, Tom McCabe, revealed the free care in an emergency statement.

The u-turn had been brought about by the prospect of a cross-party rebellion which threatened to see Labour's LibDem coalition partners desert them to join an axis of SNP and Conservative MSPs and reject the compromise care package.

The decision opens the biggest policy rift yet between Holyrood and Westminster. Mr McLeish, who had hinted when he took office that he wanted to implement the Sutherland recommendations in full, was said to have been pressed by Downing Street not to offer a vastly superior care package in Scotland because of the problems it would create, not least raising the spectre of care being decided by postcode.

The issue is highly emotive and campaigners are unhappy with the existing deal in England and Wales where nursing care is free but personal care is means tested.

Paul Burstow, Liberal Democrat health spokesman, said the decision in Scotland "would mean that a Scottish pensioner choosing to move into a nursing home in England would get free personal care, but the English person in the next room would have to pay for it. This is like the tuition fees anomaly all over again."

About 40 Labour MPs have signed a Commons motion calling on the government to reconsider its stance.

The charity Help the Aged said: "We can't have a system that gives better care for people in Scotland than in the rest of the UK. That goes down the road of creating a new postcode lottery. The NHS is meant to provide care at the point of need throughout the UK and should not be dependent on where people live."

webTitle: Vinnie Jones avoids typecasting in The Fenman

fields.headline: Vinnie Jones avoids typecasting in The Fenman
fields.trailText: The Snatch star hopes that playing a medieval warrior will stop him from being stereotyped as only being able to play thugs
fields.body:
Vinnie Jones is to play a medieval warrior in his next film in a move which he hopes will prevent him from being stereotyped as a gangster hardman.

ITN reports that the Snatch star told reporters that his next project would be a new drama called The Fenman which will be filmed in East Anglia. Described as "a cross between Predator, Braveheart and Last of the Mohicans" by the 36-year-old star, the film will be produced by Matthew Vaughn, co-owner with Guy Ritchie of the Ska Films Company. Jones added: "I will be playing the lead, which is superb."

Jones apparently hopes that this new role will quash questions over his acting credibility which has so far traded on his football hardman persona. He didn't help his case, however, by describing his yet to be named character as "a bit of a nutter."

It was long thought that Jones's next project would be a biopic of bare knuckle fighter, Lenny McLean, but reports earlier this month suggested that the project was in jeopardy after Patsy Kensit pulled out.

webTitle: Councils in line for £25m fund for homeless and asylum seekers

fields.headline: Councils in line for £25m fund for homeless and asylum seekers
fields.trailText: The government is set to unveil a funding package worth at least £25m to help councils meet the costs of homelessness and asylum seekers. The move will be widely seen as an attempt to dampen down large council tax increases.
fields.body:
The government is set to unveil a funding package worth at least £25m to help councils meet the costs of homelessness and asylum seekers. The move will be widely seen as an attempt to dampen down large council tax increases.

The money is expected to come through the housing benefit system and, although the size of the fund has yet to be confirmed, it is understood that around £25m will go to London. It is not yet known whether northern metropolitan councils will also get a share.

The timing of the announcement is unclear, but ministers will be keen to use the money to attract positive publicity on the refugee issue after yesterday's revelation that the Home Office is rejecting nearly a third of asylum seekers without examining their cases.

The asylum money will come on top of an £11.6m fund announced today by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and aimed at helping the Environment Agency meet the costs of last autumn's catastrophic flooding. These were due to be met by local authorities.

In Yorkshire, councils claimed the agency's proposed 63% increase in the annual flood levy could add £7 to local tax bills.

Elliot Morley, chairman of the government's floods task force, said: "I am very pleased to announce this fund from the government today, thus reducing the costs of the flooding being passed on to council tax payers."

The funds come after a campaign from councils across the country for more money to help them deal with the funding problems caused by asylum seekers and flooding.

Ministers have been accused of panicking over the possibility that these costs will push up council tax increases, which the Conservatives claim could reach an average of 9%. The tax rises could hit the nation's doormats at the height of the general election campaign.

Councils in London could be particularly hard hit by asylum costs because of government proposals for funding "ceilings". These would effectively cap the budget increases due to authorities including Hillingdon, Newham, and Kensington and Chelsea in the next financial year.

The money saved will help pay for a funding "floor" - a minimum 3.2% raise for all councils that provide education and social services.

Ministers plan to announce the final local government finance settlement on Monday, but it is not thought to contain any significant new funds. A well-placed government source said it would be "pretty much confirmation of the provisional settlement announced last year".

The money saved will help pay for a funding "floor" - a minimum 3.2% raise for all councils that provide education and social services. Ministers plan to announce the final local government finance settlement on Monday, but it is not thought to contain any significant new funds. A well-placed government source said it would be "pretty much confirmation of the provisional settlement announced last year".

webTitle: Royal Society warns against research concentration

fields.headline: Royal Society warns against research concentration
fields.trailText: The perennial debate over how much research funds should be skewed to the top rated research departments is hotting up again as the Research Assessment Exercise approaches.
fields.body:
The perennial debate over how much research funds should be skewed to the top rated research departments is hotting up again as the Research Assessment Exercise approaches.

A report from the elite academic club, the Royal Society, has urged the Higher Education Funding Council for England not to cut funds from mid-rated departments in the assessment. But just how the funding council is supposed to finance this, while continuing to support the growing numbers of top rated departments is unclear.

The Royal Society working group says that further concentration of funding council block grants would damage the UK's research effort.

Both the English and Scottish funding councils have said that they will protect funding for top rated departments - even at the expense of support for departments with lower ratings. It is expected that more departments will achieve the highest rating in the 2001 assessment, which signifies international research standards. But the councils only have fixed research budgets.

The Royal Society working group though warns that cutting funds to lower rated departments would threaten researchers who help "maintain the vitality of UK university research".

The group though does support the funding council's proposals to concentrate funding for postgraduate training, so that fewer departments can train PhDs.

The working group included and Sir Christopher Llewellyn-Smith, president and provost of University College London, Professor Peter Scott, vice-chancellor of Kingston University, and John Enderby, vice-president of the Royal Society.

fields.headline: Profile: Beverly Malone
fields.trailText: In offering the charismatic Beverly Malone the job of general secretary, the RCN may have, at a stroke, gone a long way to countering its reputation as a risk-averse, cautious and conservative organisation.
fields.body:
In offering the charismatic Beverly Malone the job of general secretary, the RCN may have, at a stroke, gone a long way to countering its reputation as a risk-averse, cautious and conservative organisation.

If her track record in the US is anything to go by, the theatrical (by UK standards) and ultra-professional Ms Malone could signal not so much a change of approach in the way the RCN is managed as a cultural revolution.

She is a master of the quotable phrase. It is likely the nursing profession will take a little time to acclimatise to a leader who does not shy away from making statements like: "We all need to start thinking about acquiring a taste for chaos."

The appointment of a black American woman to one of the biggest trade unions in the UK would be unprecedented. It is, in NHS cultural terms, a move not dissimilar to the appointment of Sven Goran Eriksson to the job of England football coach.

Ms Malone has a reputation as America's "top nurse". She is politically influential - most obviously as an adviser to former US president Bill Clinton - professionally experienced and has an extensive grasp of health policy.

But it is, perhaps, her approach to leadership which will cause the biggest ripples throughout the NHS. She is a fluent and witty speaker, radical and unafraid to speak her mind, often in a folksy, un-British "inspirational" manner.

"To hear Beverly Malone speak is to come away with renewed nursing pride and with a missionary zeal to harvest the 'best and the brightest' into the profession - now," says one nurse, writing on an American nursing website.

A former psychiatric nurse, Ms Malone's CV is a lengthy story of professional and academic success, topped off with a spell as president of the American Nurses Association (ANA) and a year as deputy assistant secretary at the US Department of Health.

Despite being an "outsider" - she is not registered as a nurse in the UK and reports suggest she may face problems getting a visa to work here - the issues that she has majored on in the US are remarkably similar to those faced by nurses in the UK.

On professional issues, she is an advocate of extending the medical role of nurses to take on more of the work currently done by doctors, and of raising professional standards by supporting degree-level qualifications for nurses. She is a fervent believer in personal and professional development (often expressed in a guru-ish motivational style), she supports whistleblower protection for nurses, is big on health and safety in the workplace and on workplace rights. On wider health policy issues, she is a firm believer in patient (or in US terms, "consumer") centred care, the need for government to regulate health markets, and the need to ensure clinical decisions are made by clinicians rather than accountants.

Ray Rowden, a nurse and RCN activist, has been critical of the way the RCN has handled the appointment. But he welcomed the possibility Ms Malone might come to the UK. "She's absolutely brilliant," he says.

fields.headline: Pinochet 'headache' threatens trial bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The investigation into Augusto Pinochet's role in the murders of political prisoners may be postponed again after the general was taken to a military hospital today complaining of strong headaches.
fields.body:
The investigation into Augusto Pinochet's role in the murders of political prisoners may be postponed again after the general was taken to a military hospital today complaining of strong headaches.

According to reports from Radio Cooperativa in Santiago, doctors fear he may have suffered a stroke.

Gen Pinochet has frequently visited the hospital in recent months for a variety of health problems. Earlier this month he underwent four days of testing there that showed he suffered from "moderate dementia".

On Tuesday Gen Pinochet made his first appearance before Judge Juan Guzman, who is investigating charges that the former dictator ordered the death and disappearance of at least 74 political prisoners. Judge Guzman has been questioning Gen Pinochet over the so-called "caravan of death", a military party that toured several cities soon after the bloody 1973 coup. The troops dragged 75 political prisoners from jail and executed them. Eighteen of the victims remain unaccounted for.

Earlier today, a retired army general said Pinochet was responsible for killings. Joaquin Lagos said on state television that the chief of the caravan, former general Sergio Arellano, was acting as a direct representative of Gen Pinochet at the time of the deaths.

Gen Lagos, who was commander of the northern military region where most of the executions occurred, said that when he confronted Gen Arellano, he produced a document "showing that Gen Pinochet had appointed him as his personal delegate".

"In a situation like that, there was nothing I could do," Gen Lagos, 80, said. "Having a delegate of the commander of the army in front of you is the same as having the commander himself. There's nothing anyone can do, nothing, nothing. He gives the orders as he deems convenient."

Retired Gen Arellano, who has been indicted in the case, did not immediately comment, but has steadfastly denied any wrongdoing.

According to Gen Lagos, he talked to Pinochet himself about the case and warned him that "sooner or later, we will all be tried for this, especially you, as the commander of the army".

Gen Pinochet may well face trial. Judge Guzman last month indicted him but ChileÍs supreme court subsequently dropped the charges because the judge failed to first interrogate Gen Pinochet.

When Gen Lagos heard the answers given during Gen Pinochet's interrogation on Tuesday, he was prompted to air his views on television.

Gen Pinochet said the regional commanders, not himself, were responsible for what happened in their areas and for ordering an investigation after the executions were known. "I am not responsible. I am not a criminal," Gen Pinochet told Judge Guzman, according to the published text of the legal interrogation.

Judge Guzman has yet to decide whether to reinstate the charges against Pinochet, or close the case on health grounds. Gen Lagos told state television that he felt ashamed at seeing the bodies of the victims.

He said: "They were destroyed, they didn't look like human bodies, so I had to arrange them, to leave them in a more decent shape before handing the bodies over to the families."

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about
fields.standfirst: Couture gossip
fields.trailText: Couture gossip
fields.body:
At least they had something to talk about as they waited for the late-running Dior show to start on Monday. Not only who was going to take over at Givenchy (fashion-land is still getting used to the idea of surprise front-runner Olivier Theyskens), but what were McQueen's clothes actually like? After LVMH pulled the plug on the Givenchy show for "production problems", the house showed to an audience of 60 specially selected clients - ie no press.

There were varied reports of the 30-odd outfits. McQueen's overall theme was apparently Africa and the collection included an "unbelievably beautiful" but "unwearable" asymmetric gown in perforated snakeskin, held together by rings of tortoiseshell. McQueen was present, but witnesses saw him jump in a taxi minutes after the show. He is still supposed to be showing Givenchy ready-to-wear in six weeks' time - anyone want to place bets on when that show's cancelled?

Then there were the week's other top stories to discuss, about the take-over plans at Gucci. If you believe the rumours, Tom Ford and Domenico de Sole have been busy - they are said to be close to signing up hot labels Balenciaga and Bottega Veneta. Sources say the deals would be similar to the one they've made with McQueen, giving the designers (Nicolas Ghesquière and Giles Deacon) creative freedom and strong financial support.

When the Dior show started, the gossip wasn't over. In a week low on celebrities (the A-list were in Hollywood for the Golden Globes), Dior had bagged the most. Unfortunately, Liv Tyler snuck in late. Cue glares from LVMH boss Bernard Arnault's wife, Madame Hélène, and sniggers from the back row. Who said anything about fashion being immature?

webTitle: Teachers ballot for action on shortages

fields.headline: Teachers ballot for action on shortages
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Thousands of pupils face the threat of disruption to their schooling after the two largest teaching unions combined to be balloted on joint action in protest at teacher shortages.
fields.body:
Thousands of pupils face the threat of disruption to their schooling after the two largest teaching unions combined to be balloted on joint action in protest at teacher shortages.

The National Union of Teachers is to join the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers in a vote on "protective action" in London - members would refuse to cover for unfilled vacancies and long term teacher absences.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said: "More and more demands are being placed on teachers causing excessive, unreasonable and increasing work load and working hours. Our members are suffering under a burden for which they are not responsible and which can no longer be tolerated."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, said: "Having warned the government and employers against these dangers for many years, our members cannot reasonably be expected to cover for ministerial mistakes and councillors' complacency."

The unions want a four day week rather than force teachers to cover extra lessons.

A spokesman for the Department for Education said industrial action by the unions would only damage children's education and the threat of such action was "grossly irresponsible".

Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said she could not condone industrial action, but "the government has been told repeatedly that teachers are at breaking point".

Meanwhile lecturer unions taking industrial action over a pay claim were infuriated last night by a survey showing vice-chancellors received double the pay rises on offer to them.

 The first 25 education action zones, set up by the government to raise school standards in poor areas, only enticed 50% of the £2.6m business sponsorship targeted for 1998-99, a national audit office report showed. But overall, the report gave the scheme a clean bill of health. The government is announcing another 14 small EAZ's today.

webTitle: Humanities and social sciences 'must be part of EU research'

fields.headline: Humanities and social sciences 'must be part of EU research'
fields.trailText: The British Academy has urged European Union officials to make humanities and social sciences an integral part of its European wide research programmes.
fields.body:
The British Academy has urged European Union officials to make humanities and social sciences an integral part of its European wide research programmes.

The call comes in a submission to the European Commission which is currently finalising plans for Framework Programme 6, the European Union's four-year research strategy.

The learned body for the humanities and social sciences has urged the Commission to maintain a separate strand for the support of socio-economic research. The submission also argues that this should be either broadened to include humanities research in certain key areas, or a distinct theme should be created for the humanities for the first time.

The Academy argues that European research should "exploit the human and social sciences in order to fully examine the social consequences of scientific and technological progress and inform policy on European expansion."

The Academy also suggests a major EU-wide analysis of issues such as income and financial deprivation, work and labour markets, heath and ageing and the dynamics of well-being.

The Academy is currently working with other European academies to raise the profile of the humanities and social sciences in EU research policy, in thr un up to the implementation of the Framework Programme 6 in June 2002.

The submission was sent to Philippe Busquin, EU Commissioner for Research, in response to a report by the European Commission on the creation of a 'European research area'. The European Parliament and Council aims to publish their decision on the new Framework Programme in February 2001.

webTitle: Lennon's art showed a sick mind, said Yard

fields.headline: Lennon's art showed a sick mind, said Yard
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Confidential files released by the Metropolitan police yesterday reveal the motives for Lennon art seizure
fields.body:
The exclusive rights had been sold to America's NBC television. The rest of the world's press from Japan's Asahi Shimbun to the Sydney Morning Herald had happily beat a path to New Bond Street for the 1970 champagne opening of John Lennon's BAG ONE exhibition of original lithographs.

But that was not enough to prevent Detective Inspector Frederick Luff, the head of Scotland Yard's obscene publications squad, gatecrashing the fashionable London gallery and seizing eight of the 14 drawings depicting Lennon and Yoko Ono's sex life on the grounds that they were "the work of a sick mind".

The confidential Metropolitan police files released yesterday at the public record office however disclosed that the real reason Luff had staged the raid was because of the "great influence of John Lennon as a Beatle".

Eugene Schuster, the owner of the London Arts Gallery, who was charged with exhibiting "indecent prints" under an obscure 1830 law, said Lennon had exposed his own private sex life "to encourage a more introspective commitment to content by today's artists who can be so timid".

Schuster admitted that Lennon's previous attempts to establish himself as an artist "beyond pop music" had only led to ridicule and scorn and although Lennon had not won many friends he had "committed himself to a particular cultural leadership".

Lennon himself was more straightforward about his drawings of Yoko and him meeting, getting married and then engaging in a variety of intimate sexual pursuits: "It's just a bit of fun," said the Beatle.

DI Luff, who specialised in mounting "celebrity raids", did not see it that way. He said of the drawings, which were selling for £40 each or £550 the set: "Many toilet walls depict works of similar merit. It is perhaps charitable to suggest that they are the work of a sick mind."

He told the director of pub lic prosecutions: "The only danger to a successful prosecution, as I see it, is the argument that they are so pathetic as to be incapable of influencing anyone and therefore unable to deprave or corrupt any person. However I feel the great influence of John Lennon as a Beatle must be borne in mind."

Luff caused a bit of a stir by asking the 40 people present in the New Bond Street gallery during the raid to give the police their names and addresses and with the help of three witnesses persuaded the DPP to press charges.

The first witness, Nansi Creer, a housewife, aged 48, from Egham, Surrey and a justice of the peace, claimed she had been "stunned" by what she saw. "I couldn't believe what I was looking at. I went and looked at two or three more. I went to the other wall and suddenly felt I could not stay in the gallery any longer. I realised I was red with embarrassment. I deny that John Lennon or the organiser, have or had the right to shock me."

His second witness, George Holmes, a chartered accountant, aged 64, from Wandsworth, south London, was even more disgusted: "They were exaggerated, distorted caricatures depicting intimate sexual relationships of a repulsive and disgusting nature ... To think that a man could use his own wife, not even using a model hitherto unknown to him, was to me making the marriage a farce."

A rather more sophisticated critique was contained in the third police witness statement from Michael McNay, the Guardian's then arts correspondent, who said the drawings displayed talent but it was not very highly trained. "I took exception to them because I thought the exhibition was trading on Lennon's name rather than talent."

That may well have been the case but the magistrate, St John Harmsworth, did not consider it a crime. He threw out the case on a technicality.

webTitle: De Niro and Stiller sign up for Meet the Parents 2

fields.headline: De Niro and Stiller sign up for Meet the Parents 2
fields.trailText: After the unexpected success of Meet the Parents, the original stars are to return for a sequel to the comedy of family distress
fields.body:
It has been confirmed this afternoon that a sequel to the surprise hit comedy of the year Meet the Parents will go ahead with original stars Robert de Niro and Ben Stiller already signed up to the project and original screenwriter Jim Herzfeld penning the script.

According to ananova, De Niro's production company Tribeca has signed a three-year deal with Universal, which includes the follow-up to the blockbuster comedy. The new film will be called Meet The Fockers (a reference to Stiller's character, Greg Focker) and will also star original cast members Teri Polo, who played Stiller's girlfriend, and Gywneth Paltrow's mother Blythe Danner, who played De Niro's wife.

A surprise hit both in Britain and the United States, Meet the Parents knocked Jim Carrey's The Grinch off the number one spot in the UK in December 2000, taking £2.3m during its first weekend on release.

A remake of the 1993 comedy of the same title, the film is the story of a young woman who brings her fiancé home to meet her parents. But when her father takes an instant dislike to him, a disastrous family weekend ensues.

fields.headline: Holocaust memorial day
fields.standfirst: The UK's first annual Holocaust memorial day is proving a controversial affair, with the Queen staying away and angry reactions from Turkey. But supporters say  Britain should be proud of it. Here's our guide to the best sites on one of the  20th century's landmark events  and how to commemorate it
fields.trailText:
NetNotes: The UK's first annual Holocaust memorial day is proving a controversial affair, with the Queen staying away and angry reactions from Turkey. But supporters say Britain should be proud of it. Here's our guide to the best sites on one of the 20th century's landmark events and how to commemorate it.
More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. The first annual UK Holocaust Memorial Day will be held on Saturday, 56 years after British soldiers helped liberate Nazi concentration camps.

2. Prince Charles, the prime minister, Tony Blair, the archbishops of Canterbury and Westminster and Britain's chief rabbi, Jonathan Sacks, all plan to attend an evening memorial service. Buckingham Palace said the Queen, however, would not be attending.

3. Celebs who have agreed to attend include Emma Thompson, Bob Geldof, Anthony Sher and Ian Mckellen.

4. The memorial caused controversy after reports that the slaughter of 1.5m Armenians by the Turks in 1915 would be remembered in the ceremony. This has angered the Turkish government and a state TV station, which set out to prove that "only 300,000" Armenians died. Some Jews have also criticised the day.

5. The original idea was to call it Genocide day as the annual Yom Hashoah international Holocaust remembrance day already commemorates the six million Jews and five million others who perished under the Nazi regime.

6. However, the government feared this would take the Jewish holocaust too far out of the focus. Victims of atrocities in Cambodia, Rwanda and Bosnia will also be present.

7. The BBC is screening the ceremony and has controversially given editorial control of the service to the Home Office.

8. The memorial comes at a time when the United States and many European countries have started to promise financial compensation for Holocaust victims cheated by banks and insurance companies. However, some say the process is too slow.

9. In the weeks leading up to the anniversary, organisers have sponsored Holocaust education activities in schools around Britain, held forums on discrimination and opened an exhibition at the House of Commons.

10. During the second world war, Britain offered a haven for thousands of refugees, but also turned many away. The organisers of the event have said they hope the stories resonate in a country now divided over the emotionally charged issue of political asylum.
