webTitle: Prince William effect boosts applications to St Andrews

fields.headline: Prince William effect boosts applications to St Andrews
fields.trailText: St Andrews University has seen bar far the biggest increase in applications for degree courses among UK universities this year, signaling the 'Prince William effect'. Applications are up by 44% compared with last year according to figures from the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.
fields.body:
St Andrews University has seen bar far the biggest increase in applications for degree courses among UK universities this year, signaling the 'Prince William effect'. Applications are up by 44% compared with last year according to figures from the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.

Last year, the British Council reported a surge in interest from young women - particularly from the United States, after Prince William decided to enrol on an art history degree starting this autumn.

Other universities witnessing large increases are Kingston University (up 15.9%) and Aberdeen University. Universities which have seen the biggest falls in applications meanwhile include Imperial College, London, Goldsmiths College, East London and Sunderland, all down by more than 12%.

By 15 December 2000, a total of 322,621 people had applied for university courses starting in autumn 2001 - up by 2,171 on the previous year. A total of 77,512- one in four applicants - used the electronic application system, compared to 35,477 the previous year.

Business studies, computer science and law remain the three most popular subjects, but there have been increases in the number of applications for degree courses in nursing, media studies, software engineering, history and combined science courses. Subjects showing a decrease in applications include teaching, pharmacy and marketing.

The number of mature applicants from the UK has risen by 1%, from 35,558 to 35,89.

Applications from the Republic of Ireland to UK institutions have fallen by just under 25%, show the figures, while applications from EU countries has fallen by 12.5%. Applications however from overseas students from outside the EU are up by 3.1%.

fields.headline: Lawyers, Soldiers, and the Police
fields.trailText: KOOGAN COINS IT IN
fields.body:
KOOGAN COINS IT IN

Can you recall the last time Kelvin Koogan enjoyed a totally successful day? No, we don't know anything about the Bundesliga in the late 70s either. But these things no longer matter. Because today, Koogan's run of piss-poor luck ended when the News of the World was forced to pay the badger-haired oaf £150,000 in libel damages after accusing him of a "£40,000 bet shame" in one of their world-famous "in-depth investigations".

In yet another high point of Rebekah Wade's editorship, everybody's favourite riot-inciting comic claimed little Kelv had "masterminded" massive betting sessions on nights before England matches. They also suggested that the squat tactician encouraged players to use tenners as £100 notes "so they could gamble away fortunes". However, it was today accepted that these "lurid" and "sensational" tales were not only a "serious attack on [Koogan's] professional and personal probity and integrity" but also a steaming pile of News International.

Before anyone could say "professional and personal probity and what?!?", along came a victorious Koog with a few shocking words of his own. "The article contained so many things that weren't right," he simpered as nearby News of the World executives tried to kid on they didn't care. "We've waited three months to put this right. I can get back on with my job now." When asked whether the word "job" was being used in a football context, Koog shrugged "Who knows?" (ie: "yes") and said that there is "every possibility" that he will return to the game.

Exactly whether anyone is daft enough to offer Koog a job is a moot point (although Aston Villa, Tottenham and Reading have already been mentioned). So if all 92 league clubs see sense, as they surely must, he'll have to find something else to do. Which is where you come in. What use could you find for Koog? Email the.boss@theguardian.com with 'Find-a-Koog-a-job' in the subject field and we'll print the best. If we can't find anything better to do with our time, that is.

THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK

It's what every true supporter of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II dreams about most: the return of the mighty British Empire! But while we wait for our chance to tackle Johnny Foreigner - just give us the word, Lizzie, and ours will be the first short fat neck over the parapet - the Fiver will have to make do with lobbying for a British football team in the Olympics, something which came a tiny step closer today.

Overturning a position seemingly laid down before the birth of Christ, Fifa insisted that the home nations would not be forced to give up their national identity - or packets of Prawn Cocktail crisps - if Team GB was fielded in the Olympics. "We would continue to recognise the four British associations separately," whispered Fifa communications director Keith Cooper in his best you-can-trust-us-guffaw-we-never-snicker-lie voice, before adding: "They would retain their separate status even if a Great Britain team competed at the Olympics."

On hearing the news, the Fiver jumped out of its Union Jack duvet, gave the Charles and Di mug a rinse and readied itself to belt out all six verses of Rule Britannia across the Farringdon Road. Others, however, were less enthusiastic. "From an SFA perspective we would not comply to a British team under any circumstances and there is no prospect whatsoever of a deal taking place," blasted a fiery Scottish FA spokesman. "It would mean scrapping the Scotland Under-21 side which is something that would not be considered because it is an essential stepping stone to the full national team." But as a unified team will probably be made up of nine Englishmen and two token Welshman, we're hopeful that all is not lost.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"There is a faction at Tottenham which wants Glenn to be their manager and while I accept that, we are moving to a new ground in the summer which will make us comparable with Spurs. Why would Glenn want to join a club no bigger or better than ours?" - Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe talks big. Well, when we say big, we mean Tottenham-sized.

HOW TO APPEAR MAGNANIMOUS, THE JOHN BARNES WAY

Get yourself sacked after leading a club - let's call them Celtic - to the most embarrassing defeat in their history. Watch ruefully as your mate - Kenny, for argument's sake - heaps all the blame for the shambles on to you. Keep a dignified silence. Instead, spend all week making noises about how you'd really like to get back into management "at any level". When there are no offers, look wistfully towards the floor, just like you do in that police recruitment advert. That won't cut much ice, mind you, so get your chin up and write a column for Teamtalk.

You need to take the sting out of Kennyphrases like: "It was John who signed all the [bad] players at Celtic ... obviously there was some consultation between us but, at the end of the day, the guy who is responsible for who plays and how we played is ultimately responsible for buying players". So why not try this? "If anything, Kenny was paying me a compliment!" While you've got 'em laughing, explain that Kenny "was stating that he had felt comfortable leaving me in charge of team affairs" and blame "heavy spin" for the whole affair.

Now make sure the whole world knows you're still big pals. This sort of guff should do it: "Kenny actually phoned me in the wake of the article but before he started talking I made it clear to him that there was no need because I understood completely what had happened." Say the whole thing is a "mountain" made out of a "molehill" and then expertly change the subject by chuntering on about Liverpool. A lot.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Argentinian U-21 international Andres D'Alessandro could be heading for West Ham in a £2.5m deal. "The Premiership is one of the most important leagues in the world and I'm looking forward to playing there," he admitted. The 19-year-old River Plate midfielder, who famously outshone Joe Cole when Argentina played England in a youth international last year, would have no work permit problems as he has an Italian passport courtesy of his grandfather.

Chelsea are lining up an moves for Manchester United striker Dwight Yorke and Middlesbrough defender Gianluca Festa, according to reports.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The Japanese FA has denied offering Arsene Wenger £5m a year to lead the national team in the 2002 World Cup. Japan FA spokesman Hideto Teshima said: "It will never happen. We don't know why his name has cropped up."

David Seaman has declared that he has no intention of following Tony Adams into international retirement. "I love playing for England," said Seaman. "The day that I retire from international football is the day that I retire completely."

Dan Petrescu has dismissed comments by his Italian agent Giovanni Becali, who told Romanian TV that Petrescu and Glenn Hoddle would be off to Spurs at the end of the season. "The agent who spoke on Romanian television was not involved in my move from Bradford. I am enjoying life in Southampton and I have no intention of going to Spurs or anywhere else," he said.

Chesterfield chief executive John Green has insisted the FA investigation into alleged illegal payments to players will clear the club of any wrongdoing. Green told the Sheffield Star: "We are confident that, after all inquiries have been finalised, we will be fully vindicated."

Blackburn have been handed an £80m windfall courtesy of the late Jack Walker. At the club's 125th AGM it was agreed to convert £80m, loaned to Rovers by Walker, into shares. Rovers chairman Robert Coar said: "This significantly strengthens the club balance sheet and proves beyond any doubt that Jack Walker was in for the long term."

Leicester are seeking a new club sponsor after ending their 13-year association with Walkers Crisps.

Chelsea chairman Ken Bates has denied a rift with Claudio Ranieri. "I am very pleased with him. We all are!" he claimed.

West Brom manager Gary Megson has signed a new five-year contract.

Charlton have put central defender Carl Tiler on the transfer list at his own request.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.45am)

A programme about world football.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

A programme about world football.

Hold The Back Page (11.30pm)

A programme about world football. World football is just Manchester United, Arsenal and Chelsea, isn't it?

fields.headline: 'Lesbian Kiss' ad hoarding for sale
fields.trailText:
5pm: Gay website Queercompany.com is to auction off its controversial 'Lesbian Kiss advertising hoarding, writes Daniel Rogers.
Jan 2: ASA clears 'Lesbian Kiss' ad
fields.body:
Gay website Queercompany.com is to auction off the huge "Lesbian Kiss" ad hoarding that created such a storm last month.

Queercompany said it would frame the image from the ad hoarding at Centrepoint in the West End, sell it off to the highest bidder and split the proceeds between gay campaigning group Stonewall and "queer arts projects".

The number of potential bidders will be limited however by its size - 90x10m.

Today the company splashed a "For Sale" strip across the billboard, which shows two women kissing on a bed and the strapline "Thank God for Women".

"This is a unique opportunity to acquire a one-of-a-kind memento of the breaking of a major barrier in the depiction of lesbian and gay lives in our society," said Dominic Richards, CEO of Queercompany.

The ad campaign, created by agency Anti Corp, is running on 11 billboards at major junctions in London.

Other executions showed two semi-naked men embracing with the strapline, "Thank God for Men".

Despite 50 complaints from members of the public - who complained it promoted homosexuality to children - and outrage from some tabloid newspapers, the Advertising Standards Authority cleared the campaign on January 12.

The ASA ruled that it was not sexually explicit and was unlikely to affect children.

"We have been amazed by the response to our poster and we're delighted that in the space of a month it has become a cultural icon, appearing in newspapers and magazines around the world," added Mr Richards.

He said Queercompany has been inundated with emails praising the ads and the uncompromising stance that they take.

The site has also received pleas for posters and T-shirts bearing the images.

fields.headline: DC Thomson ups SRH holding
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: DC Thomson has raised its stake in Scottish Radio Holdings to nearly 9.6%, reports Jason Deans.
Dec 20: Scottish Radio Holdings seeks white knight bidder
fields.body:
DC Thomson, the publisher of the Beano and Dandy children's comics, has raised its stake in Scottish Radio Holdings to nearly 9.6%.

The privately owned Dundee publisher, whose titles also include the Sunday Post and People's Friend, paid around £7.4m for 431,000 shares in SRH yesterday, taking its holding to almost 3.16m.

SRH, owner of Radio Clyde in Glasgow and Edinburgh's Radio Forth, said on Thursday it was still in talks with a number of parties that could lead to a takeover offer.

The company's shares were down 20p at £17.05 at 2.30pm, valuing the group at £563m.

SMG (formerly Scottish Media Group) started building a stake in SRH last December, ahead of the expected liberalisation of British media ownership rules in the upcoming communications legislation.

It currently holds around 20.75% of SRH shares.

fields.headline: Couture shock
fields.standfirst: She's never been to a show before and now here she is, in the French fashion capital, in four-inch heels. Jackie Moore Award-winner  Rachel Garnett  on Paris the first time
fields.trailText: She's never been to a show before and now here she is, in the French fashion capital, in four-inch heels. Jackie Moore Award-winner Rachel Garnett on Paris the first time.
fields.body:
I tripped my way into the Paris spring/summer collections. No rock'n'roll parties were involved, sadly, just my new four-inch heels. Ricocheting up the steps to the Théatre National, to Versace and my first ever couture show, I fell into the arms of a burly security guard. Thinking I was late, I had been rushing and arrived five minutes before the show was due to start. Pushing open the glass doors to the deserted catwalk area, I learnt my first valuable lesson, that fashion is never on time.

Watching the couture customers, fashion editors and celebs arrive was as interesting as the show itself. As they settled into their front-row seats, fur-clad women licked their collagen-enhanced lips in anticipation of spending yet more cash.

An elderly woman, skeletally thin, in a low-cut evening dress, was fawned over and air-kissed to oblivion. The photographers began pushing each other in earnest as Lil' Kim and Pamela Anderson appeared. According to the show notes on my seat, Donatella has decreed that shoulders are altars, but here they were being used in a most ungodly way.

As the techno music became so loud that my already vibrating seat was ready to spring into another galaxy, the show started. The clothes were stunning. My favourite was a green shimmery micro-mini - perfect, I thought, for going down the pub in on a Saturday night.

At 25 minutes, the show was much shorter than I had expected and the applause at the end was muted, which surprised me as I'd assumed there would be standing ovations, flowers thrown and cries of "Bravo!" Even when Donatella appeared, the reception was hardly enthusiastic.

Later in the week, John Galliano produced a collection for Dior so brilliant that I wanted to start a mexican wave, but still the clapping was half-hearted. Yet at the Morteza Pashai show, which had all the atmosphere of a school assembly, with clothes that would not have looked out of place at M&S, the reception was thunderous.

The Dominique Sirop show was chaotic, with models parading around on the balcony as everyone spilled free champagne over each other in the race to get the best view. One gorgeous dress, of sheer black and gold material, had the model naked underneath - and as his wife nattered on to him, one lecherous man made it clear his mind and other parts of his anatomy were elsewhere.

At Emanuel Ungaro's show, the models walked around in groups, chatting. It looked rather contrived and one girl forgot where she was and gave her poor arm a good scratch. But the superb fuchsias, oranges and turquoises added vibrancy to a dull morning. At every show, there was one outfit that made me want to shout: "Mine! Give it here!" In this case it was a pale pink suit with silver threads.

The show I enjoyed most was Dior. I knew it would be fun as soon as a tiny old woman near me, with incredibly short, blue-tinted hair, began clicking her diamanté cowboy boots in time to the Knight Rider tune being played. Dior had distinct themes, ranging from a dramatic cavewoman wearing gold silk to the idealised 1950s woman. He even managed to make plastic rain-hats and cocktail glass-print dresses look chic.

At the Louis Féraud and Hanae Mori shows, the clothes took a back seat. At Mori, I was distracted by one couture customer saying to another: "I love your jacket. Of course my husband gave me a dressier version for my birthday, which we spent at our third home in Morocco." The man who showed me to my seat was so fantastically good-looking that concentrating was difficult, but even to my naive eye the clothes were perfectly tailored, though more to my mother's taste than mine.

At Féraud, the very late start gave everyone ample opportunity to knock back the Moët. As a result, the normally sedate front row shouted out increasingly slurred commands - "Stop, turn around!" - to the startled models.

The Yves Saint Laurent show was a fitting end to my first couture collections. The clothes were very beautiful, very 1950s French Riviera. Much less flesh was on view than normal, which was great because after days bloating out on chocolate and Camembert, I couldn't face seeing any more ribs, stomachs and hipbones. Saint Laurent himself looked like a sweet old boy who'd tell you to button up your coat if it was cold out.

After just five days of hurtling around in taxis, schmoozy lunches and having to make a real effort with my own appearance, I was exhausted. But I had a great time and at the very least I learnt to walk in four-inch heels.

fields.headline: Learning curves
fields.standfirst: Bottoms are back! Yes, even those tall, thin creatures on the catwalks have been transformed into hourglass figures.  Jess Cartner-Morley celebrates the shape of things to come
fields.trailText: Bottoms are back! Yes, even those tall, thin creatures on the catwalks have been transformed into hourglass figures. Jess Cartner-Morley celebrates the shape of things to come.
fields.body:
I have seen some weird and wonderful things on catwalks. Tap-dancing, cartwheeling, fake snow, real rain, boys dressed as girls, supermodels dressed as pantomime horses, Playboy centrefolds in babydoll negligees and, I'd wager, more naked breasts than Peter Stringfellow has had highlights.

But until this week, I had rarely seen a bottom. Oh, I've seen endless back views of girls in thongs - but the nakedness serves only to accentuate the fact that there is not a bottom in sight. Catwalk models have a totally different physique from normal women. Viewed from the side they are as long and thin and sleek as eels; from behind they have shoulderblades, then pebble-path spines, then legs. No bottom.

But at Paris couture this week, there were definitely bottoms. I'm sure of it. Not because the models had got any bigger, but because the clothes were deliberately designed to shape the wearer's behind - even to create one out of thin air, or skin and bone.

It all started at Versace. Which seems apt, somehow, since Donatella herself has a pint-size glamour model figure with an unmistakable derrière. She has long made clothes for women with proper curves - Ms Lopez herself (you didn't think we could get through a piece about bottoms without mentioning her, did you?) looks particularly fine in a pair of white Versace hipsters. On the catwalk, however, the Versace image has up until now been of the bosomy-but-snake-hipped Gisele ilk.

But this time breasts were upstaged. A tortoiseshell corset over a black dress placed the emphasis firmly on the curves of the waist - going out, as well as in - for the first time in years. A pink swimsuit-dress was boned and shaped to give a tiny waist which served to make the hips look wider. A black corset dress with spiking bustier had a skirt tight to the knee, then flared, emphasising the hips by contrasting them with the radius at the knee. Until I saw Erin O'Connor, a model who resembles a skinny heron, looking as if she had hips, I had never quite realised the power of corsets.

There were plenty of opportunities to marvel at these wonders of engineering over the next few days. At Christian Dior, the eroticism of corsets - restrained sexuality straining at its silk ribbon ties - was played to the hilt with sexy secretaries wearing basques and suspenders under sheer skirts and blouses. At Gaultier, Sophie Dahl looked utterly luscious spilling out of her bandage-tight pale pink dress, trailing ribbons. At Lacroix, Alek Wek looked heart-stopping (and possibly at risk from a heart attack) roped into a cartoonishly tight corset and thigh-high boots.

Thankfully, the hourglass shape was also achieved by gentler means. Fishtail skirts, nipped in tight at the knee to emphasise the curve of the hips (and accentuate wiggle), were an eveningwear staple at Versace and Chanel.

Easier still were the curvy belted suits at Valentino and Yves Saint Laurent. These are just about the only shows where couture is still about knocking 'em dead at Le Caprice rather than at the Oscars. Here, suits had sharp shoulders and slightly puffed sleeves, to accentuate a teeny-tiny belted waist; instead of falling in a sleek column from the hip, skirts were nipped in at the back to emphasise the swell of the bottom.

While manipulating tiny bodies into a different shape may not be much of a step forward for fashion, it still felt liberating to look at bodies that weren't built like dainty skyscrapers. For almost a decade, a willowy silhouette has dominated fashion. Tom Ford's early collections for Gucci, which focused on unbuttoned shirts tucked into long hipster trousers worn with spike heels, cast a long shadow.

Not only did those long-legged trousers look fantastic on the catwalk: real women, who tend to have a less than happy relationship with their bottoms, tried them (or the high street copies), found that they magically made hips disappear (almost) and adopted them with almost religious zeal.

What goes around comes around and the seeds of this week's hourglass revival were sown last season at Gucci. Then, the boned corset dresses and bustiers looked almost shocking, and received a mixed reception. But perhaps the new shape will catch on now the Paris couturiers have given it their blessing. Couture, after all, is fashion's VIP room.

The security guards are scarier, the models thinner, the free champagne of better vintage. What happens behind this red rope is naturally imitated by those who seek admittance. And being unfettered by commercial considerations, couture functions as a chichi brainstorming session for ideas that later take root in ready-to-wear collections. Fancy, women having hips. Whatever will fashion dream up next?

webTitle: RSPCA wins court battle to ban pro-hunt 'infiltrators'

fields.headline: RSPCA wins court battle to ban pro-hunt 'infiltrators'
fields.trailText: The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) was today given a route by a High Court judge to bar pro-hunt campaigners trying to "infiltrate" the charity in a bid to change its policy over blood sports.
fields.body:
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) was today given a route by a High Court judge to bar pro-hunt campaigners trying to "infiltrate" the charity in a bid to change its policy over blood sports.

The charity was, however, advised not to introduce its preferred method of excluding anyone it believes has suspicious motives. Mr Justice Lightman said the society should give these members a chance to explain their reasons for joining in writing.

The RSPCA sought guidance from the High Court to clarify its membership rules after deciding it needed to block the influx of pro-hunting campaigners. It delayed confirming the memberships of around 600 potential new members who, it says, appear to belong to the pro-hunt Countryside Animal Welfare Group (CAWG).

The CAWG is chaired by three-times Olympic gold medallist equestrian Richard Meade, a member of the society since 1970, who insists there is no campaign to infiltrate the RSPCA.

He was represented at the hearing, together with two applicants whose membership had not been confirmed, to oppose the RSPCA move. The society, which has opposed hunting with dogs since 1976, told the judge that any infiltration campaign to bring about a change of that official policy and promote field sports was damaging.

Mr Justice Lightman said the RSPCA did have the right to exclude or remove members under its rules, but that to do so meant every case would have to go before the charity's full 25-strong governing council, which cannot delegate its powers.

The RSPCA had asked the judge to approve a scheme allowing it to exclude anyone who fell within categories it thought indicated they were joining to promote hunting with dogs - without giving them a chance to deny this. The judge said: "This draconian approach proposed by the council is very much the first choice of the council, for it has dual merits of the utmost simplicity and maximum economy in application.

"After long and anxious consideration I have concluded that it is not in the interests of the society or conducive to its good name to adopt such an arbitrary and unattractive method of implementing the membership policy."

He said to exclude people who may be perfectly innocent must be "a method of last resort".

The judge called for a change in the RSPCA's rules to allow a delegation to take over the full council's deciding powers for these applications.

webTitle: Eddie Izzard sent to hell for new film

fields.headline: Eddie Izzard sent to hell for new film
fields.trailText: The stand-up comedian will play a bungling criminal who has to break all ten commandments in the Hollywood comedy, The Other Billy Drake
fields.body:
Comedian Eddie Izzard is set to star in a Hollywood comedy about an incompetent burglar who is sent to hell. According to ananova, Izzard, who has taken a two-year sabbatical from the stand-up circuit, has been lined up for The Other Billy Drake.

Izzard will play a small-time crook who is accidentally killed while robbing an old folk's home and sent to hell. But by mistake he is re-routed to heaven because he has broken only seven of the ten commandments, so he is given one week to return to earth to break the other three to prove that he is rotten to the core.

Izzard isn't new to movies. He has appeared in Velvet Goldmine and The Avengers and has just finished making the thriller All the Queen's Men. He also played Charlie Chaplin in the drama The Cat's Meow.

However, his film career has by no means been as successful as his work as a comedian, which has seen him win various awards, including two Emmies. He has also achieved considerable success on stage, playing Lenny Bruce in the West End production of Lenny.

A close friend told Ananova: "Eddie is absolutely thrilled to be in such demand. Everything has happened so quickly for him. He says he now wakes up every day terrified it is all going to be over, whereas before he would wake up every morning just a little frightened."

 More on Eddie Izzard.

fields.headline: Show Mandy the money
fields.standfirst:
His Whitehall career may well have met its untimely end, but what does the future hold for everyone's favourite machiavellian politico? Mark Oliver asks top headhunting personnel what they'd line up for Mandelson.

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson could earn up to £300,000-a-year now he has left frontline politics, according to one of the country's most prominent headhunters.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson could earn up to £300,000 a year now he has left frontline politics, according to one of the country's most prominent headhunters.

Dr John Viney, European chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, said: "He would not make that on day one but he would certainly eventually earn enough for a big mortgage on a Notting Hill mansion."

Dr Viney added: "He clearly loves money and a certain standard of living and now he will be able to create opportunities to get it."

Mr Mandelson's resignation must have been all the more painful because it has more than halved his main income. Cabinet ministers can earn up to £100,000, while a normal MP's salary is a relatively paltry £43,000.

Ian McNeil, chief of staff at headhunting firm Odgers International in London's West End, agrees that Mr Mandelson's earning power could stretch into the hundreds of thousands.

Mr McNeil believes that both public and private companies would welcome Mr Mandelson's services in either an advisory or non-executive role.

He said: "He will no doubt be fielding calls from plenty of interested parties. He will be perceived to still have influence with the prime minister and that will be attractive.

"There could be a number of service companies which would be glad to have him on their boards.

"What he did was take a moribund political party and transform it into something successful. That is completely analogous to taking a service and re-launching it. It requires the same skill set."

Dr Viney argues public companies will be more wary of Mr Mandelson. However, he believes the outgoing cabinet minister should set up a communications firm not too dissimilar to Max Clifford's.

"Of course, it would have to be tailored more towards business than the media world Mr Mandelson probably believes destroyed him."

Dr Viney added: "His reputation would be an issue in any business but in Britain we tend to attack people and then not worry so much in the future.

"At the last election many saw him as the kingmaker, but he is not the king. His skill is controlling events from behind the scenes."

Dr Viney advises Mr Mandelson to lie low for a spell and says he may as well "keep a foot" in parliament by keeping his seat because he will have greater financial freedoms on the backbenches.

Mr McNeil believes he will take six months or even a couple of years as a transition period, and that he is unlikely to do anything too dissimilar from being a politician for a while.

Other avenues of income open to Mr Mandelson include after dinner speeches and lectures.

While he may not be able to charge around £20,000 per speech as John Major is said to do in the US, he still has a degree of political star quality he can capitalise on.

But what chance a Lazarus-like, third ministerial comeback?

"Never going to happen," counsels Dr Viney, who says he would be happy to give Mr Mandelson some pointers on his next Phoenix routine.

"Of course, it would have to be tailored more towards business than the media world Mr Mandelson probably believes destroyed him." Dr Viney added: "His reputation would be an issue in any business but in Britain we tend to attack people and then not worry so much in the future. fields.headline: Asher axed in Express economy drive
fields.trailText: 3pm: The Express has axed its star columnist, Jane Asher, in the latest round of cost-cutting, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Express has axed its star columnist, Jane Asher, in the latest round of cost-cutting by new boss Richard Desmond.

Express insiders said that Ms Asher's contract, which runs out at the end of February, will not be renewed.

Today it emerged that her column, "Tricks of the Trade", cost the newspaper more than £200,000 a year. It dealt with solving readers' household and consumer problems.

Ms Asher was on a salary of £180,000, but a writer, Alice Westgate, was also hired as a researcher for the column at a cost of around £20,000 a year.

On top of the salary, Ms Asher was able to claim expenses, which, sources say, included her cookery ingredients.

There were also charges for photographs of her carrying her various props of the week - she insisted on being snapped by a particular photographer, John Swannell, instead of Express staff, say sources on the paper.

Her demise signals the end of the "dream team" put together by Rosie Boycott who quit as editor yesterday.

Only at the beginning of this week, Ms Asher was being touted in the Express's sister paper, the Daily Star, as part of the paper's "dream team".

Others in the team, all appointed by former editor Rosie Boycott, included Alan Titchmarsh and Express astrologer Jonathan Cainer. Two weeks ago, Mr Cainer announced his plans to join the Mirror.

The news follows the resignation yesterday of the Express's editor, Rosie Boycott, and deputy editor Chris Blackhurst.

The new owner of Express Newspapers, Richard Desmond, is looking for opportunities to cut costs across the board, and has already made a number of advertising, marketing and support staff redundant.

Staff fear he will now try wield the axe in the newsroom with speculation mounting that as many as 100 jobs are on the line.

Jane Asher was unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: Keith Vaz
fields.standfirst:
Parliamentary biographer Andrew Roth and Julian Glover examine the career of the latest minister under fire

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Parliamentary biographer Andrew Roth and Julian Glover examine the career of the latest minister under fire.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the most ambitious and flexible of politicians, is an ideological weathervane, always ready to track the wind. In a decade, he has crossed the political spectrum of his party, from membership of the hard left Campaign Group to ultra-loyalty to New Labour. Throughout he has stood out for his energy and style as well as displaying political "double-jointedness" that have astounded even fellow politicians.

Early in his Commons career, he assured the novelist Salman Rushdie privately of his sympathy while marching publicly with Muslim constituents who wanted Rushdie's head. Later, this once archEurosceptic denounced those in his party critical of the European Union.

This tendency towards overexuberance masks Mr Vaz's real achievements. Elected for Leicester East in 1987, he was the first Asian MP since 1929 and the first ever Asian minister in the Commons. (Baron Sinha of Jaipur preceded him in the Lords in 1919 - a fact forgotten by most newspapers.)

Mr Vaz is a Goanese Catholic, born in 1956 in Aden, where his father was the correspondent for the Times of India. The family moved to Twickenham when Mr Vaz was nine. He went from Latymer upper school in Hammersmith to Gonville and Caius college, Cambridge, where he was a contemporary of the prime minister's spin doctor, Alastair Campbell, the BBC's political editor, Andrew Marr, and the novelist and Labour ally, Robert Harris.

Like them, he made his mark at the university, securing first-class honours in law. He then went on to study at the College of Law before practising first as a solicitor and then, from 1991, as a barrister.

He also grew up with politics. His widowed mother, Merlyn Lobo, is now a councillor in Leicester and his BBC presenter sister, Valerie Vaz, has frequently sought Labour candidacies as a leftwinger.

It was no surprise that Keith Vaz should follow the same route, at first unsuccessfully, coming a poor third in 1983 as Labour's candidate for hopeless Richmond and Barnes, and a year later losing the Surrey West Euro-constituency by 50,000 votes.

These disappointments made him an outspoken advocate of "black sections" within the Labour party, then a real cause of controversy. The stance may have helped him win selection for Leicester East, a seat with some 16,000 nonwhite voters, mostly Gujaratis, but if it did, his supporters must have been disappointed when he turned against black sections on entering parliament.

In the 1987 election, Mr Vaz took the Leicester seat from the sitting conservative, Peter Bruinvels, a flamboyant rightwinger famous for offering to act as public hangman.

In parliament, Mr Vaz made his mark as an outspoken supporter of people who had lost money in the collapse of BCCI, many of them among his Asian constituents. In 1992, he became a Labour frontbench spokesman, a success which turned to disappointment when he became one of a dozen Labour opposition frontbenchers denied office in Tony Blair's first 1997 government.

Instead, he became a parliamentary private secretary or PPS - a parliamentary bag carrier - serving Tony Blair's close friend Derry Irvine. Then came the magic endorsement: Lord Irvine said Mr Vaz was "utterly brilliant", "the most incredible networker I have ever met".

This backing from so well connected a source must have assisted Mr Vaz's rapid ministerial promotion, from parliamentary secretary in Lord Irvine's Lord chancellor's department to minister for Europe at the Foreign Office.

In that job, Mr Vaz has not shone quite as brightly as some of his predecessors, who made the post one of the most important in the government outside the cabinet. But he has coped well enough, showing all the enthusiasm of a recent convert to the European ideal.

Whether that is enough to save him from accusations that he assisted the two Indian tycoons, Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja, to obtain British passports remains to be seen.

webTitle: Greenspan drops opposition to US tax cuts

fields.headline: Greenspan in tax cut U-turn
fields.standfirst: Fed chairman won't be drawn on rate cut
fields.trailText: Alan Greenspan, the world's most powerful central banker, signalled a fundamental shift in his thinking yesterday by dropping his opposition to US tax cuts.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson, Jane Martinson  in New York and Peter Capella  in Davos
fields.body:
Alan Greenspan, the world's most powerful central banker, signalled a fundamental shift in his thinking yesterday by dropping his opposition to US tax cuts. He kept the markets guessing about the next move in interest rates.

In his first speech to be made since President Bush took office, the Federal Reserve chairman said on Capitol Hill that tax cuts - a central plank of the new administration's economic policy - would be a good defence against a worsening slowdown in US growth.

"Should current economic weakness spread beyond what now appears likely, having a tax cut in place may, in fact, do noticeable good," he said.

Monetary policy would remain the frontline weapon for steering the US economy off the rocks of recession. "Fiscal policy is too blunt a tool to work as an anti-cyclical device," he told a senate budget committee that included newly elected Hillary Clinton.

The Fed, which made a half-point emergency rate cut earlier this month, meets next week and is widely expected to reduce the cost of borrowing again to boost growth, which Mr Greenspan said was now virtually zero. He offered no clues about the size or timing of the next move.

Analysts said the refusal to give the markets any direction suggested there was internal debate about making a quarter- or a half-point cut.

Mr Greenspan previously opposed using the budget surplus for tax cuts but said he was now optimistic that its projected size - $800bn (£548bn) in 10 years' time - gave scope for fiscal relaxation.

He cautioned against "imprudent fiscal policies" and said there was a "considerable danger of overdoing it". Policymakers and economists took this to mean he would support phased tax cuts, rather than the sweeping proposals of the Bush administration.

The US slowdown and its global consequences were the main talking point at the start of the annual meeting of businessmen and policymakers in the Swiss ski resort of Davos.

In a panel discussion, Jakob Frenkel, group chairman at Merrill Lynch, played down prospects of a global downturn. "We are not talking about global recession but a slowdown in non-sustainable growth," he said.

Alan Blinder, of Princeton university, insisted Europe would not be immune from the US slowdown.

Panelists were scathing about Japanese economic policy and predicted that Tokyo would not come to grips with debt problems for at least two years. "The only way to be optimistic about Japan is if you look at the chart upside down," said Kenneth Courtis, the vice-chairman of Goldman Sachs in Asia.

 Britain ran up a record £2.8bn trade deficit with countries outside the European Union in December, mainly due to a 10% drop in exports to north America. The global deficit narrowed to £2.1bn in November from October's £2.5bn due to a growing surplus with the EU.

fields.headline: Bookies predict Popstars chart hit
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Bookmakers are already predicting that hit TV show Popstars will spawn a chart-topping single, reports Claire Cozens.
Jan 22: Popstars proves big hit for ITV
fields.body:
Bookmakers are already predicting that hit ITV show Popstars will spawn a chart-topping single with some even offering odds on a Christmas number one.

Bookies are giving odds of 2-1 on the winning competitors' first release being a number one hit. And Ladbrokes is quoting 10-1 on the group taking the prized Christmas number one slot.

"Despite the fact that even the line-up has yet to be revealed and they haven't recorded a note, we believe they've got an excellent chance of the first single being a hit," said a Ladbrokes spokesman.

"The Australian winners Bardot went straight to number one with their first single and album - and if the release is timed right they won't have to sell that many records for it to be a big hit."

The TV show has already attracted huge amounts of media attention making an unlikely celebrity of its maker, "nasty" Nigel Lythgoe.

Such is the hype behind the show that even the rejected contestants have become media stars.

webTitle: More than 1,000 feared dead in Indian quake

fields.headline: More than 1,000 feared dead in Indian quake
fields.standfirst:
 Relatives' Emergency Hotline (Home Office): 020 7008 0000

Special report: Natural disasters
fields.trailText: At least 845 people have been killed after a severe earthquake struck western India in the early hours of this morning.
fields.body:
At least 845 people have been killed after a severe earthquake struck western India in the early hours of this morning.

Many people remained trapped under the debris of buildings that collapsed in the earthquake, which hit towns across the western state of Gujarat. More than 100 buildings collapsed in the region and desperate relatives have begged authorities to dig their family members from under the rubble. India's prime minister has called an emergency cabinet meeting.

The quake measured 7.9 on the Richter scale and struck at 8.46am (03.16 GMT) as the country was preparing to celebrate Republic Day with parades and public gatherings. The epicentre was the Rann of Kutch, near the town of Bhuj in a desert plateau near the border with Pakistan. The death toll at Bhuj is at least 150 and 90% of the town's buildings have been damaged.

All of the reported deaths in India were in Gujarat, where there were accounts of mine cave-ins, train derailments, broken water pipes, and downed power and phone lines. Police in the commercial centre of Ahmedabad - the state's capital city of 7m people - reported 200 dead and said that 50 multistorey buildings had collapsed.

Hundreds of people besieged the fire station in Ahmedabad asking for help to dig out their relatives, said fire chief Rajesh Bhat.

"This is an emergency. We are facing a riotous crowd," Mr Bhat said. "A fear psychosis is developing in the city. People have fled their homes and are taking refuge in open fields." Corpses were piled up on the verandah of the NS hospital, while patients overflowing into the hallways wailed and screamed with broken limbs and bleeding wounds. Press Trust of India reported 70 people died while waiting to be treated.

Communications have been disrupted all over Gujarat, according to the state's home minister Haren Pandya. He said the army was on alert and a rapid force had been called in to help dig through the rubble.

The final number of casualties will be much higher, according to the Indian government's home minister LK Advani. "The death figure in the earthquake could be 1,000 or more," he said.

In the town of Surat - where police reported at least 31 dead - three people were killed in a stampede at a diamond factory. When the quake hit, diamond workers in the three-storey factory crowded into a narrow stairwell and tried to push their way to the only exit, said police official Vineet Gupta.

Meanwhile in Pakistan, at least four people died and buildings collapsed in the southern province of Sindh. A 15-day-old child and an eight-year-old girl died and four were injured when a four-storey building collapsed in the central Sindh city of Hyderabad, officials and ambulance workers said. Collapsing buildings also killed at least two people in the southern Sindh town of Badin.

The quake's epicentre was also perilously close to Jamnagar, the site of a large petrochemical factory, according to the US Geological Survey.

Residents of the capital, New Delhi, endured about a minute of shaking. The quake hit just before a Republic Day parade, where thousands of police and soldiers were on alert against a terrorist attack. The cities of Bombay, Madras and Pondicherry also saw panic as people felt the tremors.

This is the world's second major quake of the year, following the 7.6 magnitude earthquake that killed at least 700 people in El Salvador on January 13, injuring almost 4,000 people and making 10% of the population homeless.

fields.headline: New Labour passports scandal
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's closest ally, Peter Mandelson, has had to resign for a shaming second time and now another minister is under fire. But what is the passports scandal really about? Julian Glover  explains
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's closest ally, Peter Mandelson, has had to resign for a shaming second time and now another minister is under fire. But what is the passports scandal really about? Julian Glover explains.
fields.body:
What is the scandal about?
The story revolves around the efforts made in 1998 by two Indian tycoons to acquire British passports. They applied - and later qualified for citizenship.

So far so good. Why the scandal?
It now appears that the tycoons' applications were assisted by two Labour ministers, Peter Mandelson, then the secretary of state for trade and industry, and Keith Vaz, then a junior, unpaid, parliamentary private secretary, but now minister for Europe. Quite what the ministers did and whether or not their intervention affected the standard application process is unclear, though it now seems the tycoons received their passports in six months rather than the usual 20. That has raised eyebrows.

What did the ministers do?
Peter Mandelson, who resigned on Wednesday, has admitted to making a phone call while he was at the department of trade and industry to the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien. The call - says Mr O'Brien - lasted less than two minutes. Mr Mandelson apparently enquired about the progress of the application made by one of the tycoons, SP Hinduja. He says he did not lobby on the man's behalf and merely asked whether new rules would help the application. Since Mr Mandelson's resignation, Keith Vaz has also admitted involvement in the applications, writing to the Home Office to ask about the progress of the applications. He says he too has nothing to hide.

So why has Mr Mandelson resigned?
Because he did not make the fact that he had telephoned about the application clear to the culture secretary, Chris Smith (who had to answer a Commons question on the subject), or to the prime minister's press secretary, Alistair Campbell. Mr Campbell told journalists at a briefing on Monday that Peter Mandelson had not been involved. On Tuesday he had to admit that this information was wrong and shortly afterwards Mr Mandelson resigned, for misleading colleagues and, indirectly, parliament.

So if he had come clean earlier, would he have had to resign?
Probably not. Though the phone call may technically have been in breach of some rules governing ministerial conduct, the offence was not a serious one - unless Mr Mandelson and Mr Vaz had actively lobbied on behalf of the Hinduja brothers. They say that they did not and are willing to cooperate with an enquiry that the government has set up.

fields.bodyText: What is the scandal about? The story revolves around the efforts made in 1998 by two Indian tycoons to acquire British passports. They applied - and later qualified for citizenship. So far so good. Why the scandal? It now appears that the tycoons' applications were assisted by two Labour ministers, Peter Mandelson, then the secretary of state for trade and industry, and Keith Vaz, then a junior, unpaid, parliamentary private secretary, but now minister for Europe. Quite what the ministers did and whether or not their intervention affected the standard application process is unclear, though it now seems the tycoons received their passports in six months rather than the usual 20. That has raised eyebrows. What did the ministers do? Peter Mandelson, who resigned on Wednesday, has admitted to making a phone call while he was at the department of trade and industry to the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien. The call - says Mr O'Brien - lasted less than two minutes. Mr Mandelson apparently enquired about the progress of the application made by one of the tycoons, SP Hinduja. He says he did not lobby on the man's behalf and merely asked whether new rules would help the application. Since Mr Mandelson's resignation, Keith Vaz has also admitted involvement in the applications, writing to the Home Office to ask about the progress of the applications. He says he too has nothing to hide. So why has Mr Mandelson resigned? Because he did not make the fact that he had telephoned about the application clear to the culture secretary, Chris Smith (who had to answer a Commons question on the subject), or to the prime minister's press secretary, Alistair Campbell. Mr Campbell told journalists at a briefing on Monday that Peter Mandelson had not been involved. On Tuesday he had to admit that this information was wrong and shortly afterwards Mr Mandelson resigned, for misleading colleagues and, indirectly, parliament. So if he had come clean earlier, would he have had to resign? Probably not. Though the phone call may technically have been in breach of some rules governing ministerial conduct, the offence was not a serious one - unless Mr Mandelson and Mr Vaz had actively lobbied on behalf of the Hinduja brothers. They say that they did not and are willing to cooperate with an enquiry that the government has set up. What will happen next? The Conservative party will want to make Keith Vaz resign, too and hope to tag the prime minister with accusations of sleaze. But they may find this difficult, not least because it seems that the Hinduja brothers also associated with several Tory politicians, including the former prime minister, Sir Edward Heath. fields.headline: Aftershock in Santa Tecla
fields.standfirst: In her third diary instalment, aid worker Rachel Stabb recounts the extent of the damage in Santa Tecla and the fragile nature of the clean-up operation in El Salvador's earthquake zone
fields.trailText: They were still pulling bodies from the mudslide exactly a week after tonnes of brown earth buried part of the suburb of Santa Tecla. Seven days after families heard the deafening roar, nine more names were added to the list of dead. Many more are missing. The final tally may never be known.
fields.body:
They were still pulling bodies from the mudslide exactly a week after tonnes of brown earth buried part of the suburb of Santa Tecla. Seven days after families heard the deafening roar, nine more names were added to the list of dead. Many more are missing. The final tally may never be known.

Rescue teams in protective masks work methodically, their bulldozers digging into the compacted mounds. It's hard to tell the size of the area covered by mud, but I'm told it was "three streets wide and seven or eight streets deep". And, now, there's little to show what was there before.

The impact of earthquakes is indiscriminate. One family loses everything - possessions and loved ones - while, just 50 yards away, a neighbour escapes virtually unscathed.

Joost Martens, Oxfam's director in El Salvador, lives close to the mudslide and his first-hand account of the destruction on his doorstep helped Oxfam headquarters to understand the severity of the tremor and act quickly.

He took me back there a week later. He has moved his family to rented accommodation for a month. His daughter suffers from asthma and the dust that hangs in the air easily irritates her condition.

We visited his house. A few broken tiles show the extent of the physical damage but it was a frightening experience, particularly for his children who were upstairs at the time and had to brave a swaying staircase to reach the safety of the garden.

Nearer the site, it's shocking to see that the mudslide has left occasional houses and streets standing, when logic tells you they should have been crushed along with the rest.

Cars are mangled and twisted out of all recognition, except for the odd wheel. Personal items litter the mud. And, in the midst of all this destruction, untouched shrubs of crimson bougainvillea blossom against whitewashed walls, reminding you of the quiet residential streets that have disappeared.

While the number of deaths - 700 to 1,000 - is shocking and many residents of Santa Tecla are unable to bury their dead, people are slowly turning their attention to the enormous task of helping the living to get back on their feet. It's thought that at least 1m people, out of a population of 6.5m, have been affected by the quake, with 185,000 homes damaged or totally destroyed.

The figures are difficult to grasp. Talking to families in the camps, you begin to see what it means. But what brought it closer to home was sitting in front of the hotel computer last night in a slight daze because of the late hour. I became aware of an underground train passing beneath the hotel.

Within seconds, I realised it was my first aftershock. I jumped up and ran into the foyer. Postcards were shaking in their stand, but no other effects were visible and it was over in about 10 seconds. But I had an inkling of what the Salvadorans have just experienced and the uncertainty they are still feeling.

fields.headline: BBC 'unperturbed' by unregistered domain names
fields.trailText:
3.30pm update: The BBC has said it is unperturbed by the number of crucial domain names it has not yet registered, writes Amy Vickers.
Jan 26: Former exec snaps up BBC domain names
fields.body:
The BBC has said it is unperturbed by the number of crucial domain names it has not yet registered.

In response to MediaGuardian.co.uk's story about a former executive, David Docherty, owning various permutations of BBCThree and BBCDrama, the corporation said it was likely it would take up Mr Docherty's offer to transfer over the domains.

"We're glad to see they're in good hands, because of all people David is aware that they can't be used commercially by anyone but the BBC," said a spokeswoman from the BBC.

She said the BBC was as yet undecided about the United Arab Emirates-based company, Vanilla Ltd, which currently owns BBC3.com and BBC4.com.

"If we come across a cybersquatter that is benefiting from, or exploiting the BBC name, then there are now legal procedures established to deal with these people," said the spokeswoman.

"There are an awful amount of brand names that can be registered - either we have too many or we don't have enough. We've registered all the likely ones in order to give the widest possible access to the BBC," added the spokeswoman.

Condensed in the style of the original

fields.trailText: Richard and Joanna discover that their love for each other is every bit as narcissistic as their public personas
fields.body:
"Maybe I am a posh cunt," thought Richard McAllister, as he fingered the scar where a thug had stabbed him. "We've got a problem, minister," said Talfryn, the prime minister's press secretary. "The Express has discovered your affair with the actress Joanna Jermyn." Richard sighed. How dare the press contaminate the purity of his love. "There's no link between the stabbing and the affair, is there?" continued Talfryn. "Good, then the PM is right behind you."

Joanna wrapped her arms round Richard's neck. "Jeremy was a bit spiteful when I told him our marriage was over and that I was leaving him for you," she whispered. "Gosh how I love you. Truly, madly, deeply."

Richard lay low in his brother's loft, while Joanna flew to America to make another film with Case Stipe. He tried to work on Labour's new manifesto, but politics seemed so shallow.

"The police have identified the man who stabbed you," said Talfryn. "You'll have to testify."

"I can't," replied Richard. "I didn't see him. Besides I deserved it because I'm a posh cunt."

"You have to," insisted Talfryn."The PM's tough on law and order."

"OK."

"My father's died, darling," cooed Richard. "You'll have to stay away a little longer or the funeral will turn into a circus. I love you."

"How was it possible for one woman to love one man so much," wondered Joanna, as she pretended to take some coke before a meaningless actressy one-night stand with Case.

"We hear that Joanna's implicated in a drug and sex scandal," said Talfryn.

"You will still testify against the thug? Good. The PM loves you."

"It meant nothing, I love you," pleaded Joanna, but all Richard could see were the thin globules of betrayal that coated her breasts. He just couldn't bring himself to tell Joanna how much he loved her, he thought as he eased himself into Jenny, the stablehand.

"The PM is very angry that you didn't testify," said Talfryn. "Here's your resignation letter."

Richard waited at the stage door of the Almeida.

"You can't come in," said a minder.

"Send the limo after him," shrieked Joanna. Richard and Joanna lay entwined, a chasm of empty promises between them.

fields.headline: FCB 20-30 lands Club Med ad brief
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Club Med has hired Paris-based FCB 20-80 to develop a youth sub-brand to update its image, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Club Med has hired Paris-based agency FCB 20-80 to develop a youth sub-brand called Bazic.

The ageing French holiday operator is striving to update its image.

FCB 20-80, owned by the True North advertising group, will develop a global campaign to build awareness of a new resort format aimed at young holidaymakers.

The main Club Med ad account is held by Publicis, which is also thought to have pitched for the Bazic business.

The Bazic concept offers stripped-down holiday resorts run along similar lines to low-cost airlines.

Club Med believes an emphasis on sport and music - with rudimentary levels of service and simple accommodation - will appeal to the booming market of 18 to 30- year-olds.

The first Bazic resort will open in Tunisia this summer and around 10 more should follow over the next five years.

Club Med, 50 years old this month, has traditionally aimed its all-inclusive resort concept at middle-class couples.

But Philippe Bourguignon, the former Disney executive who took over as chief executive in 1997, is gradually revolutionising the chain, having rescued it from near bankruptcy.

He has revamped Club Med's 120 resorts and brought down prices to make the holidays appeal to families.

Several resorts - particularly in the Mediterranean region - are aimed principally at the British market.

fields.headline: Read my letters on Hinduja affair - Vaz
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Foreign office minister Keith Vaz today refused to explain the details of his involvement in the Hinduja passport affair but said he would be "very happy" for all his correspondence  on the subject to be published eventually.
fields.body:
Foreign office minister Keith Vaz today refused to explain the details of his involvement in the Hinduja passport affair but said he would be "very happy" for all his correspondence on the subject to be published eventually.

Mr Vaz said publication would have to wait until after a government inquiry led by Sir Anthony Hammond QC.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, lent the minister support today, saying: "From the look of the papers I have seen I cannot see anything wrong with what has been done.

"Keith is a prominent Asian MP, they are prominent people from the Asian community - he made representations on their behalf."

Mr Blair, speaking in his Sedgefield constituency, added: "I cannot see anything wrong in him making representations on [behalf of] other members of the Asian community."

Mr Vaz, MP for Leicester East, has become embroiled in the controversy over the application for naturalisation by wealthy Indian brothers Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja.

The controversy that followed Peter Mandelson's resignation over the row showed no sign of dying down today with the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, tabling parliamentary questions asking for more details.

The Home Office has already disclosed that Mr Vaz asked when decisions would be made in the brothers' cases.

"Let's get the facts, let's not talk about innuendo," Mr Vaz told BBC Radio Leicester this morning.

"Let's put aside all the garbage that's written about Peter Mandelson. Let's get at the facts. I'm very happy to have all my correspondence published. I don't think you will find it as exciting as you think it will be."

Asked why he would not now fully disclose all his correspondence, the minister replied: "There's an answer, which was put down in the House of Commons. It's not anything new. It's quite clear what everyone did.

"What the prime minister has done is, because there's concern, he's asked Anthony Hammond, who is one of the finest lawyers of his generation, to conduct a review of the file.

"[Then] I would be quite happy for all the letters to be released so there's full disclosure."

The Tory leader, William Hague, has said Conservative MPs will be demanding to know whether and why Mr Vaz wrote to Mr Blair and Mr Mandelson in 1997 about the Hindujas' bid to become British citizens.

Mr Hague has said a "whiff of suspicion" was hanging over the government and warned ministers against trying to duck outstanding questions by hiding behind Sir Anthony's review.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, whose inquiries initiated the sequence of events which led to Mr Mandelson's resignation, was also seeking more answers.

"I don't think it's over yet. There are a whole load of unanswered questions. We need to know exactly who lobbied whom and when, and for what purpose," said Mr Baker.

Another written parliamentary answer to Mr Baker, from the home secretary, Jack Straw, confirmed that SP Hinduja's ultimately successful passport application was filed on October 20 1998, just days after the brothers' £1m donation to the Millennium Dome.

fields.headline: The things she has said
fields.trailText: The new RCN leader on leadership, doctors, stress, patients and crying
fields.body:
The new RCN leader on leadership, doctors, stress, patients and crying

On being a nurse leader: "My job is to offer my vision. The beautiful thing about it is when you share the vision, it changes. If you hold on to it, it won't change; it will only be your personal vision. The way to make it real is to share it."

On nurses, doctors and power: "We need nurses who have power, and nurses have a lot of power, but we just don't acknowledge it. We don't admit it. It's as if we had it and we left it somewhere Or, we think the physicians are going to figure out that we need it and they are going to just walk up and say: 'I know you have been wanting my power base for a long time, I came to just drop it off for you.' That really is hallucinating, colleagues, if you think a doctor is going to walk up to you and offer you some power. We have got to make sure there are other ways of getting power in order to manage change."

On taking her nursing exams: "I took mine in a barn. It was the state fair grounds, and we knew the animals had been in there just the day before. It had that antiseptic smell to it, but we knew the cows and the pigs had just recently vacated the place. I remember, they kind of lined us up (we are very regimented in nursing) so it was like a sort of concentration camp at the time, and our monitors were like the Gestapo."

On seeing the big picture: "We allow petty things to get in our way. One of the things I've been blessed with is I don't get caught up in petty things."

On being a role model: "Seventy-five per cent of getting there is seeing yourself there. I would not take it personally if they thought to themselves: 'She's not that much, I could do that.' In fact I would say, go for it. That's really the whole issue. I hope others will say, I can do this. I can do what Bev Malone does."

On nurses' traditional role: "Clinical expertise is not going away ... We are always going to have to go with hands-on care. There is nothing wrong with any of the new things, but it doesn't eliminate the need for individuals to feel the touch."

On managing stress: "Managing yourself is so important. Make sure you treat yourself well. Find ways to give yourself some breathing time. Some rest time in between that crazy place called work and that equally crazy place called home. Find ways to buy yourself some bedroom door locks - and use them. And tell those wonderful family members that you don't want to be interrupted for 45 minutes after you get off, unless they are dying and they have documentation."

On getting in touch with your emotions: "If you have a tendency to cry, don't worry about it, you can get through anything, just get yourself lots of Kleenex. It shouldn't stop you from accomplishing anything."

On getting in touch with your charismatic side: "I know we can have charisma, but we (as nurses) are not packaging each other well. We tend to exhibit and demonstrate the pain in nursing. I think nurses luxuriate in pain. We have a special relationship with it. We value it, instead of just looking for some of the joy. Showing the joy in what you do is really the best definition of charisma."

On surviving organisational change: "One of the things nursing has developed is a great ability to deliver quality care in the middle of chaos. There is not a nurse I know who cannot manage that, and do that extremely well. We need to start thinking about acquiring a taste for the chaos."

On redefining the role of nursing: "We're talking about partnership - not just with patients - but among ourselves too. fields.headline: Europe unruffled by Mandelson's fall
fields.standfirst: The fall of Peter Mandelson will not unduly worry Europe's political elite, which   believes Britain will join the euro when Tony Blair says so,   writes Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.trailText: The fall of Peter Mandelson will not unduly worry Europe's political elite, which believes Britain will join the euro when Tony Blair says so, writes Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
The shock resignation of the government's most outspoken advocate of Britain joining the euro may be lamented by the UK's low-key army of europhiles, but on the continent Peter Mandelson's demise has hardly raised an eyebrow.

Little known in Brussels, Paris or Berlin, Europe's power elite has already put its faith in just one man to lead the UK into the single currency and that man is not Peter Mandelson. It is Tony Blair.

The dark prince may have enjoyed a stellar profile back at home but on the continent his name is scarcely known, largely because his career, firstly at the Department of Trade and Industry and latterly at the Northern Ireland Office, has been exclusively domestic.

Mr Blair's towering stature as a European statesman is something which Mr Mandelson can only dream about. Had he achieved his thinly veiled ambition of becoming foreign secretary, however, then it would perhaps be a different story.

But as it is his fall from grace was relegated to the inside pages of Europe's serious press with many papers merely reporting that Tony Blair had lost his 'eminence grise'.

At the European Commission's headquarters in Brussels where officials would give their left arm to see the UK safely in the eurozone there was also precious little disquiet.

"It seems strangely irrelevant, everyone is fascinated by it and everyone is talking about it but nobody thinks it is going to make any difference to us," one highly placed commission insider told the Guardian.

"He was not that high profile and he didn't make many important visits here. I don't think people will fear that Britain will be less pro-European because of his departure."

There was even a little schadenfreude in Brussels where some Eurocrats still remember with disgust a highly publicised speech given by Mr Mandelson in the summer of 1999 when he was between jobs after resigning over the home loan debacle with Geoffrey Robinson.

Ironically he argued at the time that the commission needed to improve its media management skills and shake off the lingering whiff of fraud and corruption which had caused the entire Brussels executive, then under Jacques Santer, to resign.

"There is a feeling that Blair decides everything and that he doesn't need Mandelson. Even people who are deeply interested in British politics are not worried. The most pro-European Brit known abroad is Tony Blair," explains one veteran French foreign correspondent.

"I'd be really surprised if many educated people on the continent had even heard of Mandelson."

Only the French daily Liberation seemed to think that Mandelson's loss might be a setback for the British pro-European cause.

It wrote: "With his departure the Labour government is losing one if its most brilliant and pro-European members who was destined to become the foreign secretary. He was almost the only person to openly defend the pound's entry into the single currency."

His resignation was greeted in most quarters, however, with a deafening silence. Mr Mandelson, it seems, will now never get his chance to make his mark on the European stage. and his dream of representing Britain abroad is instead being realised by Robin Cook.

Shortly before his appointment to the Northern Ireland office the great euro proselytiser managed to hold one or two meetings with German politicians to discuss Labour's 'third way' philosophy.

However, he never really had enough time to distinguish himself and it now looks as if Peter Mandelson's dream of becoming a European statesman will remain painfully unfulfilled.

webTitle: Liddell joins cabinet after Blair's choice is blocked

fields.headline: Liddell joins cabinet after Blair's choice is blocked
fields.standfirst:
First woman in job praises devolution parliament

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Helen Liddell became the first woman secretary of state for Scotland in the notoriously male-dominated world of Scottish politics after Tony Blair's first choice of Brian Wilson was blocked by the devolved administration in Edinburgh, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Helen Liddell became the first woman secretary of state for Scotland in the notoriously male-dominated world of Scottish politics after Tony Blair's first choice of Brian Wilson was blocked by the devolved administration in Edinburgh, it emerged last night.

Though he has kept quiet in recent years, Mr Wilson - John Reid's deputy before Wednesday's mini-reshuffle - remains a gut anti-devolutionist, a view anathema to Henry McLeish, the new Scottish first minister.

Downing Street refused to confirm that Mr Wilson's promotion had been blocked, but it is understood from friends of Mr Wilson that Mr McLeish prevented him getting the post he expected. The politics behind the choice of Ms Liddell - who becomes the seventh woman in the cabinet - emerged as she spoke of being "overwhelmed and humbled" at becoming the first woman to hold a post she was tipped to get 20 months ago instead of Mr Reid.

The MP for Airdrie and Shotts, who entered Parliament in 1994 after winning the Monklands East byelection caused by John Smith's death, allied herself to her "old friend" Mr McLeish as she pledged to make devolution work. Insisting she had "fought all her life" for devolution, the former energy minister said: "I look forward to a very exciting time here in Scotland and I am very conscious that I have been given a huge privilege to play my part in building the new Scotland in the 21st century.

"The initiative taken in establishing the Scottish parliament is one of the most exciting constitutional developments in the European Union and I am delighted to have this opportunity to work with my old friend Henry McLeish to make sure that Scotland and all of the United Kingdom benefits to the full."

Once described as having "balls of steel" by the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, 50-year-old Mrs Liddell has held four ministerial posts since the 1997 election.

webTitle: Hackers caused site breach, says Microsoft

fields.headline: Hackers caused site breach, says Microsoft
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Software giant Microsoft admitted late last night that it was the victim of hackers who left millions of customers without access to popular services like Hotmail and Expedia for most of Thursday
fields.body:
Software giant Microsoft admitted late last night that it was the victim of hackers who left millions of customers without access to popular services like Hotmail and Expedia for most of Thursday.

Yesterday marked the third day running that Microsoft web sites had been down, though the company said site failures on Tuesday and Wednesday were due to an error made by a company technician and not a hacker.

The company has asked the FBI to investigate Thursday's incident, which Microsoft described as a denial-of-service attack. These attacks happen when hackers flood a network with useless traffic so that it cannot respond to normal requests from users.

The company said that normal access has now been restored, and added: "It is unfortunate that an individual or group of individuals would engage in this kind of illegal activity. Microsoft has made the FBI aware of this situation."

Similar attacks caused problems for companies like Amazon, CNN, eBay and Yahoo! last year. Last week, a 16-year-old Canadian boy known as "Mafiaboy" pleaded guilty to 56 charges of mischief in connection with some of those attacks. Ten other charges were dropped.

Microsoft, which prides itself on providing reliable internet access, was quick to point out that none of the site failures had anything to do with its software.

"This was an operational error, and not the result of any issue with Microsoft or third party products nor the security of our networks. Microsoft regrets any inconvenience caused to customers due to this issue," said a statement on the company's website.
