fields.headline: Turn off the money tap
fields.standfirst: Relying on rich men is bad for democracy
fields.trailText: Relying on rich men is bad for democracy
fields.body:
In politics, where there's brass there's muck. Money and power make explosive chemistry: the struggle to separate the two has been the story of the birth of democracy since the first reform acts ended pocket boroughs and public voting. Yet the world's leading democracies are all mired in financial scandals. The stench of politicians trading favours and honours for cash hangs in a thick pall from the Potomac to the Rhine. Little of it concerns old fashioned Jonathan Aitken or Neil Hamilton back-handers. Most of it concerns raising private money for political parties or for semi-political projects like the dome. Enough words have sent Peter Mandelson on his lonely way: the man has paid a painful price. But the question remains - should democratic politicians ever be put into a position where they have to raise vast sums from rich men? As a mea culpa, Labour's manifesto should now include a pledge to end political fund-raising sleaze once and for all and commit to state funding and regulation of parties from now on.

The party conferences reek of ill-gotten cash, more each year that passes. Delegates and press alike are forcibly decked out in advertising slogans of sponsors on security passes. Everything is sponsored, chairs you sit on, air you breathe, all sponsors fruitily praised and thanked for the canapes and drinks at meetings or the printing of the party agenda packs, as ministers scuttle between gold plate dinners among the fund-raising access, easements and embellishments. Looking round the colossal exhibition halls at Labour's conference last year, the smell of lucre from industrialists, lobbyists, benefactors and even cash-paying fatcat charities overpowered the fish and chips. What were they all doing there, paying a small fortune for their showy booths to catch the politicians' eyes? Either it was for the personal vanity of CEOs who want to be there while their shareholders or charity fund collectors pay the bill - or it is plain cash for influence. An aroma of favours, the minister's ear, influence, greasy palms, the shimmer of power swills together in foetid hotel meeting rooms. Innocent by US standards, nothing like the ostentatious company champagne flowing at Tory conferences in their glory days, still small beer - but this is how it begins.

Its tentacles reach out to the think-tanks and party affiliates. Those that can persuade potential benefactors that they have the true ear of their party leaders can expect rich rewards in spon sorship money. Is it because companies, banks or management consultancies genuinely want to nurture creative new political thought? More likely they hope that linking their name to a close party organisation will somehow, some day ease their way into whatever it is they want - a contract or just a pleasing rubbing of shoulders with the mighty for their managing director.

It is the big money from the millionaires that is most lethally damaging. Asil Nadir, Jeffrey Archer, Michael Ashcroft, the Hindujas, Bernie Ecclestone, Michael Wheeler, Stanley Kalms, Robert Bourne - whether eccentrics or sincere believers, whether paying to steer the party's ideology or paying for naked gain, the mud always sticks. And it sticks both ways. Scrupulously honest men like David Sainsbury or Paul Hamlyn get tarred with the same brush by the simple act of giving to a cause they support: in politics generosity is turned to acid spite. There is no free lunch, there is no donation without strings. Even those who want nothing are still using their deep pockets to promote the party of their choice. But the days of buying elections must be over now. A royal commission should be appointed to devise a generally acceptable fair funding formula: there is no perfect system, but anything is better than government by millionaire.

Labour has been oddly tentative about this. Not because it has anything to fear - it is the Tories who might suffer more from fair state funding. The Blairites fear that politicians and parties are so thoroughly loathed that the public would rebel at taxpayers' money paying for Millbank and Central Office. This super-caution on all electoral reform is Labour cowardice: part of the reason for cynicism, low turnout and sinking public trust is because of the slush money. On the doorsteps too many people say: "None of them! They're all the same, only in it for themselves!" They do not distinguish clearly between dubious party fundraising and criminal lining of politicians' pockets. Voters would be easily persuaded that a piffling sum from the Treasury - around £50m - is a price well worth paying for seagreen incorruptibility. A royal commission would have to devise a quid pro quo for state funding: the IPPR points out that present near-derelict parties would need a duty to engage voters with a recruit-or-die formula instead of running local democracy as private fiefdoms.

On February 16, the Neill/Nolan reforms come into force obliging revelation of all gifts over £5,000 and banning foreign donors. But each revelation only adds to public contempt. This election each party will be capped at £20m, money splashed all over the country in gigantic hoardings selling incredible promises and preposterous insults against the enemy that bring politics into disrepute. People will rightly see this as money badly raised and badly spent, futile frittering of fortunes to virtually zero electoral effect, offending the voters' IQ. Trade unions (30%) and individual big donors (20%) now pay for half Labour funding: an unknown but higher proportion of Tory costs are paid by companies and big donors. Tony Blair said he was "absolutely proud" of the mega- donations from successful entrepreneurs. He cannot be serious - but how can he admit it is shaming and humiliating to a democratic leader?

This is a pretty clean government. Venality accusations just don't stick to Tony Blair, Gordon Brown or the rest - so how have they allowed Eccelstone and Hinduja allegations to sink them in the mud? Because big money will always corrode politics. Helmut Kohl's giant reputation for uniting Germany when lesser leaders might have hesi tated now lies in perpetual ruin because of illegal channelling of £600,000 in undisclosed donations to his party. French president Jacques Chirac and his party likewise are mired in allegations of selling building contracts for party-funding deals. As for George Bush, nearly £.5bn was raised and spent in hard and soft money - hugely more than Al Gore: the indulgences it bought are already rolling out. How is the west to high-horse it over third world dictatorships diverting national treasuries into Swiss bank accounts if our own democratic elections are financed by cash for favours?

This is Labour high ground and Labour should go for it, do it now and defy the Tories to defend the buying of votes by plutocrats.

webTitle: Q&A: Free personal care - where does Scotland stand now?

fields.headline: Q&A: Free personal care - where does Scotland stand now?
fields.trailText:

In principle, yes. fields.body:
Is Scotland now committed to free personal care?
In principle, yes. During the course of yesterday's heated debate, first minister Henry McLeish made it abundantly clear that the voice of the Scottish parliament could not, and would not, be ignored. The majority of MSPs in the parliament are clearly in favour of full implementation of the Sutherland report which called for free personal care. When faced with the prospect of an embarrassing defeat, the Scottish executive committed itself to bringing forward proposals for "free personal care for all".

What did the executive say?
In an emergency statement just minutes before the vote, parliament minister Tom McCabe said that proposals would be brought forward "as soon as practicable" after a development group to consider the practicalities, costs and implications has produced its report in August. He did add ominously though, that any proposals would be accompanied by a full analysis of the costs and implications.

What does this mean exactly?
Just what it says. The executive has really only committed itself to coming up with proposals. There is no mention of any timetable for implementation, as was demanded by the original Liberal Democrat motion. When pressed on the detail, the Scottish executive has refused to confirm whether it has accepted the principle of free personal care or whether it was now committed to accepting the proposals. This clearly upset Liberal Democrat health spokesperson Keith Raffan, chief Sutherland protagonist and author of the motion, who has offered his resignation to leader Jim Wallace. The SNP, meanwhile, is calling for a clarification of the executive's statement.

What do the opposition parties feel about it?
The largest opposition party, the Scottish Nationalists, can barely contain their rage. Although they appear to have got what it wanted, the prospect of an executive defeat slipping through their fingers seemed almost too much to bear. An inconsolable SNP health spokesperson Nicola Sturgeon later described the climbdown as a "shameless exercise" in political skin-saving. The Liberal Democrat leadership is understandably ecstatic that it has succeeded in reversing the executive's policy and is claiming a great victory. The Tories, meanwhile, claim the Lib Dems have been bought off cheaply because, without any definite timetable, the executive's commitment falls well short of what was originally demanded.

So where does that leave the Labour-Lib Dem coalition?
According to Mr McLeish after the debate, the coalition is working well, and for the time being there doesn't seem to be any danger of a major split. The Lib Dems are no doubt be happy that they have been able to exercise a bit of political muscle and are likely to make great play of it, along with previous concessions on student tuition fees, in justifying the coalition to both their supporters and the electorate.

And what about Mr McLeish?
Ironically, he seems to have got what he wanted all along - although his means of achieving it may strike some people as somewhat bizarre. Whether it was all down to some Machiavellian plot or just plain crisis management, no-one knows. He certainly didn't seem fazed after the apparent "cave-in" just minutes before yesterday's crucial vote. And if, in the coming months before the general election, he should get a lot of stick from Tony Blair and Gordon Brown for causing ripples south of the border, he can always say: "Well, that's democracy for you."

fields.headline: Interactive TV firm denies it's Open to fraud
fields.trailText: 2pm: Open has brushed off claims that its interactive platform on BSkyB is prone to abuse by fraudulent users, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Interactive TV company Open has brushed off claims that its interactive platform on BSkyB is prone to abuse by fraudulent users.

Open told MediaGuardian.co.uk its service was still much safer than the high street or the internet, in the light of a report on Netimperative.com that suggested 19 cases of credit card fraud were under investigation.

"Open is the only medium where the user is protected because we don't even ask for a delivery address - we automatically send goods purchased out to the address where the set-top box is registered," said Ricardo Tejada, director of corporate communications at Open.

If the credit card proves to be fraudulent Open can immediately switch off the set-top box and give the police the fraudster's address.

"Consumers are in no way threatened. It's certainly not possible for hackers to get credit card details as it's a closed service run by HSBC.

Stolen credit cards used to buy products is the only type of fraud we've encountered, and that is minuscule - only 19 cases against hundreds of thousands of transactions," added Mr Tejada.

webTitle: Living children's glands given to drug firms

fields.headline: Living children's glands given to drug firms
fields.standfirst: Society.Guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The hospital at the centre of a scandal over the stockpiling of babies' organs today faced fresh criticism after admitting that it gave a pharmaceutical company body parts from living children in return for financial donations
fields.body:
The hospital at the centre of a scandal over the stockpiling of babies' organs today faced fresh criticism after admitting that it gave a pharmaceutical company body parts from living children in return for financial donations.

Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool said thymus glands removed from youngsters during complex heart operations were sent to the company for research purposes between 1991 and 1993.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, said: "This is yet another piece of deeply distressing news for the parents of children treated at Alder Hey.

"This was a particular practice which was happening in the early 90s at Alder Hey and, it seems, some other hospitals.

"The NHS already knows this practice of taking organs without consent is totally unacceptable to this government. To reinforce this we will be issuing further guidance to the NHS."

Mr Milburn added: "Next week we will publish the report of an inquiry into the appalling sequence of events at Alder Hey and I will be making a full statement to parliament. It is clear that changes will have to be made to ensure that patients' consent comes first."

A spokeswoman for Alder Hey said: "The hospital obviously regret if this information is causing any sort of grief to parents."

The mother of a baby boy whose organs were removed and stored by Alder Hey without her consent said she was appalled at the latest disclosure.

The exchange of organs for cash is the latest twist in the Alder Hey organs scandal - and the first time body parts from living children have been involved.

A spokeswoman for Alder Hey refused to name the company involved, but it is understood to be Aventis Pasteur, a leading vaccination research firm which has its headquarters in the French city of Lyons.

The company donated money to the hospital's cardiac department after receiving thymus glands from the operations.

The Alder Hey spokeswoman said: "In some cases to carry out complex heart surgery it is necessary for the thymus gland to be removed.

"The hospital can confirm that for a brief period between 1991 and 1993 these were made available to a pharmaceutical company for research, and that we are aware that during that period contributions were made to the trust's cardiac department."

She would not confirm the how many children were involved.

A consultant paediatrician at Alder Hey, Dr Mark Caswell, said: "It is a routine procedure which means that the thymus gland is taken out to allow better access for cardiac surgeons to perform their operation."

"Up until 1993, these thymus glands were supplied to a pharmaceutical company for them to produce drugs which would allow us to treat children with aplastic anaemia.

"This was a very important part of their treatment and was something that the hospital felt it was very important to be involved in.

"In 1993, there were concerns about this being a commercial transaction even though there was only a small token payment being made for these thymus glands and supply of thymus glands then stopped," he added.

Parental consent was not sought for the removal of the thymus gland because it was a routine part of the procedure, Dr Caswell said.

The pharmaceutical company paid £5 for each thymus gland, he told Sky News, and the hospital regretted any distress caused to parents.

Paula O'Leary, of the families' support group Pity2, said she was "appalled" by the disclosure. Mrs O'Leary, of Bootle, Merseyside, asked: "What right have they got to treat our children like that?

"It is bad enough that they treated them with disrespect after their death, but disgraceful that they did this when they are alive.

"I keep saying, 'There can be nothing worse to come out', but each new week brings an horrific revelation."

Ian Cohen, a solicitor who represents more than 150 families affected by the Alder Hey scandal, said he hoped the latest development would be contained within the independent inquiry report.

"We have been trying to put pressure on Alder Hey for 15 months to tell us about whether pharmaceutical companies were involved in paying money in exchange for organs, but they have always said 'not to the best of our knowledge'.

"I have always had very grave concerns that Alder Hey will only disclose information like this when pressurised."

The thymus gland, a vital part of the immune system, is made up of two parts and lies in the upper area of the chest, close to the heart.

The two lobes, named thymus because they resemble a bunch of thyme flowers, produce healthy cells to attack foreign substances around the body.

One lobe develops cells to attack diseases as they enter the body, while the other continually produces defensive antibodies to keep the body healthy.

Aventis Pasteur, which also has sites in the United States, Canada, Argentina, Japan, Turkey, the Philippines and Mexico, specialises in vaccinations and is a partner in the Global Polio Eradication Initiative launched by the World Health Organisation in 1988.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Serpent's Kiss | Return to Me | Love & Basketball | Small Time Obsession
fields.trailText: The Serpent's Kiss | Return to Me | Love & Basketball | Small Time Obsession
fields.body:
The Serpent's Kiss
Rental and DVD (£15.99) Guerrilla Cert 15 ***

Many worse films than this intriguing video debut won a place in the cinema, and with Ewan McGregor, Greta Scacchi, Pete Postlethwaite and Richard E Grant, it didn't miss out for lack of star power. Made in 1997, and set in 1699, it's perhaps a little too similar to Greenaway's best film, The Draughtsman's Contract, for comfort. But it keeps you interested as McGregor's mysterious Dutch garden architect is taken on to build a monument suitable for rich foundry-owner Postlethwaite, who lives with wife Scacchi. When her malicious cousin, and ex-lover (Grant at his campest) pays a visit, a devious plot kicks into action. The directorial debut of noted French cinematographer Philippe Rousselot, who made La Reine Margot look so sumptuous, it has its rough edges. However, its twisty themes - gardening's taming of nature combined with the taming of human nature through duplicity, blackmail and propriety - with simmering sexual undercurrents make it well worth a try.

Return to Me
Rental and DVD (£19.99) Fox Pathé Cert PG **

The story of a man who falls in love with the woman who received his wife's heart in a transplant. What are the chances of that happening, as Harry Hill - or indeed William Hill - might ask. Fortunately, it's not as bad as it sounds. Minnie Driver's freshness can liven up the most preposterous of plots and David Duchovny has a better range than The X Files allows for. It's briskly directed by debutant Bonnie Hunt, who balances humour with schmaltz and also plays Driver's acerbic best friend, married to James Belushi, a squabbling couple who anchor the film loosely to real life.

Love & Basketball
Rental EV Cert 12 ***

With a female director (Gina Prince) and viewed largely through the eyes of a tomboyish girl ballplayer (Sanaa Lathan), this is a black sports movie that has remarkably little in common with the kids struggling in the ghetto in the memorable documentary Hoop Dreams. It is a rare slice of black middle-class life and a simple, small-scale film about the ups and downs of relationships as much as sporting dreams. It has only modest ambitions but achieves them nicely with sparky performances from Lathan and Omar Epps from Scream 2, in a playful relationship punctuated by sassy backchat. Its use of subjective camera in the scenes on court, sometimes with thoughts superimposed, is striking too. It's co-produced by Spike Lee, and ironically, much more convincing than his own overwrought basketball movie, He Got Game.

Small Time Obsession
Rental and DVD (£15.99) Guerrilla Cert 15 *

London-born Anglo-Polish director Piotr Szkopiak spent five years raising the money for this personal project - he was also producer, writer and editor. Like East is East, its interest lies in a first-generation immigrant community but it proves to be a predictable, glum soap-operatic tale of youngsters getting involved in petty crime. The acting is variable and the action scenes largely unconvincing.

fields.headline: Viewers lose appetite for Big Breakfast
fields.trailText: 1.45pm TV overnights: Channel 4's revamped Big Breakfast is proving an early morning turn-off, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Channel 4's revamped Big Breakfast is proving an early morning turn-off with viewing figures slipping still further yesterday.

The departure of Big Breakfast star presenters Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen has hit the show hard.

Just 300,000 viewers tuned in yesterday morning, less than half the 700,000 who watched the duo's last show two weeks ago.

Even last week the new line-up of Melanie Sykes, Paul Tonkinson, Amanda Byram, Donna Air and Richard Bacon was attracting around 500,000 viewers.

It was a bad day for Channel 4, which also pulled in disappointing ratings for its critically acclaimed US drama, The West Wing.

The show, set in Washington's corridors of power, was watched by 1.3m viewers to give it a 7% share - lower than any of the other terrestrial channels.

Elsewhere, ITV's News at Ten continued its winning streak, attracting 5.6m viewers - 700,000 more than watched the BBC's version.

And Channel 5 scored its highest audience share of the day with its late-night cult film show Outthere, which attracted 900,000 viewers to give it an 18% share.

The media interest in Rosie Boycott's departure from the Daily Express didn't do much to swell audiences on Question Time last night.

It was watched by just 2.6m viewers - a 21% share of the audience.

fields.headline: Libertad Lamarque
fields.standfirst: Argentina's first lady of the tango
fields.trailText: Argentina's first lady of the tango
fields.body:
The career of Libertad Lamarque, who has died aged 92, spanned more than 70 years. In the 1930s, she was one of Argentina's great tango singers and first cinema stars; later, she left the country after a public fight with the young Eva Duarte, "Evita" Perón.

Born in Rosario, on the Rio de la Plata, Lamarque was the daughter of an ironmonger, himself the child of French immigrants. It was in sketches he wrote for the anarchists that she began to perform, and the family moved to Buenos Aires to promote her career. In 1926, she began singing tangos in Calle Corrientes variety shows, and, in 1932, won a national contest, from whence she became universally known as the "queen of tango".

It seemed that her own life came straight out of tango and its passions. She was married at 18, and had her only child, her daughter Mirtha. The marriage did not last, and stormy love affairs followed. One story recalls how, desperate in love, Lamarque threw herself out of a hotel window while performing in the Chilean capital, Santiago, only to land on top of a dentist who happened to be walking by. This saved her life, and the dentist became a hero throughout Latin America.

Lamarque also had great acting talent. She was fortunate to come to the fore just as the film industry was starting up, and in 1929 appeared in Adiós Argentina, shot in a single day by the Italian Mario Parpagnoli. Four years later, she starred in what is generally regarded as Argentina's first sound film, appropriately enough entitled Tango!

The 1930s were boom years in Argentine cinema, and Lamarque was tied into film production just like a Hollywood star, churning out one or two movies a year. In these, she represented the suffering woman who - in a world full of faithless men, impossible love, treacherous female friends, and dying children - found her only consolation in the bittersweet melancholy of the tango.

These films met with an enormous success throughout Latin America, and proved more popular than anything offered by Hollywood; Argentinians like to say that it was to steal her talents that Lamarque was offered a huge Hollywood contract. She refused, staying on to make more films in Argentina, and marry a second time, to her long-standing companion, Alfredo Malerba.

In 1945, however, her career in Argentina suffered an abrupt break, while she was filming La cabalgata del circo (The Circus Parade), in which another of the actresses was the young Eva Duarte. According to widely repeated accounts, there was a furious row on the film set, and Libertad publicly slapped Eva. Soon afterwards, she realised it would be safer to head for Mexico.

Her arrival there coincided with a lively period in the arts, due in part to the presence of intellectuals and artists who had fled Spain after the civil war, among them Luis Buñuel. Lamarque's first Mexican film, Gran Casino was directed by him, though it is not one of his - or her - most memorable movies. Soon though, Mexican directors found a niche for her, as the loyal, suffering woman in high melodramas, and she went on to make more than 40 films.

Lamarque continued to sing tangos for a new generation in the 1940s and 1950s: as one appreciative review put it, "through her voice and the movements of her body, the tango gained energy, vitality and emotional depth". In 1955, after Perón's overthrow, she returned to Argentina, and worked both there and in Mexico. In the 1960s, she became a sought-after character actress in soap operas.

Above all, she kept working: in 1976, in Mexico, RCA Victor, the record label she always sang for, released three records of her songs from five decades, and when Argentina was looking for someone to star in the Spanish-language version of Hello Dolly, they turned to Lamarque.

She died in Mexico City, still working on Cara de ángel (Angel Face), a soap opera in which she played the mother superior in a convent.

This saved her life, and the dentist became a hero throughout Latin America. Lamarque also had great acting talent. She was fortunate to come to the fore just as the film industry was starting up, and in 1929 appeared in Adiós Argentina, shot in a single day by the Italian Mario Parpagnoli. Four years later, she starred in what is generally regarded as Argentina's first sound film, appropriately enough entitled Tango! The 1930s were boom years in Argentine cinema, and Lamarque was tied into film production just like a Hollywood star, churning out one or two movies a year. In these, she represented the suffering woman who - in a world full of faithless men, impossible love, treacherous female friends, and dying children - found her only consolation in the bittersweet melancholy of the tango. These films met with an enormous success throughout Latin America, and proved more popular than anything offered by Hollywood; Argentinians like to say that it was to steal her talents that Lamarque was offered a huge Hollywood contract. She refused, staying on to make more films in Argentina, and marry a second time, to her long-standing companion, Alfredo Malerba. In 1945, however, her career in Argentina suffered an abrupt break, while she was filming La cabalgata del circo (The Circus Parade), in which another of the actresses was the young Eva Duarte. According to widely repeated accounts, there was a furious row on the film set, and Libertad publicly slapped Eva. Soon afterwards, she realised it would be safer to head for Mexico. Her arrival there coincided with a lively period in the arts, due in part to the presence of intellectuals and artists who had fled Spain after the civil war, among them Luis Buñuel. Lamarque's first Mexican film, Gran Casino was directed by him, though it is not one of his - or her - most memorable movies. Soon though, Mexican directors found a niche for her, as the loyal, suffering woman in high melodramas, and she went on to make more than 40 films. Lamarque continued to sing tangos for a new generation in the 1940s and 1950s: as one appreciative review put it, "through her voice and the movements of her body, the tango gained energy, vitality and emotional depth". In 1955, after Perón's overthrow, she returned to Argentina, and worked both there and in Mexico. In the 1960s, she became a sought-after character actress in soap operas. Above all, she kept working: in 1976, in Mexico, RCA Victor, the record label she always sang for, released three records of her songs from five decades, and when Argentina was looking for someone to star in the Spanish-language version of Hello Dolly, they turned to Lamarque. She died in Mexico City, still working on Cara de ángel (Angel Face), a soap opera in which she played the mother superior in a convent.  Libertad Lamarque, tango star and actress, born November 24 1908; died December 12 2000

fields.headline: Murdoch set to shelve Sky Global flotation
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Rupert Murdoch is likely to abandon the flotation of satellite TV operation Sky Global Networks, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch is likely to perform a sensational about-turn and abandon the flotation of his Sky Global Networks satellite TV operation.

The News Corporation chairman has been struggling to get the £27bn company off the ground.

The move is the result of wrangles over its shareholder structure, along with volatile market conditions.

Mr Murdoch told CNBC Asia he may instead merge existing public companies but did not name them.

"The market conditions for floating Sky Global will be tough," said Marc Loneux, media analyst at Commerzbank.

"Murdoch will have to look at other options."

However, he said a flotation was still possible if talks with US satellite broadcasters were successful.

Mr Murdoch is known to be interested in buying satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV from General Motors in the US.

However, the lack of cash at NewsCorp is a major stumbling block.

NewsCorp is saddled with £6.2bn-worth of debt and the threat of its debt rating being downgraded to junk bond status.

On top of this, it must pay £3.6bn for US TV company Chris Craft.

NewsCorp also faces a £1bn bill after Haim Saban, co-owner of NewsCorp's Fox Family network, exercised an option that forces Mr Murdoch to buy back his partner's stake.

Mr Murdoch is planning to reverse his TV businesses - which include BSkyB and Asian station Star TV - into DirecTV, with General Motors remaining a key shareholder.

DirecTV would be renamed Sky Global Networks and General Motors would gradually sell its holding to strategic investors.

If this plan does not work, Mr Murdoch will be left with a vastly weakened company which is unlikely to attract interest from investors.

This has sparked today's change in strategy.

BSkyB was unavailable for comment but it will play a key role in the future of Sky Global.

One option is to inject Mr Murdoch's TV assets into the company, creating an enlarged satellite and digital broadcaster.

However, French media giant Vivendi Universal is trying to sell its 22% stake in the company.

This issue must be resolved before BSkyB's shareholder structure undergoes further tampering.

webTitle: Britt Ekland seeks backing for Peter Sellers biopic

fields.headline: Britt Ekland seeks backing for Peter Sellers biopic
fields.trailText: The Swedish actress is looking for funding for a film, in which she intends to play herself, about her life with her former husband
fields.body:
Britt Ekland is apparently struggling to find a backer for a film based on her life with former husband Peter Sellers. According to peoplenews, the Swedish actress plans to play herself in the movie, but hasn't been able to secure funding as the industry thinks she does not have enough distance from the subject.

One insider said: "Making a film about Sellers is a fantastic idea, but it looks like it won't get off the ground; the feeling is that she's too close and it won't be objective."

Peter Sellers first made his name as a performer on the radio series, the Goon Show, a landmark in British comedy. His remarkable comic talent together with a gift for mimicry made a move into films inevitable and his movie debut in Penny Points to Paradise in 1951 soon led to a successful career in British films before he was taken up by Hollywood in the 60s.

His most notable roles include The Ladykillers, Dr Strangelove, The Pink Panther and Being There, for which he received an Oscar nomination. Ekland, 57, was Sellers' second wife, marrying him just ten days after they met. She was 21, he was 38 and they were married for four years. Sellers, who was married four times, died of a heart attack in 1980.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-two

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-two
fields.standfirst: It's the next instalment of our Blue Square-sponsored betting game. With yet another punter off ill, our gamblers are making up for the lack of bets by having more punts than they technically should
fields.trailText: It's the next instalment of our betting game. With yet another punter off ill, our gamblers are making up for the lack of bets by having more punts than they technically should.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £154.49, Sean Ingle = £52.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £39.40, Paul MacInnes = £28.15

Scott Murray: Sheffield Wednesday to win at Southampton (£5 at 15/2); Tranmere to win at Everton (£5 at 13/2).

It's Super Bowl weekend. Shall I watch the big game with a corn dog and a soda? What about a Sloppy Joe and a root beer? Or maybe I'll cheer on the Red Bay Sox or whoever the hell is playing with salami with extra mayo on rye, followed by a burger.

Sometimes it's difficult making choices. Sometimes, like couch-bound US sports fans, it's best to go for the lot, just to be sure. This week, I can't decide whether the FA Cup shock of the weekend will see Tranmere win at Everton or Sheffield Wednesday triumph at Southampton. So I'm betting on them both.

Everton can't score for Toffee (I'm really sorry) unless they're playing Coventry, and if a team like Manchester City can put five past them, a Jason Koumas-inspired Tranmere can certainly grind out another Cup shock.

The other bet looks more dodgy, as Southampton are solid and have a good home record. But they're not scoring at the moment, a problem that could be exacerbated if James Beattie misses the game with head and foot injuries - and the return of Marian Pahars could mean little if he's stuck out on the wing again.

Wednesday have already dumped one Premiership team out of cup competition this season - West Ham in the Worthy - and if Koumas can inspire Tranmere at Everton, someone like Owen Morrison can scrape a winner here.

Pretzel, anyone?

Sean Ingle: Most goals tomorrow selection: £5 on Bristol City @ 3/1 and £2 on Sunderland at 12/1.

With my betting stash dropping faster than Chris Evans's trousers, I've decided to switch tack. Again. I like the look of Blue Square's Special on which team out of the eight they have chosen - Charlton, Bristol City, Southampton, Arsenal, Sunderland, Everton, Blackburn and Manchester City - will score the most goals tomorrow. You can virtually write off the last three teams - and I don't fancy Southampton to put many past Sheffield Wednesday either.

That leaves Charlton, who will probably cruise past Dagenham and Redbridge, and Arsenal, who should also be too good for QPR. But I think the value in this market lies with in-form Bristol City - who have scored more than two goals a game at home - to score a hatful against Conference strugglers Kingstonian. I also think Sunderland are worth a punt to repeat their four goals against Ipswich of earlier this season. So two single bets on the same market it is, then. What do you reckon, Patrick Murray?

Joe Fortune of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Sunderland v Ipswich - half-time draw, full-time Sunderland £5 @ 4/1.

I'd expect Sunderland should win this as they have an excellent home record, while Ipswich are coming off of a 4-1 thumping at Chelsea.

However, Sunderland aren't the most prolific of scorers and Ipswich have an excellent away record, which makes me think it will be quite a tight game.

Hence it seems quite likely that the sides will make it to half-time on level terms, with Sunderland's home advantage hopefully telling thereafter (Marcus Stewart not willing).

Make sure and get some rest, poorly Paul MacInnes!

webTitle: 'No question' of free personal care in England

fields.headline: 'No question' of free personal care in England
fields.trailText: The government has said there is "no question" of the UK government following Scotland's lead in offering free personal care to people living in residential homes in England and Wales.
fields.body:
The government has said there is "no question" of the UK government following Scotland's lead in offering free personal care to people living in residential homes in England and Wales.

Ministers stood firm today in the face of claims that the Scottish executive's shock decision would create a "two-tier system" of elderly care in the UK.

But they face renewed pressure to amend elderly care policy after the Scottish executive was last night forced to offer free long-term care for Scotland's pensioners.

The Scottish executive promised to introduce free personal care "as soon as practicable" in an astonishing policy u-turn designed to head off a potentially damaging parliamentary defeat.

The decision reversed an announcement made 24 hours earlier in which the executive said it would not make personal care for the elderly universally free.

Events in Scotland immediately gave fresh hope to campaigners in England, who hope to persuade the government to change their position on long term care.

Age Concern director general Gordon Lishman said Westminster would now have to "seriously consider" bringing policy into line with Scotland.

Proposals to provide free nursing care - but means tested personal care - in England and Wales are contained in the health and social care bill currently working its way through parliament.

Commons select committee chair David Hinchliffe said he wanted to see the government make amendments to the bill, which is currently at committee stage.

But health minister John Hutton said there was "no question" of the government following Scotland's lead.

He told the BBC: "Both the government and the Scottish executive are committed to improving health and social care services for older people, but we are doing it in different ways.

"We do not believe that this would be the best way forward for improving elderly care services in England."

fields.headline: Goldsmith slams 'insensitive' BBC
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Lady Annabel Goldsmith has accused the BBC of 'crass insensitivity' in its Nairobi plane-saboteur coverage. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Lady Annabel Goldsmith has accused the BBC of "crass insensitivity" for broadcasting a sympathetic interview with the man who nearly brought down a plane and its 400 passengers.

Lady Goldsmith was on the plane with her daughter Jemima Khan and other celebrities, including singer Bryan Ferry.

She said she "watched aghast as the BBC portrayed Paul Mukonyi in a sympathetic light" in its Ten O'Clock News on Monday night.

Mr Mukonyi had seized the controls of the BA jumbo jet on a flight to Nairobi, almost causing it to crash.

The BBC bulletin led with the interview, which was branded an "exclusive", on the night it went head to head with ITV's reinstated News at Ten.

In a letter published in today's Daily Telegraph, Lady Goldsmith said: "Mr Mukonyi was interviewed in bed. He told us he was sorry about what had happened and claimed he had not intended to crash the plane.

"Whether Mukonyi is mad or bad, I am unqualified to judge, but it seems clear from his behaviour he is one or the other.

"Why then did the BBC see fit to parade him as the subject of a human-interest story? The only element of genuine journalistic interest - why on earth the Kenyans could consider releasing him - was left unexamined."

Lady Goldsmith also accused the BBC of "bad news judgment" in broadcasting the interview.

"For those of us who have been severely traumatised and left terrified of flying as a result of our experience, it was crass insensitivity," she said.

A BBC spokesman said: "It was a legitimate story to cover and the interview with Mr Mukonyi and his psychiatrist was of the normal rigorous BBC news quality.

"We are always sensitive to the feelings of those involved in these types of story and we included the reaction of another passenger on the plane in the package."

The BBC contacted the Goldsmith family twice to ask if Ms Khan would take part in the Ten O'Clock News piece, but they declined, according to a senior source.

Other passengers from the flight, including Bryan Ferry, were also approached and the BBC contacted BA to see if any of the cabin crew were willing to be interviewed, the corporation insider added.

fields.headline: eToys and StepStone post poor results
fields.trailText: 1pm: Internet companies eToys and StepStone today posted disappointing financial results, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Two large web companies today posted disappointing financial results.

The once celebrated e-retailer eToys, which has taken a beating recently, admitted it only had enough cash left to last until the end of March.

While revenues for the third quarter rose 23% to £90m, losses mounted to £58m.

eToys is bracing itself for a tough couple of months.

It has convinced creditors to agree not to press their claims until at least the end of January.

The company has slashed its workworce by 70% and suffered depressed sales over the normally buoyant Christmas period.

eToys is already working with creditors on a restructuring plan that would keep it away from court and enforced liquidation.

Meanwhile, European internet recruitment giant StepStone reported slower than expected revenue growth for its fourth quarter.

Shares in StepStone fell 12% on Friday as analysts said the slower than expected sales growth cast a shadow over prospects for profits.

StepStone said revenues rose to £13m in the fourth quarter against pre-tax losses of £24m.

fields.headline: Infrastructure of corruption
fields.standfirst: A recent accident in Morocco drew all-too-brief attention to the lack of safety and widespread bribery on roads across the Arab world, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: A recent accident in Morocco drew all-too-brief attention to the lack of safety and widespread bribery on roads across the Arab world, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Our bus was full when it left Tangiers, but it's even fuller now. Along the way we've picked up a dozen extra passengers and they're standing, crammed in the aisle, for a six-hour journey.

This is both illegal and dangerous, but not to worry - the surplus passengers don't officially exist. They won't show up in the bus company's records because they haven't got tickets. Instead, they have come to a private understanding with the driver and conductor.

Financially, this is a happy arrangement for all concerned. The extra passengers pay less than full fare, while the driver and conductor make some money on the side - which in turn saves the bus company the expense of paying them a decent wage.

Getting money is one thing, but hanging onto it in a poor country like Morocco is something else: other people want a share.

You can't go many miles along a main road without coming to a police checkpoint where officers are on the lookout for overcrowded vehicles, or those with bald tyres, smoky exhausts and other defects they'll be prepared to ignore in exchange for a few dirhams.

As we approach the checkpoints the conductor tells the standing passengers to sit on the floor so that they can't be seen through the windows.

The police order the bus to stop but they don't take a look inside. Instead, the conductor folds up a small banknote in the palm of his hand and gets out to greet one of the officers. He shakes hands with the policeman. The policeman's hand slides discreetly into his pocket and out again, then he waves us on. Everything is in order.

Last Monday a crowded bus on another route - from Marrakesh to Asni in the Atlas mountains - careered off the road and rolled down a hillside, killing 31 people and injuring 34.

Nobody in Morocco was terribly surprised by this, and the local media that bothered to report the tragedy had little to say beyond emphasising that King Mohammed had personally sent condolences to the victims' families and that the injured were being treated in military hospitals (ie the sort with decent facilities).

A full investigation into the accident has been promised but whatever it finds, you can be sure that any part played by roadside corruption will not be mentioned.

Cavalier approaches to safety are not just a Moroccan problem, but they are certainly a bigger problem in Arab countries than in the west. Nor is it just a matter of road accidents: the number of jerry-built houses in Egypt, for example, that fall down, killing their occupants, is quite amazing.

At one level, this can be blamed on a widespread sense of fatalism - that God alone determines whether we live or die. In most Middle Eastern countries if you get into a taxi and try to fasten your seat belt, the driver will, if he's in a good mood, merely ridicule you. The more macho ones treat it as defamatory comment on their driving skills. Many cars have colourful stickers on their dashboard saying, in Arabic calligraphy, "Ma sha' Allah" (Whatever God wills).

In the poorer countries, fatalism is coupled with a belief that safety is an expensive luxury. It is certainly cheaper to put your trust in God and buy a little sticker to say so, than to replace worn-out brake linings.

Sometimes this comes down to a choice between daily necessities and hypothetical possibilities. Imagine a family whose only source of income is the father's unroadworthy taxi. Should they go short of food in order to repair it, or carry on and pray that he won't have an accident?

That, of course, is where safety laws come in: to protect us from our own (and other people's) reluctance to take precautions. But laws in the Middle East are rarely what they seem. Often they exist, not for the public good, but for the good of those appointed to enforce them.

Anyone who is inconvenienced by a law can usually get round it by lubricating the bureaucracy with a little cash. Over time, this becomes the norm and laws serve only to generate income for the officials in charge.

Privately, most Arabs find the system disgusting. Some quote a verse from the Koran which says that the person who pays a bribe is as guilty as the person who receives it - but a refusal to pay can, at the very least, prove enormously time-consuming.

Others find ways to avoid a confrontation. One Moroccan of my acquaintance bought a stethoscope which he keeps on his car's dashboard where any policeman who stops him will see it and assume he's a doctor. Policemen, he says, are superstitious about harassing doctors lest they be struck down with sickness.

From time to time, when the level of grumbling gets too much, governments announce an anti-corruption drive. In Yemen, a couple of years ago, the president reportedly drove incognito from Sana'a to Aden to see how many policemen would ask for bribes along the way. That certainly scared a few people, but nothing more.

Once institutionalised, corruption becomes very difficult to eradicate. A good first step, in many countries, would be to reduce temptation by paying the police (and other officials) a decent salary. But that would mean putting up taxes - and persuading people to pay them without bribing the tax collectors.

fields.headline: Loss of direction
fields.standfirst: Sean Penn can extract great performances from actors - shame he can't build a movie around them
fields.trailText: Sean Penn can extract great performances from actors - shame he can't build a movie around them
fields.body:
In the late 1980s and early 1990s in Los Angeles there was a period in which it became briefly fashionable to associate yourself with books. It was quite the done thing to affect swotty specs and the divinely sozzled/enlightened bearing of a wandering drinker-scholar while toting a copy of either Charles Bukowski's Women or Raymond Carver's What We Talk About When We Talk About Love. People whose only previous literary exploits consisted of moving their lips as they read the TV guide would suddenly reappear in the social orbit garbed in the austere vestments - the designer hairshirts - of literary pretension; not existentialist berets or the patented Albert Camus greatcoat/Gitane combo, but in pseudy, plain-lens goggles and carrying chintzy notebooks considerably more valuable than anything ever likely to be scrawled in them.

It was a phenomenon that never spread much beyond twentysomething, middle-class, well-monied graduates of dodgy colleges, the kind of people who've never been anywhere or done anything and feel vaguely guilty and lightweight about it. Thus the literature they venerated was by and about people who had been places and done stuff, barebones writers and chest- beating primitives from the American working class such as Bukowski and Hubert Selby Jr, Carver and Harry Crews, the kind of skilful minimalists who, fatally, make their readers think writing is easy. They liked poetry, too, particularly if it was "free" and could be declaimed in actorly tones by its authors in absurdly self-important bookstores and java houses around the city.

Among those twentysomething, middle-class, well-monied types you could often find ageing members of the Brat Pack, itching to be taken seriously now that the glow was gone from their hitherto rosy teenage careers. You'd be amazed how many of these duffers ventured forth to read their own emetic poetry. Ally Sheedy, Molly Ringwald, even Charlie Sheen could at various times be seen clearing their throats and hymning in atrocious verses the degradation and horror they had witnessed growing up in rugged Malibu or the mean streets of Pacific Palisades.

Thankfully most of them got over their cultural pretensions and returned to what they did best - being retired. The lone hold-out was Sean Penn, easily the most talented actor of the group but also given to fatal delusions about his own creativity in areas unconnected with acting. In literary terms, his tastes ran to Selby, Bukowski and bullnecked, triumph-of-the-will-type punk ranters like Henry Rollins. Among moviemakers he was drawn to people like John Cassavetes, another guy with a hard-on for "emotional truth", an unshakeable faith in the actor as auteur, and all that sub-Method striving whose end results have an insight-to- excrement ratio of roughly one to 1,000. Penn showed every sign of wishing to become another sub-Beat Method, crazy-creative, heavy-drinking, hard-brawling, Marlon-Mailer wannabe, as boring as James Dean, and not nearly as pretty.

Perhaps it was inevitable that Penn would sooner or later yearn to direct movies himself, and when he did so it was hardly surprising to find him labouring in Cassavetes' shadow, and writing scripts of his own that were fatally derivative and emotionally dishonest. There is a grating sense of cultural superiority in Penn's interviews over the last six or seven years, with all his pontifications about how these are the movies he's really proud of, and how this is where his creative spirit truly takes wing and so on.

But in his directorial debut, The Indian Runner, there was nothing to match his own performances in, say, The Falcon and the Snowman or even Fast Times at Ridgemont High. Based on a Bruce Springsteen song, it was windy, baggy, shapeless and overbearingly self-regarding. The same applies to the Penn-penned Crossing Guard, which had an A-list cast and some fine performances, particularly from Jack Nicholson, but no governing directorial intelligence, no firm hand on the tiller.

The Pledge, the story of a retired cop tracking a serial killer, is easily the best film Penn has ever directed, which isn't saying much. It helps that someone else wrote it, but not nearly enough. Nicholson is again the star and again gives a detailed and moving performance, as do the name actors - Mirren, Redgrave, Sam Shepard, Mickey Rourke - who show up for five-minute cameos. Penn can extract great performances but he can't build a movie around them.

Fatally, he seems to have contempt for genre. This is a serial-killer thriller that resolutely fails to thrill us. Penn is forever making ungainly detours to insert tiresomely "honest" details and "found moments" that remain resolutely unintegrated into the movie's overall fabric. He seems to think he's too good to give this workmanlike story the clipped, unadorned Don Siegel/Richard Fleischer treatment it badly needs.

No, he wants to gussy it up with straight steals from Badlands and The Thin Red Line. Now the trouble with trying to out-Malick Terrence Malick is that the reclusive Texan has a coherent worldview entirely his own, a deep reservoir of literary and visual knowledge with which to enrich his work. Where Penn is a fan of Bukowski, Malick is a former Rhodes scholar who once interviewed Martin Heidegger - in German - while Penn was still soiling nappies in his parents' beach house. You can't be the same kind of film-maker merely by lifting Thin Red Line's gorgeous overhead shot of a girl on a swing.

The Pledge isn't an imitation of life, it's just an imitation of art - and of better art by better artists. It's high time Penn got himself back on the other side of the camera where he knows exactly what he's doing. Out there he's a real artist; behind the lens he's just an arse.

webTitle: Kohl cleared of arms bribe accusation

fields.headline: Kohl cleared of arms bribe accusation
fields.standfirst: Special report: German corruption scandal
fields.trailText: A German parliamentary committee has found no evidence that former chancellor Helmut Kohl was swayed by bribes or kickbacks when he approved a 1991 delivery of weaponry to Saudi Arabia.
fields.body:
A German parliamentary committee has found no evidence that former chancellor Helmut Kohl was swayed by bribes or kickbacks when he approved a 1991 delivery of weaponry to Saudi Arabia.

The committee's chairman, Volker Neumannn, said yesterday that he considered the inquiry into Mr Kohl's part in the scandal, which has ripped apart the conservative Christian Democratic party (CDU), to be closed.

The announcement was the first taste of victory for Mr Kohl since the inquiry into whether government decisions were bought during his 16 years in power was launched last year.

Allegations of massive kickbacks have long surrounded the delivery to Saudi Arabia of 36 armoured military vehicles by German arms maker Thyssen during the Gulf War. Lawmakers investigated the deal because Mr Kohl's government approved the export license.

But after the committee questioned Mr Kohl about the deal for six hours on Thursday - his third day before the panel since last summer - Mr Neumann said he considered this part of the investigation closed and that the committee would now move on to other questions.

"There is no indication that the chancellor was influenced in his decision," committee chairman Mr Neumannn told reporters.

Mr Kohl has always insisted that none of his government's decisions were influenced by money. Mr Neumann, a member of the governing Social Democrats, said he expects to present the committee's final report in December. It was not clear whether Mr Kohl would be summoned again.

During Thursday's occasionally stormy session, Mr Kohl told the panel he did not need to be bribed to make the decision in favour of the tank sale. He reiterated that he had no reason to believe that a DM1m mark (£340,000) handover to his party treasurer a few months after the deal by an arms lobbyist with links to Thyssen had any connection.

The scandal erupted in late 1999 when Mr Kohl admitted accepting anonymous campaign donations - an illegal move in Germany - as chancellor in the 1990s. It grew when he refused to reveal the names of the donors, saying he had promised to keep their names secret.

On Thursday, he made it clear he would not budge. "I will never name the donors," he told reporters. "I've said that from the start."

The party funding scandal has threatened to destroy the German conservative opposition. In February last year, CDU leader Wolfgang Schäuble quit after changing his story about his role in the affair several times. He said the party needed to make a fresh start with new leadership.

fields.headline: Bushwhacked Democrats look for answers
fields.standfirst: As Al Gore emerges from the wreckage to start a new life, Martin Kettle in Washington wonders if the Democrats can work out what went wrong.
fields.trailText: As Al Gore emerges from the wreckage to start a new life, Martin Kettle in Washington wonders if the Democrats can work out what went wrong.
fields.body:
With George Bush now installed, the defeated Democratic Party is beginning to contemplate post-Clinton realities rather than to agonise about what might have been.

There were two clear signs of that at the top this week. First, Al Gore emerged from media exile to announce that he is getting a new life next month as a lecturer at Columbia University and at two colleges in his home state of Tennessee.

Second, at a lunch for Democratic senators this week, their leader Tom Daschle faced his colleagues with the cold facts. They no longer control the White House, the Senate or the House of Representatives. "All we have is us," Daschle said. "Our only hope of survival is each other."

Things are moving on in American politics. Bush is finding his way in the White House - and is making an impressively confident start. Florida is beginning to become just a memory. Bill Clinton has left the stage in a cloud of criticism over his pardons and his unembarrassed exit from which the dust has not yet quite settled. The Democratic Party, meanwhile, is trying to understand what hit it.

The debate inside the party started in earnest this week. It's an important debate, and not just for the Democrats themselves. It will shape the next decade of American politics. It will be carefully watched from abroad too, and by no one more intently that by the British Labour Party, which has developed a not entirely healthy habit of seeing American politics as a dry run for future British developments. If only it took European domestic politics half so seriously.

The most striking thing about the US debate is simply that there is very little agreement. In recent weeks, two of Gore's pollsters have each produced analyses of what went wrong, but the question they ask is just about the only thing the two analyses have in common.

Mark Penn, who became pollster of choice to both Bill and Hillary Clinton, released a report this week which was a devastating centrist indictment of Gore and his campaign. Gore's "populist" campaign - with its emphasis on working families, its attack on tax cuts that favoured the rich, and its emphasis on an activist government - worked well with the party faithful, Penn concluded. But it fell far short with the swing voters who could have pushed him over the top.

In particular, Penn argued, Gore's decision not to talk about the Clinton administration's economic achievements meant that the Democrats forsook a golden opportunity to win over the large majority of Americans who felt that the US was on the right track.

The contrast between Penn's analysis and that of Gore's other pollster, Stanley Greenberg, a familiar crony of Tony Blair through his connection with Labour's Philip Gould, was striking. Greenberg has offered a robust defence of what Gore tried to do.

Gore was hamstrung by four factors, Greenberg argues. First, the 2000 election was a cultural battle, in which hostility to Clinton's scandals severely constrained Gore from celebrating the Clinton legacy. Second, Gore mishandled the campaign at key moments, leading to doubts about his trustworthiness. Third, Bush successfully blurred a lot of issues by his compassionate conservatism campaign. Fourth, there are a lot of white working class men in America who basically dislike government and who preferred Bush to Gore in the absence of a Ross Perot or a Jesse Ventura.

These are big differences - and this summary only scratches the surface of the strikingly contrasted picture that the two men's reports paint. And these are only two, albeit two very well-placed, voices among many others.

At a seminar in Washington this week, organised by the centrist Democratic Leadership Council (for whom Penn is the house pollster), there was a strong defence of Gore by trade union political strategists, who pointed out that Gore's most successful moments in the campaign all came when he went unashamedly to the left in the manner of which Penn and the DLC so disapproved.

Meanwhile, at the same seminar, there was also a devastating attack on Gore's handling of the campaign from the man whose intervention played such a crucial role in ensuring that Bush won the election, the Green candidate Ralph Nader.

The Democrats' willingness to debate these issues is undoubtedly a healthy sign. Whether the party can really agree about what went wrong, on the other hand, and what they can do about it if they can agree, remain very uncertain.

There is a great danger, one senses, that the participants will simply fasten on the conclusions which confirm their prejudices, which is certainly what seems to have happened in Labour's internal reflections on the US election.

Meanwhile, as Gore heads off to give a few recuperative lectures, the question of who will lead the party against Bush in 2004 will begin to be asked more soon than it should.

In that respect, the event to watch is not Gore's lectures, or Hillary Clinton's performance in the senate, let alone the debate among the strategists and pollsters. It is how Governor Gray Davis handles California's energy crisis. If the Democrats don't realise the political significance of Davis's performance in this testing emergency, I can assure you that the Republicans certainly do.

Greenberg has offered a robust defence of what Gore tried to do. Gore was hamstrung by four factors, Greenberg argues. First, the 2000 election was a cultural battle, in which hostility to Clinton's scandals severely constrained Gore from celebrating the Clinton legacy. Second, Gore mishandled the campaign at key moments, leading to doubts about his trustworthiness. Third, Bush successfully blurred a lot of issues by his compassionate conservatism campaign. Fourth, there are a lot of white working class men in America who basically dislike government and who preferred Bush to Gore in the absence of a Ross Perot or a Jesse Ventura. These are big differences - and this summary only scratches the surface of the strikingly contrasted picture that the two men's reports paint. And these are only two, albeit two very well-placed, voices among many others. At a seminar in Washington this week, organised by the centrist Democratic Leadership Council (for whom Penn is the house pollster), there was a strong defence of Gore by trade union political strategists, who pointed out that Gore's most successful moments in the campaign all came when he went unashamedly to the left in the manner of which Penn and the DLC so disapproved. Meanwhile, at the same seminar, there was also a devastating attack on Gore's handling of the campaign from the man whose intervention played such a crucial role in ensuring that Bush won the election, the Green candidate Ralph Nader. The Democrats' willingness to debate these issues is undoubtedly a healthy sign. Whether the party can really agree about what went wrong, on the other hand, and what they can do about it if they can agree, remain very uncertain. There is a great danger, one senses, that the participants will simply fasten on the conclusions which confirm their prejudices, which is certainly what seems to have happened in Labour's internal reflections on the US election. Meanwhile, as Gore heads off to give a few recuperative lectures, the question of who will lead the party against Bush in 2004 will begin to be asked more soon than it should. In that respect, the event to watch is not Gore's lectures, or Hillary Clinton's performance in the senate, let alone the debate among the strategists and pollsters. It is how Governor Gray Davis handles California's energy crisis. If the Democrats don't realise the political significance of Davis's performance in this testing emergency, I can assure you that the Republicans certainly do. webTitle: Ex-Clinton aide gets top nursing job

fields.headline: Ex-Clinton aide gets top nursing job
fields.trailText: Former White House adviser Beverly Malone has today been formally invited to become the new general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing (RCN), the most powerful job in UK nursing.
fields.body:
Former White House adviser Beverly Malone has today been formally invited to become the new general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing (RCN), the most powerful job in UK nursing.

It is understood that an emergency meeting of RCN council last night agreed to offer Ms Malone the £100,000-a-year post and she is expected to accept within days.

Ms Malone, a deputy assistant secretary at the US Department of Health, was chosen from a shortlist of four for the top job.

Her appointment follows a row within the college over who should succeed the present general secretary Christine Hancock, who is leaving to be president of the international council of nurses.

Ms Malone's arrival could see the departure of deputy RCN general secretary Tom Bolger, who was controversially not shortlisted for the position.

Another internal candidate who was not shortlisted, RCN head of policy Pippa Gough, is understood to have already resigned.

Ms Malone has a formidable reputation in international nursing circles and was named by Ebony magazine as one of the most influential African-Americans.

However, she could face a rocky introduction to the UK nursing scene - she is not currently registered within the UK as a nurse, and there is speculation that she may face problems obtaining a UK work permit.

Despite her extensive political experience, there is concern among RCN activists that her lack detailed knowledge of UK and NHS politics could be a handicap in the short term.

fields.headline: Keegan wins £150,000 damages
fields.trailText:
11.30 update: Kevin Keegan has won £150,000 from the News of the World following his successful libel action, writes Jessica Hodgson
10.30am: Keegan wins News of the World libel case
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has won £150,000 in damages from the News of the World following his successful libel action.

The newspaper must also pay his legal costs and print an apology on page 2 in its next edition.

His solicitor Alasdair Pepper said News Group and News of the World editor Rebekah Wade wholly accepted and recognised the wrong they had done Keegan.

The article, which appeared last November, shortly after his resignation as England manager, was a "serious attack on his professional and personal probity and integrity", said Mr Pepper.

The front page banner headline read, "Keegan's £40,000 bet shame: he was players' bookie at Euro 2000 Exclusive".

A statement read out in court said the newspaper accepted that betting and card games among players were "harmless".

The newspaper's solicitor, Robert Clinton, said he wholly accepted everything that had been said.

"The defendants recognise that there was nothing wrong or improper in the conduct of Mr Keegan or the harmless race nights and card games which the players enjoyed.

"The defendants through me wish to offer their sincere apologies to Mr Keegan for the wrong they have done him and for the distress that the publication of the articles which this action is concerned, caused him."

News of the World managing editor Stuart Kuttner said: "We are very glad to have settled the dispute with Kevin Keegan quickly and in a civilised fashion. The matter is now closed."

fields.headline: Sunderland wins Micra
fields.standfirst: Nissan agrees to build its new small car in Britain - but suppliers to pay the price
fields.trailText: Nissan agrees to build its new small car in Britain - but suppliers to pay the price.
fields.body:
Nissan yesterday wielded a double-edged sword by agreeing to build its new small car in Britain rather than France - but forcing the nation's hard-pressed component suppliers to bear the brunt of the foreign exchange risks.

The decision has sparked a political row, with anti-Europeans claiming that the prime minister had given Nissan's president, Carlos Ghosn, assurances about when Britain would join the euro. This was denied by the prime minister's spokesman and by Whitehall sources, who said no deal had been done.

Mr Ghosn - known as "le cost killer" - ended months of speculation by saying that Nissan would invest £235m to make the next-generation Micra at the group's Sunderland plant, rather than at a Renault factory near Paris.

He added that the Sunderland unit, which makes the current Micra, Almera and Primera models, would increase its capacity from 350,000 to 500,000 cars a year, creating 500 new jobs.

Nissan's long-awaited decision will secure the future of the Sunderland plant, which employs about 5,000 people. About 1,300 jobs would have been lost if Micra production had moved to France.

Mr Ghosn said that the Sunderland plant had committed itself to reducing costs by 30% to offset the impact of the strong pound. It aimed to neutralise the currency risk by purchasing components in the same currencies in which it sold vehicles.

This meant that the amount of Micra components billed in euros would rise from 35% to "more than 65%". He added that it would be up to the component suppliers to decide whether to manufacture in Britain or in the euro zone.

Paul Everett, head of policy and economics at the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, said Nissan, like other British-based car groups, was "pushing the pain down the supply chain" to overcome the disadvantages of being outside the euro zone.

"What's good news for Sunderland is not that good news elsewhere," he said, urging ministers to reassure component suppliers.

"They need a stable, competitive exchange rate and there's a growing view among them that that is not going to be delivered, certainly not until the government gives a clear timetable for entry to the euro."

Mr Ghosn said last September that the Micra would only be built in Britain if the euro was stable against the pound. Yesterday he said that a "stable and competitive" pound was essential, but refused to say whether British ministers had indicated that they would take the country into the euro.

He said that Britain's position on the euro had been "very important for us in coming to this decision".

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary - who was alongside Mr Ghosn when he made the Micra announcement - reiterated the government position. "In principle, we can see the benefits of joining a successful euro currency, but the conditions have to be right. It will be considered in the next parliament," he said.

But Conservative leader William Hague said: "If [Nissan] have received any assurances about joining the euro from the current administration, we would be interested to know what they are."

fields.headline: Basque car bomb kills cook
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A Spanish navy cook was killed today when a bomb exploded inside his car in the Basque city of San Sebastian, in an attack blamed on the armed separatist group Eta.
fields.body:
A Spanish navy cook was killed today when a bomb exploded inside his car in the Basque city of San Sebastian, in an attack blamed on the armed separatist group Eta.

Police identified the victim as Ramon Diaz Garcia, 51, who was married with two children. He was a civilian employed by the navy as a cook. Two other people, aged 16 and 40, were slightly injured in the blast and were being treated at a hospital in the city.

A police spokesman confirmed: "It was a loud blast in the area of a barracks and army residences."

Politicians immediately attributed the explosion to Eta, which claimed responsibility for 23 assassinations in 2000, marking an escalation in its terrorist activity to levels unprecedented since 1992.

The attack in the Guipuzcoa province, a stronghold of separatist feeling, is the organisation's first killing this year. Two other car bomb attempts failed in northern Spain earlier this week.

"This is a cold-blooded killing that will achieve nothing," Jesus Posada, Spain's public administration minister, said. "They are not going to change how the government or people in Spain and the Basque country think about them and about freedom."

The Arsenal boss is stalling on a new contract - citing the uncertainty in future of the transfer market - and Steve Perryman, former boss of J-League club Shimizu S-Pulse, claims: "I believe that Arsene Wenger will be their manager for the 2002 finals. I think he'll go."

Chelsea, fresh from signing a £24m deal with Emirates airlines, will make Manchester United an offer for Dwight Yorke, according to the Mirror. Claudio Ranieri will also spend some of his new-found wealth on Middlesbrough defender Gianluca Festa.

Tottenham plan to steal Glenn Hoddle from Southampton in the close season. The North London club will also take Dan Petrescu with him, the Mirror claims in a brilliant "exclusive" that was reported in yesterday's Fiver.

Liverpool will offer nursery club Crewe £1m for 17-year-old striker Dean Ashton. Arsenal have already offered Dario Gradi £800,000 and Manchester United are said to be interested. But Liverpool are favourites as they are prepared to cough up and loan Ashton back to the First Division club for the immediate future.

webTitle: Schwarzenegger takes heart over court ruling

fields.headline: Schwarzenegger takes heart over court ruling
fields.trailText: The Berlin High Court has ruled in favour of the former body builder after a doctor, who had never examined the actor, alleged that he was unlikely to live for long because of a heart condition
fields.body:
A Berlin appeals court has upheld Arnold Schwarzenegger's 1999 legal victory over a German cardiologist who publicly predicted that the actor would soon die from a heart condition.

A publicist for 53-year-old Schwarzenegger (pictured) told Reuters that the ruling, which ordered Dr Willi Heepe to pay him $10,300 (£7,058) in damages and issue a retraction, had been upheld by the Berlin high court on appeal.

Heepe, who never examined Schwarzenegger, had said during a radio interview that the Austrian-born former body builder wasn't likely to live much longer because of a heart condition. Schwarzenegger had elective surgery in 1997 to repair a defective heart valve.

"I am delighted that the Berlin high court agreed that it was wrong for Dr Heepe to make false statements about my health," said Schwarzenegger in a statement. "This reconfirms that the record must be set straight that I am in excellent health as I have been since my elective surgery in 1997."

Schwarzenegger donated his winnings to Special Olympics Germany. On his official website, he says that the Special Olympics and the Inner City Games are both causes "very close to my heart."

webTitle: Keegan wins £150,000 damages from News of the World

fields.headline: Keegan wins £150,000 damages from News of the World
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has accepted £150,000 high-court libel damages over an article in the News of the World which claimed the former England manager masterminded betting nights on the eve of matches.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has accepted £150,000 high-court libel damages over an article in the News of the World which claimed the former England manager masterminded betting nights on the eve of matches.

The newspaper had alleged - under a front-page headline that read "Keegan's £40,000 Bet Shame: He was players' bookie at Euro 2000" - that Keegan was the ringleader in a betting school that caused bitter rifts between the gamblers and non-gamblers in the team.

The article, published in November last year, also alleged that Keegan masterminded huge betting nights at the team hotel, where players would gamble thousands on card schools and the outcome of videoed horse races on the eve of England matches.

But today the News of the World accepted that there was no truth in any of the defamatory allegations and agreed they ought never to have been published.

After the settlement, an emotional Keegan said: "We've waited three months to put this right. I can get back on with my job now.

"The article made me look like somebody who did not care," he added. "I think that everybody who works with me knows that is not true. Today has been a great day for us. It should never have happened. They published it. They paid the price."

Later, the News of the World revealed it paid £150,000 in damages to Keegan plus legal fees, the cost of which has yet to be worked out.

News of the World managing editor Stuart Kuttner said: "We are very glad to have settled the dispute with Kevin Keegan quickly and in a civilised fashion. The matter is now closed."

When asked if he thought he might eventually return to football, Keegan was non-committal, replying: "Who knows?"

But he did take time to pay tribute to FA chief executive Adam Crozier, who tried unsuccessfully to persuade Keegan to carry on after the Germany defeat.

"I want to thank Adam Crozier," he said. "He is the only one who has stuck by me. I know some people in the FA felt he was wrong to do that but Mr Eriksson, the new manager, will feel I think a lot of comfort from me saying that he's got someone behind him there who will stick by him and stick by his principles."
