fields.headline: Albanian gunmen training for war
fields.standfirst:
Guerrillas fire on British troops trying to keep the peace in the bit of Serbia that Kosovo wants

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Guerrillas fire on British troops trying to keep the peace in the bit of Serbia that Kosovo wants.
fields.body:
British troops were shot at by Kosovo Albanians yesterday on the boundary with Serbia. The soldiers, part of the K-for peacekeeping force in Kosovo, were trying to prevent the flow of men and weapons to and from the province.

The patrol from the first battalion, the Princess of Wales Royal Regiment, challenged a group of 10 armed men crossing from Serbia into Kosovo. The gang responded by firing two shots and running off. Nobody was hurt.

Those who recruit and train the gunmen say they are preparing for a new offensive.

Tension on the boundary has increased since K-for stepped up its patrols in October after ethnic Albanian militiamen, some of them disgruntled former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army, began trying to take over three Albanian towns in southern Serbia.

On Wednesday the British commander in the area, Lieutenant-Colonel Stephen Kilpatrick, met leaders of the rebel bands to try to avoid just such an incident.

But while K-for tries to keep a lid on the situation, Belgrade fumes at the Albanian attempt on Serbian territory, and local people grow more apprehensive, the rebels are busy training more fighters. A ceasefire agreed in November is only just holding.

At a training camp in the area, the two men in charge - who gave their names as Commander Zola and Commander Rama - said they had trained up to 600 volunteers in 10 months.

The camp belongs to a group calling itself the Karadaku brigade.

The commanders disputed the US estimate of the current Albanian fighting force in this sector, saying it was four or five times greater.

Whatever the truth about the numbers of gunmen, the continued existence of the training camp shows that the Nato-led peacekeeping force has been unable to stop the rebel movement, though its action has put some constraints on the commanders.

The camp lies in the hills near the boundary with Kosovo and border with Macedonia. It is away from the eyes of Yugoslav troops and Serb police, to whom the area is off-limits, under the terms agreed with Nato.

Up to 60 recruits are in the camp at any time and are given a month of basic training.

"Then they go home and wait, so they are ready for when the fighting starts," Commander Rama said.

"We are preparing for war but are always ready to give a chance to diplomacy. War will happen when everything else fails."

The recruitment goes on while K-for tries to foster talks between local Albanian leaders and the Yugoslav government.

"Currently we are under a peace agreement," said Commander Rama.

"All the same, our warriors are getting trained and armed to be ready for an offensive to get the Serbs out of this area."

The rebel movement in this corner of Kosovo and Serbia emerged in February last year. It wants independence for three Albanian populated towns in southern Serbia, and names itself after them, the liberation army of Presevo Medvedja, and Bujanovac, (UCPMB).

Its existence has become a real embarrassment to K-for, because the gunmen have penetrated what is supposed to be a military exclusion zone in Serbia stretching three miles back from the boundary with Kosovo.

Spirits were high as soldiers sang songs to the tune of the US marines' chants.

fields.headline: 'I'd love to play a psycho killer'
fields.standfirst: She played a pregnant cop in Fargo and won an Oscar. Now she's back as a funny, fretful rock mum in Almost Famous.  Michael Ellison  takes pancakes with Frances McDormand
fields.trailText: She played a pregnant cop in Fargo and won an Oscar. Now she's back as a funny, fretful rock mum in Almost Famous. Michael Ellison takes pancakes with Frances McDormand
fields.body:
The reviews could hardly have been more harrowing: "I have never encountered anything as deadly," said one, and he was not talking about an innovative horror film. "Things could get a whole lot worse," ventured another, and she did not mean she was looking forward to the sequel. No, last year was the worst for American movies since the end of the silent era, according to a straw poll of critics in USA Today, the nation's largest-circulation newspaper.

Never mind that some seemed to recall similar judgments being delivered every year about this time and that the public didn't appear to notice the dearth of quality: a new record was set at the box office in 2000 - $7.46bn, an increase of 2% - but then a new record was set in each 12-month period throughout the past decade.

Two of the movies exempted from this derision, Almost Famous and Wonder Boys, have at least three things in common: they didn't make much money; they, and their stars, are being talked about for Oscars; and, finally, the woman in blue denims recommending the pancakes in a cafe above a supermarket on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

Frances McDormand knows all about the opening skirmishes of the movie prize-giving season but will just as readily discuss motherhood, playgrounds and schools, the way chain stores and shopping malls are stifling diversity, and what happens to the neighbourhood when you can't find a launderette. Then there's the mortgage that needs to be paid.

"Guess what?" she asks rhetorically, in the manner favoured by New Yorkers. "I am an ordinary person. And when I fart in a minute, you'll know I am." She and her husband Joel, one half of the film-making Coen brothers, threw a party the night before and she breaks off every so often to exchange small talk or greet a friend passing through the coffee shop. "See you, hon."

But not so many ordinary people have won an Oscar (for her part as the pregnant police chief in the Coens' Fargo) or have been nominated for a Golden Globe (for her part as the mother of the impossibly young rock writer in Cameron Crowe's Almost Famous - she was beaten by co-star Kate Hudson). "It's like all those awards things. It's the movie social season, it's the time when everybody celebrates that they're in the business. It's interesting for us because we don't live there."

She means that she and Coen inhabit neither the physical Hollywood, nor its machine. And no, she does not need awards to fuel her ego or her self-esteem. "I'm really proud of my work, of all the movies that I've made in the last year. It's nice when you make a movie and other people think the same thing and you're not deluding yourself. But it's also the case that I already knew it."

She also knows bullshit when she sees it, and says so - she greets the observation that she once shared an apartment with fellow Oscar-winner Holly Hunter with the inquiry: "What's so amazing about that?" "Confidence? No, I've just got that perspective. Been doing it for 20 years. I think awards are good for the movie. They can bring a new audience to the movie. I've always claimed that things like that don't get you work. Work gets you work. That's my blue-collar protestant work ethic."

Graduates of Yale are not usually remarkable for their blue-collar work ethic, protestant or otherwise. "Yale? I was at Yale on a scholarship. I guess it shouldn't be a sensitive subject after all this time, should it?"

"All this time" started 43 years ago, when a preacher and his wife had a baby and they called her Frances. The family lived in Illinois, Georgia, Kentucky and Tennessee before coming to a halt in Pennsylvania when she was eight. McDormand moved to New York City after finishing at Yale School of Drama, and her second job, in 1984, was a lead role in a low-budget thriller directed by a couple of first-time film-makers: the Coen brothers' Blood Simple.

Since then, she has worked in television and theatre, notably A Streetcar Named Desire on Broadway and, 10 years later, in Dublin. Two years ago, she co-starred with Billy Crudup in an off-Broadway production of Oedipus. On screen, she is most closely identified with the films made by her husband and his brother Ethan, even if she has appeared in only three of them, unless you include an uncredited bit part in Miller's Crossing; the other was Raising Arizona. Other roles include that of a Klansman's wife in Mississippi Burning - another Oscar nomination - a human rights activist in Ken Loach's contentious Northern Ireland drama Hidden Agenda, Tim Robbins's lover in the Robert Altman triumph Short Cuts, and a football-mad divorcee in John Sayles's Lone Star.

It is a hallmark of her work that you tend to come away from it full of admiration for an actress who is an essential part of the fabric without being the movie itself. Rarely do you feel that you have just seen a Frances McDormand movie: she says that, even in Fargo, hers was never intended as the central role.

"I don't think of myself as a movie star and I can pretty easily convince other people that I'm not a movie star. I love it, and this happens rarely, but I'm at the grocery store or I'm on the subway and someone says, 'What are you doing here?' and I say 'I'm going to work' or 'I'm buying my groceries, for God's sake. What do you mean what am I doing here?' It's partly the way I look but it's also the characters I play. It's all pretty familiar and it's all pretty acceptable. There's nothing mysterious about any of them or off-putting. I've never played a psycho killer, although I'd love to."

Movies, says McDormand, will never give her the same charge as the theatre, and she has been back at Yale recently talking to drama students, exchanging her experience for their energy and lack of cynicism. "It's a scary thing going into the workforce with a $50,000 debt and you've been trained as a classical theatre actor. There's always a depression in the theatre. There's only two givens with choosing acting as a profession: one is you will always be unemployed, always, and it doesn't matter how much money you make, you're still always going to be unemployed; and that you have no power. The only power you have is the word no." McDormand says that it is a word she uses often and never regrets. "I forget about 'em. No, no, no, no, no. I don't hold on to them. It can't be about regret or I wouldn't have chosen this job."

She wishes, though, that some people would use the power a little more often, not being a great admirer of big stars who chose to slum it for a spell on the stage, giving a grateful public their Hamlet, for instance. "It's bullshit. Even though I'm an actor, I've gone to productions where there has been someone whose work is known in film and you can't take your eyes off them. It unbalances the production. Whether they're good or not, it doesn't matter."

McDormand is not a creature of the gossip columns, a mainstay of much of the New York press, but Coen brothers films have a long shelf-life and, no matter how elusive her lustre, that Oscar must confer some sort of celebrity. Wrong again. "You know what? Here's what I have at my advantage: I've never been a personality. I've always been a character actor. I think it's also about people not knowing who I am."

She is, among other things, someone who appreciates a knowledgeable audience in the theatre. Dublin? "Great. They have a steady exposure to it and it's about education." New York? "Here it's about being able to say who you saw and what you did, not the experience. I sat behind these two women the other night in the theatre and, granted, it wasn't a great production but it was an interesting production. And they got up in the middle of the act to go to the bathroom, rustle, rustle, they were looking at their fingernails during the play, they were commenting on the age of one of the actresses on stage. I mean, what are you doing here? It was astounding."

This is not the sort of behaviour one would expect from either of the characters she plays in Wonder Boys (an academic involved in an extra-marital affair) or Almost Famous (a mother who is also an academic).

Cameron Crowe's film is based on his time as a juvenile rock writer who goes on the road for Rolling Stone in the early 1970s. The McDormand role is the vehicle for some of its funniest and most touching moments. Naturally, she is concerned for the boy, but even back then, only the absurdly over-protective could have seen Satan in Simon and Garfunkel.

"It's really fascinating; it's not about rock'n'roll, it's about innocence, and it's a lot about journalism. There's nothing controversial about the movie, there's no real hard edges, there's no real deep pits. But, hey, not every movie needs that. It's a good story well told.

"It's not nostalgic, because it's more immediate than that. You know when the kid flips through those albums? I can't tell you how many, and it was great, it's like guys my age were on the verge of tears when Cream comes up and it's 'My God! duh, duh...' It tells so much. Within the realms of female archetypes - there's the mom, there's the daughter, there's the sister, there's the girlfriend - within that, it was a great role."

But McDormand has her mind set on something beyond the secondary parts in which she has had so much success. "I haven't had that challenge in movies hardly ever, only in the theatre, where the thrust of the story is about the female character. I'd like to try that. But then I have to be available for that, too. It's much easier to play supporting roles because that's what I do in my life: I support my son." Until then, there is a month's work on a movie directed by Michael Caton-Jones and, later in the year, a stage production of Phaedra with the Soho avant-garde theatre company the Wooster Group. Right now, though, she must get back to six-year-old Pedro. And, no, McDormand never did follow through on her threat to deploy the effect that would prove just how ordinary she really is.

 Almost Famous is released on February 9.

webTitle: In brief: Sally Field only third woman to receive top award

fields.headline: Sally Field only third woman to receive top award
fields.standfirst: Plus: Elliott Gould latest star to join cast of Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven; Edward Burns and Christy Turlington to marry
fields.trailText: Plus: Elliott Gould latest star to join cast of Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven; Edward Burns and Christy Turlington to marry
fields.body:
 Actress Sally Field (pictured) is to become only the third woman in the history of the American Society of Cinematographers to receive its prestigious Board of Governors Award. According to the Hollywood Reporter, Field will follow in the footsteps of Jodie Foster and Fay Kanin. The award, the only prize which the ASC presents to people who are not cinematographers, is intended to recognise individuals who make "significant and enduring contributions to advancing the art of filmmaking." The award will be presented during the 15th annual ASC Outstanding Achievement Awards ceremony on February 18.

 Elliott Gould is the latest actor to be added to the starry cast of Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven, according to Michael Fleming in Variety. George Clooney, Brad Pitt, Julia Roberts and Matt Damon have already signed up for the much-hyped remake of the ratpack classic. Gould will play Ruben Tischkoff, the man who finances Danny Ocean's casino heist.

 Actor-director Edward Burns and supermodel Christy Turlington have announced their engagement, according to ananova. The couple, both 32, had just ended relationships with other people when they met. Burns and actress Heather Graham broke up last spring, just before Turlington's six-year relationship with actor Jason Patric ended. Burns, who has been acclaimed for She's the One and The Brothers McMullen, has a new movie, 15 Minutes, coming out in May.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapstake | Quick bites | On the menu
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15
Fairuz
3 Blandford Street, London W1
Tel: 020-7486 8108

Now Lebanese restaurants are hitting the A lists, let us celebrate an elegant early entrant, and still one of the best for novices to cut their teeth on meze and kebabs. Others may do more meze (although 39 seems plenty), but few do the great standards of hummus, falafel, tabouleh (Lebanese salad), baba ganoush (see On the menu, below) and foul moukala (broad beans) better.

Kebabs and other grills use decent meat and are on the generous side. Wash it all down with Chateau Kefraya (less expensive and mind-numbing than the more famous Chateau Musar). Prices veer towards the upper end of the Guzzler limit, but potent warmth and hospitality will distract you from that.

Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
Patisserie Valerie at Sagne
105 Marylebone High Street, London W1
Tel: 020-7935 6240

Fab time capsule - a reminder of when eating was a more leisurely, mannerly, civilised pastime than the relentless, food-as-fashion-accessory, hot-design-driven standard we have become used to. Grand for coffee. Splendid for tea. Heaven for hot chocolate. With a croissant to dunk in it.

Big on pastries - marvellous millefeuille, exquisite eclairs and corset-busting cakes. Also a dab hand in the light lunch department, eg excellent croque monsieur and properly scrambled egg with proper smoked salmon. Decor crusty and fusty. Service sharp and sassy. All very Trevor Howard and Celia Johnson.

Just out: Kellogg's Winders

Form: Flat coil of "real fruit" that looks like semi-transparent, dull, pinky-purple Sellotape sandwiched between a strip of silicone paper.

Flavour: Vaguely semi-transparent, dull, pinky-purple undefinable fruit.

Verdict: Under-12s: "very yummy", "quite tasty". Over-12s: vague; I have eaten a full roll and still find it hard to make up my mind. The flavour doesn't hang around long enough to be analysed. The blurb claims that each roll contains "over 50% real fruit", which makes you wonder what is "real" about extruded mashed fruit, and what the rest consists of. Still, it is not aimed at thee and me, and unrolling the coil is fun. I suspect that the packaging costs more than the product inside.

Price: £1.29 per box of six rolls.

Food on the net

NY Seafood Council

This site boasts a brief description of almost everything with gills that swims in the region of New York City, illustrated with pretty little pictures of your poisson of choice. In no time at all you will know your hake from your herring and have a detailed knowledge of precisely how the blue crab swims.

There is information on seasonal availability and appropriate substitutes, and an idiot's guide to preparation methods including pan frying, poaching and steaming. The site, run by the New York Seafood Council, also lists nutritional values and even possible pollution content, as well as dozens of recipes such as monkfish belle meuniere and scallops with green onion butter.

On the menu: Baba ganoush

Come again? Or baba ghanoush, or baba ganush, or baba ganouj, or ...

I know rum baba and Babar the Elephant, but what's with this baba gh ... however you spell it? It's a Lebanese dish that has become something of an international celebrity on the modish restaurant circuit.

Why? Because it is cheap, easy to make, tastes lush and sounds exotic.

Is it? Not unless you find aubergines, garlic, tahini, lemon, cumin and parsley all mashed up together exotic.

Hardly, these days. And how do I eat it? Chilled, with a little pitta or flannel bread.

Flannel bread? That's enough for this week.

The taste test: vegetable curry

"What is vegetable curry?" you may well ask. The category is a bit on the broad side, but some supermarkets have embraced a semblance of recognising Indian regional cooking while others have yet to move beyond the chicken tikka masala/all-purpose veg curry level of sophistication.

Tesco Gobi Aloo Sag
£1.99/350g
Pukka tucker; respectable chilli; distinctive spicing; excellent veg; not too liquid.
Rating: * * * * *

Safeway Vegetable Curry
£1.99/300g
A touch short on seasoning and veg, but long on flavour, spice and heat.
Rating: ****

Waitrose Vegetable Biryani
£2.35/400g
Distinctly warm; posh spice; the locals might even recognise it in Hyderabad.
Rating: * * * *

Budgens Vegetable Curry
£1.69/200g
Medium everything.
Rating: * * *

Sainsbury's Veg. Curry
£1.99/227g
Indian-effect; sloppy and gloppy.
Rating: * *

Morrisons Veg. Biryani/Masala
£1.79/400g
Untouchable rather than unspeakable.
Rating: *

fields.headline: Oversubscribed
fields.standfirst: Women's suits
fields.trailText: Women's suits
fields.body:
The sequined cardigan is well and truly dead, left to decay in the same pit as the pashmina. No more of those feminine fripperies, thank you very much; we'll take sleek, simple, intelligent and classy instead.

Yes, it's the return of the suit. In this week's couture shows, Gaultier, Lagerfeld and that master of the look Yves Saint Laurent all updated the woman's suit. These pared-down, elegant versions disrobed the phrase "woman's suit" from its shoulder-padded, Dynasty associations. Not that such associations are necessarily a bad thing - after all, as everyone knows, 80s fashion is the way of the future. But perhaps power suits would take style slavishness a step too far.

Instead, aim more for the figure-flattering suits of the 60s. Think Catherine Deneuve rather than Melanie Griffith: suits that follow the body's proportions instead of dwarfing them with incongruous padding. Smart and elegant, without making you feel too Country Casuals.

And fear not: you need not empty your bank account on a YSL number. Wardrobe, the posh shop for working women, is having its annual sale this weekend. So never mind catching up on Dawson's Creek this Saturday lunchtime - get down to Conduit Street and pick up a truly lovely suit for as little as £50. A smart suit for just a few of your pennies? Your mother would be so proud.

 Wardrobe is at 42 Conduit St, London W1, 020-7494 1131. Sale: Saturday January 27, 10am-6pm; Sunday, 11am-5pm.

fields.headline: Overexposed
fields.standfirst: Pineapples
fields.trailText: Pineapples
fields.body:
Pineapples. Yes, pineapples. Silly name, silly appearance, but perfectly tasty. And that, to be honest, is where our thoughts end on the subject of pineapples. But, oh, how foolish we have been because pineapples are set to be THE pattern come spring.

First there was Scott Henshall who slipped one in on a studded T-shirt in his spring/summer collection. Fine: one was bearable and easy to overlook.

But then the normally fantastic Stella McCartney took it to a whole new level in Chloe's last collection. Banana appliqués appeared on T-shirts at strategic points; ditto pineapples on swimsuits. Far from being delightfully cheeky, the result is the high-fashion equivalent of donning a pair of plastic breasts, Gazza-style. Not offensive, just puzzling and sad. The pineapple must have struck a chord with Stella, for she repeated it on shirts as well.

Now Yves Saint Laurent has joined the fruity farrago. Considering he is now relegated to designing just couture, and each season could well be his last, you'd think he wouldn't mess about. But no, he had to go and ruin one of the most beautiful dresses of his collection this season (white, A-line skirt cut on the bias) by chucking on it, yes, images of pineapples.

What on earth is going on here? Has collective pineapple-madness taken over the fashion world? Is this part of some new diet that fashion folk are on but we are too behind to know about yet? ("Design a pineapple - it will drain your body of cellulite!") Is it an inexplicable homage to Carmen Miranda?

Who knows and, frankly, who cares? It's ugly, it's silly and, worst of all, in a few months, people will be saying: "Pineapples are soooo last season." The stomach turns.

webTitle: Star cast set for story of Warsaw ghetto

fields.headline: Star cast set for story of Warsaw ghetto
fields.trailText: James Woods, Donald Sutherland and Sadie Frost are among the stars who will appear in a miniseries about the Warsaw ghetto uprising during world war two
fields.body:
A starry cast is being brought together by NBC and Warner Bros to make Uprising, a miniseries about life in the Warsaw ghetto during world war two. According to Michael Fleming in Variety, Jon Avnet (Fried Green Tomatoes) will direct a cast featuring James Woods (pictured), Leelee Sobieski, Stephen Rea, David Schwimmer, Sadie Frost and Donald Sutherland.

The project, which starts shooting in Slovakia in late March, was originally envisaged as a feature film, but it was decided that would not enable the story to be told properly.

The Warsaw uprising began on the eve of Passover, April 19, 1943, when German troops commanded by General Stroop tried to level the ghetto, but its inhabitants fought back during the night. The Jews, armed only with pistols and a few automatic weapons held out against heavy German attack for 27 days. Unable to capture the fighters, the Germans burned the ghetto, building by building.

Sobieski will play a Jew with Aryan looks who is sent out of the ghetto to smuggle arms, Sutherland plays a Jew who is pressured to turn others in to the Germans and Woods will portray Stroop.

 More on the Warsaw ghetto uprising.

fields.headline: Ericsson flees mobile phone business
fields.trailText: 11am: Telecoms company Ericsson is fleeing the mobile phone business after reporting disastrous full year results, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms company Ericsson is fleeing the mobile phone business after reporting disastrous full-year results.

The world's third largest handset maker will outsource manufacturing of its wireless equipment after its mobiles unit lost a staggering £1.15bn for the whole of 2000.

"The results in our mobile phones business, while in line with expectations, remain unsatisfactory. We have decided to completely outsource supply and production of mobile phones," said Ericsson chief executive Kurt Hellstrom.

Despite announcing profits of £2.03bn, which beat analysts' expectations, the City remained unconvinced by Ericsson's drastic reforms, and some expect it to exit the mobile phone business altogether.

"They are moving in the right direction, but I would have liked them to have done something more radical in one step. They now have quite a complex web of agreements to manage," said Susan Anthony, telecoms equipment analyst at Credit Lyonnais.

Ericsson has struck outsourcing deals with several firms, leading some analysts to describe today's announcement as a "half-way house" solution.

The core strength of the company is its fixed-line infrastructure business, and today's move should at least distance Ericsson from its troublesome subsidiary.

Ericsson blamed the shortfall in its mobile business on equipment shortages and tough competition.

Close rivals Nokia and Motorola have also released disappointing results recently, although some analysts have defended Nokia after it reported a 64% growth in year-on-year sales.

fields.headline: Traffic
fields.standfirst: Traffic is an ambitious exploration of America's drug trade, says Peter Bradshaw, but it's been cut with a bit too much schmaltz
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The evasions and confusions can't cancel-out the fact that this is an entertaining piece of storytelling, handled with real chutzpah by Soderbergh.
fields.body:
From President Nixon's appointment of Elvis Presley as his special agent against narcotics, to Nancy Reagan's doe-eyed pronouncements on the subject and the grisly era of Noriega and Iran-Contra - not notably repudiated by ex-president Clinton - the United States government has solemnly invoked its "war on drugs". But it is a dirty war, and a war in which, according to Christopher Hitchens, they have repeatedly found themselves on the wrong side.

Steven Soderbergh's watchable, ambitious, multi-storyline, multi-ethnic movie about the drug trade is adapted from the 1989 Channel 4 drama series Traffik, about the trade route from Pakistan to Germany and England. Soderbergh and his producers, Edward Zwick, Marshall Herskovitz and Laura Bickford have imported this racy stuff from Europe but cut it with quite a bit of pro- American schmaltz.

It's now the Mexican Connection: two infinitely wealthy, infinitely violent Tijuana cartels are at war over the exclusive prerogative of exporting under-the-counter analgesics to Tio Sam in the form of solid cocaine-dolls called Spastic Jacks. Meanwhile their Californian connection is taken in by the DEA and the new White House-appointed drugs tsar, frowningly played by Michael Douglas, finds that his own daughter is an end user. But despite an apparent equivalence of moral squalor between Mexico and the United States, Traffic makes it subtly clear that the official corruption is all happening south of the Rio Grande; the worst that the Americans are guilty of is a surfeit of innocence.

Naivety aside, Traffic demonstrates a big, bold HBO-isation of the big screen. For some time, the subtlety and sophistication of shows like The Sopranos and Larry Sanders, with their ability to develop characters and plots over hours and hours of broadcast time, has been thought to represent a serious challenge to the movies. Traffic looks like a response to this - and a very dynamic and energetic response. It differs from "portfolio" movies like Short Cuts or Pulp Fiction, in looking like a giant, strenuous compression of the sort of far-reaching, intermingling storylines more familiar from the small screen, and in which the denouement feels a lot like a "series finale".

The movie's undoubted star is Benicio Del Toro as Javier Rodriguez, a harassed underpaid street cop in Tijuana, already mired in the venal business of back- handers over parking violations. But he and his partner Manolo (Jacob Vargas) are doing an eye-catchingly honest job in tackling drug felons and attract the attention of the sinister General Salazar, played by Tomas Milian, who co-opts them into his own ruthless theatre of operations in the drug war. This is a riveting performance from Del Toro: understated, flintily tough, reticent and, finally, infinitely weary and battle scarred.

Meanwhile, over the border, their equivalents are the DEA foot soldiers played by Luis Guzman and Don Cheadle who dream of the ultimate prize: "busting white people". And when their team busts a top-ranking white person, his haughty trophy wife Helena (Catherine Zeta-Jones) is astonished by what her husband has actually been doing to keep her in the style to which she has become extensively accustomed. This is a rather stately, proprietorial performance from Ms Zeta-Jones, who, according to the publicity material, used her "own accent" for the film: a cultured English-American.

But at the apex of Wasp self-deception is Michael Douglas as Judge Robert Wakefield, the anti-drugs supremo unable to face up to the fact that his pampered, preppie daughter Caroline, played by Erika Christensen, is a serious addict. The scene in which she is getting high with her unspeakably spoilt rich friends is a black comic gem: one of them collapses with a life-threatening fit and they all shrug and giggle and finally panic, rowing over whose father to call. "Your dad's a doctor !" "He's a doctor in sequencing the pig genome!"

Caroline eventually disappears into the street-cauldron and Michael Douglas goes on a George C Scott Hardcore-type quest to find her among the exotic drug dens. Soderbergh appears to be inviting us to consider his eventual reunion with her, and support for her therapy programme, as the morally redemptive centre of this big complex film.

It's a bit suspect. Traffic aspires to show a total vision of drugs, and yet the only actual users shown are The Kids: whereas we all know the users are The Adults, too: blue-collar and white-collar, lawyers, truck-drivers, cops and, erm, movie folk. It would be a bit cheeky for Hollywood to sell us a straightforward anti-drugs line, and Traffic ostentatiously doesn't do that, its teeming 147 minutes favouring neither the crackdown hawks nor the decriminalisation doves. The movie appears to content itself with anatomising the huge geopolitical hypocrisy of it all.

But to work as an exposure of hypocrisy, its geopolitical assumptions have to be a lot less loaded than this. Persistently, Mexico is shown as corrupt in a way the US evidently isn't: the Mexican cops and army are on the take; the DEA and American political establishment are not. Everything down Mexico way is photographed in a burning, flickering, hellish glow, whereas high-tone Georgetown in Washington DC is filmed neutrally, while Michael Douglas gets his straight-A offspring tearfully back on the straight and narrow.

fields.bodyText: From President Nixon's appointment of Elvis Presley as his special agent against narcotics, to Nancy Reagan's doe-eyed pronouncements on the subject and the grisly era of Noriega and Iran-Contra - not notably repudiated by ex-president Clinton - the United States government has solemnly invoked its "war on drugs". But it is a dirty war, and a war in which, according to Christopher Hitchens, they have repeatedly found themselves on the wrong side. Steven Soderbergh's watchable, ambitious, multi-storyline, multi-ethnic movie about the drug trade is adapted from the 1989 Channel 4 drama series Traffik, about the trade route from Pakistan to Germany and England. Soderbergh and his producers, Edward Zwick, Marshall Herskovitz and Laura Bickford have imported this racy stuff from Europe but cut it with quite a bit of pro- American schmaltz. It's now the Mexican Connection: two infinitely wealthy, infinitely violent Tijuana cartels are at war over the exclusive prerogative of exporting under-the-counter analgesics to Tio Sam in the form of solid cocaine-dolls called Spastic Jacks. Meanwhile their Californian connection is taken in by the DEA and the new White House-appointed drugs tsar, frowningly played by Michael Douglas, finds that his own daughter is an end user. But despite an apparent equivalence of moral squalor between Mexico and the United States, Traffic makes it subtly clear that the official corruption is all happening south of the Rio Grande; the worst that the Americans are guilty of is a surfeit of innocence. Naivety aside, Traffic demonstrates a big, bold HBO-isation of the big screen. For some time, the subtlety and sophistication of shows like The Sopranos and Larry Sanders, with their ability to develop characters and plots over hours and hours of broadcast time, has been thought to represent a serious challenge to the movies. Traffic looks like a response to this - and a very dynamic and energetic response. It differs from "portfolio" movies like Short Cuts or Pulp Fiction, in looking like a giant, strenuous compression of the sort of far-reaching, intermingling storylines more familiar from the small screen, and in which the denouement feels a lot like a "series finale". The movie's undoubted star is Benicio Del Toro as Javier Rodriguez, a harassed underpaid street cop in Tijuana, already mired in the venal business of back- handers over parking violations. But he and his partner Manolo (Jacob Vargas) are doing an eye-catchingly honest job in tackling drug felons and attract the attention of the sinister General Salazar, played by Tomas Milian, who co-opts them into his own ruthless theatre of operations in the drug war. This is a riveting performance from Del Toro: understated, flintily tough, reticent and, finally, infinitely weary and battle scarred. Meanwhile, over the border, their equivalents are the DEA foot soldiers played by Luis Guzman and Don Cheadle who dream of the ultimate prize: "busting white people". And when their team busts a top-ranking white person, his haughty trophy wife Helena (Catherine Zeta-Jones) is astonished by what her husband has actually been doing to keep her in the style to which she has become extensively accustomed. This is a rather stately, proprietorial performance from Ms Zeta-Jones, who, according to the publicity material, used her "own accent" for the film: a cultured English-American. fields.headline: Outflanking the rich and powerful
fields.standfirst: They are shrieking about unfair competition in Davos. Poor things
fields.trailText: No fair! That's what they are screaming from the mountaintop in Davos this week. Every year since 1971, executives of the richest multinational corporations have met with the most powerful heads of state in an alpine village in Switzerland. Davos is where Bill Clinton and Bill Gates put their differences aside, where flaky internet gurus and name-brand Harvard economists get together to agree that the world would be an infinitely better place with freer markets.
fields.body:
No fair! That's what they are screaming from the mountaintop in Davos this week. Every year since 1971, executives of the richest multinational corporations have met with the most powerful heads of state in an alpine village in Switzerland. Davos is where Bill Clinton and Bill Gates put their differences aside, where flaky internet gurus and name-brand Harvard economists get together to agree that the world would be an infinitely better place with freer markets.

But what they really do at Davos, which opened yesterday, is pray. They pray not to a god, but to an idea: competitiveness. The bible of Davos is the global competitiveness report, measuring the success of nations against a "growth competitiveness index". There seems to be no problem that more competition cannot fix.

So what has these high priests of competition crying foul? A tax hike? A wave of government regulation? Hardly. Their enemy is a not a foe but a friend: competition. This year, for the first time, the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos has some serious competition. It's called the World Social Forum (WSF) - colloquially, "the Anti-Davos". It will take place on precisely the same days at the Davos summit (which continues until Tuesday), in Porto Alegre, Brazil. And the force that broke up Davos's intellectual monopoly was yet another traitorous pal: supply and demand.

At protests around the world, loud questions are being asking about the effects of increased competition, sometimes called "turbo capitalism": what has it done to workers? To the environment? To democracy? More to the point: if the widening economic disparity of the past two decades has been the result of "unprecedented prosperity", what can we look forward to in a downturn?

To borrow the language of Davos, there is a demand for something else. Bringing together more than 1,000 organisations, the WSF is a critical stage in moving from protests against the free market's assaults on the public sphere to an articulation of concrete alternatives. The forum slogan - as optimistic as anything heard at Davos during the dot.com craze - is: "Another world is possible."

The significance of this competitive threat hasn't been lost on the organisers of the WEF. Last year, it summoned a handful of its critics to the mountain, holding special sessions on the "backlash against globalisation". And the conference was "carbon neutral": the planetary debt incurred by ferrying oil executives by helicopter was wiped clean, apparently, by planting some trees in Mexico. Or so the organisers declared, to much fanfare.

This year, economic euphoria isn't even on the agenda at Davos. The sombre theme is "Sustainable growth and bridging the divides". The captains of industry are, they say, ready to listen. Only, wait a minute: where is everybody? Gone south. Davos director Claude Smadja complained to reporters that the opposition has been poaching his "civil society" delegates. And Klaus Schwab, founder the WEF, insists that "The best place for dialogue is inside the congress centre." Not in the messy, unwieldy, outside world.

And that is the heart of the dispute between these battling global gatherings. The world economic summit, by its own admission, assembles the world's "leadership team" - superheroes of the global stage who "are fully engaged in the process of defining and advancing the global agenda". Unconcealed elitism is the governing structure of Davos: attendance is by invitation only and even journalists are hand-selected. This exclusivity is protected at all costs - even when the cost is inviting a few pesky critics to be part of the "leadership team".

The WSF, on the other hand, won't be gathering a competing league of experts to draft an equally dogmatic set of global prescriptions. Yes, Nobel laureates such as East Timor's Jose Ramos Horta will be in attendance, as will civil society leaders such as Canada's Maude Barlow and activists such as Jose Bove, France's McDonald's-battling cheese farmer.

But the real goal of Porto Alegre is to transform globalisation from a site of experts-only oligarchy into an arena of genuine democracy. The forum's founding premise is that decision-making that affects us all should be open to everyone who wants to participate. That's why the gathering is organised on the principle of participatory democracy: whoever wants to get involved can do so. Originally, estimates were that 2,500 people would attend. Now that number is up to 10,000, with some predicting twice that. At last count there were over 400 self- organised workshops scheduled and a giant campsite has been set up to catch the hotel overflow.

Compared to Davos, the WSF promises to be sprawling, chaotic, even frustrating. I'm going anyway because, well, I'm invited. So is everyone else. And when it comes to global democracy, that gives Porto Alegre a distinct competitive advantage.

 No Logo by Naomi Klein is published by Flamingo.

fields.headline: Former exec swoops on BBC domain names
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC has been caught napping by a former employee who has registered six crucial BBC domain names, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC has been caught napping by a former employee who contacted MediaGuardian.co.uk to reveal he had registered six crucial BBC domain names.

David Docherty, managing director of broadband content at Telewest and a Media Guardian columnist, got in touch with MediaGuardian.co.uk after we broke the news that Auntie had already registered 3,000 domain names and was encouraging staff to come up with even more suggestions.

In a most alarming oversight on the BBC's part, Mr Docherty said he had yet to be contacted by the corporation asking for the domain names - even though he registered them more than six months ago.

He said he registered them last year after a night out with some BBC interactive people who thought it would make an amusing wind-up.

"The question is - why haven't they done a name search to discover who owns BBCthree?" asked Mr Docherty."

BBC 3 will be the new name for BBC Choice when it relaunches at the end of the this or early next year.

Mr Docherty added he would happily relinquish the names and was "just tweaking their tail for not doing it before".

Mr Docherty also owns BBCDrama.com, BBCDrama.co.uk, BBCDrama.net, BBCThree.com, BBCThree.co.uk and BBCThree.net. He said he would have registered BBCFour.com but decided it was already costing him too much.

His year-long ownership of the domains expires this coming June.

BBCFour.com has since been registered by the BBC, but BBC4.com is registered to a company called Vanilla Ltd in the United Arab Emirates.

The BBC hasn't even been registered BBC3.com, which is also registered to Vanilla Ltd. Other key domains not yet owned by the BBC include BBC3.co.uk and BBC4.co.uk.

But still up for grabs and not registered by anyone is BBC Five.com and BBC Six.com - channels the BBC may feasibly launch one day.

Although the corporation has no plans for such channels, more stations are in the pipeline such as a sports service that easily could be branded BBC5.

Mr Docherty left his BBC post as deputy director of television and new services at the end of June last year, after more than a decade at the corporation.

He is now waiting for his former employer to get in touch and claim the domain names.

fields.headline: Prince invited to PCC's birthday party
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Prince William will smoothe relations with the press by attending a Press Complaints Commission birthday party. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Prince William will attempt to smoothe relations with the press ahead of his first term at university by attending a Press Complaints Commission birthday party.

The prince's first official engagement will be at the PCC's 10th anniversary party next month, where he will mingle with Fleet Street editors who will track his every move when he begins his studies at St Andrews in October.

"We are honoured that Prince William has decided to come. The idea came from a discussion between the Prince and his father. It was entirely an initiative from their end," said Guy Black, director of the PCC.

Relations between Buckingham Palace and the PCC have improved since the watchdog stepped in to protect the privacy of Prince William and Prince Harry by banning interviews and photos of the young royals while they were at school.

"The relationship between the press, the princes and the PCC has been most satisfactory. It is a good example of how self-regulation and co-operation can work. Our guidelines for the princes have worked extremely well over the past few years," added Mr Black.

Prince William's attendance at the event, taking place at Somerset House, is seen as a sign of appreciation from the royal family for the PCC's efforts in protecting the princes' privacy since Lord Wakeham became chairman in 1995.

However, this bridge-building process will be tested to the limit as soon as Prince William starts university, with several newspapers reported to have bought flats for reporters in St Andrews.

fields.headline: Keegan wins News of the World libel case
fields.trailText: 10.30am: News of the World has been ordered to pay Kevin Keegan substantial libel damages, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former England coach Kevin Keegan today accepted "very substantial" high court libel damages over an article in the News of the World that alleged he masterminded betting nights on the eve of matches.

Outside court Keegan said he was delighted with the outcome, adding: "I just want to get this out of the way and get on with my life."

Keegan and his wife, Jean, were at the high court in London to hear lawyers for News Group Newspapers offer "sincere apologies" over the article in the News of the World in November last year.

His solicitor, Alasdair Pepper, told Mr Justice Gray that the newspaper published a detailed account of what were said to be "scandalous" allegations against Keegan.

The paper alleged he was the ringleader in a betting school that caused bitter rifts between the gamblers and non-gamblers in the team.

It also said that Keegan masterminded huge betting nights at the team hotel where stars would gamble thousands on the outcome of videoed horse races.

And it said he allowed gambling to go on long into the night on the eve of matches.

Mr Pepper said the newspaper accepted there was no truth in any of the defamatory allegations and they ought never to have been published.

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: Don't do it, Guy...

fields.headline: Don't do it, Guy...
fields.standfirst: Can Madonna's new husband be prevented from putting her in his next offering?
fields.trailText: Can Madonna's new husband be prevented from putting her in his next offering?
fields.body:
In a happy accident of scheduling, US audiences this week were blessed to receive not only the third directorial effort from the first Mr Ciccone, but also Snatch, the second film from the very latest Mr Ciccone.

Having seen Snatch in preview late last year, my timing was scrambled by the time of the official release, and it's only now that I've noticed just how cunningly those nuptials were timed to maximise the movie's US box office. Apparently I retain one shred of naivety after all.

Still, it reached number four, not bad in a chart still boasting several long-haul Christmas heavyweights. But it raises one serious, ugly question: will Ritchie really find a place for his new missus in his next movie? Will he overcome the obstacles that thwarted Sean Penn and even Warren Beatty when it came to making the charisma-lite Material Girl into a film star? Will he help her surpass both Shanghai Surprise and Body of Evidence?

But should we care? If the woman had any brains she'd never have co-sponsored Evita or The Next Best Thing. She appears to have an anti-talent for understanding cinema - the impulses that work so well for her in the pop/MTV marketplace turn rapidly to liquid shit in her hands once the public catches on to the joke.

fields.headline: 'Technical' rebuff for 30% of asylum seekers
fields.trailText: Home Office figures show applications at a record high
fields.body:
Nearly one in three asylum applications last year were rejected on "technical" grounds without their cases being looked at at all, according to the annual asylum figures published yesterday by the Home Office.

The statistics show that while the number of asylum applications reached a record 76,040, the highest in Europe, more than 26,630 were turned down on "non-compliance" grounds. In 1999 only 1,085 or 5% of all applications were refused on these technical grounds.

The Refugee Council last night said that the phenomenal rise in these refusals showed there was a flaw in the new "faster but fairer" asylum system that ministers claim they have put in place since last April. Between September and November the number of asylum seekers refused refugee status on "non-compliance" grounds was touching 40% of all claims.

Most of those refused entry on these grounds have failed to comply with the new requirement to find legal advice and complete in English a complex 19-page form within 10 working days. If they fail to do this, their asylum claim is rejected.

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said last night that the sharp rise in these rejections meant the Home Office had lost sight of the purpose of the asylum process - to provide sanctuary to those fleeing persecution. "If 40% of all applicants are rejected without their cases being looked at, then the system itself is at fault. This is a gross injustice on asylum seekers."

But the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, yesterday defended the practice, saying it was reasonable to expect asylum seekers to state their case within the time limits. "The form is not an exam or a test and you don't need a lawyer to complete it."

She added that significant numbers of asylum seekers were in Britain for some time before they made their claim.

The figures show that the 76,000 applications in 2000 were about 5,000 above the 1999 figure, with the greatest increases in applications from Iraq, Iran and Zimbabwe. A to tal of 110,065 initial decisions were made on asylum cases last year, with a further 19,000 resolved on appeal. The number of decisions reflected a £600m programme to try to get the backlog of cases down. The backlog has fallen from 103,495 in January 2000 to 66,196 now.

The recognition rate for asylum seekers in 2000 ran at about 24%, with 10% granted full refugee status, a further 12% allowed to stay on exceptional or humanitarian grounds, and a further 2% allowed to stay after an appeal hearing.

Mrs Roche said a reduction in asylum applications from Poland (down 47%) and the Czech republic (down 31%) reflected the success of new measures.

Although the figures showed Britain now had the highest number of asylum applications across the European Union, Mrs Roche said other countries, such as France, Ireland, Sweden and Belgium, were actually facing greater pressures. "Unfortunately the concept of asylum is being undermined by those who are using it as a back door route to migration," she said.

The figures show that the 76,000 applications in 2000 were about 5,000 above the 1999 figure, with the greatest increases in applications from Iraq, Iran and Zimbabwe. A to tal of 110,065 initial decisions were made on asylum cases last year, with a further 19,000 resolved on appeal. The number of decisions reflected a £600m programme to try to get the backlog of cases down. The backlog has fallen from 103,495 in January 2000 to 66,196 now. The recognition rate for asylum seekers in 2000 ran at about 24%, with 10% granted full refugee status, a further 12% allowed to stay on exceptional or humanitarian grounds, and a further 2% allowed to stay after an appeal hearing. Mrs Roche said a reduction in asylum applications from Poland (down 47%) and the Czech republic (down 31%) reflected the success of new measures. Although the figures showed Britain now had the highest number of asylum applications across the European Union, Mrs Roche said other countries, such as France, Ireland, Sweden and Belgium, were actually facing greater pressures. "Unfortunately the concept of asylum is being undermined by those who are using it as a back door route to migration," she said.

webTitle: Vandals hounded refugees out of Bradford estate

fields.headline: Vandals hounded refugees out of Bradford estate
fields.trailText: Splinters of window glass and a mangled pushchair mark the site of the siege of Ferriby Close, a six month campaign of violence which has led to Britain's first eviction of thugs who terrorised asylum seekers.
fields.body:
Splinters of window glass and a mangled pushchair mark the site of the siege of Ferriby Close, a six month campaign of violence which has led to Britain's first eviction of thugs who terrorised asylum seekers.

At least two more houses on the hilltop estate in Bradford will shortly be boarded up like the six on the Close, where families from Poland, Latvia and the Czech republic said they could not stand the persecution any longer.

"We have started the eviction process against a barbaric and idiotic minority and we will see it through," Kris Hopkins, a Bradford city councillor, said yesterday. "Anyone who comes to Bradford is going to be treated like everyone else."

The evictions are the first in the country specifically triggered by harassment of asylum seekers - including stone throwing and attacks on children which has nauseated neighbours in the cul de sac.

"They were decent people," said Jack Howgate, a retired bus driver whose semi now looks out on eyeless houses with every window sealed by metal grilles. "I lent them my lawnmower when they moved in last summer and they got into the habit of coming over and mowing my lawn after they'd done theirs."

Further up the close, Billy Smith, 23, started weight-lifting sessions with Derek, the burliest of the Czechs, who have moved with the other Ferriby families to undisclosed addresses in Bradford. "They were OK," Mr Smith said. "There was a problem with English but there was a nine-year-old kid called Vanessa who did loads of translating. The trouble is, there are a lot of idiots on this estate - the same ones who stone the buses and spray the drivers with that smelly stuff you get from joke shops."

There was wider resentment, however, said Derek Learoyd, a night shift truck driver who lives in Ferriby Close. "There was jealousy when their houses were redecorated ready for them," he said. "Nothing against the families themselves, but everyone round here's been waiting for ever for repairs."

Initial abuse in the street was followed by stones through windows and trailing of families when they went shopping or to school. Over Christmas, most of the asylum seekers went to see relatives in London and Kent and returned to find their houses burgled and vandalised.

The estate's residents' association, Fagley Action Group, tried to use the local grapevine to explain that government refugee money, not Bradford cash, had paid for the repairs.

"We're not standing for a situation where the majority of decent people on estates dare not protest, because they think they'll be out on a limb and the council will just pussyfoot around," said Mr Hopkins. "We're using our standard tenant enforcement policy, agreed with all tenants. This case happens to involve asylum seekers but we'll do the same for anyone who gets picked on."

fields.headline: WPP's Red Cell will target global brands
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Advertising giant WPP has unveiled details of its new global communications network, Red Cell, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Martin Sorrell's giant advertising group, WPP, last night unveiled details of its new global communications network, which is to be called Red Cell.

WPP is combining its European advertising business, Conquest, with the US agency Cole & Weber and the Asian advertising business Batey to form Red Cell.

The group aims to fill a gap in the market between major multinational advertising networks such as WPP's Young & Rubicam, J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather and the smaller creative hot shops.

It will target so-called "challenger brands" - relatively new companies such as Virgin or Asda that challenge the established market leaders.

"Globalisation and technology have resulted in the emergence of a group of global challenger brands - lean, ambitious, agile, digitally-wired businesses - that demand worldwide marketing and communications capabilities," said WPP chairman Sir Martin Sorrell.

"Red Cell is the first global communications network dedicated primarily to the success of these global challenger brands."

Red Cell will be headed by Luca Lindner, who has been chief executive of Conquest for the past three years.

The creation of a fourth agency network will enable WPP to take on new clients that it would otherwise be prevented from handling due to conflicts with clients in its existing businesses.

Conquest was originally set up to service the Alfa Romeo advertising account, to avoid a conflict with WPP's existing Ford client.

fields.headline: Memories aren't made of this
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow's Holocaust Day tries to impose banal liberal ideas about the lessons to be learnt from history
fields.trailText: Tomorrow's Holocaust Day tries to impose banal liberal ideas about the lessons to be learnt from history.
fields.body:
It's no coincidence that the first Holocaust Memorial Day falls tomorrow, almost exactly a year after the David Irving trial began in London. The day provides one sort of answer to the question of how Holocaust denial can be challenged. Instead of legislation to make it illegal, a Memorial Day aims to supply the educational tools with which Holocaust denial can be countered.

Yet though I understand the motives, I'm not persuaded by the methods. Is an institutionalised day the best way of remembering an event? It's one thing in Israel where Yom Hashoah, the annual day of Holocaust remembrance is, for obvious reasons, an important part of collective mourning. But in Britain, whose connection with the Shoah is less direct, institutionalising the day may actually serve to promote the process of forgetting.

The Holocaust scholar James Young, writing about Holocaust memorials, has argued that "once we assign monumental form to memory, we have to some degree divested ourselves of the obligation to remember. In shouldering the memory-work, monuments may relieve viewers of their memory burden". The recent debate about the statuary in Trafalgar Square is proof. Drained of vitality, they've become empty tributes to the institutionalised great and good.

Even in Israel, Yom Hashoah doesn't have the shared, universal meaning which a national day of commemoration is designed to create. Sephardic immigrants and Arab-Israelis have different, almost certainly dissonant, memories and reactions, not unlike the black Bronx schoolchildren who cheered when they watched Schindler's List.

I fear the shared sanctimony which a Holocaust Memorial Day will inevitably bring. Even in the Department for Education and Employment education pack, although prepared by an impressive team of Holocaust educators and well-informed, the platitudes are inescapable. The Spielberg agenda of using the Holocaust to teach liberal values is strongly in evidence. Of course children should be taught to challenge racism and appreciate difference, yet I feel seriously discomfited by the notion of lessons to be learnt from the Holocaust.

The historian Peter Novick has argued that "If there are, in fact, lessons to be learnt from history, the Holocaust would seem an unlikely source... because of its extremity. Lessons for dealing with the sorts of issues that confront us in ordinary life, public or private, are not likely to be found in this most extraordinary of events". By all means teach children to cherish each other, but why have recourse to the Holocaust to do so?

Bracketing the Rwandan and Bosnian genocides with the Shoah - as the Holocaust Memorial Day does - is equally problematic. Not because it disturbs the notion of the Holocaust's uniqueness (that most spurious and sterile of debates), but because it's doubtful that the factors which these distinct atrocities share can be boiled down to a set of neat, progressive maxims.

One assumes that Holocaust Memorial Day will be primarily directed at children. But what of their parents and grandparents? Let's not forget that anti-Semitism actually increased in Britain during the second world war, with many sharing the Joyce Grenfell belief that "there's something a bit un-cosy about a non-Aryan refugee in one's kitchen".

And if we're to have an annual Holocaust commemoration, it shouldn't idealise the British government either, whose policy on pre-war refugees and post-war survivors was pitted with prejudice and self-interest.

Above all, I'm sceptical about a Holocaust Memorial Day because it arrives on a wave of Holocaust material. In a dizzyingly short period, a 50-year near silence has turned into an omnipresent obsession. Both distort, and each serves current social needs. As a culture we've become grave-robbers, raiding the past for the ethical meanings - of good and evil - which the present can't supply, and which shouldn't be imposed upon the Shoah.

That said, the day is here and must be used. When the Holocaust was first included in the national curriculum, it stimulated the creation of a mass of effective new educational materials. The memorial day may do the same. As a daughter of survivors, I also hope that survivors and refugees will be involved in public speaking - they constitute the best educational aid of all.

At my most optimistic, I think the day might enhance sensitive teaching about the Holocaust. And yet I worry that, by creating the conditions through which it becomes part of official rhetoric, we risk desensitising future generations to the Shoah. In 50 years' time, will there be schools full of children chafing at having to feign sorrow over a distant historical atrocity? Can you mandate collective memory?

 Anne Karpf is a journalist, Jewish Chronicle columnist, and author of The War After: Living With The Holocaust, (Minerva).

webTitle: Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly averts vote defeat

fields.headline: Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly averts vote defeat
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive has embarked on a collision course with Westminster after a parliamentary rebellion forced the first minister, Henry McLeish, to offer free long-term care for all Scotland's pensioners.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive has embarked on a collision course with Westminster after a parliamentary rebellion forced the first minister, Henry McLeish, to offer free long-term care for all Scotland's pensioners.

Minutes before a vote on the issue in the Scottish parliament yesterday, the executive announced a dramatic policy u-turn and said it would implement plans to fund long-term care for all pensioners.

Scottish pensioners will now get free personal care, including bathing, changing dressings and assistance with eating - services that pensioners in England and Wales will continue to pay for.

The government thought it had repaired its reputation with pensioners by promising to increase pensions faster than inflation this year, but the policy split between London and Edinburgh may make it harder for Labour to garner the grey vote at the forthcoming election.

The decision to implement the care package, at a cost of £110m a year, reverses the announcement by Mr McLeish just a day earlier when he had offered a scheme that stopped short of the universal free care recommended by the Sutherland royal commission.

Facing certain defeat after a stormy debate on the issue yesterday, the parliament minister, Tom McCabe, revealed the free care in an emergency statement.

The u-turn had been brought about by the prospect of a cross-party rebellion which threatened to see Labour's LibDem coalition partners desert them to join an axis of SNP and Conservative MSPs and reject the compromise care package.

The decision opens the biggest policy rift yet between Holyrood and Westminster. Mr McLeish, who had hinted when he took office that he wanted to implement the Sutherland recommendations in full, was said to have been pressed by Downing Street not to offer a vastly superior care package in Scotland because of the problems it would create, not least raising the spectre of care being decided by postcode.

The issue is highly emotive and campaigners are unhappy with the existing deal in England and Wales where nursing care is free but personal care is means tested.

Paul Burstow, Liberal Democrat health spokesman, said the decision in Scotland "would mean that a Scottish pensioner choosing to move into a nursing home in England would get free personal care, but the English person in the next room would have to pay for it. This is like the tuition fees anomaly all over again."

About 40 Labour MPs have signed a Commons motion calling on the government to reconsider its stance.

The charity Help the Aged said: "We can't have a system that gives better care for people in Scotland than in the rest of the UK. That goes down the road of creating a new postcode lottery. The NHS is meant to provide care at the point of need throughout the UK and should not be dependent on where people live."

fields.headline: Countrywide snaps up Fodor Wyllie
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Countrywide Porter Novelli has bought new media PR agency Fodor Wyllie, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Fodor Wyllie Associates, one of the first British PR agencies to focus solely on new media, has been bought by Countrywide Porter Novelli for an undisclosed sum.

The 34 staff at Fodor Wyllie will now be absorbed into the Porter Novelli Convergence Group, boosting the division to 45 employees.

Neil Backwith, chief executive at Countrywide Porter Novelli, said: "This acquisition speeds up our development as one of the leading international groups servicing the digital revolution."

He added the acquisition would give the European PNCG operation a better footing to match that of the US division, which claims to be number one in the US market.

Grace Fodor, who co-founded Fodor Wyllie in 1994 with Jean Wyllie, said: "Integrating our expertise into the global infrastructure of PNCG will enable us to cater for all areas of the international technology industry."

The combined business now has clients such as DirectLine.com, jamjar.com, Thomas Cook Interactive, Novell, Google, Thames Water, DoubleClick, Vignette and CapCom.

webTitle: Plans to ban morning after pill from the high street slammed

fields.headline: Plans to ban morning after pill from the high street slammed
fields.trailText: Sexual health charities have spoken out against a House of Lords initiative to deny Britain's women over-the-counter access to the morning after pill, a measure only recently introduced.
fields.body:
Sexual health charities have spoken out against a House of Lords initiative to deny Britain's women over-the-counter access to the morning after pill, a measure only recently introduced.

The Family Planning Association has slammed the move, saying that peers would be guilty of "an extraordinary attack on women's health" by voting for such a proposal.

A spokesman for the Brook Advisory Centre said: "We hope the Lords won't reverse the government's decision. It would be a huge step backwards and there's no good reason for the decision to be reversed."

Lady Young, the Tory former leader of the Lords, has tabled a motion calling for immediate quashing of the decision to make the emergency contraception available to women aged over 16 at all chemists, instead of on prescription, which came into effect on January 1.

Peers will vote on the procedural order on Monday, and, if they back it, will succeed in immediately quashing the order permitting over-the-counter sale.

Last night, the Department of Health warned: "It will be a major step backwards and pharmacies would have to be alerted immediately to shop sales of a safe and effective emergency form of hormonal contraception."

The pill would still be available on prescription but the immediacy - important if the drug, which can be taken up to 72 hours after unprotected sex, is to be most effective - would be lost.

Women "should be able to access emergency contraception as quickly as possible for it to be most effective", added its spokeswoman, Juliet Hillier. "We hope that the Lords will recognise this and vote against Lady Young's motion."

Lady Young, who led the campaign against the bill lowering the gay age of consent to 16, and successfully persuaded peers to back her and reject the change before the government used the Parliament Act to force it on the statute books, was last night unavailable for comment.

She also last year successfully led opposition to the government's bid to scrap clause 28 which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

But the Tories, who tired to halt the decision in the Commons, will back her and could secure a victory if the Lib-Dems decide not to support the government, or if a Labour-Lib-Dem coalition fails to turn out in sufficient numbers.

The Tories' criticism of the government's decision has been unremitting, with the shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox telling the Nursing Standard on Wednesday: "My worry is not about the ability of pharmacists but about whether the high street chemist is the appropriate place for it to be given."

webTitle: GMC chief left isolated by agreement on reforms

fields.headline: GMC chief left isolated by agreement on reforms
fields.trailText: The president of the General Medical Council, who recently criticised doctors for dragging their feet over reforms, looked isolated yesterday after professional groups agreed to bypass his ideas for change
fields.body:
The president of the General Medical Council, who recently criticised doctors for dragging their feet over reforms, looked isolated yesterday after professional groups agreed to bypass his ideas for change.

Turning the tables on Sir Donald Irvine, a new alliance between the British Medical Association - the doctors' trade union - and the Academy of Medical Royal Colleges said that the GMC reform plans were bureaucratic.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the BMA, said: "The profession has been calling for reform of the GMC for many years. Recent cases of professional incompetence, malpractice, and, worse still, criminal behaviour, have strengthened our case.

"Yet the process of the reform and the GMC's own proposals are bogged down in bureaucracy. The public and doctors expect swift action to restore confidence in this regulatory process and now the entire medical profession has come together to agree measures which we believe will restore confidence and end the uncertainty."

The heads of the royal colleges sit on the GMC and were thought to back Sir Donald's plans. The change of alliances is a potential threat to Sir Donald's position.

The BMA and the academy yesterday put forward 11 proposals. They reject the idea of a small executive backed by a 200-strong conference of doctors and lay people to run the GMC. They want to see the present 104-strong council cut to 50 with an executive of only 10 or 15.

The failure to get agreement on a reformed GMC to reassure the public that doctors are being properly policed leaves many wondering whether the government will eventually scrap the GMC and set up a new structure.

In a recent lecture, Sir Donald warned that the public was not convinced they were doing enough to modernise the profession. "The cultural flaws in the medical profession show up as excessive paternalism, lack of respect for patients and their right to make decisions about their care," he said.

A GMC spokesman said yesterday that all the proposals would be incorporated in a consultation document to be brought out next month.

Asked if the new alliance left Sir Donald isolated, he said: "We will have to wait for the conference in February to see that. It consists of people who are not just the BMA or the academy - there are lay members and doctors who are elected in their own right."

fields.headline: Thalidomide may fight cancer
fields.trailText: Tablets that caused horrific birth defects thought to help shrink tumours.
fields.body:
Thalidomide, the notorious drug that caused appalling deformities in thousands of babies 40 years ago, is making a comeback as a possible therapy for cancer.

Trials have begun on 30 British patients with inoperable lung cancer after indications that regular doses can help shrink tumours and prevent their return.

Scientists hope that within five years they will know whether thalidomide is an effective treatment for a range of cancers.

It was widely used between 1958 and 1962 as a wonder drug against morning sickness in pregnant women but caused horrific birth defects.

Other studies over the past 10 years, mainly in the US, have suggested that the drug can combat some other cancers and threats to the immune system through HIV and lupus. It has an American licence to treat leprosy.

Thalidomide appears first to stabilise blood flow around tumours where it tends to pulse and be chaotic. This can allow a better supply of traditional anti-cancer drugs administered through chemotherapy. But then it appears to block blood flow associated with the growth of new tumours.

It was this that damaged foetuses more than a generation ago and left babies without limbs. About 450 British thalidomide victims survive, with a further 5,000 in other countries.

The Cancer Research Campaign, which has funded some promising work suggesting low dose thalidomide treatment could help renal cancer, is funding the new project which has already recruited 13 volunteers with small cell lung cancer, which accounts for 9,000 deaths a year - a quarter of all those who die from lung cancer.

Researchers are looking for more patients for the study based at UCL/Middlesex and Guy's hospitals in London and Cookridge hospital, Leeds.

Gordon McVie, the campaign's director general, said: "It is an extraordinary bit of lateral thinking. Thalidomide has such awful connotations in most people's minds. It has been completely revisited by biologists because it has quite extraordinary properties."

He warned that it was "early days" but the research had exciting potential.

Dr Siow Ming Lee, one of the researchers, said: "Existing treatments for small cell lung cancer remain unsatisfactory and clearly finding new ways to improve the treatment of this disease is vitally important."

Patients are taking 100mg tablets of thalidomide each night for two years as well as having chemotherapy. Margaret Edwards, a 52-year-old grandmother, from Stevenage, Hertfordshire, sought out clinical trials when she was told the cancer, which had caused secondary tumours in the brain, was inoperable.

"I have nothing to lose, but if I can help someone on the way it is great and if it can benefit me and give me a little extra time, wonderful. I stopped being able to read and I have noticed over the last month that my abilities to read are returning and speeding up. I hope that's not coincidence."

Vivien Kerr, coordinator for the Thalidomide Society, said: "Some people have extremely strong views that it should never, never be used again because of the side effects and the impact it has had on their lives.

"It should really be used as a drug of last resort. If there is no other drug that has potential benefits in something like cancer, as long as guidelines are in place, are strict and properly monitored, particularly for women of child bearing age, we would not stand in the way."
