fields.headline: Editor 'provided cover for spies'
fields.standfirst:
Plot thickens: Dominic Lawson denies new accusations that he helped MI6 agents when working for the Spectator

Related stories:
MI6's lawyers lose spy book appeal
Pen mightier than the sword
Russian colonel's defection an intelligence coup for Britain
fields.trailText: Sunday Telegraph editor Dominic Lawson has denied new accusations that he helped MI6 agents when working for the Spectator, write Ian Traynor and Richard Norton-Taylor.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Moscow and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Dominic Lawson, the editor of the Sunday Telegraph and son of the former Tory chancellor, Nigel Lawson, provided journalistic cover for an MI6 officer on a mission to the Baltic to handle and debrief a young Russian diplomat who was spying for Britain, the renegade MI6 officer, Richard Tomlinson, has alleged.

He also claimed he was given cover by the Spectator magazine while on a mission to Macedonia to develop contacts with ethnic Albanian politicians.

In his controversial book being published in Russia, Tomlinson, according to book excerpts leaked to the Moscow press, said that in the early 1990s the editor of the Spectator was on MI6's books and provided cover for an agent named as Spencer who was put on the case of a young Russian diplomat, Platon Obukhov, in Tallin, the capital of Estonia.

Tomlinson writes that Mr Lawson's MI6 identity was "Smallbrow". Mr Lawson was the editor of the Spectator from 1990-95 before moving to its sister publication, the Sunday Telegraph.

Mr Lawson yesterday strongly denied both allegations. "It is complete rubbish that I gave journalistic cover to an MI6 officer who wanted to go to Tallin," he added. The Obukhov case triggered the worst spy row between Britain and Russia since the end of the Soviet Union, with each country expelling four diplomats af ter Obukhov was arrested on charges of spying for Britain in April 1996.

According to Komsomolskaya Pravda, the bestselling Moscow tabloid which has obtained a copy of the Tomlinson book and has been publishing excerpts this week, Spencer, who joined MI6 at the same time as Tomlinson, was given the job of handling Obukhov, codenamed Masterwork.

"For the meetings with Obukhov, Spencer chose Tallin, the capital of the newly independent state of Estonia which was cosying up to the west," the newspaper quoted the book as saying.

"For the trip Spencer took one of his favourite MI6 covers - journalist. The editor of the Spectator magazine provided him with the cover on condition that Spencer wrote just one article for him."

The agent turned to the MI6 section, I/OPS (Information Operations), that deals with the British media to arrange the bogus journalistic credentials, according to the leak from the Tomlinson book.

"Flippin' outrageous!" Spencer laughed as he came back from his visit to I/OPS. "They've got the editor of the Spectator magazine on the books. He's called Smallbrow," he chuckled.

"He's agreed to let me go out to Tallin undercover as a freelancer for his magazine. The only condition is that I have to write an article which he'll publish if he likes it.

"The cheeky bastard wants a story courtesy of the taxpayer!"

Tomlinson also writes that for his mission to Macedonia he was given a letter of accreditation from the Spectator and told by his superiors that if his Albanian interlocutors phoned the Spectator to check on him, Mr Lawson would vouch that Tomlinson was a Spectator journalist.

Mr Lawson's Spectator has been at the centre of a row over MI6 and journalism before. Tomlinson has previously alleged that MI6 agents were asked to write media articles under pseudonyms while in Bosnia during the 1992-95 war.

The Guardian reported in 1998 that the Spectator ran articles by an MI6 officer under a false name during the Bosnian war. The articles were written from Sarajevo by a Kenneth Roberts, though the Spectator noted that the author's name had been changed at his request without revealing his true employer. The MI6 officer has since been publicly identified as Keith Craig.

Mr Lawson yesterday repeated what he said two years ago. "I have never been an agent either paid or unpaid of MI6 or any other government agency."

A Foreign Office spokesman speaking for MI6 said that Mr Tomlinson's claim "comes from someone now wearily familiar as a source of sensational inventions".

Kenneth Roberts also appears in the Tomlinson book as the MI6 agent in Sarajevo whom the rogue agent said he replaced in late 1993.

In the case of Obukhov, the Russian newspaper quoted the Tomlinson book as saying that "Spencer" continued to meet the junior Russian diplomat on a bi-monthly basis in Tallin, then later in Moscow until Russian counter-intelligence arrested Obukhov in Moscow in April 1996. A writer of pulp spy novels who has been in psychiatric care and whose relatives and lawyers said he was a schizophrenic, Obukhov is the son of Alexei Obukhov who was deputy Soviet foreign minister to Eduard Shevardnadze in the Gorbachev era.

After Obukhov was arrested, triggering the tit for tat spy row, the Moscow city court found him unfit to stand trial and ordered compulsory psychiatric treatment which he received from 1997 until July last year when he was sentenced to 11 years imprisonment.

Last month an appeal court overruled the 11-year sentence and Obukhov now faces a new hearing.

webTitle: Distribution delays for Sony's PlayStation2 consoles

fields.headline: Sony console delays spoil fun
fields.trailText: Gamers who have been unable to get hold of PlayStation2 consoles face further disappointment after Sony warned production problems would aggravate delays, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Gamers who have been unable to get hold of PlayStation2 consoles face further disappointment after manufacturer Sony warned that production problems would aggravate distribution delays.

The Japanese giant said its PS2 shipments were being cut by 10% to 9m, and warned that profits for the year were likely to be lower.

The news adds to the troubles of the games publishers, which have seen sales hit by the lack of new consoles being made available in shops. Eidos yesterday became the latest firm to admit its profits would be hit by the slowdown.

Sony's roll-out of PS2 has been hindered by technical difficulties and shipment delays which have led to a dramatic turnaround in the fortunes of its games division. It registered a loss of ¥13.9bn in 2000 compared to a profit of ¥57.5bn the year before.

For its part, Eidos blamed its third profits warning in a year largely on the short supply of PS2 consoles. A slowdown in games sales in the US and delays to three key titles were also to blame, chief executive Mike McGarvey added.

Eidos shares slumped by 27% in early trading and closed down 21p at 256p, even though Christmas trading was ahead of expectations.

Eidos has been actively courting City analysts and its biggest shareholders after a year in which its share price has plunged, executives have left and takeover talks have collapsed. Mr McGarvey admitted there was no quick fix to its problems, saying: "Clearly, the company is not going to turn around in a couple of weeks, it's going to be a much longer process, but we're making strong progress."

Nick Gibson, an analyst at Durlacher, said that it was "entirely predictable" that publishers' profits were falling, given their dependence on the introduction of new consoles to spur sales of games.

fields.headline: E's the man
fields.standfirst: Channel 4 entertainment boss Kevin Lygo has brought E4 into the world under the influence of corporate Capricorn, narcotic Neptune Pythonesque Pluto and plain old bad taste.
fields.trailText: Channel 4 entertainment boss Kevin Lygo has brought E4 into the world under the influence of corporate Capricorn, narcotic Neptune and Pythonesque Pluto, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Kevin Lygo, head of entertainment for Channel 4 and supremo of its newly launched E4, is playing so coy about his birth data that Media Medium suspects a touch of Cancer or Scorpio. But no matter. His programming genius is stamped all over the horoscope for E4's launch (8:15pm, January 18 2001).

As an ambitious, corporate Capricorn, the new digital channel is part of Channel 4's long-term strategy to increase the "Channel 4 family" and thereby its audience share. It is targeted at the media-aware world of 18 to 34-year-old ABC1s, which is why Aquarius, the sign of alternative culture, is also strongly emphasised.

fields.headline: Sponsors line up for '£5m' Big Brother 2
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Pepsi, Budweiser and Sony PlayStation are considering sponsoring the next series of Big Brother, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Youth mega-brands Pepsi, Budweiser and Sony PlayStation are taking a close look at sponsoring the next series of Big Brother in what will be one of the hottest TV branding opportunities ever.

Sponsorship experts believe the Big Brother 2 package may be sold for up to £5m as Channel 4 promises more sex appeal from the new series.

The broadcaster says it is already talking with potential sponsors amid rumours that C4 bosses will pick contestants most likely to have sex on the show.

Nick Theakston, head of broadcast at MediaVest, which negotiated Southern Comfort's original sponsorship, said he thought the sponsorship would go for "at least £3-4m".

The deal is likely to exceed Alliance & Leicester's £3m tie-up with ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, announced this week, and run second only to Cadbury's £10m backing of Coronation Street.

Southern Comfort, £1m sponsor of the first series, is still considering whether it can afford to bid for the second.

The new series is expected to smash the 4.7m audience attracted by the first outing, while the profile of viewers is the advertiser's "holy grail" - upmarket 16 to 34-year-olds.

This makes it particularly attractive to high-spending youth brands such as beers, soft drinks and computer games.

"The success of Big Brother 1 is obvious. This is going to be a big one," said Blair Krempel, managing director of TV sponsorship specialist Sponsorvision.

Channel 4 has yet to decide on the date of the broadcast, the format of the show and the amount of airtime it will receive.

Once these benchmarks are decided, it will issue a formal tender for sponsorship.

fields.headline: Boycott quits Express
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Express takeover
More media news: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Rosie Boycott, the editor of the Daily Express, walked out with a £200,000 payoff yesterday in a move likely to end the paper's flirtation with the liberal left.
fields.byline: Matt Wells, David Teather and Mary Fitzgerald
fields.body:
Rosie Boycott, the editor of the Daily Express, walked out with a £200,000 payoff yesterday in a move likely to end the paper's flirtation with the liberal left.

Her departure came after months of speculation and negotiation, bitterness and farce since the paper was taken over by Richard Desmond last year: relations between editor and proprietor had almost completely broken down. She will be replaced by the current associate editor of the Express, Chris Williams.

Ms Boycott said the parting was amicable, but it had been clear that the former editor of Spare Rib would not last long with the man who publishes Asian Babes and Big Ones.

"I would like to wish the newspaper, its staff and the new proprietor well in their endeavours to build on the great name and tradition of the Daily Express," Ms Boycott said in a prepared statement. Her deputy, Chris Blackhurst, also quit.

A few minutes before leaving the Express headquarters in London, Ms Boycott bade a tearful farewell to staff. She would not comment further: her severance agreement includes a gagging clause, but she was due to appear on the BBC's Question Time last night.

Relations between Mr Desmond, the publisher of OK!, and Ms Boycott were quickly strained after he took over in November. They deteriorated a month later when he made 60 support staff redundant. Ms Boycott condemned "heavyhanded" treatment of workers, expressing outrage that a pregnant woman and a disabled man were sacked.

The breaking point was understood to have been Mr Desmond's demands at the end of last year that she cut editorial staff by at least 100, and the pair have not spoken since then.

The editorial director, Paul Ashford, is set to take a more active role, and there are likely to be redundancies next month as well as further cost-cutting. Mr Williams is a veteran of the Express and worked under the previous editor Richard Addis.

Mr Desmond made a brief appearance yesterday to wish Ms Boycott well.

Her next move is unknown. There has been speculation that she might be offered a place in the House of Lords.

Ms Boycott's tenure at the paper has met with mixed success. She steered the paper to wards a progressive stance with a mix of socially conscious reporting and soft feature-driven content.

Despite its New Labour leanings, the paper turned hard on the Blair's government for the 75p increase in state pensions. But circulation has continued to decline.

Her appointment in 1998 was the latest twist in an unpredictable career. She co-founded the 1970s feminist magazine Spare Rib, and has always championed women's rights. After battling drug and alcohol addiction she became an award-winning editor at the men's glossy, Esquire.

During a stint as editor of the Independent on Sunday she earned the nickname Rizla Rosie when she spearheaded a campaign to legalise cannabis. She later took over at the IoS's daily stablemate, in an uncomfortable joint editorship with Andrew Marr, now the BBC's political editor.

fields.headline: Channel 4 puts family in African mud hut for new 'reality' series
fields.trailText: 8.30am: An English family is to live in a mud hut in Africa without electricity or water for a Channel 4 series, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A mixed race English family has been flown to Africa to live in a mud hut without electricity or running water for an upcoming factual series for Channel 4.

The family of five from south London will have to live in a rural village in Swaziland for three months for the show, African Village, which is being made by UK indie RDF Television.

The two adults and three children are taking a full part in village life, with the grown-ups going out to work and their offspring attending the local school.

The mother, who is a nurse back in Britain, is working alongside the other village women washing and working on the land. Her partner, a lorry driver back home, is looking for a driving job.

Their eldest child, a 13-year-old boy, has to walk 9km to school each morning. The schoolteachers have big sticks they are not afraid to use, according to the show's executive producer, RDF director of programmes Stephen Lambert.

Mr Lambert said the wife was already fed up because local custom meant her husband got hot baths but she didn't, even though she has been out working on the land.

"Swaziland has a very traditional African society with an absolute monarchy," he added. "They still have very strong social structures and consider foreigners to be quite inferior."

The series gives a new twist to the reality TV genre, which has included Channel 4 shows 1900 House and 1940s House.

African Village is being series produced and directed by Helen Richards, who is working on location in Swaziland with a five-strong RDF production team.

The three-part series is due to go out on Channel 4 in the autumn.

fields.headline: Nescafe man sets up online talent agency
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Seventies TV heartthrob Gareth Hunt has set up an online talent agency, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Seventies TV heartthrob Gareth Hunt has caught the internet bug and launched his own dot.com.

The veteran actor, famed for the New Avengers and Nescafe coffee ads, is setting up an online talent agency.

He has teamed up with Michael Wendt, a former investment director of London & Edinburgh Insurance, to develop e-media-c.net.

Aimed at casting directors, ad agencies and producers, e-media-c.net offers users an easy and efficient way of sourcing celebrities, venues or music.

It was originally devised five years ago as a CD-Rom by Mr Hunt, but has since evolved into a website featuring more than 20,000 bookable locations and more than 1,000 audio samples of voice-over artists.

For companies looking to hire talent, all they have to do is go to e-media-c and choose what they want, and then book it via the site.

Mr Hunt has caught the attention of major organisations, signing up EMI to provide audio clips, Ridley Scott Associates for locations and model agency Premier Models.

Mr Hunt declined to disclose his own financial stake in e-media-c.net or who other shareholders were.

e-media-c.net has already managed to raise £1.85m by floating the business on Ofex, an exchange for small businesses, leading to the company now being valued at around £14.5m.

Useful link:

e-media-c.net

webTitle: TV and Radio: BBC period dramas

fields.headline: A touch of class
fields.standfirst:
What do you need to make a period drama? A few old costumes and a stately home? Not quite, as Maggie Brown discovered when she talked to the makers of the eagerly awaited adaptation of Love in a Cold Climate

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: What do you need to make a period drama? A few old costumes and a stately home? Not quite, as Maggie Brown discovered when she talked to the makers of the eagerly awaited adaptation of Love in a Cold Climate.
fields.body:
The recent television adaptations of two classic 20th century novels, Sword of Honour and Take a Girl Like You, highlighted a creative problem.

How do you faithfully revive the spirit of the 1940s or 1950s, decades that are within living memory for many viewers, yet as remote as the other side of the moon to the under 40s (including most of the cast and production team)? Channel 4's Sword of Honour was criticised for failing to capture both how the upper classes spoke and Evelyn Waugh's now embarrassingly snobbish dislike of the rising lower classes.

Take a Girl Like You, Kingsley Amis's 1950s tale of predatory males, also missed the mark, despite its build-up as BBC1's prestige autumn Sunday night drama - it was small consolation that the clothes and the cars were great.

For everyone associated with these high-profile projects, from the scriptwriters downwards, the challenge lies in reinventing the tone of an almost lost world, but doing so in a near-vacuum, without support from the comforting conventions of traditional costume dramas.

We all know what to expect from a televised Dickens - high and low life, and well-known actors' faces under mobcaps - while Jane Austen requires bonnets, breeches and formal dances. But when directors try to break the mould of audience expectations - as with the sparse Anna Karenina on Channel 4 - they usually come a cropper. A Christmas Carol worked for ITV last month because it made a clean break: Ross Kemp and modern dress.

In Love in a Cold Climate, the forthcoming BBC1 Sunday drama, this problem has been tackled with vigour. Although set in the run-up to and early stages of the second world war, barely 65 years ago, it's been produced according to the exacting conventions of grand costume drama.

Based on the Nancy Mitford tragicomic novels, The Pursuit of Love and Love in a Cold Climate, the curious decaying aristocratic way of life it captures is arguably ideally suited to this treatment: a relic from the previous century.

The cast studied dozens of tapes of the Mitfords speaking, in order to get the specific posh, clear accent and inflections right, noting that class then affected everything else - how people walked, sat and behaved.

Producer Kate Harwood, script writer Deborah Moggach and director Tom Hooper decided they wanted detail as the "extra flavour" to make the opulent two-parter as authentic as possible. Harwood's last project on this scale was David Copperfield, (repeated over the New Year) where she used the same approach.

The point about these two well-loved books is that they were semi-autobiographical, clearly based on the Mitford family. Mitford's father, Lord Redesdale, was the model for the mad, eccentric Lord Alconleigh (Uncle Matthew).

"Suddenly we realised we had an adviser on our doorstep," says Harwood - in the form of younger sister Deborah, now the Duchess of Devonshire, who lives at one of Britain's grandest country estates, Chatsworth. The team were invited for tea and given a full briefing. Many members of the Mitfords, including the Duke and Duchess, are attending next week's gala performance at London's BAFTA.

Actress and Oxford student Rosamund Pike, who plays Fanny, narrator of the story and one of a trio of young women in pursuit of love at the core of the novels, says the effort to replicate the way they spoke "is not done in a spirit of nostalgia. We are not trying to romanticise it too much. It's the way they lived."

The Duchess of Devonshire told her visitors she hated seeing (in TV costume dramas) servants hanging around behind chairs, bobbing and curtsying, saying Ma'am and Miss all the time. "She said that they were much more functional, just there, and not so precious," says Harwood. "She was also very adamant that at coming-out balls (there's one for the central character, Linda), the girls, only 18 or 19 years old, would wear a string of pearls at most, not jewels."

The key challenge for Moggach was what to do about Lord Alconleigh - Uncle Matthew - who is, by modern standards, totally beyond the pale in his ravings and prejudices. But the team were adamant he shouldn't be edited down to a shadow. Uncle Matthew was a very close portrait of the real Mitford father, and the Duchess confirmed that he was very fond of the books.

Harwood says "You'd be amazed at how few people can play such parts. The list was terrifyingly short. Only four names. It was a huge relief when Alan Bates accepted."

The one thing that isn't in period is the plot compression. Moggach has kept the essential charm. But, as Celia Imrie - who plays Lady Alconleigh - observes, there are an awful lot of characters for the audience to get to know in just two episodes. A lot takes place - fast. Linda, the key character, marries twice, has a baby, becomes a communist, flees to the borders of the Spanish civil war, has a love affair with French aristocrat Fabrice, gets pregnant, is bombed out in London, and then dies.

Those who love the books will find many characters absent, from fussy hypochondriac Uncle Davey to Linda's French bulldog, although Fanny's mother, the notorious Bolter remains intact. The ending has been reworked, for dramatic effect.

When the BBC last did Love in a Cold Climate, in the 1970s, there were six parts. "Six parts - we'd be in deep water. It would be so expensive, and a lot of it would be just chatting. We tell stories differently now," says Harwood. "I watched the 1970s version before doing this and felt like saying, get on with it."

After Rebel Heart's difficult passage, it's hard to predict how this version will fare. But Harwood claims "This is heartland BBC stuff, and Sunday night is the place most of our audience look for classic drama."

 Love in a Cold Climate, 8.45pm, Sunday 4 February, BBC1. Concluding part, Sunday 11 February.

webTitle: G2: Is Gore a good journalist?

fields.headline: Can he hack it?
fields.standfirst:
Al Gore has found a new job - teaching journalism at Columbia University. But is he qualified for it? Well, he was once a reporter on the Tennessean, so Hugh Stephenson, professor of journalism at London's City University, dug out an old piece by the former vice-president and assessed it

Special report: George Bush's America
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Al Gore has found a new job - teaching journalism at Columbia University. But is he qualified for it? Well, he was once a reporter on the Tennessean, so Hugh Stephenson, professor of journalism at London's City University, dug out an old piece by the former vice-president and assessed it.
fields.body:
In his handling of the Clariday stock scandal story, cub reporter Gore shows an instinctive grasp of the basics of reporting. Any properly constructed news story has to tell the reader who did what, where, when and why.

"Who" is clear. "Where" was presumably clear to his Tennessee readership. "What" Councilman Jack did, obviously, was to get hold of stock in a campground. And young Al deftly used that trick of the trade, so beloved of Sunday newspaper journalists and others who need to justify reporting as hot news something that happened some while ago. "Last night the question was an open controversy on the council floor" is a classic way of solving the "when" question in a way that makes a story smell fresh.

But a cub reporter taking a story to the news desk has also to pass a harsher test - the "so what" test. In order to pass it, the first paragraph of the story (and, if possible, its first sentence) needs to contain the answer to the hard-bitten news editor's automatic reaction: "Yeah, so what?"

On this score young Gore should have been told to do some more work on his story. Councilman C. owned stock. OK? So what? For those, like Lady Damask Monogram in The Way We Live Now, who could see no clear line between commerce and fraud, the facts as presented may be enough proof of skulduggery.

But for most readers, unversed in the detail of company ownership and municipal ethics, it is not really a story unless you say in the first sentence exactly what it is that Jack is being accused of doing, or not doing. To back up that introduction, we should then have been told when he bought the stock, who sold it to him, when the zoning permission was applied for and granted, what registration of members interests he had failed to make and the like.

The next rule of good story construction is that it should have a coherent shape, flagged to the busy reader by the first paragraph. This story flouts that basic rule. You are led to believe that you are about to read a story concerning J Clariday and Pennington Bend campground.

But then, just as you are getting your mind round that idea, you are led off "at the same time" (a sure indicator that what follows has little to do with what has gone before) into complications involving two more local politicians and then a third, who seems to have liked pears and peaches, and a DA who has no usable proof about allegations that, in any event, have nothing to do with brother Jack in the first place.

So his news editor should have said to young Al: "Is this a story about widespread municipal corruption? In that case, say so in the intro. But, if you are gunning for Jack, let's have a story on Jack."

And whoever was subediting Al's copy might usefully have called him over and told him about putting commas in sentences to break up subordinate clauses (eg after campground at the beginning) and not using jargon words like "councilmanic".

He also needed to decide what to do with verbatim quotes that are not grammatical. It is accepted practice to tidy up politicians' grammar, provided you leave their sense inviolate.

Overall young Gore showed competence, rather than flair. You rather feel that a young journalist with more of an instinct for the jugular could have got a sexier story out of this material. He might be advised to look for jobs in the local press, rather than go for the nationals. Overall mark? 58%

fields.headline: Braking point
fields.standfirst:
As analysts expect no growth in the American economy for at least a couple of quarters, euroland must keep a sharp eye on the exchange rate

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: As analysts expect no growth in the American economy for at least a couple of quarters, euroland must keep a sharp eye on the exchange rate.
fields.body:
For two years, since the creation of the single currency, euroland has played understudy to a global superstar, watching frustratingly from the wings as the American economy received applause and adulation. Now it has been thrust centre stage by the US slowdown. With Japan, the world's second largest economy, also in trouble, economists predict euroland will be the best performer of the big three this year. But will it live up to its billing?

Euroland's prospects are certainly encouraging. For the first time in three years, it grew more strongly than the US between July and September and is on course to do so again in the final quarter of 2000. Forecasters expect that performance to be sustained. Merrill Lynch, the investment bank, takes a relatively upbeat view of the prospects for the American economy yet still expects euroland to grow by 2.7% in 2001, outpacing the US by 0.2 percentage points. Others expect the gap to be much wider. Goldman Sachs, which has slashed its forecast for American growth from 4% to 2%, reckons the difference in euroland's favour will be more than half a percentage point.

Compared to the 2-3% gap in the US's favour at the height of the boom, euroland's triumph will be modest but it should help to sustain global growth, albeit at a slower pace than last year, and bring about a recovery in the euro's exchange rate against the dollar - a process which is, indeed, already under way.

This rosy outlook rests on both structural and cyclical factors. Cyclically, euroland is much less advanced than the US and has none of the imbalances which have built up during the decade-long American boom. Having financed consumption out of earnings rather than borrowing record amounts based on dubious stock market valuations of their wealth, euroland consumers may not have had such a good time as their American counterparts but they are now in a position to carry on spending rather than retrenching. At the same time, euroland companies have not indulged in the same degree of over-investment in information technology and are less likely to cut back sharply to preserve profitability.

Structurally, the received wisdom is that euroland remains less dynamic than the US, suffering from lower productivity growth, heavier regulation and relatively inflexible labour markets - although many of these alleged shortcomings may be no more than a misperception caused by the strength of the American boom.

But the arrival of the euro has certainly been a catalyst for change. Although the European Union accepts further progress needs to be made, the new currency has brought nearer the prospect of a truly single market, creating a wave of cross-border mergers and acquisitions and persuading governments to cut taxes and introduce more flexible labour laws to make euroland more competitive.

In France, income tax was cut by 0.2% of GDP in the final quarter of last year and the tax on cars for individuals was suspended. In Italy, lower tax rates were introduced in November for individuals and firms worth 0.6% of GDP. And in Germany, euroland's largest economy, an income and corporate tax reduction worth about 0.75% of GDP took effect at the beginning of this year.

Together, these structural reforms should support growth irrespective of the cold trade winds blowing from across the Atlantic - assuming that they do not turn into a blizzard.

If the US does sink into a deep recession, no countries are likely to escape unscathed. Euroland will not necessarily be the first to suffer. Canada, Mexico, Japan, Hong Kong, Brazil, Malaysia, China and Korea all do more trade with the US than any single euroland economy but JP Morgan, the investment bank, says that one of the lessons of 1997-98 (the Asian financial crisis, Russian debt default, American hedge-fund collapse, Brazilian devaluation) was that regions in the global economy are now more closely linked in a variety of channels, both financial and economic. "Policy makers ignore these at their peril," the bank says.

One channel where the European Central Bank (ECB) will have to remain especially alert is the euro/dollar exchange rate. For two years it has suffered the humiliation of seeing the fledgling currency fall on the foreign exchanges. The ECB and euroland politicians have taken comfort from the euro's recovery since last autumn but exchange rates are prone to overshooting.

While investors continue to believe in the soft landing scenario for the US, they may do no more than push the euro above parity against the dollar. But if the markets suddenly become more gloomy about the US, the value of the euro could rise as quickly as it fell, with damaging consequences for euroland exporters and companies with American operations.

There are already signs that the slowdown in global growth is taking its toll. Euroland GDP growth peaked at 4% towards the end of 1999. Nevertheless, the weakening of growth has been far less pronounced than in the US, where most analysts expect the economy to register almost no growth at all for at least a couple of quarters.

So long as euroland continues to make steady progress it will win the plaudits it so craves but compared to the US's performance over the past decade, one which has enriched the whole globe, euroland's will be less impressive. By avoiding the excesses of the US, however, it might prove more durable.

 Mark Atkinson is the Guardian's economics correspondent.

webTitle: Fuel costs drive down new cab sales

fields.headline: Fuel costs drive down new cab sales
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: London's cabbies are feeling the pinch from higher fuel prices and road congestion, according to taxi maker Manganese Bronze, which yesterday issued its second profits warning in three months.
fields.body:
London's cabbies are feeling the pinch from higher fuel prices and road congestion, according to taxi maker Manganese Bronze, which yesterday issued its second profits warning in three months.

Manganese's sales of black cabs slumped 30% in the five months to December - a shortfall of about 380 vehicles. The firm admitted it was likely to make a half-year loss of up to £2m, sending its shares down 26.5p to 87p.

Chief executive Ian Pickering said many drivers had delayed buying new cabs: "Petrol prices have been rising and the cost of insurance has gone up much more for taxis than for other cars. There's also been some effect from the rail crisis - fewer people have been coming into London, and the roads have been disrupted."

Mr Pickering took the top job three weeks ago, replacing long-serving Jamie Borwick, who became non-executive chairman. Mr Borwick's family owns 40% of the company, which has seen its market value plunge from £49m to £16m over the last year.

Mr Pickering said the shake-up was due to the retirement of chairman Hugh Lang, 68, and had "nothing to do with" disappointing trading.

Manganese has put the 400 workers at its Coventry factory onto a three-day working week. The firm has cut its weekly output of vehicles from 68 to 51.

There has been some improvement in demand this month. March, when vehicle registration letters change, will be crucial.

The taxi trade is traditionally considered a bellwether of the economy - a slowdown is reputed to be among the first signs of recession. Metrocab, Manganese's main rival, went into administration earlier this month. Mr Pickering said he remained confident of Manganese's longer term position: "Looking further ahead, there's going to be more use of public transport and taxis are an important part of the public transport chain."

webTitle: Clinton staff accused of vandalising White House

fields.headline: Clinton staff accused of vandalising White House
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush is reported to have ordered an investigation into possible systematic vandalism of the White House and its offices by outgoing members of Bill Clinton's staff last weekend.
fields.body:
President George Bush is reported to have ordered an investigation into possible systematic vandalism of the White House and its offices by outgoing members of Bill Clinton's staff last weekend.

The allegations are said to include a range of much more serious damage to government property than the previously reported "prank" involving the removal of the "W" keys from dozens of White House computer keyboards. Among the new damage being examined are cut phone lines, filing cabinets that have been glued shut and pornographic pictures left in office printers.

The damage was particularly bad in the offices previously occupied by staff working for former Vice-president Al Gore, whom Mr Bush defeated in November's controversial election. Mr Gore's wife, Tipper, was reported to have telephoned Lynne Cheney, wife of the new vice-president, to apologise for the mess.

A story on the cybergossip Matt Drudge's sometimes uncorroborated website yesterday said that prosecutions could follow the investigation by Harriet Miers, a newly appointed presidential assistant and the Bush administration's staff secretary.

Ari Fleischer, White House press spokesman, said yesterday that the new administration would be reviewing the reports but refused to go into details about any incidents and said no legal action would be taken. "Whether things were done that were perhaps less gracious than should have been, it is not going to be what President Bush focuses on, nor will it be what his staff focuses on."

One report said graffiti had been painted on a door frame saying "Office of Strategery", a reference to a Saturday Night Live spoof on Mr Bush's occasional difficulty with multisyllabic words.

The evidence is said to include obscene messages on answering machines and misconnection of phones, and some printers were found to have pornographic pictures interspersed among blank paper loads. Filing cabinet drawers had been glued shut, the report claimed.

The reports coincide with claims that Mr Clinton's last ride in Air Force One, from Washington to New York on Saturday afternoon, was the occasion for an orgy of pilfering. The presidential plane was reported to have been "stripped bare" by souvenir-hunting members of the outgoing administration's staff. Among items missing were china, silverware, and salt and pepper shakers, most of which bear the presidential seal, according to a diary item in the Washington Times yesterday.

Old hands of the Clinton administration yesterday said that when they took over the White House from Mr Bush's father's administration in 1993, they also found a few unpleasant surprises left by the previous tenants - including in several desk drawers a prophetic note inscribed: "We'll be back."

fields.headline: Passports row: net spreads
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The controversy over the exact circumstances in which a billionaire Indian businessman applied for a British passport threatened to engulf a second government minister last night as the scope of the official inquiry was widened to embrace the entire nine-year saga.
fields.body:
The controversy over the exact circumstances in which a billionaire Indian businessman applied for a British passport threatened to engulf a second government minister last night as the scope of the official inquiry was widened to embrace the entire nine-year saga.

Keith Vaz, Europe minister, became embroiled in the controversy that ruined Peter Mandelson when the Conservatives tabled a clutch of parliamentary questions about his involvement with the controversial Hinduja brothers.

The investigation, by former Treasury solicitor Anthony Hammond QC, will include letters written by Mr Vaz to the Home Office asking about progress on the applications for UK passports from SP Hinduja and his brother GP Hinduja.

Sir Anthony promised Downing Street a report on the affair within "weeks not months", before the expected May general election. The QC started reading key documents yesterday amid a welter of new allegations.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, last night ordered his officials to check official records for his contacts with the Hindujas. The Tories also demanded to know why Mr Vaz, described by Downing Street as "an important point of contact with the Asian community", had written to Mr Blair or Mr Mandelson about the Indian tycoons. The Hindujas are not his constituents.

"What are the full contents of Mr Vaz's representations on their behalf?" asked William Hague, who raised the campaign stakes further with a fresh personal attack on Tony Blair's role. The prime minister could not distance himself from "a culture of spin, cronyism, dishonesty and deceit" by sacking his Northern Ireland secretary, Mr Hague said, "because the values he represents are still there" in the shape of Mr Blair himself.

It was confirmed that Mr Vaz, MP for Leicester East, a Goan Catholic who is Britain's first ethnic Asian minister, did write letters to the Home Office asking about progress on the applications for UK passports from SP and GP Hinduja.

Mr Vaz said last night he was "very relaxed" about the affair, but would not comment further because of the inquiry.

Sir Anthony will read Mr Vaz's letters, as well as any relevant correspondence dating back to the brothers' first, abortive application in 1990. No 10 confirmed that the QC's terms of reference will allow him to range over the whole 1990-99 period.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP whose Commons questions elicited Mr Mandelson's weekend evasion - which cost him his political career on Wednesday - established last night that both brothers were turned down for a UK passport in 1990, apparently because they had not spent enough time in Britain. By then the first allegations of corruption involving a huge arms deal in India had surfaced. The pair made inquiries again in 1994 but were warned by the then Tory immigration minister, Charles Wardle, that he could not help them.

It also emerged that the Hindujas threw a party in honour of Mr Hague, and the former prime minister Sir Edward Heath served as a trustee on a research institute founded by the brothers.

The party, which was held after Mr Hague became Tory leader in 1997, was designed to give him a chance to meet members of the Asian community, according to Surina Narula, a leading Asian Tory. A Tory spokesman declined to comment.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, also told Mr Baker last night that GP Hinduja had successfully applied for a passport in March 1997, when John Major was still in power. He got his passport later that year under Labour.

SP Hinduja applied again on October 20 1998, days after the Hinduja donation to the dome's faith zone was confirmed. Though he denies any improper pressure, Mr Mandelson's brief call to Mr O'Brien came in late June, after the Hindujas had offered up to £3m. It was Mr Mandelson's initial claim that his private secretary had made the fateful call that led to his resignation.

fields.headline: Gore to teach people a lesson
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Al Gore broke his post-election silence yesterday with the announcement that he plans to teach and write for the next few months while he considers his political future.
fields.body:
Al Gore broke his post-election silence yesterday with the announcement that he plans to teach and write for the next few months while he considers his political future.

He said he would give a series of lectures on the relationship between the news media and public policy to graduate students at Columbia University school of journalism in New York, beginning next month.

He also intended to lecture on "community building" at two universities in Tennessee, his home state, and to write a book with his wife Tipper, about families.

"I'm not considering anything political right now, but I haven't ruled out thinking about such things later on," he said.

The Democratic presidential candidate has kept an exceptionally low profile since he conceded victory to George Bush on December 13, emerging only to complete his last public duties as vice-president.

"I've always wanted to try teaching ,and I'm particularly excited about teaching these courses on community building, because it's something new and to me it's very exciting," he said yesterday.

His announcement comes as the Democratic party begins to assess the lessons of the election and take the first tentative steps towards the challenge to Mr Bush in 2004. Its possible candidates include the senators John Kerry, Joe Lieberman and Hillary Clinton, Governor Gray Davis of California, and Congressman Dick Gephardt. But none has even hinted at standing yet, and the field is unlikely to take shape until Mr Gore declares his intentions.

Significant differences over the lessons of the Gore campaign have emerged among Democrats since Mr Bush's inauguration last week.

Left and right accuse him of veering too far towards the other camp. Some on both sides say he was simply a bad candidate.

The argument signals the start of a serious battle for the soul and direction of the party post Bill Clinton. It is being closely watched by the British Labour party, where the rival advisers of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have been quick to draw the conclusions that suit them.

At an election postmortem seminar in Washington this week, the centrist Democratic Leadership Council condemned Mr Gore for a "populist" campaign which emphasised "class warfare".

Mr Clinton's pollster, Mark Penn, said Mr Gore had failed to build on Mr Clinton's winning formula of fiscal responsibility and a smaller, more activist government.

The former White House pollster Stan Greenberg's assessment lays more of the blame on Mr Clinton.

"The right's cultural war to bring down Clinton and the impeachment took its toll," he said

Steve Rosenthal of the trade union federation AFL-CIO said Mr Gore's did best in the election when he tried to separate himself from Mr Clinton, and when he adopted a more aggressive stance in support of working-class families.

The Green candidate, Ralph Nader, told the seminar: "Gore beat Gore ... He was so waffling and wavering."

 Fidel Castro said yesterday that he hoped President Bush was "not as stupid as he seems". In a speech in Havana he said: "Someone very strange, with very little promise, has taken charge of the great empire we have as a neighbour."

webTitle: UN cannot punish Iraqi oil surcharges

fields.headline: UN cannot punish Iraqi oil surcharges
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A new and damaging crack opened in the international sanctions against the Iraqi regime yesterday when the United Nations accepted that it cannot penalise oil firms which make illegal payments to Baghdad.
fields.body:
A new and damaging crack opened in the international sanctions against the Iraqi regime yesterday when the United Nations accepted that it cannot penalise oil firms which make illegal payments to Baghdad.

Iraq is demanding that its customers pay a surcharge of 40 cents a barrel straight to the regime, in violation of the sanctions.

"If there is a violation - if it's among the oil buyers - it's up to their governments to take action," a UN official said.

Given the widespread belief that the sanctions are crumbling, few governments will be eager to prosecute, so the companies will probably get away with paying the surcharge, industry analysts believe.

Evidence may be hard to get, moreover."Paying a surcharge is hard to prove, particularly when Iraq is dealing with the sort of smaller, lesser known traders," Raad Alkadiri of the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consultancy, said.

Iraq's recent oil sales have been to obscure firms registered in Russia, Belarus, Leichtenstein, Ukraine, Sudan, Malaysia and South Africa. Through middlemen, two big companies, BP Amoco and Exxon Mobil, have recently bought Iraqi crude, but they say that their suppliers have not paid the surcharge.

So far no company has admitted paying surcharges, despite the strong industry suspicion that some are doing so.

Iraq's aim is partly to discredit sanctions but also to maximise the amount of money it receives outside the UN's control.

Under the sanctions, payments for Iraqi oil are meant to go into an account controlled by the UN. Almost half the money is assigned to compensating victims of the 1991 Gulf war, feeding Iraq's Kurds, and paying administration costs.

Iraq suspended its oil exports - about 5% of the world total - last month because of the dispute over surcharges.

They resumed a few days later, but at only 600,000 barrels a day, well below the previous 2.3m barrels. Since then sales have crept up again.

In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday: "We continue to advise UK companies that the payment of any surcharge to the regime outside the oil for food programme would be a breach of sanctions.

He said the government would "investigate thoroughly any apparent breach of sanctions". In Britain this would be done by HM customs, and abroad by embassies and "other sources".

fields.headline: France gridlocked by pension protests
fields.standfirst:
Anger at bid to raise retirement age to 65

Audio: Stuart Jeffries in Paris
fields.trailText: Thousands of French workers went on strike yesterday in protest against a scheme which threatens their pensions and undermines their right to retire at 60.
fields.body:
Thousands of French workers went on strike yesterday in protest against a scheme which threatens their pensions and undermines their right to retire at 60.

Many urban areas were engulfed in chaos as trains, buses and domestic flights were cancelled as a result of the one-day action. There were demonstrations in 65 cities.

In Lille, firefighters who took to the streets to protest about pensions and the lack of resources for meeting safety standards clashed with riot police and sprayed them with foam.

One fireman had to have his hand amputated after one of the many teargas and stun grenades the police fired to control the 600 protesters ripped off a finger and badly damaged the rest of the hand. Eight people were injured, mostly by teargas, the police added.

Elsewhere the protests were less violent but equally disruptive. In the Nantes, teachers, police officers, rail workers and hospital staff took to the streets. Lyon, Montpellier and other cities were gridlocked throughout the day as those not on strike tried to drive to work.

Union leaders have promised more concerted industrial action if the employers' federation, Medef, does not listen to their demands.

They fear that under Medef's scheme 15m employees, most of them in the private sector, will have to continue working well into their 60s to collect a full pension.

France's pension system is jointly managed by trade unions and employers. Employees contribute to a state-run minimum pension fund and to two top-up funds which guarantee better retirement packages.

Medef is threatening to change the nature of these top-up funds unilaterally, saying that employees must continue working until they are 65 to receive the full rewards, to counter the rising cost of the system.

The head of Medef, Ernest-Antoine Seillière, has long warned that unless people work longer the system will collapse when post-war baby boomers begin to retire later this decade.

But Medef's decision comes at a time when the unions and the Socialists are pressing for a shorter working week and a better quality of life for employees. "We live in a modern country which produces more and more wealth, so it is possible to make sure that life is not just systematically about work," Bernard Thibault, head of the CGT union, said.

He has been backed by the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, who vowed that the state would step in to ensure that workers could continue to retire at 60.

"Contrary to what some people say, retirement at 60 is not a slogan or an outdated situation," he said. "The government is following this issue carefully and will assume its responsibilities if necessary."

Mr Jospin wants most of the country's labour force to work a maximum of 35 hours a week, as this could help the country reach his primary economic goal of full employment and bring a boom in the leisure industry.

Medef's insistence that workers retire at 65 acts against the government's plans to cut unemployment.

But a leader in today's Le Monde accuses the prime minister of taking on the employers' federation to court popularity for the forthcoming municipal elections.

"Indulging in polemics with Ernest-Antoine Seillière is just a diversion that does not go to the heart of the question which is this: is the French system of pensions in grave danger?" it says

Medef and the government are already at loggerheads over whether France should encourage economic migrants. The employers suggest that workers from abroad could fill the many manual vacancies; Mr Jospin is worried that this would undermine his full employment goal.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott on the election in Israeli

fields.headline: Israel grimly waits out the troublesome Palestinians
fields.standfirst:
People don't believe the election for premier will settle anything

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: People don't believe the election for premier will settle anything.
fields.body:
The election campaign in Israel ought to be vitally important business for the citizens of that country. Surely it concerns matters which touch on Israel's very existence and which will determine whether a generation of Israelis and Palestinians will live lives - and die deaths - shaped by war or by peace? But, as presented by Israeli politicians and as understood by the majority of electors, this campaign is about none of those things. Instead of debating peace, Israelis are lackadaisically turning over in their minds which of two ex-generals, both discredited in different ways, should hold the unenviable job of prime minister.

Indeed, some say that this is the most boring campaign in Israeli political history. The degree of disinterest, according to Mark Heller of Tel Aviv University, an expert on the Israeli political scene, is unprecedented. With less than two weeks to go before the election, polls suggest up to 20% of the electors may not vote at all, either abstaining or casting a blank ballot. Evidence of voter participation, like bumper stickers on cars, neighbourhood meetings, and canvassing, is scant, and few are watching the political broadcasts on television.

The reasons for this curiously vacuous response are partly to do with Israel's strange political system and partly with the country's failure to grasp that the relationship with the Palestinians has shifted radically in the past few months. The terms on which peace might be available have changed, yet Israel seems still to be living in a past when it had much greater influence over the way in which Palestinian aspirations were pursued. The polls show that Shimon Peres, who is not a candidate, would take more votes than Ehud Barak and might be able to beat Ariel Sharon. But this support for Peres seems to reflect less the thought that he would be a better leader for peace than a generalised discontent with the situation and with the two declared candidates. If Peres did replace Barak, as some have urged, these "votes" might in any case float away.

If there were a world contest for misconceived democratic arrangements, Israel would have a fair chance of victory. The divisiveness of Israelis always made it difficult to achieve the critical mass necessary to govern coherently, but the situation was made worse by the decision to change the constitution so that people vote separately for parliament and for the prime minister.

The idea was that leaders would come in with a big mandate which would make them more effective, both in terms of policy generally and in terms of relations with the parties in the Knesset. The result instead was that prime ministers got their big majorities, but that the larger parties were undermined, to the point where the two biggest, Labour and Likud, cannot now even achieve a majority together. Israelis vote in a "national" frame of mind for the prime minister, but in an even more sectional way than before for the Knesset. Any Israeli prime minis ter now faces a cohabitation with chaos, as he tries to appease an unruly gaggle of secular, religious, and ethnic interests and the parties that represent them. A powerful personality may be able to overcome these odds, as many once hoped Barak would, but it is inherently difficult.

Israelis see a contest just for the premiership, as on February 6, as one which will settle little. Whoever is elected - Barak, Sharon, or Peres, if he should replace Barak as candidate - will face the same unamanageable parliament, and will have little freedom of movement on any front. The likelihood is that general elections to choose both a new prime minister and a new Knesset will have to come soon, and these will certainly feature Binyamin Netanyahu, prevented from joining the present contest. In other words, more important choices are just down the road, so why bother overmuch with what are essentially interim decisions?

This inclination is reinforced by the fact that there is little mainstream discussion in Israel of how best to work for peace. The consensus is that Barak offered the maximum possible, so now the problem lies on the Palestinian side. Israel has no op tion but to wait until the Palestinians come to their senses, a process assisted by tough Israeli military and economic measures. All Israeli leaders can do is to offer slight permutations of the Camp David proposals, as Barak is still doing in the talks in Taba, or propose an interim settlement, as Sharon says he plans to do. There is nothing that can be decided in an Israeli election campaign, on this argument, which will affect the fact that the only policy toward the Palestinians is to wait them out.

Some, like the American analyst Anthony H Cordesman, suggest that this violence-strewn "waiting" could go on for years. The trouble with the waiting game is not only that it takes lives almost every day but that with each death this conflict becomes more entrenched, and the still not wholly dissipated little capital of trust between Israelis and Palestinians wastes away. Nor is there any guarantee that the violence can be stabilised at some particular level. There may be a joint interest, as Cordesman suggests, in avoiding "excessive" violence, but that kind of violence could surely come, by accident, or by the design of either side.

One exception to the rule that Israeli prime ministers are usually weak is that they can authorise large scale military operations, particularly if they are ex-generals. Escalation cannot be ruled out, and at its worst, it could force Arab neighbours, however reluctantly, to take action against Israel. This may be remote, but it would be foolish to believe it could never happen.

In the face of such dangers, the sad thing about the Israeli election campaign is that the proposition that Israel needs to offer significantly more to achieve peace simply cannot be discussed, because it is beyond the limits of the possible except for a minority of radicals. On the Palestinian side it may be that feelings have reached such a point that even if by some miracle Israel did bring itself to make an improved offer it might still be rejected.

Whether there is any real exploration of these possibilities going on at Taba seems unlikely. Yasser Arafat ought to want to avoid a Sharon government and, if he does, he must know that some signal of progress from Taba might help Barak. Barak himself seems to be calculating that once he can get Peres out of the picture he will be able to pick up the extra votes he needs to have a chance of victory. If he won, Sharon might behave, as most seem to think, in a circumspect way, but his history suggests there is no guarantee of that. Barak as prime minister would be preferable to Sharon. But he would come in not as the peace candidate he once appeared to be but as a man pledging to hold the fort against all assailants through bad times to come.

fields.headline: Congolese put Belgium on trial
fields.standfirst: Families sue Brussels for murder of independence hero Patrice Lumumba
fields.trailText: Families sue Brussels for murder of independence hero Patrice Lumumba.
fields.body:
Days after burying one assassinated leader, the Democratic Republic of Congo is to rake over the bones of another.

The son of the murdered independence leader Patrice Lumumba goes to court in Kinshasa today to sue Belgium, Congo's former colonial master, for killing his father.

The hearing was originally due on January 17, the 40th anniversary of Lumumba's death, but it was delayed by the assassination of President Laurent Kabila, who always claimed that he had modelled himself on Congo's first elected prime minister.

The parallel case is due to be heard in a Belgian court next week.

Roland Lumumba, 43, the nationalist leader's youngest son, says he is bringing the action against Belgium, several Belgian individuals, and a CIA officer in an effort to establish the truth about his father's death.

It has long been suspected that the Belgium ordered Lumumba's death, and its role has been highlighted recently by a film and several books.

The Assassination of Lumumba, by the Flemish expert on Africa Lugo De Witte, claimed that he was assaulted in the presence of Belgian officers, tortured in a villa guarded by Belgian troops, and shot by an execution squad supervised by a Belgian captain.

His body was later exhumed by a Belgian police commissioner, Gerard Soete, and dissolved in acid.

Mr Soete admitted on Belgian television last year that he had kept two of the victim's teeth, prompting calls for their return to Congo.

He insisted that he had later thrown them into the North Sea.

"We are doing this not for revenge but to know the truth," said Mr Lumumba, whose case is being funded by the Belgian organisation Affaire Patrice Emery Lumumba.

"They have hidden it for 40 years and that is now enough."

Lumumba, a postal worker who became an inspirational anti-colonialist leader, was released from jail in 1960 to help negotiate independence terms.

fields.headline: Cisco buys into ailing Softbank
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Cisco, the US network equipment manufacturer, yesterday gave a $1.5bn vote of confidence to Softbank, the troubled Japanese internet investment group.
fields.body:
Cisco, the US network equipment manufacturer, yesterday gave a $1.5bn vote of confidence to Softbank, the troubled Japanese internet investment group.

At a time when many companies are cutting back on internet investment, the Silicon Valley giant is spending $200m buying a 1.65% stake in Softbank - which has struggled in recent months with the collapsing value of its online investments.

As part of the deal, the pair are setting up a $1.05bn fund run by Softbank which will target Asian businesses involved in broadband, optical, wireless and internet-based technologies.

Cisco has also agreed to buy back the bulk of Softbank's 12% share in Cisco Systems KK, its Japan operations, for around $275m after deciding to cancel plans to list the business on the stock market.

Shares in Softbank rose sharply as a result of the announcement, gaining 16.53% in a weak market. Investor reaction to Cisco's decision was less positive. At lunchtime in New York yesterday, its shares had fallen more than 3% to $41.2.

In announcing the deal, the highly acquisitive Cisco said that it wanted to increase demand for its internet switching equipment in Asia - and that it trusted Softbank to help it do so.

Robyn Jenkins, a Cisco spokeswoman, said: "Softbank has a broad experience of Asia, especially in internet investing, so we felt this was particularly appropriate."

Masayoshi Son, the chief executive of Softbank, said: "This is one of the most significant ventures Softbank has undertaken to date.

"We have had a close and successful relationship with Cisco for many years. We know each other very well, and know that we have unique synergies in working together."

The two companies started working together in 1994, when Softbank invested in Cisco Japan. The investment made by the California-based company makes Cisco the eighth largest shareholder in its Japanese partner.

fields.headline: Promoting the rottweiler
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson's resignation
fields.trailText: John Reid was tailor made to be a front man for Tony Blair. A man of certitudes: he had absolute certitude as a communist; as a militant trade union functionary; as an aide to Neil Kinnock when he was still remotely socialist. John Reid now has absolute certitude in the rectitude of New Labour.
fields.body:
John Reid was tailor made to be a front man for Tony Blair. A man of certitudes: he had absolute certitude as a communist; as a militant trade union functionary; as an aide to Neil Kinnock when he was still remotely socialist. John Reid now has absolute certitude in the rectitude of New Labour.

He always viewed disagreement with his prevailing certitude as treachery or a violation of the Holy Grail. If Mr Blair was under fire in Scotland Mr Reid in his previous job was sent on television to do battle and put the nation straight. No matter how absurd the brief he never blushed but instead looked intently into the camera and delivered the message - with absolute certitude.

As predicted - and no doubt for these services rendered to Number 10 - he is now deemed worthy of higher office as Peter Mandelson's replacement. Furthermore, in the Times earlier this year, we had already been told that Mr Reid was to be one of the select few who will spearhead New Labour's election campaign.

Mr Reid's credentials for such elevation have to be questioned. And any questioning should include scrutiny of the evidence submitted to MPs on the standards committee by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner. In essence this is concerned with allegations that Mr Reid misused parliamentary funds for party political/electoral purposes.

The evidence and findings were published on December 22, a time when parliament was closing shop for some weeks - a time of office parties, a void time for matters political. The timing was deliberate. Through the week New Labour spin doctors had been at work telling their trusted hacks that Mr Reid would be cleared. This duly appeared in the Scottish press. When the voluminous details were made public, the office parties were in full swing. Hopefully, from the government's point of view, the grisly facts would therefore be sunk without trace. I am fed up with New Labour's manipulation of a too compliant media. It was between Christmas and New Year, highly valued time in the Jimmy Reid calendar, that I took time to scrutinise all the documents. It was not an uplifting experience.

Members of the select committee had split along party lines. The majority are Labour. The verdict was comparable, in a partisan context, to that of the US supreme court's ruling on the counting of votes in the state of Florida.

If the verdict had been guilty, Mr Reid would have had to resign and all hell would have been let loose in the run up to the election: for New Labour this was something to be devoutly avoided. The select committee of MPs ruled the allegations not proven.

But Mrs Filkin had found that there was an arrangement, agreed by Labour party officials and sufficiently formal to have been incorporated within budget assumptions, whereby parliamentary office funds were used to supplement the party salaries of three researchers.

Mrs Filkin concluded that as their employers, John Reid and John Maxton MP must at the very least have been aware of the arrangement, if not involved in its instigation. She also had regard to the evidence of Mr Rowley and Mr Rafferty, senior officials with responsibility for the deployment of campaign staff. Their evidence, in her view, was corroborated by the evidence of Paul McKinney, formerly Labour's director of communications in Scotland, and Willie Sullivan, formerly Scottish development officer at SLP headquarters.

Messrs Reid and Maxton rubbished these witnesses as untrustworthy and driven by a grudge because of the circumstances in which they left the Labour party. If they were all untrustworthy, what does this tell us of New Labour, who appointed them to all these key positions? Or did they become "untrustworthy" only when they disagreed with Mr Reid?

But for me the real clincher was the transcript of the telephone conversation between John Reid and Alex Rowley, former general secretary of the Scottish Labour party, which ended:

AR: It also says in [Filkin's] letter "I shall ask if you prefer to give evidence to me under oath."

JR: Yeah, well, you can say "no".

Words I think have meanings in addition to their literal meaning. The language employed throughout the transcript has disturbing tones. There is menace abroad. Alex Rowley was told that if he didn't play ball he would never work again in the Scottish Labour movement. He didn't. He has now left Scotland to take up employment elsewhere.

It's not without significance that John Reid is widely referred to in Scotland as "the rottweiler".

 Jimmy Reid and John Reid were both formerly in the Communist party in Scotland.

fields.headline: Turn off the money tap
fields.standfirst:
The political need for big funding did for Mandelson. Relying on rich men is bad for democracy

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The political need for big funding did for Mandelson. Relying on rich men is bad for democracy.
fields.body:
In politics, where there's brass there's muck. Money and power make explosive chemistry: the struggle to separate the two has been the story of the birth of democracy since the first reform acts ended pocket boroughs and public voting. Yet the world's leading democracies are all mired in financial scandals. The stench of politicians trading favours and honours for cash hangs in a thick pall from the Potomac to the Rhine. Little of it concerns old fashioned Jonathan Aitken or Neil Hamilton back-handers. Most of it concerns raising private money for political parties or for semi-political projects like the dome. Enough words have sent Peter Mandelson on his lonely way: the man has paid a painful price. But the question remains - should democratic politicians ever be put into a position where they have to raise vast sums from rich men? As a mea culpa, Labour's manifesto should now include a pledge to end political fund-raising sleaze once and for all and commit to state funding and regulation of parties from now on.

The party conferences reek of ill-gotten cash, more each year that passes. Delegates and press alike are forcibly decked out in advertising slogans of sponsors on security passes. Everything is sponsored, chairs you sit on, air you breathe, all sponsors fruitily praised and thanked for the canapes and drinks at meetings or the printing of the party agenda packs, as ministers scuttle between gold plate dinners among the fund-raising access, easements and embellishments. Looking round the colossal exhibition halls at Labour's conference last year, the smell of lucre from industrialists, lobbyists, benefactors and even cash-paying fatcat charities overpowered the fish and chips. What were they all doing there, paying a small fortune for their showy booths to catch the politicians' eyes? Either it was for the personal vanity of CEOs who want to be there while their shareholders or charity fund collectors pay the bill - or it is plain cash for influence. An aroma of favours, the minister's ear, influence, greasy palms, the shimmer of power swills together in foetid hotel meeting rooms. Innocent by US standards, nothing like the ostentatious company champagne flowing at Tory conferences in their glory days, still small beer - but this is how it begins.

Its tentacles reach out to the think-tanks and party affiliates. Those that can persuade potential benefactors that they have the true ear of their party leaders can expect rich rewards in sponsorship money. Is it because companies, banks or management consultancies genuinely want to nurture creative new political thought? More likely they hope that linking their name to a close party organisation will somehow, some day ease their way into whatever it is they want - a contract or just a pleasing rubbing of shoulders with the mighty for their managing director.

It is the big money from the millionaires that is most lethally damaging. Asil Nadir, Jeffrey Archer, Michael Ashcroft, the Hindujas, Bernie Ecclestone, Michael Wheeler, Stanley Kalms, Robert Bourne - whether eccentrics or sincere believers, whether paying to steer the party's ideology or paying for naked gain, the mud always sticks. And it sticks both ways. Scrupulously honest men like David Sainsbury or Paul Hamlyn get tarred with the same brush by the simple act of giving to a cause they support: in politics generosity is turned to acid spite. There is no free lunch, there is no donation without strings. Even those who want nothing are still using their deep pockets to promote the party of their choice. But the days of buying elections must be over now. A royal commission should be appointed to devise a generally acceptable fair funding formula: there is no perfect system, but anything is better than government by millionaire.

Labour has been oddly tentative about this. Not because it has anything to fear - it is the Tories who might suffer more from fair state funding. The Blairites fear that politicians and parties are so thoroughly loathed that the public would rebel at taxpayers' money paying for Millbank and Central Office. This super-caution on all electoral reform is Labour cowardice: part of the reason for cynicism, low turnout and sinking public trust is because of the slush money. On the doorsteps too many people say: "None of them! They're all the same, only in it for themselves!" They do not distinguish clearly between dubious party fundraising and criminal lining of politicians' pockets. Voters would be easily persuaded that a piffling sum from the Treasury - around £50m - is a price well worth paying for seagreen incorruptibility. A royal commission would have to devise a quid pro quo for state funding: the IPPR points out that present near-derelict parties would need a duty to engage voters with a recruit-or-die formula instead of running local democracy as private fiefdoms.

On February 16, the Neill/Nolan reforms come into force obliging revelation of all gifts over £5,000 and banning foreign donors. But each revelation only adds to public contempt. This election each party will be capped at £20m, money splashed all over the country in gigantic hoardings selling incredible promises and preposterous insults against the enemy that bring politics into disrepute. People will rightly see this as money badly raised and badly spent, futile frittering of fortunes to virtually zero electoral effect, offending the voters' IQ. Trade unions (30%) and individual big donors (20%) now pay for half Labour funding: an unknown but higher proportion of Tory costs are paid by companies and big donors. Tony Blair said he was "absolutely proud" of the mega-donations from successful entrepreneurs. He cannot be serious - but how can he admit it is shaming and humiliating to a democratic leader?

This is a pretty clean government. Venality accusations just don't stick to Tony Blair, Gordon Brown or the rest - so how have they allowed Eccelstone and Hinduja allegations to sink them in the mud? Because big money will always corrode politics. Helmut Kohl's giant reputation for uniting Germany when lesser leaders might have hesitated now lies in perpetual ruin because of illegal channelling of £600,000 in undisclosed donations to his party. French president Jacques Chirac and his party likewise are mired in allegations of selling building contracts for party-funding deals. As for George Bush, nearly £.5bn was raised and spent in hard and soft money - hugely more than Al Gore: the indulgences it bought are already rolling out. How is the west to high-horse it over third world dictatorships diverting national treasuries into Swiss bank accounts if our own democratic elections are financed by cash for favours?

This is Labour high ground and Labour should go for it, do it now and defy the Tories to defend the buying of votes by plutocrats.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText:
Float
Discount
Cuts
Positive
fields.body:
 Float Computer games firm Warthog yesterday said it would float on the stock market and has raised £5m to develop games for mobile phones and digital TV. The shares, placed at 43p each and valuing the firm at £18m, are set to start trading on London's Alternative Investment Market at the beginning of next month.
