webTitle: Misys and Baan lift moribund IT sector

fields.headline: Misys and Baan lift moribund IT sector
fields.trailText: Software firms Misys and Baan yesterday helped calm fears about a slowdown in information technology spending by delivering slightly better than expected trading figures.
fields.body:
Software firms Misys and Baan yesterday helped calm fears about a slowdown in information technology spending by delivering slightly better than expected trading figures.

Executives at Misys, which specialises in systems for the banking and health care sectors, said they saw no evidence of slowing demand, and predicted that earnings growth would be back to the 20% level the firm historically registered before fears of the millennium bug hit software spending.

Dutch group Baan, rescued by UK software and engineering group Invensys last summer following nine consecutive quarters of heavy losses, surprised investors by announcing that it had become profitable again six months ahead of schedule.

Dealers expressed relief at the two announcements, which followed a raft of profit warnings from other technology firms. However, they said they would also be keeping an close eye on scheduled revenue updates from firms such as Baltimore Technologies, Autonomy and Logica, before giving the software sector a clean bill of health.

Although Misys pretax profits for the six months to November 30 were down from £48.3m to £37.4m year on year, they were marginally ahead of most analysts' expectations, and made chairman Kevin Lomax optimistic that last year's slow sales would soon be forgotten.

"For the year as a whole, we expect a much better year and a progressive return to the group's long term [earnings] growth rate of 20% per annum," he said.

Order intake was strongly ahead of last year, and there was no evidence that a slowdown in the US economy was affecting demand from important customers like investment banks, Mr Lomax added.

Revenues in Misys' crucial banking and health care division grew just 3%, but insurance revenues climbed 66% to £153m. Group revenues for the period were up 20% to £413m, and the dividend was lifted 15% to 1.6p per share.

Shares in Misys were the biggest risers in the FTSE 100, climbing 42.5p to 659p. However, they still trade at less than half the price they commanded last year.

Invensys shares also rallied, up 10.75p to 185.5p, on the back of its upbeat Baan data. The firm said that the combination of a cost-cutting programme that saw 1,000 Baan workers made redundant, rapid revenue growth and several new customer wins had enabled it to break-even at an operating level.

It had previously said that was unlikely to happen before the end of June.

Total sales climbed 37% to $100m, while license revenues more than trebled to $32m.

Shares in troubled Anglo-French software group Sema staged a rare rally, up 39p to 410p, on reports that it plans to hire investment banks Credit Suisse First Boston and NM Rothschilds to advise it on a restructuring. Sema has issued two profit warnings in as many months as it struggles to integrate a £3bn US mobile phone billing company.

Much criticised chief executive Pierre Bonelli said earlier this week that he was preparing to step down following a slump in Sema shares leaving them valued at one-sixth of the level they traded at less than a year ago. Rival Logica has been rumoured to be preparing a bid but yesterday a company spokesman insisted: "We haven't made a bid [for Sema] and we don't intend to."

fields.headline: Executed Saro-Wiwa tried again
fields.trailText: Ken Saro-Wiwa, the writer and Ogoni activist hanged by the Nigerian military government five years ago, is once again on trial - this time before the country's truth commission.
fields.body:
Ken Saro-Wiwa, the writer and Ogoni activist hanged by the Nigerian military government five years ago, is once again on trial - this time before the country's truth commission.

The families of four Ogoni chiefs murdered by Saro-Wiwa's supporters have told a special hearing by the commission, which is investigating human rights abuses under military rule, that he was responsible for the killings and deserved to hang.

Saro-Wiwa's supporters say he was the victim of a conspiracy between the army and Shell to break the Ogoni protests.

Saro-Wiwa,leader of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop), was hanged with eight supporters in November 1995 after a widely discredited military tribunal convicted him of ordering the murder of the four chiefs because they questioned his confrontational tactics in the Ogoni campaign for political autonomy and against Shell's dire environmental standards.

The executions, which coincided with a Commonwealth summit in New Zealand, drew strong world condemnation.

Although abroad he was widely regarded as a peaceful environmental activist, Saro-Wiwa kept a tight political grip on Ogoniland.

His opponents there accused him of using brutal tactics against dissenters.

The families of the four chiefs told the truth hearings that Saro-Wiwa used Mosop's youth wing as a personal militia against opponents, and that he condemned the chiefs to death by denouncing them as collaborators with General Sani Abacha's government.

"Saro-Wiwa's faction of Mosop unleashed terror on the community. They set up vigilante courts where they tried innocent Ogonis for unimaginable crimes and executed them by burying," the families said in their submission.

"We are here to seek justice and compensation for the loss of our fathers," Joseph Kobani, brother of one of the murdered chiefs, was reported to have told the panel in Port Harcourt.

But Ledum Mitee, the present Mosop leader and the only one of the Ogonis on trial with Saro-Wiwa acquitted, said the hanged men were victims of a long conspiracy between Nigeria's various military rulers and Shell.

He accused the oil company of arming the police and military so that they could crush opponents of its drilling in the Niger delta. He alleged that armed men had on several occasions used Shell-owned boats and helicopters in attacks on Ogoni villages. Shell is expected to make a submission later in the hearing.

Military officers have also been called to testify about their role in Ogoniland. Abacha's former deputy, General Oladipo Diya, said the hanging of Ken Saro-Wiwa was wrong. "The execution I regretted at the time it was done."

But Colonel Paul Okuntimo, head of the task force accused of brutally suppressing dissent in Ogoniland under the dictatorship, was unapologetic.

"If God did not send me Ogoniland, there would be no Ogonis today. I was a saviour, not a butcher," he told the hearings. "I am their redeemer. I am the embodiment of truth. You people should be grateful to me that you are living. You should worship me."

Asked why he had once told a news conference that he knew of more than 200 ways to kill people and that the Ogonis had discovered only three or four, he said the statement was "psychological warfare".

Mr Mitee said: "If soldiers with the attitude of Colonel Okuntimo are allowed to walk free, then this panel will come to nothing."

Before the hearing, the commission's chairman, Justice Chukwudifu Oputa, visited Ogoniland and offered an emotional apology.

"We all know that the Ogoni people, along with tens of other communities in the Niger delta, have suffered excessively [and] many precious lives were lost," he said.

"I call on you to forgive and forget the past ... This is what many of your gallant children who lost their lives would have wished for."

webTitle: Chip designer Imagination Technologies lands 3D deal

fields.headline: Clouds lift as chip firm lands 3D deal
fields.trailText: Chip designer Imagination Technologies yesterday signed a marketing deal which it hopes will put its three-dimensional graphic chips into three-quarters of the world's mobile phones as well as into television set-top boxes.
fields.body:
Chip designer Imagination Technologies yesterday signed a marketing deal which it hopes will put its three-dimensional graphic chips into three-quarters of the world's mobile phones as well as into television set-top boxes.

The deal, with Cambridge-based ARM Holdings, will mean Imagination's Power VR graphics chip will be integrated into many of ARM's forthcoming microprocessors.

Imagination's share price leapt 15.22% to 297.5p yesterday as a result of the announcement.

The good news for the Hertfordshire-based company has come just in time - analysts were concerned that its profits could be hit after a key customer, the Japanese video games maker Sega, was said to be abandoning Dreamcast, its poor performing games console. Approximately 22% of Imagination's revenue is thought to stem from Sega.

Robin Saxby, ARM's chairman and chief executive, yesterday said that the first products to market will be next-generation mobile phones and set-top boxes, followed by in-car navigation technology.

Hossein Yassaie, the chief executive of Imagination, added that if Sega were to pull out of the games console market, Imagination's Dreamcast chips could be used in set-top boxes.

Shares in ARM closed down 7.5p at 559.5p.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip.
fields.body:
Does anyone remember when Ross Kemp got his bald head bitten by mosquitos in Alaska? No? Well it was one of those TV moments that make years of sofa-dwelling worthwhile.

It was in the genre of "celeb gets dropped in the middle of nowhere and is left to fend for himself with only a video camera for company". Our Ross was dropped on the edge of a very scenic lake, as I recall, and told to build his own shelter (which he did, but it flooded while he went to look for wood, so he had to build another one). The camera crew duly slunk off at sundown, leaving Kemp with only a gun and a cuddly bear provided by his (quite famous) girlfriend for company.

Needless to say, especially if you watched the Without Motive dramas on ITV last year, he survived. Even if he did wake up to find the paw-print of something very large and grizzly right outside his tent. Scary!

And now Jamie Oliver lookalike Ewan McGregor is having a go. He's currently slogging it out in a South American jungle, learning how to survive for a BBC1 programme, Trips That Money Can't Buy. The hour-long special should be on our screens later this year, assuming he does survive (one wonders what the companies insuring these actors think of all this Tarzan business).

But a final question remains. Is McGregor the right frontman for a programme called Trips That Money Can't Buy? Surely McGregor could afford just about any trip he wants, anywhere in the world, even one that involved swinging from vines in deepest Peru. After all, he charitably set up a stage company earlier this month, and he's about to reap the rewards of his second Star Wars role.

Honestly, these celebrities, they'll do anything to make us like them.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I've found an address for my violent ex's mother - should I contact her?
fields.trailText: I've found an address for my violent ex's mother - should I contact her?
fields.body:
The question

Fifteen years ago, my former husband's mother, with whom I had always been on very good terms, suddenly moved and cut herself off from everyone for no reason that I could figure out. For a while I tried to contact her, but without success. Then, last year, I discovered her address on a CD-rom that we had on trial at work.

My dilemma is whether or not to write to her. The thought that she might be a lonely old lady tempts me to do so - she was widowed before we lost touch and had no other relatives, having quarrelled with all her sisters long before I ever knew her.

She now has two little great-grandchildren that she does not know about, but I do not want to do anything that might mean re-establishing contact with my ex-husband. He was violent, always lied and was sometimes in trouble with the police; my son would never forgive me if I did anything to bring him back into our lives. It may be because of him that she disappeared.

Should I leave well alone, or risk contacting her? I thought of using a PO box number, but that seems a bit devious.

Get in touch

I do not have any experience of mothers-in-law but I do have experience of ex-boyfriends' mothers. It is a sad truth that when a couple breaks up, it is more than just the partner you are breaking up with. I certainly miss the mothers of my ex-boyfriends.

If you considered your mother-in-law to be a friend, then it is worth getting in touch with her. Don't regret what you didn't do. She may well be lonely but too proud, or too ashamed (given her son's behaviour) to contact you.

As for having to be in touch with your ex, unless he and his mother have a close relationship - and you imply they don't - I don't see any reason why he should know about you being in touch with her. Together you could support each other and forge something positive out of your former relationship.

Something good always comes from a bad experience. Good luck.
Liz Ford
London

Check your motives

This woman has chosen to cut herself off. She fell out with half her family and liked the sensation so much that she chose to lose touch with the rest as well.

Ask yourself whether the temptation to try to fix things for her is part of a general trend in your life to pick people who need fixing. That could be why you chose such a difficult husband.

Are your motives even murkier than that? Are you really hoping to hear that your ex has got into even more trouble without you? If I got in touch with my alcoholic ex's family, it would be in the hope of hearing "bad news" of that sort.

Be truthful with yourself. Read Women Who Love Too Much (by Robin Norwood, published by Arrow, priced £6.99). Sort yourself out and let your ex-husband's dysfunctional family go to hell in their own way.
Name and address withheld

You're the needy one

Your former mother-in-law sounds like trouble in several ways. First, contact with her could lead to unwelcome contact with your ex-husband; second, if she is lonely and comes to depend on you, she could be a bigger burden than you could cope with; and third, she is obviously not easy to get on with. A relationship with her is unlikely to be two-way or rewarding for you or your family.

However, you clearly feel compassion for her. This has proved a tender trap for many people - I'm one of them. It starts with a tremendous need to be needed; we also press support, company and help - not always wanted! - on to all and sundry. But this need can be met in many ways in your community, perhaps by voluntary work.

There can be only two results of any approach and both rule out the need for contact. Either her self-isolation has hardened over the years, in which case she is probably not approachable. Or she has changed and has plenty of happy relationships, in which case she won't need you. However, writing care of a PO box number is a great idea - it meets your need, lets her know you care and she can choose to respond or not.
Agnes Weeks
Durham

Next week

I have lived with my partner for eight months (we had dated for two years). I knew he had three children (now 12, 17 and 19) but was naive to the emotional complications involved. I can't seem to come to terms with sharing him with three significant others he in turn shares with someone else. I'm 37, have led a full life, have no children and would like a family with this man whom I love dearly. He recently underwent a vasectomy reversal which was unsuccessful. He seems to have so much in terms of his "other life". I fear that I will always feel a poor second to his children.

I've tried getting to know them by inviting them to stay occasionally and joining us on holiday (it allowed me to see them as individuals and we did get along fine). I've also tried distancing myself.

My partner tells me they are not competition but feels I'd be better off with a "free" man who could give me children as he doesn't want to be the cause of any future bitterness for me. We want desperately to stay together but I for one don't know how to achieve it.

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words.

fields.trailText: Can it be that her Turncoat of Turncoats candidacy is affecting my old friend Barbara Roche?
fields.body:
 Can it be that her Turncoat of Turncoats candidacy is affecting my old friend Barbara Roche? Andy Roberts writes enclosing an answer from the enchanting Home Office minister to his letter about the poisonously neo-Alabaman and disastrously failing voucher system for asylum seekers.

Barbara takes a strong line on such people, as we know, but even by her own standards the reply is eccentric. "Mr Roberts feels that the voucher system is discriminatory," she writes to Andy's MP. "I do not agree... Mr Roberts will be interested to know that the National Asylum Support Service has received very few complaints about the voucher system from asylum seekers which suggests they are content with the way the scheme operates."

But of course. The aversion of these scared, displaced people to writing complaining letters to authority figures in a language they cannot speak is irrefutable proof of how well it's all working. Given this, it seems odd that Babs then admits the government is "reviewing" this piece of vicious rightwing thuggery. Still, there we are. Babs knows best.

 Meanwhile, 11-4 Turncoat co-favourite Peter Hain, benefits from Mandy's demise. Peter has been promoted out of the Foreign Office to take over at Energy.

Admittedly this will reduce his scope to pontificate piously as to why cancer-stricken Iraqi children must be denied medication, but at least the oil angle to his new job will give him a chance to keep his hand in. We wish Peter well in his posting, and look forward to watching him prosper.

 It is not this column's way to labour a point, but worries voiced here over recent times about David Yelland's memory crescendo alarmingly. The alopecian Sun editor yesterday described Mandy judiciously as "a lying, manipulative, oily, two-faced nasty piece of work who should never have been allowed near government in the first place."

David, have you no recall at all? Fifteen months ago, you wrote a leader headlined "The Sun welcomes Mandelson's return", a few days after actively campaigning for his reinstatement. "He is close to Blair and a bright, determined, ambitious politician," Old Slappy wrote. "He would have the gravitas and intellectual firepower to sort things out. The quality of the cabinet is not that strong if you remove the top five or six ministers under Blair. They need Mandelson back." Is it coming back now? No? Oh dear.

 Such is our concern for David that we are actively examining the possibility of having him committed under the Mental Health Act, on the grounds that so poor is his memory, we fear that he is liable at any time to forget that he left the gas on and thus blow up his house.

Consultant psychiatrists are asked to contact the Diary on Monday morning as a matter of urgency to discuss the next step. Raj Persaud will do in an emergency.

 One of the redeeming pleasures of recent days has been seeing old friends on the telly. Little Timmy Allan has been everywhere (and looking so grown up too!). So has Dolly Draper, once New Labour's very own Arthur Daley but now, when not adroitly knifing his old boss, more concerned with new age crystals than high politics.

Just one thing. You've been wearing the same remarkably hideous brown shirt and jumper combination all week. Get a change of clothes, there's a good lad, before the next round of knifings begin.

 Strange news from the BBC. Several members of staff ring to report that the Beeb is now employing someone called Elvis Presley. Although he has no phone extension, confirmation comes when we send Elvis an email and it doesn't come back in what I suppose we must call "return to sender" mode.

Exhaustive research in the grand "check, check and check again" tradition of the Diary conclusively proves the matter: a similar email to Roy Orbison is bounced back to us within seconds.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: An account of a trip through the contested Western Sahara, page 18, January 22, mentioned that Polisario fighters were wearing fake designer clothes from a batch confiscated in Britain and sent to the area by the relief agency War on Want. The charity has asked us to make clear that its clothing consignment was sent to the Sahara refugees as a whole.
fields.body:
An account of a trip through the contested Western Sahara, page 18, January 22, mentioned that Polisario fighters were wearing fake designer clothes from a batch confiscated in Britain and sent to the area by the relief agency War on Want. The charity has asked us to make clear that its clothing consignment was sent to the Sahara refugees as a whole.

In early editions of the paper, page 19, January 22, a leading article said that "defused responsibility" made it hard to prosecute companies or their officials suspected of safety lapses resulting in deaths. This was corrected later to "diffused".

A documentary about General Pinochet's Caravan of Death will be screened in Correspondent on BBC2 at 7pm on Saturday, not on Sunday as we said in a headline to an article about the programme, G2, page 17, yesterday. We got the date right in a footnote to the piece.

A comment piece about Peter Mandelson's resignation, Media victim? It won't wash, Peter, page 21, yesterday, suggested that Mr Mandelson made a call about Srichand Hinduja's passport application while he was Northern Ireland secretary. Mr Mandelson made the call in June 1998. He was appointed Northern Ireland secretary in October 1999.

webTitle: John Reid need to be quick to achieve peace

fields.headline: Tough negotiator must move quickly to achieve Ulster deal
fields.standfirst:
New man takes on job at crucial moment

Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: New man takes on job at crucial moment.
fields.body:
One thing John Reid has in common with Peter Mandelson, his predecessor as Northern Ireland secretary, is that he too is stepping into the Belfast job at a crucial time in the peace process.

The 13th secretary of state and the first Catholic - something he is keen to play down - admitted his appointment came as a surprise but pledged to do all he could to make the Good Friday agreement work.

He is said to be an extremely quick learner and a tough negotiator. He will need to be with time fast running out to try to broker a deal on decommissioning, demilitarisation and policing that is acceptable to both unionists and republicans.

As the general election nears, hardline pressure on Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble grows, and dissident violence increases, every hour and every move counts if he is to save the province's first power sharing government in 30 years.

Yesterday, as he arrived at Stormont to meet officials and security chiefs, loyalists linked to the mainstream Ulster Defence Association were being blamed for storing six pipe bombs in the roof of an east Belfast primary school and planting a device under a car in Ardoyne, a nationalist area in the north of the city.

Most local politicians gave Mr Reid a cautious welcome, while acknowledging the difficulties he will face.

The Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor, called him a "safe pair of hands". But there was a touch of regret over losing Peter Mandelson, whom he said had the "ear of the prime minister", although the new secretary of state has a good relationship with Tony Blair.

The SDLP deputy leader, Seamus Mallon, said: "He is coming at a time when we are almost, I believe, at the threshold of either succeeding or failing completely to get this thing moving properly. He will have a substantial role to play and I will give him every support possible."

Sinn Fein, however, which preferred to deal directly with the prime minister over Mr Mandelson's head in the past few months, insisted it was British policy not individual personalities that mattered.

Sinn Fein's chairman, Mitchel McLaughlin, said it would be looking to Mr Reid "to promote, defend and act as a guarantor of the Good Friday agreement".

Unionists hope Mr Reid, a former armed forces minister, will be sympathetic to their view that security in Northern Ireland cannot be scaled down while the dissident threat remains and mainstream paramilitaries refuse to get rid of their weapons.

But Mr Reid's past role in the Ministry of Defence has already earned him criticism from nationalists. He supported two Scots Guards, Mark Wright and James Fisher, who retained their army posts after being convicted of murder and serving a jail sentence for shooting dead an unarmed Catholic teenager, Peter McBride, in Belfast in 1992.

Mr Reid met representatives of the two soldiers but refused to meet the McBride family. However, it is understood he is now willing to meet the McBrides in his new role.

fields.headline: Chancellor savours his schadenfreude balti
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Looking at Gordon Brown yesterday, one suspected that on Wednesday night he had got himself gloated as a newt. (And finished off the evening with a schadenfreude balti.)
fields.body:
It's all right to gloat," someone wrote just after Margaret Thatcher resigned, "gloating is part of the process."

Looking at Gordon Brown yesterday, one suspected that on Wednesday night he had got himself gloated as a newt. (And finished off the evening with a schadenfreude balti.)

The departure of Peter Mandelson, the man who shafted him over the Labour leadership all those years ago, had been Christmas, Hogmanay and his own wedding reception rolled into one. He was in the middle of a chutzpah hangover. No doubt there is a powder you can take - Beecham's Revenge, perhaps.

He looked like Goliath learning that the playoff with David was best of three, and he'd taken the last two bouts.

Even the Tories noticed. "He's on very good form today," said a voice that sounded like Eric Forth, the backbench boot boy.

And he was. The chancellor arrived clutching a huge ragged pile of papers as if, with his throbbing head, he had scooped up everything on his desk before scuttling down to the house. The bundle also says, "Look, I'm a very busy man running Britain's booming economy. It's really damn kind of me even to come to talk to you."

Michael Portillo has been on good form lately too, even though William Hague and Ann Widdecombe appear to be still in place. He wanted to know why the government wasn't doing more to stop social security fraud. "Why does the chancellor lack the willpower to do something about it?" he demanded.

Mr Brown looked as if he hardly had the willpower to roll over in bed. But he braced himself and launched into an attack on the Tories.

The Speaker (whom many MPs still call "Mr Deputy Speaker", by accident I suppose, though it may imply that they can't quite believe that he has the top job) interrupted gruffly. Could he suggest that the chancellor limit himself to answering for the government and not criticising the opposition? At least I think that's what he said: halfway through his remarks, Mr Martin usually tails off into his native Glaswegian. Either way Mr Brown ignored his advice and continued to belabour Mr Portillo as if he were the chancellor instead.

The next question was trickier. This concerned the Equitable Life scandal, a subject of huge concern to MPs since very many of them have their pensions tied up in this troubled company. What makes it worse is that two years ago Equitable asked the Treasury if it could stiff some of its borrowers in order to carry on trading. The Treasury advised that it could, and this in turn led to the near collapse.

How could Mr Brown wriggle out of answering this in front of his angry colleagues? The solution was to hand it over to Melanie Johnson, the economic secretary, a minister who is to great oratory what hippos are to line dancing. What Miss Johnson does is read a civil service brief. She reads it out in a dull, dogged, determined way, as if she almost understood what it was saying.

When incredulous MPs tried to get some answers about how the scandal had been allowed to happen, she found another part of the brief and read that out too.

"The report will describe the regulatory work and will indeed identify any lessons to be learned," she mouthed, to sarcastic cries of "Wonderful!" The Treasury, she actually dared say, did not give investment advice. Except to companies like Equitable Life, she failed to add.

On and on she went. Miss Johnson is like the Duracell bunny, but makes less sense.

Mr Brown glowered beside her. He clearly needed the hair of the dog - a double nemesis with tomato juice and a stick of celery, perhaps.

webTitle: Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly averts vote defeat

fields.headline: Rebels force u-turn on care for elderly averts vote defeat
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive has embarked on a collision course with Westminster after a parliamentary rebellion forced the first minister, Henry McLeish, to offer free long-term care for all Scotland's pensioners.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive has embarked on a collision course with Westminster after a parliamentary rebellion forced the first minister, Henry McLeish, to offer free long-term care for all Scotland's pensioners.

Minutes before a vote on the issue in the Scottish parliament yesterday, the executive announced a dramatic policy u-turn and said it would implement plans to fund long-term care for all pensioners.

Scottish pensioners will now get free personal care, including bathing, changing dressings and assistance with eating - services that pensioners in England and Wales will continue to pay for.

The government thought it had repaired its reputation with pensioners by promising to increase pensions faster than inflation this year, but the policy split between London and Edinburgh may make it harder for Labour to garner the grey vote at the forthcoming election.

The decision to implement the care package, at a cost of £110m a year, reverses the announcement by Mr McLeish just a day earlier when he had offered a scheme that stopped short of the universal free care recommended by the Sutherland royal commission.

Facing certain defeat after a stormy debate on the issue yesterday, the parliament minister, Tom McCabe, revealed the free care in an emergency statement.

The u-turn had been brought about by the prospect of a cross-party rebellion which threatened to see Labour's LibDem coalition partners desert them to join an axis of SNP and Conservative MSPs and reject the compromise care package.

The decision opens the biggest policy rift yet between Holyrood and Westminster. Mr McLeish, who had hinted when he took office that he wanted to implement the Sutherland recommendations in full, was said to have been pressed by Downing Street not to offer a vastly superior care package in Scotland because of the problems it would create, not least raising the spectre of care being decided by postcode.

The issue is highly emotive and campaigners are unhappy with the existing deal in England and Wales where nursing care is free but personal care is means tested.

Paul Burstow, Liberal Democrat health spokesman, said the decision in Scotland "would mean that a Scottish pensioner choosing to move into a nursing home in England would get free personal care, but the English person in the next room would have to pay for it. This is like the tuition fees anomaly all over again."

About 40 Labour MPs have signed a Commons motion calling on the government to reconsider its stance.

The charity Help the Aged said: "We can't have a system that gives better care for people in Scotland than in the rest of the UK. That goes down the road of creating a new postcode lottery. The NHS is meant to provide care at the point of need throughout the UK and should not be dependent on where people live."

webTitle: Reid at centre of row over intimidation

fields.headline: Reid at centre of row over intimidation
fields.standfirst:
New Northern Ireland minister 'tried to frustrate standards inquiry'

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: New Northern Ireland minister 'tried to frustrate standards inquiry'.
fields.body:
Only four weeks ago John Reid, the new Northern Ireland secretary, was at the centre of a row for threatening and intimidating witnesses who gave evidence to an inquiry by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, into the forbidden use of taxpayers' cash for the benefit of the Labour party. She claimed that Mr Reid's conduct amounted to "an attempt to frustrate my investigation".

The report contained an extraordinary tape-recording showing an increasingly irascible Mr Reid pressing witness Alex Rowley, the former general secretary of the Scottish Labour party, just before he was due to be interviewed by Ms Filkin on the scandal.

The inquiry began after a complaint by journalist Dean Nelson, then with the Observer. He reported that Mr Reid, then Scottish secretary, and John Maxton, Labour MP for Glasgow Cathcart, had employed three researchers, paying their salaries from the MPs' official allowances. He claimed that the three, contravening the rules governing publicly funded MPs' researchers, were involved in Labour party campaigning. One was Mr Reid's son, Kevin.

The parliamentary commissioner upheld the complaint, but MPs on the standards and privileges committee overturned her findings. The money was about £16,000 to pay the salaries of the researchers; and not all their working time was spent on Labour party campaigning. There is no suggestion that Mr Reid misused the money for any other purpose.

The main body of Ms Filkin's report, however, concentrates on the way Mr Reid and Mr Maxton - who later apologised - had interfered with four witnesses to the inquiry. They were Alex Rowley; John Rafferty, former Scottish Labour party campaign co-ordinator; Paul McKinney, former Labour party director of communications in Scotland; and Willie Sullivan, former Scottish development officer for the Scottish Labour party.

Ms Filkin said "the conduct of Dr Reid caused serious and increasing concern" as her inquiries proceeded. "I was left with the impression that many witnesses felt under considerable pressure as to what they should, or should not, say to me and how far, if at all, they should co-operate with my inquiry."

In a strongly worded conclusion she found that loyal members of the Labour party had been put under enormous pressure not to provide her with evidence that could damage Mr Reid's explanation.

Misleading

On Mr Rowley in particular, she said: "It is clear that Mr Rowley felt, and continues to feel, under pressure from Mr Reid to say things to me which he does not wish to say and which he regards as not wholly accurate or even misleading. And so far as other witnesses are concerned, he has told me: 'I have to say to you that I find it quite astonishing that many young people such as Annmarie Whyte [Scottish Labour party office manager] are being put in the position by one of the most senior politicians in Scotland that they are having to give dishonest information to the parliamentary commissioner for standards. I have been told that others whom you have contacted have felt under immense pressure'."

Ms Filkin commented in her report: "I view this conduct by Mr Reid as an attempt to frustrate my investigation."

She went on: "I have, for example, received evidence from Mr Rowley that, during two conversations shortly after my investigation began, Dr Reid made threats of a particularly disturbing kind to Mr Rowley, the thrust of which was that if he 'gave evidence which admitted doing wrong' he 'could face criminal prosecution and risked not being adopted by the party as a parliamentary candidate'.

She reports: "Mr Rowley was so concerned by Dr Reid's attitude that he decided, albeit reluctantly, to record their next conversation on tape. During these exchanges, which took place during a telephone call .. it is clear, both from his choice of words and the tone he adopts, that Dr Reid is seeking to agree a line with Mr Rowley which falls short of a full and comprehensive account of the events of which they both have knowledge. Thus, at one point Dr Reid says to Mr Rowley: 'You don't have to tell any lies. Do you know what I mean?' And later he adds: 'They cannot prove anything, Alex'. Towards the end of the conversation Dr Reid strongly discourages Mr Rowley from giving evidence to my enquiry on oath."

She reported: "I would add that Mr Rowley's protectiveness towards former colleagues and his continuing loyalty to the party made him initially unwilling to allow me to treat either his statement alleging threats to him by Dr Reid or the transcript of his telephone conversation with Dr Reid as evidence which I could quote in my report. webTitle: Mandelson to fight to stay on as Hartlepool MP

fields.headline: I'll fight to continue as MP, town told
fields.standfirst:
Fallen minister plans to stay on in Hartlepool

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the fallen Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday announced that he has decided not to stand down as Labour MP for Hartlepool at the coming election.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the fallen Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday announced that he has decided not to stand down as Labour MP for Hartlepool at the coming election.

"I'm going to concentrate on being a good constituency MP. I intend to fight for Hartlepool and its people," Mr Mandelson told his local paper. He also claimed that stepping down had been easy this time.

"I'd just had enough. Not the job, just all of the other stuff that goes with it," he said before leaving Belfast for the London flat he acquired after his 1998 resignation over his controversial £374,000 mortgage, now redeemed.

Mr Mandelson will now concentrate on wooing his disaffected constituents. But the general election will be fought without him being at the centre of Labour's strategic planning, Downing Street confirmed - as the Tories demanded assurances that he would not play the kind of behind-the-scenes role in which he once excelled.

"I think it's clear he won't in any sense have anything like the sort of role that was envisaged," No 10 said. "Peter is making it pretty clear he intends to remove himself from the political scene."

Party sources moved to fill the void left by the departure of Mr Mandelson by confirming that Douglas Alexander, 33, MP for Paisley South and the current general election coordinator, will expand his brief. Mr Alexander is already permanently housed at party HQ in Millbank, and has been responsible for overseeing advertising, the quality of the attack unit and research material.

Mr Alexander, a byelection victor in 1997, is close to Gordon Brown. He is widely admired in Labour circles for having a cool head on young shoulders. Until this week he was deputy to both Mr Brown and Mr Mandelson. Before the 1997 election there was no need for such a post since Tony Blair, Alastair Campbell, Mr Brown and Mr Mandelson in opposition were focused full-time on winning the campaign.

It means Mr Alexander will stay right in the middle of events during the campaign itself, rather than taking a back seat once the big guns arrive when polling day is announced.

The role of John Prescott, who did not get on with Mr Mandelson, may also grow at Millbank, though he is committed to campaigning in the regions. Ian McCartney, the Cabinet Officer minister, who is acceptable to all three men, may fill part of the gap.

In private senior Tory strategists believe that Mr Mandelson's departure is of less significance in terms of the campaign's management or his reputation as a media manipulator than his ideological influence as the man who helped rush Labour rightwards into the centre ground where elections are won.

That could mean greater influence over Labour's manifesto and campaign tactics for Mr Brown. "They may even be better off without the campaign being run by two men [Mr Brown and Mr Mandelson] who can't stand each other," said one Tory official. "The question is what will the political impact be on tax policy, the balance of the manifesto and the precise angle from which they attack us. Are Gordon Brown's instincts different from Mandelson's, for instance, on a new 50p in the pound tax rate? Yes, Mandelson saw what a stupid thing it was to do."

While Mr Blair assured cabinet colleagues yesterday that Labour will next month unveil new policies - what voters want more than this week's "froth", aides said - Mr Mandelson revealed his intentions to the Hartlepool Mail, his local newspaper, which had earlier reported growing "We've Had Enough" hostility to their famous MP.

With what some Labour MPs thought was a mischievous touch the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, told the Today programme on BBC Radio 4 yesterday: "Peter Mandelson remains an MP and a member of the Labour party and I am sure he would want to play a role, if only knocking on doors and delivering leaflets."

webTitle: Refugees hounded out of Bradford estate

fields.headline: Vandals hounded refugees out of Bradford estate
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Splinters of window glass and a mangled pushchair mark the site of the siege of Ferriby Close, a six month campaign of violence which has led to Britain's first eviction of thugs who terrorised asylum seekers.
fields.body:
Splinters of window glass and a mangled pushchair mark the site of the siege of Ferriby Close, a six month campaign of violence which has led to Britain's first eviction of thugs who terrorised asylum seekers.

At least two more houses on the hilltop estate in Bradford will shortly be boarded up like the six on the Close, where families from Poland, Latvia and the Czech republic said they could not stand the persecution any longer.

"We have started the eviction process against a barbaric and idiotic minority and we will see it through," Kris Hopkins, a Bradford city councillor, said yesterday. "Anyone who comes to Bradford is going to be treated like everyone else."

The evictions are the first in the country specifically triggered by harassment of asylum seekers - including stone throwing and attacks on children which has nauseated neighbours in the cul de sac.

"They were decent people," said Jack Howgate, a retired bus driver whose semi now looks out on eyeless houses with every window sealed by metal grilles. "I lent them my lawnmower when they moved in last summer and they got into the habit of coming over and mowing my lawn after they'd done theirs."

Further up the close, Billy Smith, 23, started weight-lifting sessions with Derek, the burliest of the Czechs, who have moved with the other Ferriby families to undisclosed addresses in Bradford. "They were OK," Mr Smith said. "There was a problem with English but there was a nine-year-old kid called Vanessa who did loads of translating. The trouble is, there are a lot of idiots on this estate - the same ones who stone the buses and spray the drivers with that smelly stuff you get from joke shops."

There was wider resentment, however, said Derek Learoyd, a night shift truck driver who lives in Ferriby Close. "There was jealousy when their houses were redecorated ready for them," he said. "Nothing against the families themselves, but everyone round here's been waiting for ever for repairs."

Initial abuse in the street was followed by stones through windows and trailing of families when they went shopping or to school. Over Christmas, most of the asylum seekers went to see relatives in London and Kent and returned to find their houses burgled and vandalised.

The estate's residents' association, Fagley Action Group, tried to use the local grapevine to explain that government refugee money, not Bradford cash, had paid for the repairs.

"We're not standing for a situation where the majority of decent people on estates dare not protest, because they think they'll be out on a limb and the council will just pussyfoot around," said Mr Hopkins. "We're using our standard tenant enforcement policy, agreed with all tenants. This case happens to involve asylum seekers but we'll do the same for anyone who gets picked on."

webTitle: Questions over choice of Reid for Ulster job

fields.headline: Questions over choice of Reid for Ulster job
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Conservative party yesterday raised "serious questions" about the appointment of John Reid as Northern Ireland secretary, saying the parliamentary commissioner for standards published damning evidence about his behaviour only a month ago.
fields.body:
The Conservative party yesterday raised "serious questions" about the appointment of John Reid as Northern Ireland secretary, saying the parliamentary commissioner for standards published damning evidence about his behaviour only a month ago.

The commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, found that Mr Reid had in his previous post as Scottish secretary tried to frustrate her inquiry into the use of taxpayers' money for party political use by the Scottish Labour party by intimidating witnesses.

Tim Collins, the Conservative vice-chairman, said: "The Mandelson saga does show that the prime minister is an appalling judge of character. Given the mistake he has made in his choice of his past Northern Ireland secretary, it is all the more important that the next one should be seen to be a person of the highest possible character, especially given the sensitivities of the province at present."

The Scottish National party also criticised Mr Reid's appointment. Mike Russell, SNP education spokesman and formerly the party's election campaign manager, said: "Dr Reid is a politician who there are question marks over in terms of his ability to do straight dealing with people. That has never seemed to be his strong suit. I don't think the prime minister's judgment was good in terms of Mandelson, and I don't think it is good in terms of Reid."

Ms Filkin's investigation found that Mr Reid had sought to get a key witness to "agree a line which falls short of a full and comprehensive account of the events of which they had both knowledge". The witness, Alex Rowley, the former Scottish Labour general secretary, according to Ms Filkin, "felt under pressure from Mr Reid to say things to me which he does not wish to say and which he regards as not wholly accurate or even misleading".

After listening to secretly taped conversations between Mr Reid and Mr Rowley, she concluded that Mr Reid's conduct amounted "to an attempt to frustrate my investigation".

She also complained Mr Reid had tried to persaude Mr Rowley from giving evidence on oath.

Ms Filkin was examining allegations that work conducted on behalf of the Scottish Labour party by three researchers based in the Commons had been improperly funded by the taxpayer. One of the three researchers was Mr Reid's son Kevin.

Mr Reid claimed the allegations were baseless and driven by malice.

Ms Filkin upheld the complaint about improper funding, but the Commons standards and privileges committee rejected her conclusion.

Mr Reid has been seen as a safe pair of hands for Labour on TV, and is widely admired in parliament for his knowledge of defence and political philosophy.

webTitle: John Reid's political career to date

fields.headline: Kinnock aide's rise and rise
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: John Reid, the 53-year-old Northern Ireland secretary, was born in May 1947 in Lanarkshire, the son of a postman and factory worker.
fields.body:
John Reid, the 53-year-old Northern Ireland secretary, was born in May 1947 in Lanarkshire, the son of a postman and factory worker.

He was educated at St Patrick's Roman Catholic secondary school in Coatbridge. The new Scottish secretary, Helen Liddell, is another former pupil.

Reid, who is married with two sons, went as a mature student to Stirling University where he gained a doctorate in economic history.

He was an active member of the National Union of Students, becoming vice-chairman of the NUS in 1973.

Communist

For a brief two year period he joined the Communist party, but has been an active member of the Labour party since 1976. He became the Scottish Labour party's research officer in 1979, and played a prominent role in the election of Neil Kinnock as Labour leader in 1983.

Reid then became Kinnock's political researcher and then Scottish organiser of Trade Unionist for Labour from 1985-87.

He entered parliament as MP for the safe Motherwell North seat (now renamed Hamilton North and Bellshill) in 1987, joining Labour's front bench in 1989.

Reid was opposition spokesman on children and defence before becoming minister for the armed forces after Labour's victory in 1997.

He became transport minister in 1998 and joined the cabinet as secretary for state for Scotland in 1999.

fields.headline: Shooting victim denies throwing nail bombs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: The first person wounded by gunfire on Bloody Sunday to give evidence to the inquiry into the 1972 shootings described yesterday how soldiers shot him in the leg when he was a 15-year-old schoolboy.
fields.body:
The first person wounded by gunfire on Bloody Sunday to give evidence to the inquiry into the 1972 shootings described yesterday how soldiers shot him in the leg when he was a 15-year-old schoolboy.

Damien Donaghy, 44, admitted he had thrown stones at troops minutes before he was injured but categorically denied he had thrown nail or petrol bombs.

Lord Saville's tribunal into the killing of 14 men on a civil rights protest in Derry in 1972, has been sitting in the city's Guildhall since March. The tribunal will have heard from more than 1,000 witnesses when it finishes next year.

Mr Donaghy said he had just gone over to pick up a rubber bullet as a souvenir when he felt a sharp jab in his leg and fell on his back.

"I did not realise I had been shot until I put my hand to my trousers. I looked at my hand and it was covered in blood," he said.

"The bullet had hit me on the right side of my knee at a slight downward angle. It broke my femur and came out at the back of my thigh."

Asked about a soldier's claims that two nail bombs had exploded just before he was shot, he said: "That's lies."

As he lay on the ground he heard two gunshots which he was later told had struck the oldest victim, John Johnston, 59, who had been bending down to pick him up. They are thought to have been the first two shot on Bloody Sunday.

Both were carried to a nearby house but did not talk to each other. Mr Johnston died five months later.

A priest later took the wounded boy to hospital, where he remembered some paratroopers laughing at him as he arrived. He was treated for six months.

He said he was never asked to give evidence to Lord Widgery's original inquiry into the shootings in 1972, and despite being questioned by the police and his clothes taken away for forensic examination he was not charged with any offence.

Several witnesses have told the tribunal that they saw civilian gunmen in the Bogside that day.

But Mr Donaghy insisted: "I view what happened to me as attempted murder. I never saw any gunmen, or nail bombers. It was a peaceful march."

In an earlier statement he denied throwing stones, but he admitted it in the witness box. "At the time I was a bit afraid in case I would be charged with rioting.

fields.headline: Room at the top
fields.standfirst:
Aitken's London home for sale

Special report: the Aitken affair
fields.trailText: Aitken's London home for sale
fields.body:
The magnificent 37ft drawing room used to be the venue of one of the most vibrant Tory salons in London. It was famous for the champagne parties and the more sombre Conservative Philosophy Group meetings. Hosts at 8, Lord North Street, were Jonathan Aitken and his wife Lolicia.

Now, rather faded and chintzy, the five storey, seven bedroom Georgian house is up for private sale. Offers in excess of £2m, please. Strutt & Parker, the Sloane Street estate agents, said it was in need of "sensitive restoration".

The sale has been arranged by Baker Tilly, Mr Aitken's trustee in bankruptcy, who were appointed after the former cabinet minister's failed li bel action against the Guardian and Granada Television's World in Action in 1997 left him with costs of £2.2m and an 18-month prison sentence for perjury.

Strutt & Parker have produced 400 glossy brochures for their list of valued clients. There are colour photographs of the elegant dining room, the table laden with silver and crystal, and one of the main bedrooms with a floral baldaquin above the head of the bed. Coyly, the brochure failed to mention the last owner, but merely said that the house had "a fascinating history owing to its close association with the political establishment of this country. It has been home to many distinguished residents including Brendan Bracken, former minister of informa tion in Winston Churchill's war time cabinet."

The house is the main asset identified by Baker Tilly in Mr Aitken's estate. He originally argued that it belonged to his wife, a claim disputed by the trustee. Lolicia has obtained a divorce in Switzerland and now lives abroad.

Once the house is sold the money will be deposited in an account held by Baker Tilly. The trustee is then likely to go to court to seek permission to distribute the proceeds to Aitken's creditors, who also include the Inland Revenue. It will then be open to Mr Aitken and his family to make representations to the court.

If the entire proceeds are given to the creditors, Mr Aitken will have discharged about half of the money he owes.

fields.headline: Veterans 'must give pledge'
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Gulf war veterans have to give an assurance that they will not sue the Ministry of Defence before they are given their medical records, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Gulf war veterans have to give an assurance that they will not sue the Ministry of Defence before they are given their medical records, it emerged yesterday.

They have also been told that medical advice given by army doctors are classified and are exempt from disclosure under the code of access to government information.

Demands for assurances that they will not sue are revealed in letters released yesterday by the National Gulf Veterans and Families Association. The ministry told former sergeant Nick Vasques from York that he could have his records on condition he gave an "assurance that you do not currently plan to sue the MoD".

The ministry yesterday released internal reports on depleted uranium. It said: "We believe that there were no significant health risks posed to personnel who served either in the Gulf or the Balkans from exposure to DU." However, it added that it was consulting experts to establish an additional appropriate voluntary screening programme.

webTitle: Middle East peace talks continue despite another killing

fields.headline: Peace talks keep going despite another killing
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, choked back his anger last night and ordered his negotiators to continue the peace talks with the Palestinians which had resumed for barely an hour when an Israeli motorist was fatally shot in a car on the road between Jerusalem and Ramallah.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, choked back his anger last night and ordered his negotiators to continue the peace talks with the Palestinians which had resumed for barely an hour when an Israeli motorist was fatally shot in a car on the road between Jerusalem and Ramallah.

Nevertheless, the latest killing could yet deliver the death blow to the stop-start talks.

It happened 48 hours after two Tel Aviv cafe owners were shot dead in the West Bank town of Tulkaram. Their death prompted Mr Barak to suspend the talks until the funerals yesterday.

The negotiators had been talking for barely an hour when the latest killing came to light. But after conferring for an hour in a separate room, the Israeli team said the talks would go on.

"They talked with the prime minister and decided to stay," a senior Israeli source said.

Security sources said last night's victim was shot in the head as he drove near the Atarot industrial estate, just north of Jerusalem.

With only 12 days to go until Israel votes for a new prime minister, Mr Barak is desperate to persuade the voters that he remains a credible peacemaker.

For his part the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, has been galvanised by the increasingly real prospect that the hardline Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, could be Israel's next prime minister.

Although the burly general's 20-point lead has slipped in the past few days, most analysts say it would take a miracle for Mr Barak to be re-elected.

But that is what he and Mr Arafat want from Taba, in Egypt, where the talks are being held.

Earlier this week Mr Barak sent the most senior figures in the Israeli peace camp to the resort on the Red Sea to try to restore his reputation for peacemaking, which has been demolished by the 17 weeks of bloody chaos in the West Bank and Gaza.

Mr Barak and his campaign aides candidly admit that they do not expect the talks at Taba to produce a final settlement to the Middle East dispute.

At most, Mr Barak and Mr Arafat would like to hammer out a road map for future diplomacy which could prevent Mr Sharon, if he is elected on February 6, imposing his own hardline agenda.

In his first reaction last night, at a campaign rally for Russian immigrants in the coastal city of Ashdod, Mr Barak condemned the killing as "a despicable murder".

He swore that Israel would hunt down the killers, but he did not immediately call his negotiators home.

That could change, however. Mr Sharon and other rightwing figures criticised Mr Barak yesterday for his indecent haste in resuming the negotiations after the earlier killing.

webTitle: Air traffic incentive deal 'may undermine safety'

fields.headline: Air traffic incentive deal 'may undermine safety'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Senior air traffic controllers have been offered performance related contracts which could undermine the service's safety culture, the controllers' union, IPMS, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Senior air traffic controllers have been offered performance related contracts which could undermine the service's safety culture, the controllers' union, IPMS, warned yesterday.

The contracts included bonuses for reducing delays which gave controllers the incentive to cut corners, it said.

Iain Findlay of IPMS said the decision had been taken without consultation and was not the way forward.

"You cannot introduce the game of chance into a safety conscious system," he said. "It puts into their [the controller's] mind the notion that if they move planes quicker and closer together, they could get some sort of bonus."

Colin Chisholm, National Air Traffic Services chief executive, denied that the plan would compromise safety. "Most of our senior managers are already on personal contracts."

He said that the first and foremost requirement was to provide a safe service, "but you can't ignore the fact that our customers also require to get off on time, subject to safety."

Liberal Democrat's Michael Moore said: "The new performance-related pay contracts for NATS' managers will fuel the uncertainty that continues about the sell-off of air traffic control.

webTitle: UN war crimes prosecutor rebukes Yugoslav President

fields.headline: Del Ponte chides Kostunica
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The chief UN war crimes prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, delivered a stinging rebuke to Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica yesterday for preventing "any meaningful dialogue" during her meeting with him.
fields.body:
The chief UN war crimes prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, delivered a stinging rebuke to Yugoslav President Vojislav Kostunica yesterday for preventing "any meaningful dialogue" during her meeting with him.

Although claiming to be "disappointed" with Mr Kostunica's behaviour, Mrs Del Ponte said she would still wait two or three months to test the promises made by other government ministers, including that the law would be changed to allow for the arrest of the former president Slobodan Milosevic and his transfer to the Hague.

She was, however, "more encouraged" by Zoran Djindjic, the new Serbian prime minister, and other officials she met during this, her first visit to Yugoslavia since Mr Milosevic was charged by war-crimes prosecutors in the Hague with crimes against humanity two years ago.

"I remain cautiously hopeful that obstacles such as the lack of domestic legislation which allegedly hinders the surrender of indicted fugitives to the Hague will soon be removed," she said. "I didn't expect the immediate arrest of indicted war criminals, but I cannot wait years until fugitives are transferred to the Hague."

Because the tribunal is a UN body, Mrs Del Ponte has always insisted that handing over fugitives should be treated as a transfer and not as a matter of extradition to a foreign country.

She denied she was leaving Belgrade empty-handed. "The important thing is that Mr Djindjic and others recognise the obligation to cooperate. They say they must implement a new law and need two or three months before they can be fully active in cooperation," she said.

Serbia's new government formally took office only yesterday after elections in December swept Mr Milosevic's Socialist party from power. Several of the new ministers have hinted that they favour a trial for Mr Milosevic in a local court on charges of corruption and abuse of power.

Some diplomats have hinted this could be a useful start, but Mrs Del Ponte insisted that the Hague had "primacy". She indicated that her lawyers would collaborate with Serbian prosecutors, giving them information about money-laundering and the illegal transfer of Yugsolav state assets abroad.

At her parting press conference, Mrs Del Ponte had unusually sharp words for Mr Kostunica, who initially refused to see her but changed his mind after pressure from his government colleagues.

"My feeling is that he was practically forced to meet me. For half an hour I had to listen to him saying things which I already knew since he had already said them to the press. I tried to get into dialogue but it was practically impossible. He obviously wanted to make a political declaration," she complained.

Mrs Del Ponte said there was no scientific evidence to justify a war-crimes inquiry into Nato's use of cluster bombs and munitions with depleted uranium in the Balkans: "At this time their use is legal."

webTitle: Letsbuyit.com's new owners predict bright future

fields.headline: The world of Kim Schmitz
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The extraordinary new double act at the helm of Letsbuyit.com last night insisted that the crisis-hit e-tailer has a bright future - despite issuing Christmas sales figures which again missed analysts' expectations.
fields.body:
The extraordinary new double act at the helm of Letsbuyit.com last night insisted that the crisis-hit e-tailer has a bright future - despite issuing Christmas sales figures which again missed analysts' expectations. The chief executive, John Palmer, and his flamboyant white knight, a 27-year-old convicted German computer hacker named Kim Schmitz, insisted that a scaled back Letsbuyit.com would raise the 40m euros (£25m) needed to take it through to 2002, when it says it will be in profit.

"I'm completely convinced that Letsbuyit can reach profitability despite its current problems," Mr Schmitz said.

Their bullish assessment, combined with confirmation that Mr Schmitz's investment vehicle Kimvestor had agreed to provide 4m euros to stave off the threat of immediate bankruptcy, prompted frenzied trading of Letsbuyit shares on Germany's Neuer Markt.

Private investors and day traders piled into the stock, driving its price up by 220% to 77 cents as a record 87m shares changed hands, in the hope that the e-commerce site will imminently resume trading.

The duo said that unnamed new and existing investors are interested in putting up the 40m euros needed to push Letsbuyit forward, even though the business's major shareholder, Pro Sieben, said it did not intend to back the company further.

"We're in the final stages of negotiations and hope to make an announcement very soon," Mr Schmitz said.

British broadcaster BSkyB, which paid £10m for a 10% stake, is unlikely to consider injecting any more money until the Letsbuyit accounts - which have been heavily criticised by administrators - are put into some semblance of order.

Lehman Brothers analyst Heidi Fitzpatrick warned that a lot of work had to be done before Letsbuyit became a viable business again. Its fourth-quarter revenues, announced yesterday, were 18% below her forecasts at 18m euros and full-year revenues for 2000 of 38.5m euros were below the company's own published targets of 45m euros.

Mr Schmitz said that marketing spend would be reigned in, jobs cut and several offices around Europe closed to trim costs. "The Paris, Munich and London operations will be the core," he said.

Mr Schmitz's dramatic emergence as a potential saviour has caused amazement in financial circles. "I've seen some circuses in my time, but this one beats the lot," said one analyst.

Rags to riches tale

The former hacker has achieved widespread fame in his homeland after being convicted of bypassing the security of Nasa, the Pentagon and Citibank under the name of Kimble, after the character of Richard Kimble in the film The Fugitive.

After giving himself up to the authorities in the 1990s, Mr Schmitz developed an encryption service that claims to allow secure payments to be made over the internet and sold an 80% stake in this business to German credit firm TUV.

The 6'4", 18-stone giant has since divided his time between growing Kimvestor - which he values at 200m euros - and spending his money on top models, fast cars and expensive boats. He now owns a Challenger jet, a helicopter, several sports cars and a yacht. Last May he spent $1m (£684,000) chartering a 240-foot luxury yacht for a week, mooring it in Monte Carlo harbour for the Monaco Formula One Grand Prix and throwing lavish parties for guests including Prince Ranier of Monaco.

Later that year, the same group of friends flew in his private jet to the party island of Ibiza and then to a castle in Ireland for a pheasant shooting trip. Mr Schmitz has posted pictures of his escapades on his website www.kimble.org, which he claims has had 20m hits.

"We are having a lot of fun," he said. However, he remains deadly serious about Kimvestor, which is midway through a pre-flotation private placement round with a target of 20m euros.

"Anyone who buys shares in this placement gets a guarantee that their value will eventually triple or they get their money back," he said. "I will personally stand responsible for the state of this company, and you don't see many chief executives doing that.

"Kimvestor will achieve a market capitalisation of 1bn euros within five years."

fields.headline: 'Technical' rebuff for 30% of asylum seekers
fields.standfirst:
Home Office figures show applications at a record high

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Home Office figures show applications at a record high.
fields.body:
Nearly one in three asylum applications last year were rejected on "technical" grounds without their cases being looked at at all, according to the annual asylum figures published yesterday by the Home Office.

The statistics show that while the number of asylum applications reached a record 76,040, the highest in Europe, more than 26,630 were turned down on "non-compliance" grounds. In 1999 only 1,085 or 5% of all applications were refused on these technical grounds.

The Refugee Council last night said that the phenomenal rise in these refusals showed there was a flaw in the new "faster but fairer" asylum system that ministers claim they have put in place since last April. Between September and November the number of asylum seekers refused refugee status on "non-compliance" grounds was touching 40% of all claims.

Most of those refused entry on these grounds have failed to comply with the new requirement to find legal advice and complete in English a complex 19-page form within 10 working days. If they fail to do this, their asylum claim is rejected.

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said last night that the sharp rise in these rejections meant the Home Office had lost sight of the purpose of the asylum process - to provide sanctuary to those fleeing persecution. "If 40% of all applicants are rejected without their cases being looked at, then the system itself is at fault. This is a gross injustice on asylum seekers."

But the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, yesterday defended the practice, saying it was reasonable to expect asylum seekers to state their case within the time limits. "The form is not an exam or a test and you don't need a lawyer to complete it."

She added that significant numbers of asylum seekers were in Britain for some time before they made their claim.

The figures show that the 76,000 applications in 2000 were about 5,000 above the 1999 figure, with the greatest increases in applications from Iraq, Iran and Zimbabwe. A to tal of 110,065 initial decisions were made on asylum cases last year, with a further 19,000 resolved on appeal. The number of decisions reflected a £600m programme to try to get the backlog of cases down. The backlog has fallen from 103,495 in January 2000 to 66,196 now.

fields.headline: From fruit to a family fortune
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The Hindujas' late father founded the family business in Bombay and moved to Tehran in 1919. He dealt in dried fruit, tea and jute. The brothers took over in the early 60s, and expanded hugely.
fields.body:
The Hindujas' late father founded the family business in Bombay and moved to Tehran in 1919. He dealt in dried fruit, tea and jute. The brothers took over in the early 60s, and expanded hugely.

Gopichand Parmanand, 60, headed the Hinduja Group operations in Iran until 1978 and then moved to London. Srichand Parmanand, 65, followed. They live in St James's, central London.

Their businesses, run from New Zealand House (below) in the West End of London, span the globe, taking in chemical, oil and media concerns. It has made them Britain's richest Asian family, with an estimated fortune of £2bn.

They have given generously to charities and institutions, including the Victoria and Albert Museum.

Another brother, Prakash, 55, is based in Geneva and looks after financial interests while a fourth, Ashok, oversees the family's Bollywood film interests.

fields.headline: Sickness drug had devastating effects
fields.standfirst: Thalidomide may fight cancer
fields.trailText: Thalidomide was first made in West Germany in 1954 and introduced as a sedative and hypnotic two years later. It also became useful for combating morning sickness and came to Britain in 1958. By the end of 1961 it was sold around the world under more than 50 brand names.
fields.body:
Thalidomide was first made in West Germany in 1954 and introduced as a sedative and hypnotic two years later. It also became useful for combating morning sickness and came to Britain in 1958. By the end of 1961 it was sold around the world under more than 50 brand names.

By then, its devastating effects on unborn babies were evident and the drug was withdrawn. As many as 10,000 babies worldwide were born with disabilities attributable to its use.

Doctors in Britain were told not to prescribe it in November 1961 but it was not until summer 1962 that the public became aware that it had been banned. It is likely that remnants remained in bathroom cabinets for years afterwards.

The drug appears to have been at its most dangerous between three and five weeks after conception, and its effects do not appear to have been directly related to dose. Most tablets came in 50mg form, but mothers seem to have taken varying amounts.

Its most obvious consequences were in the limbs of babies, but there could be heart, facial and genital abnormalities. In the late 1960s, lawyers acting for British families reached a settlement with Distillers, the liquor company that marketed the drug here: governments had said the company had met the legal requirements of the time.

In the 1970s, the Sunday Times campaigned for a better deal for a new trust fund for families and licensing rules were changed.

fields.headline: Thalidomide may fight cancer
fields.standfirst:
Tablets that caused horrific birth defects thought to help shrink tumours

Sickness drug had devastating effect
fields.trailText: Tablets that caused horrific birth defects thought to help shrink tumours.
fields.body:
Thalidomide, the notorious drug that caused appalling deformities in thousands of babies 40 years ago, is making a comeback as a possible therapy for cancer.

Trials have begun on 30 British patients with inoperable lung cancer after indications that regular doses can help shrink tumours and prevent their return.

Scientists hope that within five years they will know whether thalidomide is an effective treatment for a range of cancers.

It was widely used between 1958 and 1962 as a wonder drug against morning sickness in pregnant women but caused horrific birth defects.

Other studies over the past 10 years, mainly in the US, have suggested that the drug can combat some other cancers and threats to the immune system through HIV and lupus. It has an American licence to treat leprosy.

Thalidomide appears first to stabilise blood flow around tumours where it tends to pulse and be chaotic. This can allow a better supply of traditional anti-cancer drugs administered through chemotherapy. But then it appears to block blood flow associated with the growth of new tumours.

It was this that damaged foetuses more than a generation ago and left babies without limbs. About 450 British thalidomide victims survive, with a further 5,000 in other countries.

The Cancer Research Campaign, which has funded some promising work suggesting low dose thalidomide treatment could help renal cancer, is funding the new project which has already recruited 13 volunteers with small cell lung cancer, which accounts for 9,000 deaths a year - a quarter of all those who die from lung cancer.

Researchers are looking for more patients for the study based at UCL/Middlesex and Guy's hospitals in London and Cookridge hospital, Leeds.

Gordon McVie, the campaign's director general, said: "It is an extraordinary bit of lateral thinking. Thalidomide has such awful connotations in most people's minds. It has been completely revisited by biologists because it has quite extraordinary properties."

He warned that it was "early days" but the research had exciting potential.

Dr Siow Ming Lee, one of the researchers, said: "Existing treatments for small cell lung cancer remain unsatisfactory and clearly finding new ways to improve the treatment of this disease is vitally important."

Patients are taking 100mg tablets of thalidomide each night for two years as well as having chemotherapy. Margaret Edwards, a 52-year-old grandmother, from Stevenage, Hertfordshire, sought out clinical trials when she was told the cancer, which had caused secondary tumours in the brain, was inoperable.

"I have nothing to lose, but if I can help someone on the way it is great and if it can benefit me and give me a little extra time, wonderful. I stopped being able to read and I have noticed over the last month that my abilities to read are returning and speeding up. I hope that's not coincidence."

Vivien Kerr, coordinator for the Thalidomide Society, said: "Some people have extremely strong views that it should never, never be used again because of the side effects and the impact it has had on their lives.

"It should really be used as a drug of last resort. If there is no other drug that has potential benefits in something like cancer, as long as guidelines are in place, are strict and properly monitored, particularly for women of child bearing age, we would not stand in the way."
