webTitle: High-flyer Hain forced to take sideways step

fields.headline: High-flyer Hain forced to take sideways step
fields.standfirst:
Foreign Office said to have wanted him out

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Foreign Office said to have wanted him out.
fields.body:
The call that brought an abrupt halt to the steady rise up the ministerial ladder of Peter Hain came at 9pm on Wednesday.

At that point, he was minister of state at the Foreign Office, with a much higher public profile than colleagues of a similar rank. Yesterday, he was at a new desk, at the Department of Trade and Industry, responsible for energy, a position that is a demotion or, at best, a sideways move.

The official view from Downing Street and the Foreign Office was that he was moved to a domestic job to broaden his experience. The unofficial view, summarised by a colleague, was: "They wanted him out. The Foreign Office had been expecting him to go."

Mr Hain received the all-important call at the Commonwealth Club, in Northumberland Avenue, a few hundred yards from the Foreign Office. He had been discussing with representatives from a foreign policy thinktank his pamphlet The End of Foreign Policy when his pager went off with a message to phone Tony Blair.

Mr Blair told him he wanted him back in domestic politics and that the energy job was an important one. Mr Hain was surprised and reluctant to leave the Foreign Office but it would have been political suicide to turn down a request from the prime minister.

Mr Hain, 50, was appointed to the Foreign Office in 1999 after demonstrating his loyalty to Mr Blair during a difficult spell at the Welsh Office. His time at the Foreign Office was to prove much more turbulent.

Liked by officials, he was innovative and refreshingly undiplomatic, using Commons privilege to name those alleged to be involved in illegal arms deals. He also took initiatives on issues such as conflict diamonds. He attracted controversy over his approach to Iraq, Zimbabwe, and South Africa, and the US plan for national missile defence.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who had been close to Mr Hain politically and personally, resented the easy relationship Mr Hain had with the press, and there was a frisson after Mr Hain criticised Robert Mugabe, the president of Zimbabwe, over the seizure of white-owned farms. The Foreign Office, too, is paranoid about any suggestion of a rift between it and Downing Street on issues such as national missile defence.

The logical reshuffle would have been to move his successor, Brian Wilson, to the trade and industry department, where he had worked before. That Mr Blair opted instead to put him in the Foreign Office adds to the view that Downing Street wanted Mr Hain out.

Mr Wilson is as independently minded as Mr Hain and also from the left of the party. He has a strong interest in trade issues, has campaigned against US sanctions on Cuba, was in the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament and raised funds for medical support for Nicaragua in the 1980s.

Mr Hain's new job may turn out to be temporary, with another, bigger reshuffle after the general election.

This is borne out by a second call Mr Hain received on Wednesday. That was from Sally Morgan, who works at Downing Street, the link between the prime minister's office and the party. She is consulted on all reshuffles.

Mr Hain questioned her about what the reshuffle meant and came away feeling he had been given a vote of confidence. As one of the party's freshest thinkers, his hopes of a cabinet job remain very much alive.

fields.headline: Smallbrow - big risk
fields.standfirst: A bid to help which could have misfired
fields.trailText: Boris Johnson, editor of the Spectator, seems to have found it a good jape to "out" Dominic Lawson, predecessor in his editor's seat, as Smallbrow, the spy agency's own codename for Mr Lawson.
fields.body:
Boris Johnson, editor of the Spectator, seems to have found it a good jape to "out" Dominic Lawson, predecessor in his editor's seat, as Smallbrow. "Who was Smallbrow?" the front cover of his magazine asked prominently yesterday. Inside, the Spectator answered its own question in a despatch from ITN's worldly Moscow correspondent, Julian Manyon. It transpires that, at any rate according to the Moscow-published memoirs of the renegade MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson, Smallbrow was the spy agency's own codename for Mr Lawson, who had helped an undercover intelligence officer in eastern Europe pretend to be a journalist "in the form of a letter commissioning him to write an article".

The Spectator article called this an "unexceptional act". It is certainly not the first time that the accommodating Spectator editor, who now edits the Sunday Telegraph, has been mentioned as a provider of these services to British intelligence. Last year it emerged that Mr Lawson had also published two controversial articles on the fighting in the Balkans from Keith Craig, another MI6 officer stationed there, who was writing under a false name. The explanation offered by Boris Johnson on Mr Lawson's behalf yesterday was that the former Spectator editor did not realise the truth about those with whom he was dealing. One might comment that to be thus misled twice looks very like carelessness.

There is a bit more involved in this than jolly japes. Recent intelligence defectors such as Mr Tomlinson and David Shayler have revealed a whole series of blurrings of the line between journalist and spy, ranging from the forging of National Union of Journalist press cards to the deliberate "planting" of false stories on newspapers. One consequence is that British readers are in danger of being misled. Another is that bona fide journalists are in danger of being arrested, or worse, by foreign regimes. That is irresponsible and risks lives.

webTitle: 'Teacher in a million' found dead in school

fields.headline: 'Teacher in a million' found dead in school
fields.standfirst:
Pupils and staff in shock as MBE-decorated assistant head is discovered hanged in outbuilding after suffering from depression

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pupils and staff in shock as MBE-decorated assistant head is discovered hanged in outbuilding after suffering from depression.
fields.body:
Staff and pupils at a secondary school were reeling last night after a teacher decorated for his dedication was found hanged in the grounds just yards from classrooms where lessons were ongoing.

Patrick Stack, 45, an assistant headteacher at Sedgehill school in Catford, south London, was awarded the MBE in the Queen's birthday honours last year for his efforts in "extension and enrichment", including vocational and life skills work.

Joe Montgomery, director for regeneration at Lewisham council, described Mr Stack as "a teacher in a million". In his eight and a half years at the school he developed a programme of out-of-school activities, including an internet club, a fashion show, and about 20 trips a year, including mountain climbing, whitewater rafting and visits to Russia and Nepal.

Colleagues became worried when Mr Stack, who was married with four children, failed to attend a meeting in school on Wednesday morning.

His body was discovered at noon by another member of staff in the school's minibus garage, just inside the front gates.

Pupils will be told today by staff that Mr Stack had been suffering severe depression which had got worse in recent months, though he had hidden it well. Police do not regard the death as suspicious.

His wife, Kathy, said in a statement last night: "His family and friends were and remain immensely proud of Patrick. We are devastated by his death and the circumstances surrounding it. I have lost a wonderful husband and my children, a devoted father.

"Pat was an extraordinarily talented and dedicated teacher who worked long and hard for the school and the community."

She appealed for her family to be left to grieve in peace.

When Mr Stack's body was found, headteacher Ilir Phillips immediately cancelled lessons and sent the school's 1,700 students home.

She sent a letter to all parents explaining the school would be closed yesterday "due to the seriousness of a tragic accident involving a member of staff". Counsellors will be on hand to support pupils when the school reopens today.

Pupils reported that teachers had said Mr Stack had been depressed in recent weeks, but this was not thought to be particularly connected to his time at the school.

One union leader, Nigel de Gruchy of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said Mr Stack's workload had been "herculean".

Teachers and students placed flowers yesterday by the building where Mr Stack was found. "Thanks for always having faith in me. For the good times and happy memories," said one dedication, from Sue. A year 11 pupil, Samantha, had written a poem which said of her teacher: "He would never ever judge. He would never turn and walk away." One tearful parent said the poem summed him up exactly. And from Leyla, Sarah and Kelly: "You were a friend to everyone. You touched our lives in so many ways."

Kelly Lloyd, 16, who said: "Every day he would walk past with a big smile on his face. He was really happy. He was one of the most popular teachers in the school."

Another pupil, Debbie Monk, 15, added: "He was the best teacher ever. I just wanted to tell you how we will all miss him every day. We will all be thinking of him. Whatever anyone says, they will never know the truth of what happened to him. He was the best teacher going."

Mr Stack, who lived in Forest Gate, east London, started his career as a social worker and primary teacher in east London. He later completed a degree in health and social and vocational studies at Durham University. He worked in several London schools before joining Sedgehill. There he also helped start an On Track club for year nine pupils who felt disaffected with school, and a girls' club which focused on assertiveness training and health.

Alan Howarth, the arts minister, had been due to launch a national award scheme, Artsmark, at the school yesterday. The event was postponed.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of Mr Stack's union, the National Union of Teachers, said: "Patrick Stack was an extremely hardworking and popular teacher. He was a highly regarded teacher who will be much missed by his pupils and colleagues."

He was the best teacher going." Mr Stack, who lived in Forest Gate, east London, started his career as a social worker and primary teacher in east London. He later completed a degree in health and social and vocational studies at Durham University. He worked in several London schools before joining Sedgehill. There he also helped start an On Track club for year nine pupils who felt disaffected with school, and a girls' club which focused on assertiveness training and health. Alan Howarth, the arts minister, had been due to launch a national award scheme, Artsmark, at the school yesterday. The event was postponed. Doug McAvoy, general secretary of Mr Stack's union, the National Union of Teachers, said: "Patrick Stack was an extremely hardworking and popular teacher. He was a highly regarded teacher who will be much missed by his pupils and colleagues."

webTitle: MI6's lawyers lose spy book appeal

fields.headline: MI6's lawyers lose spy book appeal
fields.standfirst:
Related stories:
Editor 'provided cover for spies'
Pen mightier than the sword
Russian colonel's defection an intelligence coup for Britain
fields.trailText: The attempt by government lawyers to delay what they admitted was inevitable - publication in the British media of extracts from a book by former MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson - collapsed in the appeal court yesterday.
fields.body:
The attempt by government lawyers to delay what they admitted was inevitable - publication in the British media of extracts from a book by former MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson - collapsed in the appeal court yesterday.

In a judgment dealing a blow to the Official Secrets Act, the court dismissed an attempt by the attorney general, Lord Williams, on behalf of MI6, to force newspapers to seek clearance before publication.

MI6 also wanted the Sunday Times, which brought the case, to have to prove information had come to the "widespread attention of the public at large".

Michael Tugendhat QC, for the newspaper, said it was ridiculous to expect editors to consult with intelligence officials, lawyers and judges as deadlines approached.

After hours of argument, the media can now publish information about the activities of the security and intelligence services "to such an extent that the information is in the public domain".

"It is not right that they [editors] should be subjected to a fetter on freedom of expression which goes beyond this," said Lord Phillips. What precisely constituted "the public domain" was up to the judgment of editors.

Extracts have been published in Komsomolskaya Pravda, A Russian tabloid, though the book is not yet widely available in Moscow. While British and Russian journalists in Moscow have copies, the court heard, the British embassy had not been able to find one.

John Wadham, director of Liberty, the civil rights group, welcomed the result: "It can't be right for Russian people to be able to read about the escapades of MI6 but for the people of this country - whose taxes pay for MI6 - to be unable to read the same information."

But Lord Phillips sitting with Lord Justice Tuckey and Lord Justice Longmore, said it was desirable there was "consultation" between the newspaper and MI6 before it published matters which might damage the agency.

webTitle: Scales of fortune favour bigger babies

fields.headline: Scales of fortune favour bigger babies
fields.trailText: Big babies are more likely to grow up to do well at school and university and tend to have higher scores in tests to measure their powers of reasoning than small babies, according to new research.
fields.body:
Big babies are more likely to grow up to do well at school and university and tend to have higher scores in tests to measure their powers of reasoning than small babies, according to new research.

It has been remarked before that seriously underweight babies, starting life at less than 2.5kg (5.5lb), tend to have lower scores in mental ability tests than those whose birth weight is within the normal range. A study published in this week's British Medical Journal is one of the first to compare the scores in cognitive tests of babies whose birthweight is considered normal to see whether size makes any difference.

The authors are Marcus Richards and colleagues from the Medical Research Council national survey of health and development, based at University College, London. They looked at the birthweight, cognitive test scores and educational performance of 3,900 men and women, all born in one week in March 1946, who were enrolled in the national survey.

They were divided into five birthweight groups, ranging from under 2.51kg (5.5lb) up to between 4.01kg (8.9lb) and 5kg (10.1lb).

They found that rising birthweight was associated with improved cognitive (thinking) ability in tests that were carried out at the age of eight, 11, 15 and 26, although less so when the subject took a different kind of mental ability test at the age of 43. Those who were bigger babies also tended to have better educational qualifications once they reached adulthood. Taking account of factors which are known to make a difference - sex, father's social class, mother's education, birth order and the mother's age - the link to birthweight was even stronger.

The crucial stage for mental development appeared to be from birth to the age of eight, however.

The growth in the children's reasoning powers appeared to be very similar for all groups between the ages of eight and 26, but those who scored highly at age eight had a continuing advantage over those who did not.

At the age of 43, those who had been the biggest babies did not necessarily perform better. The authors said this might be because a different sort of test, based on memory, had to be used. But they also speculated that life experiences - particularly education and employment - might have exerted an influence.

The authors pointed out that there were some limitations to their study. Although they took account of crude measures such as general socio-economic background, they could not adjust for specific factors in individual cases that have a known effect on birthweight, such as smoking, the mother's height, physical work, psychological stress and nutrition.

But they believed there were some possible explanations for the sort of link between birthweight and mental ability that they found. Babies who were heavier at birth often had a bigger head circumference than others, for instance.

There were three main risk factors which could lead to low birthweight in babies, they said: nutrition, smoking and alcohol misuse.

webTitle: Snack that left puppy on a knife edge

fields.headline: Snack that left puppy on a knife edge
fields.trailText: Shaggy dog stories are nothing new to Ann Draper and her colleagues at the People's Dispensary for Sick Animals, but they admitted amazement yesterday at a sword-swallowing puppy called Kyle.
fields.body:
Shaggy dog stories are nothing new to Ann Draper and her colleagues at the People's Dispensary for Sick Animals, but they admitted amazement yesterday at a sword-swallowing puppy called Kyle.

Taken to the vet's after "not being his normal self," in his owner's words, the 18-inch collie/terrier cross proved to have eaten a 15-inch long serrated bread knife.

"It was utterly astonishing," said Dr Draper, who runs the PDSA hospital in Leeds, where the huge shadow initially appeared on Kyle's X-ray like an enormous growth. "Dogs eat things all the time, but not things like this. Kyle came in with a bit of a vomiting problem but there was no indication of any sort of foreign body inside him."

Six-month-old Kyle was lucky to survive the extraordinary snack and the extraction was a touch-and-go piece of medical manoeuvring. Dr Draper said: "The knife could have cut his internal organs to shreds at any time and it's a miracle he survived. It took an hour to complete the surgery - removing the knife handle first, and taking care that the blade didn't touch anything."

The knife had lodged handle first the entire length of the puppy's abdomen, with the blade reaching up to his throat but just hidden from checks on his mouth. Kyle's owner, Ms Eva Oliver from Leeds, said that he had not shown sign of anything seriously wrong, apart from going off his favourite habit of chewing.

"It was a total shock when I discovered the cause of his illness," she said. "But he does love to chew and I had noticed soon after Christmas that he wasn't his normal self." She had wondered where her knife was, but never remotely suspected Kyle of eating it.

"I'm so grateful to the PDSA for all the care and help. I do realise that I was extremely lucky and it is a miracle he survived," she said.

Dr Draper added: "We saw the puppy last week. He had a little swelling after surgery but he's been bouncing around and his eating is back to normal."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Lawyer on sex charges
A lawyer who successfully fought to free the Birmingham Six pleaded not guilty at Nottingham yesterday to 11 sex offences against girls aged between six and 14. Ivan Geffen, 80, of Walsall, denied all the charges.
fields.body:
Lawyer on sex charges
A lawyer who successfully fought to free the Birmingham Six pleaded not guilty at Nottingham yesterday to 11 sex offences against girls aged between six and 14. Ivan Geffen, 80, of Walsall, denied all the charges.

More apply to university
University applications are up this year on last year by 2,171 to 322,621, government figures showed yesterday.

Second man guilty of kidnap
A second man was yesterday found guilty of plotting to kidnap a supermarket manager's family. David Pleasants, 41, from Cleethorpes, was convicted by a jury at Leicester crown court.

Soccer trophy turns up
Sir Stanley Matthews' 1963 Footballer of the Year award has been handed back to his family over 30 years after it disappeared. It was found in the attic of a house in Stoke on Trent when its present owners were cleaning.

Two jailed over drugs
A South African mother and daughter were yesterday each jailed for three years for trying to smuggle cannabis worth nearly £100,000 into Britain. Johanna Kitty Metz, 72, and Jesserika Marina Jansen, 34, were arrested at Birmingham airport on November 19.

Religious law reform
Non-Anglican priests will be able to serve as MPs for the first time in 200 years under plans published by the government yesterday. New legislation will repeal laws from 1801 and 1829.

Ferry services cancelled
Cross-channel ferry companies had to halt some services yesterday as French dock workers prepared to stage another lightning strike, threatening to close the port of Calais.

webTitle: Plenty of surprises in South Bank awards

fields.headline: Plenty of surprises in South Bank awards
fields.trailText: A "10 minute filler", shot with a shaky camcorder, last night beat such lavish productions as Longitude and Tony Marchant's critically acclaimed Never Never to one of television's top prizes.
fields.body:
A "10 minute filler", shot with a shaky camcorder, last night beat such lavish productions as Longitude and Tony Marchant's critically acclaimed Never Never to one of television's top prizes.

Marion & Geoff, the experimental, no-budget BBC2 comedy series about a Welsh cabby who grows ever more optimistic as his life falls apart, won the South Bank Show's television award.

The shorts, written by Rob Brydon and Hugo Blick, which were all shot from a camera mounted on a car dashboard, were praised for their "cupfuls of humour", Brydon's "amazing central performance" and the "fact that they were only 10 minutes long".

The South Bank Show awards provided, in fact, a night of surprises with the Crucible in Sheffield striking a blow for the battered remains of regional theatre by winning the drama award for Michael Grandage's production of As You Like It.

Not only that, but Peter Ackroyd beat Martin Amis and the ubiquitous Zadie Smith to the book prize for his London: the Biography. Ackroyd was literally speechless, having lost his voice earlier in the week.

Renaissance woman Caroline Aherne accepted the comedy award for The Royle Family - which she writes, directs and acts in - by promising that she would "try my very, very best to watch a whole episode of the new series of the South Bank Show without turning over".

And the comedian Ken Dodd, who presented the prize, kept up the ribbing by continually referring to Lord Bragg, the show's socialist presenter, as "your grace".

The biggest shock of all, though, came from the veteran iconoclast Lady (Barbara) Castle, who had the cheek to tell the playwright Harold Pinter "not to just grunt" when he accepted his lifetime achievement award.

Sans grunts, and with only a trace of his trademark menace, Pinter replied: "I just want to warn everyone I'm not prepared to retire."

The other big turn-up for the books was the victory of architect Norman "Wobbling Bridge" Foster in the visual art category for his roofing of the Great Court of the British Museum. He beat off challenges from Nicholas Serota, the man behind the Tate Modern, and the artist Mark Wallinger, who is best known for his Jesus on Trafalgar Square's empty plinth.

fields.headline: Stately silverfish get their chips
fields.trailText: At Nostell Priory, one of the stateliest homes in Yorkshire, five miles of computer cable has been buried in the fabric of the building, at a cost of almost £1m, to give the silverfish their marching orders.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
At Nostell Priory, one of the stateliest homes in Yorkshire, five miles of computer cable has been buried in the fabric of the building, at a cost of almost £1m, to give the silverfish their marching orders.

Silverfish are tiny insects which can devastate paper and textiles. Like other menaces to listed buildings, such as mould, they flourish in damp conditions.

The state-of-the-art computer system now hidden in the servants' quarters of the 18th century mansion, near Wakefield, will monitor the humidity level in the dozens of rooms. If it rises to a level silverfish find comfortable, the house can switch on its own heating system to control it. The alarm will be raised not only on the spot but at National Trust headquarters in London.

Curator Frances Jackson explained that Nostell Priory had a particular problem with silverfish, which were attracted by the handpainted Chinese wallpaper in the grandest room. In the 1740s Thomas Chippendale, who made most of the furniture for the house was anxiously warning his client Sir Rowland Will that the 18 rolls of paper would set him back 15 shillings (75p) a roll. Over two centuries later, the paper was priceless but had become a running buffet for the silverfish. The insects were attracted in swarms by the egg originally used to bind the paint to the paper.

The house has been closed for 18 months for the work, but Ms Jackson estimated yesterday that the new system had extended the life of the contents by up to a century.

Nostell Priory was given to the National Trust in the 1950s but it is still partly occupied by the St Oswald family, descendants of the builders.

Derek Williams is the project joiner, with the job of dismantling dozens of mahogany door cases, and lifting hundreds of Georgian floorboards to thread the cabling.

The trick question for those tendering for the job was how to get the cable across the billiard room. Anyone who suggested moving the long case clock was disqualified. The clock was made by John Harrison whose struggles to win the Admiralty prize for an accurate sea clock were chronicled in the bestseller Longitude.

webTitle: GMC chief left isolated by agreement on reforms

fields.headline: GMC chief left isolated by agreement on reforms
fields.trailText: The president of the General Medical Council, who recently criticised doctors for dragging their feet over reforms, looked isolated yesterday after professional groups agreed to bypass his ideas for change.
fields.body:
The president of the General Medical Council, who recently criticised doctors for dragging their feet over reforms, looked isolated yesterday after professional groups agreed to bypass his ideas for change.

Turning the tables on Sir Donald Irvine, a new alliance between the British Medical Association - the doctors' trade union - and the Academy of Medical Royal Colleges said that the GMC reform plans were bureaucratic.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the BMA, said: "The profession has been calling for reform of the GMC for many years. Recent cases of professional incompetence, malpractice, and, worse still, criminal behaviour, have strengthened our case.

"Yet the process of the reform and the GMC's own proposals are bogged down in bureaucracy. The public and doctors expect swift action to restore confidence in this regulatory process and now the entire medical profession has come together to agree measures which we believe will restore confidence and end the uncertainty."

The heads of the royal colleges sit on the GMC and were thought to back Sir Donald's plans. The change of alliances is a potential threat to Sir Donald's position.

The BMA and the academy yesterday put forward 11 proposals. They reject the idea of a small executive backed by a 200-strong conference of doctors and lay people to run the GMC. They want to see the present 104-strong council cut to 50 with an executive of only 10 or 15.

The failure to get agreement on a reformed GMC to reassure the public that doctors are being properly policed leaves many wondering whether the government will eventually scrap the GMC and set up a new structure.

In a recent lecture, Sir Donald warned that the public was not convinced they were doing enough to modernise the profession. "The cultural flaws in the medical profession show up as excessive paternalism, lack of respect for patients and their right to make decisions about their care," he said.

A GMC spokesman said yesterday that all the proposals would be incorporated in a consultation document to be brought out next month.

Asked if the new alliance left Sir Donald isolated, he said: "We will have to wait for the conference in February to see that. It consists of people who are not just the BMA or the academy - there are lay members and doctors who are elected in their own right."

webTitle: Four survive as light plane hits mountain

fields.headline: Four survive as light plane hits mountain
fields.trailText: Three men and a woman had what rescue workers described as a miraculous escape last night after their plane crashed into a mountain.
fields.body:
Three men and a woman had what rescue workers described as a miraculous escape last night after their plane crashed into a mountain.

Their four-seater Cessna aircraft went down in poor weather conditions in the afternoon in the Grampian mountains, Royal Deeside. But although it landed 2,000ft up the hill, only one passenger was injured.

An RAF spokesman said: "It is a miracle to either crash land or control a landing at 2,000ft up in the Highlands in the middle of winter and walk away. It is incredible."

A full-scale rescue mission was launched shortly after 1pm when contact with the plane, which was travelling from the south of England to Inverness, was lost. The RAF's air rescue coordination centre sent a helicopter from Lossiemouth.

The rescue helicopter found the plane crew at around 3.20pm digging holes in the snow in an attempt to bed down for the night.

All four were eventually airlifted to hospital in Aberdeen. One had a minor leg injury. Two were starting to suffer from hypothermia.

Their four-seater Cessna aircraft went down in poor weather conditions in the afternoon in the Grampian mountains, Royal Deeside. But although it landed 2,000ft up the hill, only one passenger was injured. An RAF spokesman said: "It is a miracle to either crash land or control a landing at 2,000ft up in the Highlands in the middle of winter and walk away. It is incredible." A full-scale rescue mission was launched shortly after 1pm when contact with the plane, which was travelling from the south of England to Inverness, was lost. webTitle: Dictator's cash hidden in UK, says Nigeria

fields.headline: Dictator's cash hidden in UK, says Nigeria
fields.trailText: The government was accused yesterday of refusing to cooperate with Nigerian authorities in their attempts to recover £307m stolen by the late dictator General Sani Abacha, and believed to be deposited in London banks.
fields.body:
The government was accused yesterday of refusing to cooperate with Nigerian authorities in their attempts to recover £307m stolen by the late dictator General Sani Abacha, and believed to be deposited in London banks.

General Aliyu Mohammed, national security adviser to President Olusegun Obasanjo, flew in from Lagos to give evidence to MPs on the international development committee. He said: "We're concerned about non-cooperation of the British government."

He said that much of the money in London was given to the Abachas as bribes from British firms seeking contracts in Nigeria. The Home Office had said that under British law no action could be taken until charges were made. But the high commissioner told the Guardian yesterday that charges had been brought recently. He said: "Britain says this is not sufficient."

Part of the problem lies with the mutual legal assistance agreement between the two countries which requires Nigeria to provide clear proof connecting individual Nigerians to the bank account.

The Nigerian contingent was called before the committee because Nigeria stands as the most corrupt country, according to Transparency International's corruption perception index.

fields.headline: The smack of arrogance
fields.standfirst: John Reid is fortunate to get his promotion
fields.trailText: The appointment of John Reid to be Mr Mandelson's replacement as secretary of state for Northern Ireland is something of a surprise to those - admittedly few in number - who read the report of the parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's sudden resignation, coming as it did within months of an expected general election, has helped create an extraordinarily febrile atmosphere at Westminster. Packs of journalists are even now poring over the business affairs and social connections of the mysterious Hinduja Brothers. Switch on any radio talk show and you will hear comparisons with the scandal-ridden final gasps of the last government. The Europhobic tendency, still glowing over the downfall of the most europhile minister, is now focusing its sights on another euro enthusiast, Keith Vaz. Sleaze is in the air.

Much of this is laboured stuff. Where John Major was weak and prevaricating in his treatment of errant ministers, Mr Blair has been firm and decisive. And - the Bernie Ecclestone affair apart - the catalogue of Labour misdemeanours has generally been of a lesser order than those committed by their Conservative counterparts during the mid-90s. The danger that the lobbying industry would pollute Westminster as it did Washington has now receded. Most of the Nolan and Neill reforms are working reasonably well. But the appointment of John Reid to be Mr Mandelson's replacement as secretary of state for Northern Ireland is something of a surprise to those - admittedly few in number - who read the report of the parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, expediently published just as journalists were packing up for the Christmas break.

Mrs Filkin is damning about the behaviour of Mr Reid, both towards her inquiry and towards the key witnesses in the case, which concerned allegations that Mr Reid and his colleague, John Maxton, had used their House of Commons allowances to pay three Labour party researchers and had misled the fees office. Mr Reid challenged the reliability of the complainant - a journalist - and challneged the veracity of the witnesses. His solicitor was found to have launched an unwarranted attack on the integrity of Mrs Filkin. The standards and privileges committee, while disagreeing with her conclusions, found her investigation to be careful, fair and competent.

Mrs Filkin found that many witnesses felt under considerable pressure about their evidence and whether they should cooperate with her inquiry at all. She took evidence that Mr Reid had made threats of "a particularly disturbing kind" against one witness, who was so alarmed he started to tape record his future conversations with Mr Reid. The witness accused Mr Reid of trying to change his evidence in order to mislead the inquiry. Having listened to these tapes Mrs Filkin directly concluded that Mr Reid's behaviour was "an attempt to frustrate my investigation". The committee, while finding no threats, said it was "at best unwise" for Mr Reid to have discussed the investigation with witnesses.

The behaviour of both MPs leaves an unpleasant taste in the mouth. If the government is truly committed to maintaining the highest ethical standards at Westminster it should require its members to cooperate openly and courteously with the parliamentary commissioner. To do otherwise really would invite legitimate comparisons with the way the Tories behaved in the mid-90s.

Mr Reid has many admirable qualities which will doubtless serve him well as secretary of state, amongst them firmness. He might be thought lucky to receive promotion just a month after such a disturbing report from the parliamentary commissioner. His new job will require rather more candour and tact than he displayed towards Mrs Filkin.

fields.headline: Orders from above
fields.standfirst: When Brussels starts calling the shots
fields.trailText: The European Commission yesterday demanded that Gordon Brown abandon his plans for increased public spending and lower taxes on the grounds that they contravened EU policy. Oops, we've got that a bit wrong. It was not Britain but her neighbour, Ireland, to which the EU sent its missive.
fields.body:
The European Commission yesterday demanded that Gordon Brown abandon his plans for increased public spending and lower taxes on the grounds that they contravened EU policy. Oops, we've got that a bit wrong. It was not Britain but her neighbour, Ireland, to which the EU sent its missive. Yet a few years hence it could easily be Britain. And with a general election looming (as in Ireland) the political consequences would have been - well, interesting.

Ireland has not just been the best performing economy in Europe in recent years, but the best in the world. The normally taciturn OECD was moved to refer to its five years of 9% growth recently as a "stunning economic performance". It even praised the country's incomes policy (still off limits in New Labour circles) as "crucial" in preventing social discord and excessive wage increases. True, the OECD was warning as far back as 1997 about the dangers of overheating the economy, but the Celtic Tiger just cruised on effortlessly confounding its critics.

Even now, serious economists in Dublin are refusing to admit that there is a problem. They hint that the EU should be looking to learn from Ireland and not vice versa. Ireland is sitting on the EU's largest budget surplus (EU rules only require it to balance its budget) and though inflation was 6% in November, it fell to 4.6% last month amid expectations that it will fall further.

The government argues that inflation is more to do with the weakness of the euro, high energy prices and high mortgage interest rates, now no longer controlled by the Irish. Ireland, for all its dramatic success, accounts for only 1% of the EU's economic wealth, so the ECB is not going to lower interest rates on its account alone. Denied it own monetary policy, the Irish government does not want to tighten fiscal policy (ie raise taxes and reduce spending); Irish tax rates are already higher than in Europe. And it does not want to alienate the unions, whose cooperation was one of the secrets of success, along with inward investment, prudent fiscal policy and EU subsidies.

If the independent Bank of England had been controlling interest rates there, it would have raised them a long time ago. Gordon Brown will not be the only one watching to see if Ireland once again confounds its critics and proves that you do not have to be in sync with the rest of the single currency area to run a successful economy.

fields.trailText: The best Francis Wheen can do to counter the accusation that "Bron" was effete, drunken, racist and sexist is to point out that 30-plus years ago he was a "crusader" on behalf of Biafrans, and that at some stage he "championed" Angela Carter.

The best Francis Wheen can do to counter the accusation that "Bron" was effete, drunken, racist and sexist is to point out that 30-plus years ago he was a "crusader" on behalf of Biafrans, and that at some stage he "championed" Angela Carter. Waugh's friendship with Paul Foot is indeed puzzling for those of us on the outside looking in.

Polly Toynbee made it clear (Comment, January 19) that she was concerned about the damage Waugh and his clan has done to British political life and journalism. London

fields.headline: College cash
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley reports on concerns about the funding available to support further education sector colleges in improving access for disabled students (More money for disabled students, Education, January 23).
fields.body:
Simon Midgley reports on concerns about the funding available to support further education sector colleges in improving access for disabled students (More money for disabled students, Education, January 23).

He compares two years' funding for the higher education sector, £15m in 2002-03 and £41m in 2003-04 totalling £56m, with just one year's funding for the FE sector, £20m in 2002-03. However, I am pleased to be able to say that in 2003-04 we will make a further £46m available to the FE sector, making a total of £66m.

Much of that money will be capital funds, allocated to colleges by the learning and skills council on a 50% matched funding basis. This money should make an enormous difference in enabling colleges to make their buildings accessible.
Tessa Blackstone
Minister of state for education

webTitle: Letters: Poor Mandy, victim of a vicious media

fields.headline: Poor Mandy, victim of a vicious media
fields.trailText: I do not like Peter Mandelson, his style of politics or what he and his cronies have done to the Labour party and politics in general in Britain (A glittering career in ruins, January 25).
fields.body:
I do not like Peter Mandelson, his style of politics or what he and his cronies have done to the Labour party and politics in general in Britain (A glittering career in ruins, January 25).

I like even less the vendetta run against him by the national press. There has been a clear determination to get him, whatever he did or said. He may have fallen by his own mishandling of this particular affair, but, even if he had come clean immediately, the concerted effort to bring him down would have gone on until the next time.

The people who have done this do not put themselves up for public scrutiny so we can see how pure and clean they are in all their dealings; the press has become a shady underworld.

Once we scorned individual newspapers which ran vendettas, but now there seems to be a corporate mind among journalists deciding on the targets - Kinnock, Scargill, Livingstone, Mandelson. I would rather be governed by Mandelson and his wheeler-dealers than the "gentlemen" of the press.
Jeffrey Butcher
Waltham Abbey, Essex
jeff.shambles@ukgateway.net

 If the media spent as much passion kicking up a fuss over the latest horrific global warming figures (A world of extremes, January 23) as they do over the relatively trivial misdemeanours of Peter Mandelson, the world would be a better and less bitter place. I for one resent the media tyranny we now appear to live under which deluges us with trivia and pap and ignores much of what is really happening in the world.
Rev David Baker
Romford, Essex

 On Wednesday Peter Mandelson is sacked from the cabinet for interfering in a businessman's application for a UK passport the same month as a £1m donation to the dome's faith zone. On Thursday the prime minister praises the decision by Nissan to build the new Micra in Sunderland in return for a £41m donation by the government. Which of these acts is the most corrupt?
Adam Swain
Nottingham

 Peter. You are the weakest link. Goodbye!
Bert Large
Beckenham, Kent

fields.headline: A fertile debate
fields.trailText: I was very interested to read Sally Weale's report about older women having children as a result of donated eggs from younger volunteers (Grey area, G2, January 23).
fields.body:
I was very interested to read Sally Weale's report about older women having children as a result of donated eggs from younger volunteers (Grey area, G2, January 23). Our centre pioneered this development in the UK in 1986 and our first success was a 46-year-old woman who had twins and the next was a 43-year-old who had a singleton pregnancy.

In the report, Lord Winston said he would not make comments on a specific case, then stated that the patient would not have been treated at his own hospital. If age particularly concerns him, he should remember that the male partner of his own centre's first IVF quadruplets was significantly older than Derek Bezant's 55 years. If his main worry is the most appropriate use of donor eggs, why does his large IVF unit perform so few egg donor cycles? The HFEA's 2000 Patient Guide to IVF clinics reports 53 cycles of donated eggs/embryos out of a calculated total of 1,733 cycles (3%) compared to our centre's 183 out of 850 (21.5%). The recipients were mostly under 50.

Lord Winston mentions that there is a three or four-year wait and, indeed, it was this very feature in our patient's circumstances that led to her being 56 when the news was reported at 19 weeks of pregnancy. This made her case of far greater media interest than had she been able to obtain donated eggs soon after she sought our advice at the age of 52.

It is true that most donors specify that their eggs go to young women but it is not "misuse of a very valuable commodity" if specific donors agree to their eggs going to a more mature woman.
Prof Ian Craft
Director, London Fertility Centre
info@lfc.org.uk

fields.headline: Hand it to him
fields.trailText: Hugo Young (Comment, January 25) says of Jack Straw: "he has handled the political minefield of the Home Office with sure feet". Does this account for the fact that with every problem Jack handles, he inches us along in the direction of illiberality while putting his foot in it?
fields.body:
Hugo Young (Comment, January 25) says of Jack Straw: "he has handled the political minefield of the Home Office with sure feet". Does this account for the fact that with every problem Jack handles, he inches us along in the direction of illiberality while putting his foot in it?
Prof Les Allen
Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk

 John Vidal (Eco soundings, January 24) accuses the World Bank of meeting in secrecy with chief executives of agribusinesses. This was not a secret meeting and the NGO community was briefed before and after the meeting and within 24 hours the minutes were posted on our website. This was one of several intended meetings with NGOs, business, government officials and others on agricultural science and technology. This is about dialogue not conspiracy.
Caroline Anstey
Head of media, World Bank

 Let's hope GNER's bid to revamp Clapham Junction station (£4.5bn on offer to revive rail service, January 25) stretches to a pot of paint with which to apply the missing apostrophes to the signs ("Britains busiest railway station").
Andrew Collins
London

 I've complained often about readers of the international Guardian being short-changed. However, yesterday's witty letter from reader Mr Bryant makes me appreciate there are advantages in living beyond the pale: we didn't get the free Fat Boy Slim CD.
Sally Lamm
Frankfurt am Main, Germany

 I am sure that Mandelson resigning is rather important news, but I wanted to be the first in the Guardian to say that the frogs have spawned plentifully yesterday in my partner's pond down in the sub-tropical climes of the New Forest.
David Rennie
Cardiff

fields.headline: The battle for Jerusalem
fields.trailText: Jerusalem "represents our collective soul", says Elie Wiesel (Palestinians' rights do not include the right to Jerusalem, January 25). The greater proportion of Jerusalem - its large western and mainly Arab-owned sector - was commandeered by armed Jewish fighters 53 years ago, and no Arab "soul" or body has been allowed to be represented or to live or stay there since.
fields.body:
Jerusalem "represents our collective soul", says Elie Wiesel (Palestinians' rights do not include the right to Jerusalem, January 25). The greater proportion of Jerusalem - its large western and mainly Arab-owned sector - was commandeered by armed Jewish fighters 53 years ago, and no Arab "soul" or body has been allowed to be represented or to live or stay there since.

Jordan denied Jews access to the Western Wall as a direct result of this invasion and property theft and the mutually agreed armistice line that put a military frontier across the city from 1948 until 1967. Neither did Israel allow Arab Muslims and Christians to cross to their mosques and churches.

Mr Wiesel says the fact he does not live in Jerusalem is secondary: "Jerusalem lives within me." That is nice for him; but what unalloyed insensitivity and arrogance he conveys, from his distant comforts in the US. The quarter of a million Arabs who do live there, in East Jerusalem, are half-way through their 34th year of illegal Israeli military occupation, settlement and ethnic cleansing. No end to this is in sight. The Arabs' "collective soul" can go hang, along with their bodies, land and living.

Tomorrow, Holocaust Day, we should remember also the millions of dead and dispossessed Palestinians.
Tim Llewellyn
London
Timllew@aol.com

 Under international law East Jerusalem has been occupied by Israel since 1967, which is why only two states - Costa Rica and El Salvador - recognise Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and maintain embassies there. Despite Elie Wiesel's emotive cries, the holy sites are sacred for Muslims, Christians and Jews. The only possible solution to this conflict is for both Palestinians and Israelis to have access to their holy sites under a power-sharing agreement.
Sally Ramsden
London
sally@unisonfree.net

 I find Mr Wiesel's article to be one of the first objective, historically accurate, and illuminating analyses of the current Middle East situation. It is truly worthy of being written through the pen of a Nobel prizewinner. If we would all take this article to heart, much senseless violence could be prevented.
S Spira
Montreal, Canada
sspira@po-box.mcgill.ca

 Mr Wiesel's argument amounts to this: we Jews must have it because we so want it, and because our traditions and ancient myths tell us it is ours. This is not very different from the Serb nationalists' argument as to why they should rule Kosovo, the majority of whose population just happens to be ethnic Albanian. Another similarity is Mr Weisel's denial of the right of the Palestinian victims of ethnic cleansing to return to their homeland. In fact, he virtually blames the victims for their own plight.

Instead of complaining of "the faces of young Palestinians twisted with hate", he should consider whether this may perhaps be the consequence of 33 unrelenting years of vicious military occupation.
Prof Moshe Machover
London
moshe.machover@kcl.ac.uk

 Elie Wiesel ignores Jerusalem's universalist significance. Over the centuries, Jerusalem has become to much of the world a symbol of peace and of the just society, as we can see in William Blake's famous hymn. If the Jews continue to insist on the whole of Jerusalem, then they perpetuate Jerusalem as the embodiment of hatred, conflict, nationalism and injustice and betray their own universalist tradition.
Deborah Maccoby
London
fields.bodyText: Jerusalem "represents our collective soul", says Elie Wiesel (Palestinians' rights do not include the right to Jerusalem, January 25). The greater proportion of Jerusalem - its large western and mainly Arab-owned sector - was commandeered by armed Jewish fighters 53 years ago, and no Arab "soul" or body has been allowed to be represented or to live or stay there since. Jordan denied Jews access to the Western Wall as a direct result of this invasion and property theft and the mutually agreed armistice line that put a military frontier across the city from 1948 until 1967. Neither did Israel allow Arab Muslims and Christians to cross to their mosques and churches. Mr Wiesel says the fact he does not live in Jerusalem is secondary: "Jerusalem lives within me." That is nice for him; but what unalloyed insensitivity and arrogance he conveys, from his distant comforts in the US. The quarter of a million Arabs who do live there, in East Jerusalem, are half-way through their 34th year of illegal Israeli military occupation, settlement and ethnic cleansing. No end to this is in sight. The Arabs' "collective soul" can go hang, along with their bodies, land and living. Tomorrow, Holocaust Day, we should remember also the millions of dead and dispossessed Palestinians. Tim Llewellyn London Timllew@aol.com  Under international law East Jerusalem has been occupied by Israel since 1967, which is why only two states - Costa Rica and El Salvador - recognise Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and maintain embassies there. Despite Elie Wiesel's emotive cries, the holy sites are sacred for Muslims, Christians and Jews. The only possible solution to this conflict is for both Palestinians and Israelis to have access to their holy sites under a power-sharing agreement. Sally Ramsden London sally@unisonfree.net  I find Mr Wiesel's article to be one of the first objective, historically accurate, and illuminating analyses of the current Middle East situation. It is truly worthy of being written through the pen of a Nobel prizewinner. If we would all take this article to heart, much senseless violence could be prevented. S Spira Montreal, Canada sspira@po-box.mcgill.ca  Mr Wiesel's argument amounts to this: we Jews must have it because we so want it, and because our traditions and ancient myths tell us it is ours. fields.headline: Case against Derry Irvine
fields.trailText: Debora Mathews, principal private secretary to Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor (Letters, January 25), complains that my article on her boss's discriminatory management methods (Jobs for the lads, January 19) contains "many errors of fact".
fields.body:
Debora Mathews, principal private secretary to Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor (Letters, January 25), complains that my article on her boss's discriminatory management methods (Jobs for the lads, January 19) contains "many errors of fact". She says the Lord Chancellor is not a "lawbreaker", as I asserted, because the employment appeal tribunal decided that there had been no discrimination in the appointment of his friend, Garry Hart, to the post of his special adviser, without the post being advertised.

As I pointed out, "Lord Irvine ... successfully appealed ..." Hardly an error. This, however, does not detract from the original employment tribunal's decision that he had broken the law. It is is also extremely rare for an individual to be granted leave to appeal against the appeal - a process which is now underway. Mathews proceeds to correct mistakes I never made. Just to list a couple.

In the shake up of the legal aid system I wrote: "Barristers may lose their independent status..." "May" precisely because pilot schemes are underway. I did not mention, "casually" or otherwise, as Mathews asserts, that salaried defenders "will not be independent". I never discussed the details of the reforms, yet she writes, these changes will "hardly [be] a threat to the 3,000 odd solicitors' firms who will have a criminal contract". As if I had implied a threat exists.

What's interesting about Mathews' response is its arrogant, bullying tone and its use of smear and misinformation. A reflection, perhaps, of the 19th-century attitudes which prevail in the court of Derry Irvine?
Yvonne Roberts
London

fields.headline: George Alcock
fields.standfirst: Passionate amateur astronomer who discovered delightful debris in the sky
fields.trailText: Passionate amateur astronomer who discovered delightful debris in the sky.
fields.body:
For most amateur astronomers, one comet or nova would be ample compensation for the years of lonely labour on chilly nights. George Alcock, who has died aged 88, considered his five comet and five nova discoveries small reward for 65 years of serious observing. Patrick Moore described him as "one of the best and most dedicated comet and nova-hunters of all time."

The son of a self-educated railway worker, George was born and brought up in Peterborough. A bright child fascinated by insects, plants, trains and the weather, he witnessed the large partial solar eclipse of April 8 1921 and, adding astronomy to his passions, began observing the heavens with a small brass reflector belonging to his father.

Ten years later, while training to be a teacher, he joined the Meteor Section of the British Astronomical Association (BAA) and became one of its small team of meteor observers. With the aim of predicting optimum times for two-station observation of meteors, in 1933 George obtained Meteorological Office permission to set up his own weather station.

He was able to find only occasional temporary teaching posts and, permanently broke, was dependent on a borrowed telescope for his observations. Yet his drawings of comets and the planets impressed several eminent BAA members.

In 1937, he found a full-time post, and meteor watches now had to be fitted into a strict routine: "If it promised to be clear, I'd leave school at 4.30, go home for tea and then to bed till 8pm, observe 8.15 till 1am - or 3am, if there was a lot of activity. After a couple more hours' sleep I'd send my results to Manning Prentice [at the BAA] by express from the city centre before cycling to school."

After hair-raising wartime experiences - including three courts-martial - with the RAF in North Africa and Italy, he returned to teaching - and astronomy. In 1953, he embarked on a five-year search for a comet. He was not optimistic; none had been discovered in the cloudy skies of England since 1894.

He was also on the lookout for a nova. Having memorised the position of 1,000 stars down to magnitude six, he now set out to familiarise himself with an additional 20,000-plus dimmer stars. Nova-hunters, he believed, had to be able to depend on memory: "If you have to check the published charts every time you spot a suspicious object, you'll spend half the night indoors."

On August 25 1959, he discovered his first comet - and five days later became instantly famous by finding another. Celebrity, however, was not to his taste; and he avoided the attentions of the popular press by discovering Comets Alcock three and four after greater intervals (in March 1963 and September 1965).

No new novae had been discovered by anyone anywhere since 1964. But on July 8 1967 George spotted in Delphinus a sixth magnitude white star that shouldn't have been there. "I was so certain that this was a new star that I checked only two star atlases, Coeli and Eclipticalis, before working out its position." Next day the Royal Observatory confirmed his find: Nova Delphini 1967, the first nova discovered from England since 1934.

Nine months later he found his second nova, in Vulpecula; and for a brief period, two novae discovered by one man in England were simultaneously visible to the naked eye. It was the biggest thrill of his career.

The last of his subsequent discoveries - Nova Scuti 1970, Nova Vulpeculae 1976, Comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock in 1983, and Nova Herculis 1991 (the fastest nova ever recorded) - brought him the all-time record for discoveries of comets and novae from the British Isles.

Astronomy was only one of George's many passions: he spent more hours studying birds, botany and church architecture than searching the sky. And he had no doubt that his greatest achievement lay in the years he spent teaching. His former students used to enjoy a vicarious thrill on reading of the latest discovery by GED Alcock.

He received an MBE "for services to astronomy"; awards from a host of eminent astronomical establishments, from the BAA to the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, and a minor planet (3174) Alcock was named in his honour.

His wife, Mary, predeceased him; they had no children.

fields.headline: John Ryder
fields.standfirst: Gifted designer whose typographical skills helped us read good books more easily
fields.trailText: Gifted designer whose typographical skills helped us read good books more easily.
fields.body:
John Ryder, who has died aged 83, was one of the foremost British book designers of the late 20th century, a man whose long professional career was dedicated to typographical excellence and the virtues of legibility and the well-made book. He believed passionately that the way in which we read a book, the way in which the eye falls upon the printed page, can radically influence our understanding and enjoyment.

Born in London, Ryder left school in the mid-1930s to work as a bookseller at John Baker's Phoenix Book Company. It was at this time that he acquired his own hand-press and, without any formal training, made his first typographical experiments.

While a registered conscientious objector during the second world war, he served as a private in the army, working on Britain's east coast defences, loading supply ships in Cardiff and digging for unexploded bombs in Bedfordshire, before joining an airborne surgical unit that was parachuted into Normandy and over the Rhine at Wesel.

After a brief period in Palestine, he was demobilised and returned to work for John Baker, who had transferred his bookshop into the pub lishing imprint of Phoenix House, a subsidiary of JM Dent.

In 1955, John Ryder published his first book, Printing for Pleasure, a primer that gave enormous encouragement and satisfaction to generations of amateur printers and which went through numerous editions. In 1957 he joined The Bodley Head, and it was during his 30-year career there as art director that, with the support of the firm's new proprietor, Max Reinhardt, he established his reputation as a designer of books.

His distinctive, restrained and elegant house style adorned such works as the 1960 edition of Joyce's Ulysses, the first editions of books by authors such as Graham Greene and William Trevor, and some of the outstanding illustrated children's books of the time, including those of his lifelong friend and admirer, Maurice Sendak.

"The typographer's art should be invisible," he once said, "the hand which seeks perfection, but which is never actually seen." Ryder's combination of taste, skill and self-effacement was bred in him early in his working life by mentors such as Jan Tschichold, the great German designer who revolutionised design at Penguin Books after the second world war. Another powerful influence was his friend, the Italian scholar-printer and doyen of private presses, Giovanni Mardersteig, on whose beautiful books, produced at the Officina Bodoni in Verona, Ryder was an authority.

Ryder's archive of printed books, correspondence and working papers was donated to the Bodleian Library in Oxford in 1974. It was the occasion for a retrospective exhibition, one which gave illuminating insight into the designer's art and revealed Ryder's close involvement with the private press movement and his exceptionally close working relationship with the lettering artist Michael Harvey.

In 1979, alarmed by some of the startling techniques engendered by computer setting, Ryder published The Case for Legibility. "The theatre of war was sometimes terrifying," he wrote, "but the present terror of being overcome by illiteracy and blinded by illegibility is just as real... whatever is done must be done for the reader's benefit and for maximum legibility... You must present an author's work to the reader without fuss and with design techniques as invisible as possible."

His credo as a book designer was summed up in the last of his nine books, the beautifully produced Intimate Leaves from a Designer's Notebook (1993), in which he expounded his concept of "visual editing" and reflected on the many functions of the designer of words.

In her introduction, Jan Morris wrote: "He can gauge exquisitely the effect of congeniality in letterforms or an excess of spacing, he is passionately interested in the relationship between the meaning of words and the look of them, and he demonstrates that the making of the book is really a joint work of creation, achieved in collaboration between its author, its illustrator, its de signer, its binder - and, in a sense, its reader."

For 17 years Ryder and I worked together at The Bodley Head, where a stream of visitors (printers, jacket artists, librarians, book dealers and collectors) used to file daily through his door. He was a man of exceptional energy and impish humour, totally immersed in the process of publishing. He endeared himself to many of his colleagues.

He was also a man of habit, efficient and tidy, with pronounced views on literature, painting and the theatre, but little time for politics or business, or the world outside the parameters he built around himself. He liked listening to Radio 3, but refused to own a television; he enjoyed the Garrick Club, where he was a member for more than 30 years, but was equally happy dining at Pizza Express.

He was sustained in everything he did by his wife, the literary agent Herta Hagen. For almost 50 years, until her death in 1995, they shared a passion for collecting books and paintings and listening to music at their home on the edge of Richmond Park.

 John Ryder, book designer, born October 6 1917; died January 18 2001

webTitle: Market forces: For sale signs go up

fields.headline: For sale signs go up
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
From aircraft seats to quarries, the City's shrewder players move quickly. No sooner had Britax International - up 15.5p at 135p - been forced to reveal takeover talks than they were sizing up the next target, Aggregate Industries, 2.5p better at 79p.

A couple of weeks ago reports circulated around the Square Mile that Aggregate boss, Peter Tom, had called a meeting with advisers CSFB to discuss the company's "strategic options".

Apparently Mr Tom wanted to have a chat about his big idea - a merger with its larger but more lowly rated rival, RMC, up 4p 651p; the idea being that Aggregate's highly rated management would control the new company, which would be large enough to ward off potential investors.

But market professionals view things rather differently. They argue the reports, true or not, have in effect hoisted the "for sale" sign over Aggregate, and it is now open season for any interested party.

According to the trading room gossip, a predator - either Switzerland's Holderbank or Mexico's Cemex - could be about to pounce.

In the wider market, the FTSE 100 index gave up moderate afternoon gains to close 8.8 points weaker at 6,255.6 after US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan disappointed a market looking for a clear steer on US interest rates.

Speaking to the senate budget committee just days ahead of the next meeting of the Federal Reserve, Mr Greenspan said little to interest traders either here or in New York, although his backing for lower taxes raised a few eyebrows.

Over in the technology sector, the FTSE Techmark 100 index edged up 10.72 points to 2,816.47 - helped by solid interim results from software firm Misys. The figures, and a prediction from its chairman that it would get close to its 20% long-term earnings growth rate this year, helped the shares move 42.5p higher to 659p.

The news gave the rest of the sector a lift, with Logica rising 8p to £18.65p and Sage gaining 7p to 367p.

Elsewhere, the punters continued to pile into the online directory outfit, Scoot.com, which was 3.25p higher at 84.75p, in the hope of a bid from Vivendi Universal. Meanwhile Sema, the IT services group, rose 39p to 410p on reports that it had appointed investment banks to advise it on its strategic options.

Handheld computer maker Psion dropped 15.5p to 267.5p, as one broker tried to offload nearly 1m shares for a client.

But the most notable moves of the day's trading came in the retail sector.

Of course, it could have been the prospect of lower interest rates that drove up the likes of Marks & Spencer, 11p stronger at 221p, Debenhams, 27p higher at 347.5p, and Arcadia, 16p stronger at 154p.

But the buying was too selective - Boots only gained 3p to 590p and Dixons rose just 0.5p to 262.75p - and the trading volumes - in the case of M&S, 33m shares changed hands - were too big.

What seems to have happened, according to senior City traders, is a large hedge fund has got itself in to a sticky situation shorting the likes of M&S and Arcadia and has been forced to close its position in double-quick time.

That said, M&S was also benefiting from the reappearance of the Philip Green takeover story. The tale, a real market favourite, seems to have been wheeled out for no other reason than it is almost a year since Mr Green, now owner of Bhs, pulled the plug on his audacious move for the floundering retailer.

Under exchange rules Mr Green is allowed to make another bid for M&S on February 12, as year has passed since his plan was shelved.

In the small-cap world, Avon Rubber gained 12p to 210.5p on speculation of a 260p-a-share bid, while paper and packaging group Low & Bonar rose 4p to 107p on talk that corporate activist Guinness Peat Group have taken a stake.

fields.headline: At this price?  Silentnight
fields.trailText: A restless evening was on the cards for the executives of Silentnight after Britain's biggest bed manufacturer yesterday surprised the market with a profit warning.
fields.body:
A restless evening was on the cards for the executives of Silentnight after Britain's biggest bed manufacturer yesterday surprised the market with a profit warning.

The news wiped out most of the gains the firm's shares had made since the start of the month. This short-lived buoyancy was predicated on the hope that Silentnight's acquisition of Cornwell Parker, completed in December, was a positive move. As it turned out, it was Cornwell Parker - best known as the maker of Parker Knoll armchairs - which was the company's undoing yesterday.

In a trading statement, Silentnight said the difficult market conditions for Cornwell's products was continuing - which meant it would contribute a £1m loss to Silentnight's full-year figures. The future success of the group is reliant on the performance of recent purchases, which also include furniture maker Ducal, as well as its established business.

webTitle: Signs of life in BBA shareprice

fields.headline: Follow the signs at BBA
fields.trailText: Nearly five months has passed since BBA boss Roberto Quarta unexpectedly handed in his notice - and in share price terms at least, the company has yet to recover.
fields.body:
Nearly five months has passed since BBA boss Roberto Quarta unexpectedly handed in his notice - and in share price terms at least, the company has yet to recover.

It is hardly surprising. Mr Quarta spent seven years transforming the group from a sprawling conglomerate into a specialist in aviation services and materials technology.

However, over the past few trading sessions there have been signs of life in the BBA price. Yesterday, its shares shot up 26p, or 7.82%, to 358.5p, after a late buying spree by punters convinced that BBA had received a takeover approach.

Inevitably, the finger of suspicion will point towards the private equity industry, given BBA's lowly rating and leading market positions.

Paradoxically, Mr Quarta is leaving BBA to manage the European operations of one such firm - US private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice.

webTitle: Greene King and Enterprise Inns toast sector recovery

fields.headline: Greene King toasts sales
fields.standfirst: Christmas recovery bolsters pub operator
fields.trailText: Greene King and Enterprise Inns became the latest pub operators to toast a strong Christmas yesterday, with a sector recovery evident in sales of both food and drinks.
fields.body:
Greene King and Enterprise Inns became the latest pub operators to toast a strong Christmas yesterday, with a sector recovery evident in sales of both food and drinks.

In a trading statement, Greene King announced that like-for-like sales at its 504 managed pubs increased 6.5% over the holiday period. Finance director Michael Shallow said: "There was generally a bit more cheer around this time. The millennium celebrations the previous year didn't quite live up to expectations."

The company's Bury St Ed munds brewery saw a sharp rise in demand for its traditional ales. Sales of Old Speckled Hen rose 12%, with Abbot Ale sales up 14%.

Mr Shallow said: "These are all pretty strong statistics. The heritage of our ales is widely sought-after."

Enterprise Inns, which has just over 2,500 pubs, said its first-quarter trading had been boosted by the fact that Christmas fell on a Monday, which meant its outlets were packed the preceding weekend.

Enterprise's chairman, Hubert Reid, told shareholders at the company's annual general meeting that the firm had in vested £5.6m in increasing its estate by 13 pubs. Enterprise's shares rose 2p to 446p, while Greene King added 14p to 574p. Other pub operators, including SFI and Scottish & Newcastle, have already reported strong Christmas trading.

Nigel Popham, a drinks analyst at Teather & Greenwood, said: "Most, if not all, of the quoted companies are doing well, but people shouldn't get too carried away. The ones we're hearing about are relatively small players in a market of 60,000 pubs. We don't know how the big private companies like Nomura and Punch Taverns are doing."

webTitle: Applied Optical Technologies' shares drop by half

fields.headline: Bank torn off a strip as foil deals fail
fields.trailText: A disastrous attempt to supply technology to prevent the counterfeiting of euro banknotes cost the chief executive of Newcastle-based Applied Optical Technologies his job yesterday and triggered a 50% fall in the share price.
fields.body:
A disastrous attempt to supply technology to prevent the counterfeiting of euro banknotes cost the chief executive of Newcastle-based Applied Optical Technologies his job yesterday and triggered a 50% fall in the share price.

Warning that profits will be "substantially below market expectations", Applied - which produces holograms and other security items - said David Tidmarsh had resigned with immediate effect. Another 40 of the 300-strong staff also face redundancy.

Mr Tidmarsh had spent much of the last year trying to win orders for foil strips to be inserted into the 13bn euro banknotes being printed ahead of the launch of the currency in January 2002.

But it has yet to secure any firm contracts from the 11 European central banks that will be issuing euros, a fact Applied blames directly on the European Central Bank, which it accused of continually changing the specifications.

Mark Turnage, chief of the company's American operations - and who is taking over from Mr Tidmarsh - said: "While the organisation here in Europe has been focused on euro banknotes, our base business was deteriorating."

Applied's share price climbed to 525p last spring, when the news that it was working on euro banknotes first emerged, but then plummeted in the summer when the company issued a first profit warning. Yesterday, the price sank from 139p to 75.5p.

Mr Turnage insisted that Applied would still benefit when the ECB gives the go-ahead for the printing of euro notes. As to the foil inserts, the company has concluded that "there is no realistic prospect of stable long-term business in this market".

webTitle: Department store Allders on the up

fields.headline: Allders goes it alone in style
fields.trailText: Department store chain Allders, which has twice tried and failed to merge with rivals, is going it alone in style.
fields.body:
Department store chain Allders, which has twice tried and failed to merge with rivals, is going it alone in style.

The group yesterday revealed impressive trading and margin gains over Christmas.

"We have taken hold of our own future and are going for growth", said a spokeswoman for the 36-strong chain as it unveiled like-for-like sales up 7% in the eight weeks to January 20. Margins are ahead some 0.5%, and the shares climbed 9.5p to 117.5p.

Sales at the chain improved almost across the board, with electrical goods, lighting and soft furnishings among the top performers. Even womenswear sales, which have proved so difficult for so many mid-market retailers, were up - by some 11%.

The group has taken over four former C&A stores - in Guildford, York, Leicester and Kingston - and is converting three to specialist home furnishings shops; Leicester will be made into a full-line department store.

Last year Allders tried to merge with House of Fraser, but failed to agree a price for the deal.

It was also linked with a bid for smaller rival Bentalls.

webTitle: NHP cuts value of nursing homes

fields.headline: NHP cuts value of nursing homes
fields.standfirst: Troubled provider still needs to sell about £30m of properties
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest owner of nursing homes, NHP, has marked down the value of its properties by a third after an independent survey commissioned by new management.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest owner of nursing homes, NHP, has marked down the value of its properties by a third after an independent survey commissioned by new management.

The move is an attempt by chief executive Bill Colvin to draw a line under NHP's troubled past - the firm was criticised a year ago for the way it presented an earlier valuation in a £194m fundraising.

Valuation specialist GVA Grimley has told NHP that its estate is worth £586m, or £28,500 a bed.

In 1999, rival firm DTZ Debenham Thorpe attached a much higher price tag of £42,000 a bed.

The new figure emerged in NHP's annual results, which revealed that the company had swung from an £18m profit to a £13.7m loss.

Mr Colvin said: "I'm surprised at the extent of the re-valuation but I'm not surprised at the direction of it. It's possibly even an over-reaction by Grimley."

He said he was keen to obtain the strictest possible view of the estate: "I made them actually get on their bikes and look at all 400 of our homes."

In its earlier valuation, DTZ adopted a "portfolio" approach, in which it assessed NHP's rental income from the entire estate, rather than reviewing individual properties. DTZ later reprimanded NHP for citing its figure in fundraising documents without explaining that it was a departure from common practice.

A complaint about this led to an inquiry by the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors.

Under previous management, NHP's strategy was to buy care homes and lease them to operators at competitive rates.

However, it ran into financial difficulties last year when a series of tenants went bust, amid a squeeze in healthcare funding from local authorities.

Mr Colvin yesterday indicated a change in strategy which will lead to NHP operating, rather than leasing out, some homes.

The company has taken a stake in Highfield, a Scottish operator of residential homes, to obtain a management team, and is setting up its own "management capabilities".

Mr Colvin said that in five years' time, he would like NHP to have much more day-to-day involvement in its properties, as a healthcare version of Regus - the provider of serviced offices.

However, in the short-term he will need to sell about £30m of properties to reduce debt, and there are fears that shareholders may be tapped for more funds.
