webTitle: Claims Direct takes a hit from bad press

fields.headline: Claims Direct takes a hit from bad press
fields.trailText: Claims Direct, the personal injuries claims business, yesterday issued its second profit warning in three months and admitted it had not recovered from press and television coverage of a number of dissatisfied customers' experiences.
fields.body:
Claims Direct, the personal injuries claims business, yesterday issued its second profit warning in three months and admitted it had not recovered from press and television coverage of a number of dissatisfied customers' experiences.

In November last year, the BBC's Watchdog series and the Sun newspaper unearthed angry claimants who had received little or nothing in compensation for their injuries, despite winning considerable amounts in court. Their awards were wiped out because Claims charged a £1,350 premium to cover the legal costs in the event of a lost case.

By the beginning of November, the firm had persuaded more than 5,000 personal injury victims to take out a Claims policy after a powerful TV advertising campaign which appeared to offer "no win no fee" access to the courts.

But the figure had halved by December after press coverage forced the company to issue an apology and provide £5m to dissatisfied customers. So far in January, Claims has 2,523 registered claimants.

It said in November it would introduce an "enhanced policy" that would guarantee the first £1,000 of a successful claim. However, chief executive Colin Poole said yesterday an insurance underwriter for the new policy, which is to cost £1,495, had not yet been secured.

He said that, under the Access to Justice Act 1999, which abolished legal aid for personal injury cases from last April, claimants should receive insurance costs from the defence if the claim proved successful. But defence lawyers have been resisting this change on a case by case basis, Mr Poole said.

"We know what the government are trying to do, but the legislation is just not written well enough," he said. Claim's shares yesterday closed down 59.4% at 32.5p.

webTitle: Nissan's Sunderland plant celebrates Micra contract

fields.headline: 'To have the long term reassurance is just great'
fields.trailText: Production supervisor Keith Tremble was happy to join the band celebrating in front of the Nissan plant in Sunderland yesterday, sharing in the huge sense of relief felt across the north-east at the Micra decision.
fields.body:
Production supervisor Keith Tremble was happy to join the band at Nissan in Sunderland yesterday celebrating in front of the plant's Buddhist Daruma - a good luck symbol whose eyes were handpainted by Princess Diana and Margaret Thatcher 15 years ago.

Mr Tremble shared the huge relief felt across the north-east at the Micra decision. "I'd lads on my shift who were holding back on holiday bookings and pencilling in dates to see the building society manager," he said. "The average age in here's only 27, so there's hundreds of guys just starting out on raising families."

Mr Tremble's own family fortunes hung in the balance until 9.20am, when he was called in and briefed on the good news to announce to his section 10 minutes later. A widower at only 44, he has a 15-year-old daughter who is determined to study for a law degree, and a 13-year-old who is also likely to aim for university.

"It's the long-term relief that's the best thing," he said, ticking off at least 10 years of mortgage payments on the family's semi-detached in Newcastle, plus the girls' university expenses. "I wasn't so worried about short-term prospects, even if we'd lost the new Micra. But to have the long-term reassurance is just great."

Following the Daruma principle, named after a Japanese monk who was an advocate for positive thinking, Mr Tremble's company brief was packed with the Nissan-speak which has made the Sunderland plant the most productive in Europe. The script congratulated each worker on their determination to reach the 5-5-5 goal - 500,000 cars a year, 5,000 staff and 5,000 hours a year of flexible "line time".

Across the shopfloor from Mr Tremble UK managing director John Cushnagan celebrated in the same blue boiler suit with gold-embroidered name tag common to all staff. He said: "This isn't just the most efficient workforce in Europe, it's far and away the most efficient."

Labour leader of Sunderland city council Colin Andersen said: "The people here have put in such a lot of hard work. A huge weight has been lifted off everyone's shoulders."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Lloyds set to miss the boat
Spreading the Guardian net
Valor may slash 400 jobs
FSA to add a third director
NTL raises subscriber goal
fields.body:
Lloyds set to miss the boat

A decision on whether Lloyds TSB's proposed bid for Abbey National will be referred for a competition review is likely to be delayed, according to industry sources.

The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) was due to make its recommendation on the proposed deal in time for trade secretary Stephen Byers to announce a decision by February 2.

Abbey National is planning to merge with Bank of Scotland, a deal which is expected to be cleared by regulators by February 8 -ahead of the likely decision on the Lloyds TSB bid.

Spreading the Guardian net

Guardian Unlimited, the network of websites related to the Guardian newspaper, is being rebranded to make the relationship between the two more explicit.

The core web address for the sites is changing to theguardian.com, which will be underscored by a £6m marketing campaign. The group also announced the launch of three new sites: theguardian.com/travel, to be launched in February and others devoted to politics and sport. Guardian Newspapers has so far invested about £20m in the websites over the past three years and expects to break even within three to four years.

Valor may slash 400 jobs

Up to 400 manufacturing jobs are under threat after Birmingham-based gas fire company Valor announced it is considering relocating to Preston.

A review of the business has been underway since Valor's parent company, Newmond, merged with Preston-based rival Baxi three months ago.

The company admitted that "one option being considered" is to move its manufacturing away from Birmingham, and informed the 400 Valor staff at meetings yesterday afternoon.

The Birmingham plant, which the company has described as state of the art, makes one in five of the gas fires sold in the UK.

FSA to add a third director

The financial services authority is appointing a third managing director who will be charged with improving the public's understanding of financial services, it said yesterday.

Boosting financial awareness among consumers will be a key priority during the year ahead, said the FSA in its annual plan and budget for 2001-02.

NTL raises subscriber goal

NTL, Britain's biggest cable TV company, yesterday set a target of 1.25m digital subscribers by the end of the year. At the end of last year, the figure stood at 530,700.

The company is raising its subscription prices by £2 for the basic package of TV channels. Barclay Knapp, the chief executive, forecast revenues of £2.6bn in 2001 and £3.4bn in 2002 and said that the company expected to move into profit in 2005.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Finistere
fields.trailText: Finistere
fields.body:
Cutting the grass in late January is not a horticultural experience to which life in these misty offshore isles accustoms one. But that was the clearly evident need on a quick trip to the Breton fastness last weekend.

Moreover, grass seed sown in December had germinated and grown. Sunny winter days after a light frost gave conditions pleasant enough for bike rides to the beach. Waders were picking over the exposed mud of the bay at low tide. The woodstove roared satisfactorily in the evening as we watched the televised local derby: Rennes v Guingamp (2-1 to the reds).

The week-long high pressure area with only light winds had reduced the seas in the western approaches to gentle calm; even some of the smaller fishing boats, that are operated single-handedly, were going out. Given the usual expectation of sea conditions at the west end of the Channel, ferry sailings are limited until February on the usual Plymouth-Roscoff route, so we made the trip on the Portsmouth-St Malo service.

Eastern Brittany certainly looked and felt to have had a harder winter. On the return trip we left Plougasnou well before dawn and the headlights picked out a large fox as we headed east. Tail up and looking for an early breakfast, he'd have had me groping for my shotgun in our farming days with a flock of pregnant ewes.

With that phase of life over, I don't have to worry about Reynard any more and could view his activities with equanimity. The calm seas persisted for the return; we were taking a leisurely lunch as the boat threaded its way through the Channel Isles and had views, through light mist, of Sark and Alderney.
fields.bodyText: Cutting the grass in late January is not a horticultural experience to which life in these misty offshore isles accustoms one. But that was the clearly evident need on a quick trip to the Breton fastness last weekend. Moreover, grass seed sown in December had germinated and grown. Sunny winter days after a light frost gave conditions pleasant enough for bike rides to the beach. Waders were picking over the exposed mud of the bay at low tide. The woodstove roared satisfactorily in the evening as we watched the televised local derby: Rennes v Guingamp (2-1 to the reds). The week-long high pressure area with only light winds had reduced the seas in the western approaches to gentle calm; even some of the smaller fishing boats, that are operated single-handedly, were going out. Given the usual expectation of sea conditions at the west end of the Channel, ferry sailings are limited until February on the usual Plymouth-Roscoff route, so we made the trip on the Portsmouth-St Malo service. Eastern Brittany certainly looked and felt to have had a harder winter. On the return trip we left Plougasnou well before dawn and the headlights picked out a large fox as we headed east. Tail up and looking for an early breakfast, he'd have had me groping for my shotgun in our farming days with a flock of pregnant ewes. With that phase of life over, I don't have to worry about Reynard any more and could view his activities with equanimity. webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: What goes around
fields.trailText: Horizon | EastEnders
fields.body:
On the bend of a mighty river, near the point where it meets the sea, stands the ruin of a bizarre, inexplicable circular structure. It's cost the government a fortune, it was designed by a strange, secretive group of people, and nobody can figure out what it's for. And here comes the punchline, hurtling down the tracks with lights blazing and whistles blaring... No, it's not the Millennium Dome, it's the Miami Circle, a prehistoric ruin, subject of last night's Horizon (BBC2).

In 1998, a routine archaeological survey of a patch of prime waterfront real estate revealed that the limestone bedrock was pitted with man-made holes, the larger ones forming a perfect circle. Instantly, the site was inundated with comedy Americans, who queued up to say "It's sacred - a sacred thing." (In other words they had no idea what it was.)

Inevitably, someone was on hand to say it was an astronomical calendar (aren't they all?) or, excitingly, a UFO landing pad. After all this misguided enthusiasm, it was hard not to cheer the killjoy scientist who pointed out the ruddy great 1950s septic tank in the middle of the circle. Could the whole thing actually have been a modern sewage system? It was a tempting thought, particularly as the state had just bought the land off the developer for a cool $27m.

Such was the will to believe, that some more experts were brought in who discovered that, no, the 1950s sewage-way actually disgorged straight into Biscayne Bay - great! - and that these holes must be ancient because they were covered in "duracrust". With that conviction in place, it was a hop, skip and a jump to a computer reconstruction of an American Indian settlement, complete with raised wooden floors, chic woven grass wall panels and smoke drifting up from the centrally located hearth. It wouldn't have looked out of place on the pages of Wallpaper magazine.

Doubtless the archaeology that informs these assumptions is scientifically sound; Horizon, however, smacked a little of wishful thinking. Perplexed by the dozens of additional holes on the site, in no discernible pattern, the chief digger came up with a theory to match the evidence (the floor was on stilts to avoid floods) rather than being led kicking and screaming to an irresistible conclusion, as scientists usually are.

It seemed, in fact, that he was making all this up as he went along, but such are the dangers of turning archaeology (the slowest and most unexciting science) into entertaining TV. What sounds on the screen as if it's been plucked out of the air is more probably the result of several months of poring over a teaspoon of mud, which is nobody's idea of lively Thursday-night viewing.

Janine Butcher (Charlie Brooks) is fast turning into that most revered of soap characters, the Bitch Goddess. It seems only yesterday that she was sulking dumpily round the kitchen of the Queen Vic; in last night's EastEnders (BBC1) she strode through Walford in a tailored business suit and closed deals with handsome men in wine bars.

By the end of the episode she had reincarnated herself as a slum landlady, and had reduced surrogate father Terry to hysterical sobbing in the Square. She may also have had sex with Mr Parks the Property Baron. Seldom have the words "dotted line" been invested with so much erotic promise.

Phil's spectacular trans-formation into Satan took another great leap forward last night, as the birthday boy threw a great big sulk, refused to open his presents and then subjected Lisa to public humiliation in the Vic. So unpopular is he now that the rest of the cast really should be queueing up to stab him, Murder On The Orient Express-style. "Why do women wear high heels?" he jested. "So that when they walk all over you, it hurts more!" Even Roy didn't find that funny, and Lisa, instead of glassing the jowly fool, sat there like a whipped cur and later went to confide in Mel, author of all her troubles.

If it's any comfort to Lisa, one of her neighbours is even more pathetic than she is. Martin Fowler faced up to fatherhood without enthusiasm. "Shall we get her one of those mobiles to hang over the cot?" asked big brother Mark. "Why?" replied the reluctant dad. "What would Chloe want with a phone?" Some people just don't get it.

webTitle: TV and Radio: The Virgin One ad

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Virgin One ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Virgin One ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: We see a beautifully shot sequence of black and white images that at first appear to mean one thing, but which are superimposed with captions explaining their real meaning. In the first scenario a bunch of thugs are picking on a man. A caption comes up, "The one to watch out for", and a line points to a bloke who is standing quietly at the back. Another shows a politician surrounded by photographers and cameramen. "The man who runs the country" reads the caption, pointing to a shady character beside him. The ad closes with the line: "You could be better off if you look at things differently. Virgin One - Uncommon Sense".

The jargon: The strategy is that the obvious route isn't always the right route. So the new Virgin One account (in which punters pool all their money into one pot, including their savings, mortgage and current accounts) may not appear the most obvious choice, but it makes sense if you look at it closely.

Personality: You're over 18, and you're open-minded enough to try to understand the tricky Virgin One concept. You could be in your 20s (given that young people are better at getting their heads round new things), although older folk approaching retirement might well like to dabble in something new financially.

Financial status: The Virgin One account only really benefits people on higher salaries, ie £30,000-plus. It's no good for first-time buyers either, but it can save as much as £6,000 on a £100,000 mortgage over 25 years, says agency TBWA.

Telling lifestyle detail: You're independent, you don't like to be ripped off, and you like trying out new things. You might already use other Virgin products, like Virgin Airlines.

Other relevant data: The ad is beautifully filmed, but the idea behind it isn't original. A similar device was once used by The Guardian, with its celebrated skinhead/city gent "points of view" campaign back in 1986.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Matrix | Halloween H20 | Romance
fields.body:
The Matrix
(Larry Wachowski, Andy Wachowski, 1999)
8pm, Sky Premier

Sci-fi action movie that's a kinetic thrill-a-minute joyride. Full of cool kung fu, bodies flying around the trajectory of bullets, it makes John Woo look like Anthony Asquith. The labyrinthine plot feels reminiscent of Philip K Dick, with mankind unknowingly enslaved in a virtual reality induced by a malevolent master race.

Halloween H20
(Steve Miner, 1998)
11.40pm, Sky MovieMax

Twenty years on from John Carpenter's original Halloween, Jamie Lee Curtis's Laurie, survivor of the encounter with teeny slasher Michael Myers, is now a twitchy, alcoholic single mother with a teenage son (Josh Hartnett). It's only a matter of time, of course, before Myers returns to his dirty work, and Miner has fun with several false starts before Laurie realises it's not a figment of her imagination but a real, live nightmare.

Romance
(Catherine Breillat, 1999)
11.45pm, FilmFour

The story of schoolteacher Marie (played by Caroline Ducey) who, confronted by her partner's sexual indifference (he has imposed a state of celibacy within their relationship; she's deeply in love with him, but can't handle the lack of intimacy) embarks on an erotic journey that becomes increasingly masochistic. The presence of Italian porn star Rocco Siffredi's as one of Marie's new lovers is as indication as to how finely director Catherine Breillat's exploration of female sexuality treads the line between arthouse and pornography.

Fallen Angels
(Wong Kar-Wei, 1995)
3.30am, FilmFour

A Hong Kong hitman (played by Leon Lai) wants to quit the job - he's fed up with digging bullets out of his body ("It's so exhausting"). Meanwhile, his boss (Michelle Reis) harbours a secret longing for him. Elsewhere, mute ex-con Takeshi Kaneshiro, who forces food, shampoos and ice cream on people he encounters, meets a strange young woman (Charlie Young) who is looking for her lover. Paths interweave in an abstracted, dreamlike, visually compelling account of big-city alienation.

fields.headline: When the going got tough
fields.standfirst: In his acceptance speech for the Whitbread prize this week, Matthew Kneale talked about the slog of writing his book English Passengers, and how he almost gave it up to become a lawyer. Merope Mills and Abbie Kornstein ask other artistic spirits whether they ever came close to giving up their vocation
fields.trailText: In his acceptance speech for the Whitbread prize this week, Matthew Kneale talked about the slog of writing his book English Passengers, and how he almost gave it up to become a lawyer. Merope Mills and Abbie Kornstein ask other artistic spirits whether they ever came close to giving up their vocation.
fields.body:
Ian McEwan, author

I did actually think about giving it up back in my 20s. Not because I wanted to give up fiction but because I wanted to go back to university and do a science degree. It was less to do with the frustration of writing and more to do with the fact that I thought my education wasn't complete. I was quite keen on finishing it off with a degree in biological sciences or something similar. That's the closest I've ever come to changing career paths. But the idea of becoming a lawyer or a solicitor? That fills me with horror. I would never have done that.

Bernard Butler, musician

I did say at one point that I had thought about giving up music to become a professional snooker player. It was a bit of a joke, but I really do love snooker. I was very down at the time. I'd lost my record deal and I was moping around, and if you're an artist and you're fairly rock bottom you have to strip away everything in order to realise what you're good at and not good at. I play snooker all the time; I'm a member of a club. I'm obsessed by it but the truth is, I'm not that good at it. I'm slightly better at writing songs. I'd love to become a professional snooker player. I idolise snooker players a whole lot more than any current musicians but I'm not exactly sure I could make a living out of it.

Meera Syal, comedian & author

I very nearly did take a different career. The year I graduated I had an MA place lined up to do drama and psychotherapy and then a postgraduate certificate in education the year after that to teach children with learning difficulties through drama. I never finished the training, so when I got involved in comedy it was difficult to think of myself going back to that because I would have still had to retrain. But still I went through the thought process. I think everyone does when things are going bad. I've always had an interest in that area and now that I've got a wealth of experience in drama it might help if I did ever go back to it. You have to think about these things because the business is just so horribly insecure like that.

JG Ballard, author

I've often thought about giving it all up. Yes, I'd like to run a nightclub in Miami. Early on, I'm not sure whether I could have given it up. I was in the grip of a very strange obsession, writing all this fiction. And it is what I most enjoy doing. But running a nightclub? Yes, that might have been fun too.

Hanif Kureishi, playwright

I did think in some desperation at one point that I might have to become an academic. That was the only serious rethink. One has dreams of becoming a pop star but the only other serious career I considered was to teach philosophy, which I studied at university. I did think I might have to do that. I was very interested in philosophy and it was a very difficult time. It was about three years after I left university. I was writing but I wasn't getting very far. I didn't have much money. I was beginning to think about other options and I thought, I'm going to have to do a PhD. But very soon after that I had my first grown-up production and things changed for the better. But there was a very nerve-racking time when I thought I might have to get a proper job.

Steven Isserlis, classical musician

I'm not a writer but there were certainly many times in my 20s when my career seemed to be going nowhere and I felt like giving up. The problem was that I wasn't any good at anything else.

Vanessa-Mae, violinist

I have felt like throwing it all in. The first time I embarked on a world tour as a 15-year-old, most of my schoolfriends were on their summer holidays, so there were several moments during that tour when exhaustion got the better of me and I wished I could just throw it all in and go and join them on their beaches. But every time I walked out on to the stage for another show, the thrill of performing live and the satisfaction of exciting a whole new audience reminded me why I was there in the first place. I am generally a fickle person, so the attractions of an alternative career or lifestyle never appeal to me for long.

Ralph Steadman, artist and author

I have felt like giving up and becoming a matinee idol in the early black and white films. In 1994 I was promoting Tales of the Weird. On the morning I was about to go off on an author's tour, I said ''I'm not going'' to my agent. It felt like my work was all about bookshops; they do well but the author doesn't. I felt I was busting my ass for these people. After I'd done four hours' signing, they made me do the store's books and then the employees' books. All it did was feed my ego. When I'm not doing anything I get depressed and think about giving it all up, but what would I do?

Joanne Harris, author

Before I took up writing full time I had a day job as a teacher and never hankered to leave. It took me a very long time to jack it in, but I had to because of the demands placed on me when I became a successful writer. I liked working and feared losing contact with people, but it is a very lucky writer who has the choice of giving up their day job.

Alan Bleasdale, author

If I did give it up I'd definitely want to be a football manager. But once I was a writer I couldn't be anything else. For 27 years I was a human being and for 27 years I've been a writer. I was a teacher and loved it, but once I got a break into writing I could never go back. You have to do things 100%.

Andrew Motion, poet laureate

With poems, if other jobs become strangely alluring, you really can go and do something about it because poems can fit around another job quite easily. I tried a stint as a freelance poet, but you can't really live like that, even if you wanted to. I ran Poetry Review and worked in publishing for a while, which was always in my area. When the difficulties of being a poet got me down I always felt there was something within the field of poetry that I could turn to.

webTitle: Rebecca Mead  on the new virginity

fields.headline: The joy of not having sex yet
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Mead  on the new virginity
fields.trailText: Rebecca Mead on the new virginity.
fields.body:
Just as every generation of teenagers acts as if it is the first to discover sex, every generation of middle-aged adults acts as if it is the first to discover that teenagers are having sex. Certainly the current generation of middle-aged American adults is acting that way, since teen sex has become something of a cultural preoccupation here.

The Washington Post ran a front-page story a year or two ago that chronicled the sexual activities of a bunch of upper-middle-class 13-year-olds and reported that a bacchanal of blow jobs was taking place behind the bike sheds.

Then Talk magazine ran a quivering article entitled "The Sex Lives of Your Children," in which teenagers were interviewed in probing detail about their proclivities. These tended to the wildly gymnastic, to the point of actually including gymnasium equipment. A reader might well have suspected that the kids in question were pulling the reporter's leg, whatever else they were doing to each other's extremities.

This month, the government has made its own contribution to the teen-sex literature, with a report by the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development on teen sexual activity. In particular, the report centred on the efficacy of the "virginity pledge," a swearing-off of sex before marriage that has, apparently, been in vogue in recent years among teens, at least those not interviewed by the Washington Post or Talk magazine.

The virginity movement has been orchestrated since the early 90s by a Southern Baptist Church group called True Love Waits, and abetted by the likes of Britney Spears, who, according to many media reports, intends to save herself for the marital bed.

Though the report actually revealed that true love waits only for a little while - teenagers who take the virginity pledge postpone sexual relations for, on average, a third longer than those who don't - its findings were greeted with enthusiasm by Jim Hester, the group's coordinator. He told the New York Times that it provided "great news".

Actually, the details were far more ambiguous. Taking the pledge had the biggest effect on teenagers aged between 15 and 17; 18-year-old pledgers ended up having sex around the same time as their non-pledging peers. And pledgers, when they did eventually give it up, were less likely to engage in safe sex because, as the report's authors pointed out without any apparent irony, there is a contradiction in promising to save yourself and carrying a condom.

The report also reveals that taking the pledge amounted to an adoption of style, rather than an expression of conviction, something that will not surprise anyone who has ever experienced teenage anxiety over owning the right brand of sneakers.

Teenagers stuck to their virginal guns so long as only a few kids in the school were doing it; once pledging became mainstream, it stopped making the slightest difference to behaviour. And, stunningly, the researchers measured only what used to be called "technical virginity", and didn't ask teenagers about engaging in oral or anal sex. But one look at the racks of teen magazines would have revealed that what is being pushed to teenagers now isn't celibacy, but a kind of hot virginity, in which a girl (or boy) will do anything but.

This week, the US supreme court announced that it would be weighing in on the youth sex issue, too: later this year, the justices will attempt to determine whether or not the first amendment permits criminalising computer-generated pornographic images of minors.

There is already a federal law against distributing, receiving or possessing pornographic images of minors, or images of adults who look like minors. Of course, context is all: a video by Britney Spears might fall under that definition of child pornography. It isn't making light of child pornography to suggest that underlying the current public fuss in America about teen sex is an uneasy titillation.

Reading articles about the terrible things that teenagers are up to - or swearing off - provides a satisfying opportunity for both prurience and outrage; and so, for that matter, does writing them. It's smut with a clean conscience. If those readers and writers were honest with themselves, though, they might admit that the cleanliness of their consciences is only technical.

fields.headline: No: 1809
fields.standfirst: Nipper
fields.trailText: Nipper
fields.body:
Born: 1884.

Died: 1895. A brief life, but not bad for a fox terrier.

Appearance: As other fox terriers, essentially.

Rationale behind highly original name: Nipping the heels of visitors. And being rather small, perhaps.

Enthusiasms: Chasing sticks, chewing bones, all that stuff; but, chiefly, staring quizzically into the horn of an old gramophone in complete bewilderment as if struggling to comprehend the musical merits of the latest Girl Thing single.

Not a particularly auspicious recipe for attaining worldwide stardom as the logo for record label EMI and HMV music shops. Indeed. That only came about as a result of his tireless attending of auditions, writing begging letters to other famous dogs, participating in dodgy ITV reality shows, etcetera.

Enough anthropomorphism already! Fair enough. Actually, Nipper was rescued from a desperate life as a stray on the streets of Bristol by Mark Barraud, a local scenic designer at the city's Prince's Theatre. He was adopted by Barraud's brother Francis when Mark died, and then he pegged it. A dog's life, basically. Only this week, more than a century later, was he finally rewarded with a blue plaque on Mark's old house in Bristol.

So what catapulted him to fame? Francis was a talented artist, who chanced to paint his four-legged friend as Nipper contemplated the new-fangled recording device. He was less talented in titling his work, which he called Dog Looking at and Listening to a Phonograph. In 1899, the then Gramophone Company snapped up the picture for £100, copyright and all. His Master's Voice was trademarked a decade later, and a brand was born.

Still, time for an updated version? A cute puppy looking curiously at a minidisc player? I think the guys at HMV marketing will probably take a raincheck on that one.

Most likely to say: "What? Let's try this one more time: he was a dog."

Not to be confused with: Greyfriars Bobby, Gnasher, Gnipper, Napster.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: A Revolution in Five Acts | Evening Concert
fields.body:
If you had to choose one telling image of the Victorian age it would probably be that of the child chimney sweep. For the final segment of A Revolution In Five Acts (11.0am, Radio 4), recalling laws which transformed 19th century Britain, Ian Hislop looks at the Chimney Sweeps' Act of 1875. Its moving spirit was Lord Shaftesbury, who discovered that small children were still being killed in chimneys in spite of earlier legislation. The passage of his act ended the worst period of Victorian exploitation.

Nicholas Tresilian marks what would have been Jacqueline Du Pré's 56th birthday in tonight's Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). The cellist died of multiple sclerosis in 1987, having been unable to give public performances for 12 years. But she continued to play in private and to teach almost to the last. Curiously, tonight's recordings don't include her most famous, that of the Elgar concerto. The highlight is Beethoven's Cello Sonata No 2.

webTitle: Jailed Iranian dissidents predict bloody backlash

fields.headline: Jailed Iranian dissidents predict bloody backlash
fields.standfirst: Reforming journalists continue their battle for free expression from their Tehran prison cell
fields.trailText: Reforming journalists continue their battle for free expression from their Tehran prison cell.
fields.body:
From the jail cell he shares with three other dissidents Iran's most famous investigative journalist, Akbar Ganji, has predicted that a violent backlash against the conservative establishment will free him and his fellow prisoners from dictatorship.

In a covert interview arranged after his conviction was made public on January 13, Ganji said that a series of unlawful acts, including his own imprisonment and that of seven others, would incite Iranians to rebel against the conservatives' hold on power.

They were convicted of trying to overthrow the Islamic republic while attending a seminar in Berlin last year.

In response to questions smuggled into Tehran's notorious Evin prison, Ganji told the Guardian: "Slowly and step by step, [the] fascist interpretation of religion will lead to terrorist acts and other crimes which take place for the sole aim of shedding blood and demanding bloodshed in revenge. Future events will act as a detonator for an explosion."

The 12 sq metre cell, equipped with a television, a refrigerator and a desk, has become the headquarters of reformers committed to freedom of thought and expression.

Mashallah Shamsolvaezin, the founder of a string of progressive newspapers banned in the past three years, is a cellmate, as is Latif Safari, the former publisher of the progressive newspaper Neshat.

Emaddedin Baqi, another prominent journalist and former cleric, who wrote for reformist papers, is also there.

"My friends and I are prisoners of conscience cum political prisoners ... in reality we are the hostages of our opponents who have put us in prison because of their control of the judicial apparatus," said Safari, who has 19 months left to serve in prison.

The judiciary has become the instrument of the conservative campaign to jail dissidents, government officials, clerics and anyone else considered an opponent. With the tacit approval of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, it has silenced nearly all their rivals.

This week the reformist deputy interior minister, Mostafa Tajzadeh, became the latest victim, summoned to a court only to be told he would be tried unexpectedly behind closed doors. The charge was "aiding and abetting the distortion of Tehran residents' votes during parliamentary elections" last February. He was given bail of £8,600, and 10 days to present a defence.

Analysts say the conservatives intend to remove him from his post before the presidential election due in June. Mr Tajzadeh, who is responsible for supervising elections, is a key ally of the reformist president, Mohammad Khatami.

Ganji was given the harshest sentence of those convicted in the Berlin case. They had attended the seminar in Germany in April to debate the future of the reform movement. Those tried included the student leader Ali Afshari, the feminist lawyer Mehranguiz Kar, and the editor Ezatollah Sahabi.

The influential cleric Hassan Yusefi Eshkevari, who also attended the seminar, was tried in a clerical court last year. He is thought to have been sentenced to death, although it has not been made public.

The verdicts are seen both inside and outside Iran as the death throes of the fledgling reform movement.

But Shamsolvaezin, who is serving a 30-month sentence, said the reformists could only lose momentum when the people turned their backs on demands for civil liberties. "And the people of Iran are not turning their backs on these demands."

webTitle: The truth about film-maker FW Murnau

fields.headline: A bloody disgrace
fields.standfirst: In Shadow of the Vampire, film-maker FW Murnau is portrayed as a hollering dictator running amok on sets. Untrue, says  Michael Atkinson  - he was a director of rare sensitivity and genius
fields.trailText: In Shadow of the Vampire, film-maker FW Murnau is portrayed as a hollering dictator running amok on sets. Untrue, says Michael Atkinson - he was a director of rare sensitivity and genius
fields.body:
Was Max Schreck a real vampire? Did the star of Nosferatu, the 1922 horror classic, strike a bargain with its director FW Murnau - to appear in his movie in return for being allowed to drain the entire cast and crew of their blood afterwards? E Elias Merhige's semi-serious comedy Shadow of the Vampire, starring Willem Dafoe as Schreck, takes this much-mooted fantasy and runs with it to remarkably silly effect.

Film buffs have long wondered about Schreck, with his unforgettable visage, ridiculous name ("schreck" means "horror" in German), and sketchy CV. Could this creepiest of silent goths have harboured a ghastly secret we could only guess at? Such gruesome speculation has only served to invest Nosferatu with an extra frisson singular among German expressionist landmarks.

Of course, Schreck was as human as you or I, and no one on the set of Nosferatu actually died. But Shadow of the Vampire only strives for historical accuracy half of the time, and Merhige and screenwriter Steven Katz have a fine old time playing around with the facts. But re-imagining Schreck as his most famous incarnation is only Shadow of the Vampire's most conspicuous untruth. The film also manipulates and manhandles the legend of Murnau himself. John Malkovich plays Murnau as a Teutonic professor running amok in a lab coat and goggles. Ready to sacrifice life, limb and cast members to get "the shot", he's a stereotypical director-as-dictator, convinced that since art (and movies) last more or less forever and people don't, then one is expendable in the service of the other.

The closest off-screen double to this Murnau is Werner Herzog, the world's most gonzo film-maker and centrepiece of some of the most spectacular and extreme making-of-a-movie stories ever heard. Herzog actually remade Nosferatu in 1977 and, although Klaus Kinski, the lead, was not a real vampire, he was a very real nut. This made him the perfect foil for Herzog, who, unable to get the right shade of rat he wanted for filming, simply painted thousands of white rats grey. Then, notoriously, he let them loose in Bremen.

But the real Murnau was a very different animal. Born Friedrich Wilhelm Plumpe, Murnau was by all accounts a perfectly decent, disciplined professional - a gay aesthete and self-doubting artist who saw plenty of action as a combat pilot in the first world war and subsequently segued into a career as a theatre director and propaganda editor. He broke into film-making in 1919 and quickly distinguished himself within the German expressionist movement, and had made nine films in three short years before arriving at Nosferatu in 1922. Most of these films are lost (including Der Januskopf, a Jekyll-Hyde rendition starring Bela Lugosi and Conrad Veidt), but the few that aren't, like 1921's The Haunted Castle, are forgettable nonsense.

Nosferatu is a quantum leap, an experimental, moody, fluid nightmare that plays today like a crypt dream, damp, rank and perverse. Less a "masterpiece" than an artefact whose age and primitive mould contribute lavishly to its effect, Nosferatu was nevertheless a vast improvement in cinematic grace and visual originality over the influential German silents released up until that time, even Paul Wegener's The Golem and Fritz Lang's Spiders.

The film's story - essentially Dracula with the names changed to appease Bram Stoker's angry widow - seems to have been incidental for Murnau. He was one of cinema's first poets and his haphazard, accident-strewn body of work leaves the impression of an artist more in love with the abstract possibilities of movies than with the stories he was filming. Monsters, tragedies, lovers - all paled for him beside the simple sensation of cinematic motion.

Cinema has always been "about" visual movement, starting with 1902's The Great Train Robbery, with its seminal third sequence - shot from the top of a moving train. In that moment, movies departed from any other pre-existing art or cultural form and became quintessentially "cinematic" - suddenly, a ribbon of film could do things that no other medium could ever do. Griffith and others used the magnetic power of travelling shots to limited effect, but it was Murnau who revealed that moving the camera in conjunction with action and locale was an act of almost magical force, an unspoken, majestic poetry that still seems to be one of the form's most sublime achievements.

Take The Last Laugh (1923), a systematic morality tale about a pompous doorman (Emil Jannings) reduced to a washroom attendant. Now an overused film-school lynchpin , it is remembered less than fondly today. But, looking at it again, the movie is a workshop of experimental ideas, from multiple exposures to warped lenses. The camera hardly stops moving in The Last Laugh. Murnau didn't film a narrative so much as let one happen while he documented the visual-emotional terrain around it, moving in single shots from room to room, from inside the hotel to the street, up and down stairs, and so on. In this way, Murnau became the first powerhouse of mise-en-scène, creating for us a fully 3D world that was completely convincing and progressed for us far beyond the frame edge. Murnau had created that mysterious and still under-appreciated cinematic device: off-screen space.

His subsequent films - including a restless version of Tartuffe and a hellzapoppin' version of Goethe's Faust (both 1926) - are German expressionist classics. The latter's sorcerous night-time cityscapes and looming demonic visions are unforgettable (The Crow, for one, could not have existed without it). In both films, as critic David Thomson has pointed out, Murnau took the studied, decorative dead end of expressionism to another level, where it was free to roam and find poetry in the everyday.

But it wasn't until Murnau hightailed it to Hollywood that his talent was given full rein (and, as historian Lotte Eisner noted, Murnau's homosexuality was no longer subject to intolerant German law). Contracted by 20th Century Fox, Murnau took a minor, trite story about marital crisis and resolution - subtitled A Song of Two Humans - and crafted what was to become his 1927 masterpiece, Sunrise.

Anything but gothic, Sunrise is a rhapsodic, romantic work, and yet the simplistic story and its eventually conservative message were, typically for Murnau, secondary concerns. It was here that the director's camera really soared. The passage in which the discontented country husband (George O'Brien) leaves his wife (Janet Gaynor) and baby behind to meet his trampy, urbanised lover in the moonlit swamplands is, by itself, a testament to the glories of cinematic vision.

But even that sequence was beaten by the celebrated trolley scene, in which the couple (the wife now trying to escape from her apologetic husband, who came close to murdering her) take a trolley ride (with Murnau's camera) that passes from the wooded countryside to the city's bustling edge. During the ride, the two characters avoid each other's eyes. As they furtively gaze into space, we watch from our own seats the landscape passing around them, and the movement itself tells us all we'd ever want to know about marriage and fate, about being locked into powerful coupledom that's equal parts devotion and danger as the world outside rockets by.

Sunrise showcased every visual flourish Murnau could imagine, and it is a breath-taking achievement. Its failure at the box office, however, seriously restricted Murnau's subsequent studio projects, and he eventually left for Tahiti with documentarian Robert Flaherty to make Tabu (1931). Another conspicuously minor story - tribal laws obstruct the course of true love - Tabu is 90% Murnau, Flaherty having quit some time during shooting. It's difficult to imagine a less opportune pairing than Murnau the spatial poet and Flaherty the practical anthropologist, but Murnau's input ensures that Tabu isn't the travesty it could have been. It is, in fact, a beautiful, sun-soaked portrait of a 3D place lyricised by Murnau's expert eye.

Murnau's blossoming American career was cut cruelly short. On the verge of signing with the much more auteur-friendly Paramount, Murnau and his chauffeur died in a car crash on the Pacific coastal highway. (Persistent rumours about the two being engaged in oral sex prior to the crash came courtesy of celebrated scandal-peddler Kenneth Anger.) Murnau was just 42.

Murnau was a million miles from the hollering, self-serving autocrat Malkovich portrays him as in Shadow of the Vampire. He was a delicate artist, forever negotiating with industry and society, and tolerating pulp fiction in the service of getting the movie camera to fulfil its destiny. Certainly, he was the least "vampiric" of any major director this side of Renoir.

Shadow of the Vampire is funny and sharp. But if you want a true portrait of the artist, see Sunrise. By any standards, it is essential viewing.

&3149; Shadow of the Vampire is released on Friday February 2. The Murnau season is at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), until January 30.

Murnau had created that mysterious and still under-appreciated cinematic device: off-screen space. His subsequent films - including a restless version of Tartuffe and a hellzapoppin' version of Goethe's Faust (both 1926) - are German expressionist classics. The latter's sorcerous night-time cityscapes and looming demonic visions are unforgettable (The Crow, for one, could not have existed without it). In both films, as critic David Thomson has pointed out, Murnau took the studied, decorative dead end of expressionism to another level, where it was free to roam and find poetry in the everyday. But it wasn't until Murnau hightailed it to Hollywood that his talent was given full rein (and, as historian Lotte Eisner noted, Murnau's homosexuality was no longer subject to intolerant German law). Contracted by 20th Century Fox, Murnau took a minor, trite story about marital crisis and resolution - subtitled A Song of Two Humans - and crafted what was to become his 1927 masterpiece, Sunrise. Anything but gothic, Sunrise is a rhapsodic, romantic work, and yet the simplistic story and its eventually conservative message were, typically for Murnau, secondary concerns. It was here that the director's camera really soared. The passage in which the discontented country husband (George O'Brien) leaves his wife (Janet Gaynor) and baby behind to meet his trampy, urbanised lover in the moonlit swamplands is, by itself, a testament to the glories of cinematic vision. But even that sequence was beaten by the celebrated trolley scene, in which the couple (the wife now trying to escape from her apologetic husband, who came close to murdering her) take a trolley ride (with Murnau's camera) that passes from the wooded countryside to the city's bustling edge. During the ride, the two characters avoid each other's eyes. As they furtively gaze into space, we watch from our own seats the landscape passing around them, and the movement itself tells us all we'd ever want to know about marriage and fate, about being locked into powerful coupledom that's equal parts devotion and danger as the world outside rockets by. Sunrise showcased every visual flourish Murnau could imagine, and it is a breath-taking achievement. Its failure at the box office, however, seriously restricted Murnau's subsequent studio projects, and he eventually left for Tahiti with documentarian Robert Flaherty to make Tabu (1931). Another conspicuously minor story - tribal laws obstruct the course of true love - Tabu is 90% Murnau, Flaherty having quit some time during shooting. It's difficult to imagine a less opportune pairing than Murnau the spatial poet and Flaherty the practical anthropologist, but Murnau's input ensures that Tabu isn't the travesty it could have been. It is, in fact, a beautiful, sun-soaked portrait of a 3D place lyricised by Murnau's expert eye. Murnau's blossoming American career was cut cruelly short. On the verge of signing with the much more auteur-friendly Paramount, Murnau and his chauffeur died in a car crash on the Pacific coastal highway. (Persistent rumours about the two being engaged in oral sex prior to the crash came courtesy of celebrated scandal-peddler Kenneth Anger.) Murnau was just 42. Murnau was a million miles from the hollering, self-serving autocrat Malkovich portrays him as in Shadow of the Vampire. He was a delicate artist, forever negotiating with industry and society, and tolerating pulp fiction in the service of getting the movie camera to fulfil its destiny. Certainly, he was the least "vampiric" of any major director this side of Renoir. Shadow of the Vampire is funny and sharp. But if you want a true portrait of the artist, see Sunrise. By any standards, it is essential viewing. &3149; Shadow of the Vampire is released on Friday February 2. The Murnau season is at the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), until January 30.

fields.headline: Joseph O'Conor
fields.standfirst: Master craftsman of stage, screen and television
fields.trailText: Master craftsman of stage, screen and television.
fields.body:
The actor Joseph O'Conor, who has died aged 84, appeared in 1966 in BBC Television's last great success of the black-and-white era, The Forsyte Saga, playing the stern patriarch Old Jolyon.

On the big screen his career ranged from Stranger at my Door (1950) to Luc Besson's Messenger: The Story of Joan of Arc (1999) - taking in Mr Brownlow in the 1968 movie of Lionel Bart's Oliver! The latter was a role for which, with his authoritative, kindly demeanour, he was perfect casting.

But O'Conor's natural home was the stage. His 60th and last Shakespearean role was as Duncan to Sir Antony Sher's Macbeth for the Royal Shakespeare Company. The production began at Stratford in 1999, then toured. O'Conor was flown home from Japan when his failing heart forced him to step down, but within weeks was back for the Young Vic run, his voice older but his presence still commanding. The production was screened on Channel 4 on New Year's Day.

O'Conor was born in Seattle to Irish parents and, though almost all his life was spent in south-west London, he remained proudly Irish. He was educated at Cardinal Vaughan School in Kensington, and after the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art made his prewar debut in an Embassy Swiss Cottage production of Julius Caesar. At the end of the 1940s he joined the touring company of the last of the great actor-managers, Donald Wolfit, at the Bedford theatre in Camden Town. Wolfit valued his young protégé, giving him a string of Shakespearean parts. The pair alternated as Othello and Iago, and Wolfit vouchsafed his Gravedigger to O'Conor's acclaimed Hamlet.

At the Bristol Old Vic in the late 1950s he played many leads - alongside Peter O'Toole among others - including the role of Henry Higgins in George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion. There was also a production of his own early play, The Iron Harp, set in his beloved Ireland. That play gave a first important role to Richard Harris, and O'Conor wrote five others.

West End aside, his career took in an American tour, appearances in the York mystery plays, at the Glasgow Citizens', and at reps such as Windsor and Guildford. As an incurable company man from the 1970s, he enjoyed several seasons with both the National Theatre and the Royal Shakespeare Company. His years with the latter were especially happy, founded on great mutual respect and affection.

O'Conor enjoyed a fertile period acting for Jonathan Miller, most notably as the Duke in Measure for Measure in 1975. And the lure in the 70s and 80s of the actor George Murcell's ill-starred Shakespeare company at the St George's Theatre in Tufnell Park, London, proved irresistible.

There were many other film appearances, including Tom And Viv (1994) and Elizabeth (1998). A highlight was the festival favourite The Forbidden Quest (1993), directed by Peter Delpuit, which gave O'Conor a unique one-man vehicle as a polar survivor.

I was lucky enough to produce one of the very best of his many TV performances when he led the cast of Drew Griffiths' and Noel Greig's Only Connect (1979). As a devout Catholic, O'Conor had an intellectual objection to abortion, adultery and homosexuality, but in his life and work he was understanding and supportive. In Only Connect, he played a man who in extreme youth had had a sexual encounter with the writer and prophet Edward Carpenter. The play confronted a very thorny issue for gay men, that of ageism, and O'Conor embraced the theme with a generous heart.

The production coincided with his marriage to the actress Lizanne Rodger, who was young enough to be his daughter, and so O'Conor had a special connection to the material of the play, which informed his work on it.

In that play, as so often, he was cast older than he was. Kenneth More, who played his son in The Forsyte Saga, was actually two years older than O'Conor, to their shared amusement. Prematurely white-haired, but also unmistakably mature, wise and protective - and sometimes impish and whimsical - he was a natural Chebutykin in Chekhov's Three Sisters.

He rewrote as novels some of his other plays, such as Inca (sadly eclipsed by Peter Shaffer's The Royal Hunt Of The Sun) and The Lion Trap. Among his children's stories, he got to read King Canoodlum and the Great Horned Cheese on television's Jackanory. In his last months, he completed his memoirs.

He was married first to Naita Moore; they had a daughter Rachel and a son Joseph. With Lizanne Rodger, he had two more children, Charlotte and Kit.

 Joseph O'Conor, actor and writer, born February 14 1916; died January 21 2001

webTitle: G2: Profile of Palestinian fighter Leila Khaled

fields.headline: 'I made the ring from a bullet and the pin of a hand grenade'
fields.standfirst:
When Palestinian liberation fighter Leila Khaled hijacked her first plane in 1969, she became the international pin-up of armed struggle. Then she underwent cosmetic surgery so she could do it again. Thirty years on, she talks to Katharine Viner about being a woman at war

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: When Palestinian liberation fighter Leila Khaled hijacked her first plane in 1969, she became the international pin-up of armed struggle. Then she underwent cosmetic surgery so she could do it again. Thirty years on, she talks to Katharine Viner about being a woman at war.
fields.body:
In a way, the whole story is in the ring. The iconic photograph of Leila Khaled, the picture which made her the symbol of Palestinian resistance and female power, is extraordinary in many ways: the gun held in fragile hands, the shiny hair wrapped in a keffiah , the delicate Audrey Hepburn face refusing to meet your eye. But it's the ring, resting delicately on her third finger. To fuse an object of feminine adornment, of frivolity, with a bullet: that is Khaled's story, the reason behind her image's enduring power. Beauty mixed with violence.

And the ring? "I made it from the pin of a hand grenade - from the first grenade I ever used in training," she says. "I just wrapped it around a bullet."

Leila Khaled - international hijacker for the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), the papers' favourite 70s "girl terrorist" and "deadly beauty" - is now 57, and sitting with me in the House of Commons for her first ever interview on British soil. Her cheekbones are still like knives; her eyes are gentle but flicker when moved. She has a Rothmans cigarette constantly dangling languorously between her fingers (she once said of a potentially boring time in Kuwait: "I was politically conscious and a chain smoker - I needed no other diversions").

She is, of course, wearing a keffiah , fringed with wool in the Palestinian colours of red, green, black and white, like a shawl. But she looks very different now from the way she did in that famous photo, and not just because of age. Since that picture was taken in 1969, after her first (successful) hijack of a TWA plane, Khaled underwent no fewer than six cosmetic operations on her face, so that no one would ever recognise her again. She refused to wander around with the face of an icon.

"The surgeon just made a few differences to my nose and my chin," she says. "But it worked. No one recognised me." She elected to have surgery without a general anaesthetic; because, as she said in her autobiography: "I have a cause higher and nobler than my own, a cause to which all private interests and concerns must be subordinated."

Such revolutionary-speak is a reminder that Khaled is from a very different time: an age when hijacks were a political tool of the moment, when commitment, extreme risk and sacrifice were admired and often romanticised. Her sexuality was always emphasised; as recently as 1980, a Norwegian newspaper made jokes about her "bombs" (Norwegian slang for breasts) and she is supposed to have been the inspiration for Leela, Dr Who's foxy sidekick in 1975.

She is the pin-up of armed struggle; like her hero, Che Guevara, Khaled had the glamour as well as the belief. She had a certain disdain for her fellow western revolutionaries, however: "We found it very amusing that they honestly believed they were making a 'revolution' if they undressed in public, seized a university building, or shouted an obscenity at bureaucrats," she says.

The surgery meant that Khaled was able to undertake her second hijack without detection; this time of an El Al jet from Amsterdam. "At Amsterdam airport my comrade Patrick [Arguello, a Nicaraguan] and I were stopped by Israeli officers," she says. "They searched our bags very thoroughly, but they didn't find anything in there. Because the grenades were in my pockets." She takes a deep breath. "We had passports from Honduras. The officer said to me, 'do you speak Spanish?' At once I said, 'Si señor' - I was lucky, because they were the only words I knew."

In mid-flight, Khaled and Arguello tried to storm the cockpit. They banged on the door; Khaled took the pins out of her grenades with her teeth and ordered the captain to let them in. But there were armed guards on the plane and they began to shoot. "Patrick was shot in the back four times, and another man came with a bottle of whisky and banged it over his head," says Khaled. "It was terrible." Why didn't they shoot her? "I had grenades," she says, with a shrug of her shoulders. "Eventually I was hit on the back of my head, and I lost consciousness. When I woke up I was tied up and being kicked.

"Passengers were shouting; I heard a woman scream, 'Stop the bloodshed'. But we had very strict instructions: don't hurt the passengers. Only defend yourselves."

But the grenades would have hurt the passengers, had she released them. "I did not want to blow up the plane," she says, sternly. "It was only to threaten." (While the PFLP was involved in other controversial armed actions in Israel, including some which led to the deaths of civilians, no one died during either of the hijacks in which Khaled was involved.

The plane landed at Heathrow and Khaled was taken to Ealing police station where she was held for 28 days, until the then prime minister, Edward Heath, released her in exchange for western hostages held by the PFLP. Her stay in Britain was pleasant, she says. "People were very nice. They would say to each other: is she the one? They could hardly believe it, this tiny creature sitting on the bench. I was 26 and I was very thin. I had two policewomen with me in my cell, and we were always discussing our cause and our suffering. After I left I sent them books about Palestine; they asked me to. We wrote to each other. One of them had a problem with her boyfriend, and we often discussed this."

It's an intriguing thought: the Palestinian revolutionary and the Ealing policewoman finding common ground by discussing men.

Although it is not, perhaps, so surprising. Women have always related to Khaled. As Eileen Macdonald, in her book Shoot the Women First, puts it: "She shattered a million and one taboos overnight and she revolutionised the thinking of hundreds of other angry young women around the world."

She flamboyantly overcame the patriarchal restrictions of Arab society where women are traditionally subservient to their husbands, by taking an equal fighting role with men, by getting divorced and remarried, having children in her late 30s, and rejecting vanity by having her face reconstructed for her cause.

There were difficulties with being both a woman and a fighter, however. "In the beginning, all women had to prove that we could be equal to men in armed struggle," says Khaled. "So we wanted to be like men - even in our appearance." Robin Morgan, in her book, The Demon Lover: The Sexuality of Terrorism, writes about how Khaled lost out in two ways.

The men in her organisation resented the attention she got, while women were frustrated that she never spoke about women, only about the revolution. (She once said, "I represent Palestinians, not women.") This has echoes of something Mairead Farrell, the IRA volunteer who was shot dead by the SAS in Gibraltar in 1988, once said: "I'm oppressed as a woman, but I'm also oppressed because I'm Irish ... We can't succesfully end our oppression as women until we first end the oppression of our country."

But things seem to have changed for Khaled. "I no longer think it's necessary to prove ourselves as women by imitating men," she says. "I have learned that a woman can be a fighter, a freedom fighter, a political activist, and that she can fall in love, and be loved, she can be married, have children, be a mother.

"You see, at the beginning we were only interested in the revolution. We were not mature enough politically. The question of women is a part of our struggle but not the only part. Revolution must mean life also; every aspect of life." Is she a Palestinian first, or a woman first? "I cannot differentiate," she says. "A woman and a Palestinian at the same time."

Khaled was born in Haifa, now on the Israeli coast, but became a refugee with her family at a camp in Tyre, Lebanon, as a toddler in 1948. (During her 1969 hijacking of the TWA flight she forced the pilot to fly over Haifa, so that she could look at the home town she was not permitted to visit.) She can barely recall a time when she was not politicised: she remembers at the age of four being told by her mother not to pick oranges because they were in Lebanon; the fruit was not theirs, they were not in Haifa now. She committed herself full-time to armed struggle at the age of 15.

Since the time of the hijacks, Khaled has lived in Lebanon, Syria and Jordan, and has brought up two sons who are now 18 and 15. She continued her activism, first as a fighter and then as a politician for the PFLP as a member of the Palestinian National Council. (Her sons offer to be her bodyguards and when they were small really did say: "Tell us stories about the struggle, mum.")

But she is still as radical as ever. "The struggle of the Palestinians has taken many faces. Armed struggle, intifada, and now both. Which means as long as there is occupation in our country, the conflict will continue." She demands the right to self-determination, a state with Jerusalem as its capital, the right to return for refugees and the withdrawal of Israel from all the land it has occupied since 1967. "Otherwise the purpose for conflict will always be there." And now? "Now people are fed up. They are saying: now and forever. Let's do it. This time."

What she says can be difficult for peaceniks, or pacifists, to hear - the unashamed justification for violence. Many ordinary Palestinians share her views, many politicians do not. Similarly, views on Khaled herself are mixed, even among Palestinians: some think she is an inspiring heroine, others believe she reinforces the old 70s image of Palestinians as terrorists.

Is she a terrorist? "Whenever I hear this word I ask another question," she says. "Who planted terrorism in our area? Some came and took our land, forced us to leave, forced us to live in camps. I think this is terrorism. Using means to resist this terrorism and stop its effects - this is called struggle." She recalls in her memoirs thinking of the risk to children she saw on the plane she was hijacking, and telling herself: "We Palestinians are children too and we are a part of the human race."

Would she still die for the Palestinian cause? She draws on her long cigarette, and turns to face me after some silence. "Of course." She shakes her head, smiling, cigarette burning in her hand. "Of course."

What she says can be difficult for peaceniks, or pacifists, to hear - the unashamed justification for violence. Many ordinary Palestinians share her views, many politicians do not. Similarly, views on Khaled herself are mixed, even among Palestinians: some think she is an inspiring heroine, others believe she reinforces the old 70s image of Palestinians as terrorists. Is she a terrorist? "Whenever I hear this word I ask another question," she says. "Who planted terrorism in our area? Some came and took our land, forced us to leave, forced us to live in camps. I think this is terrorism. Using means to resist this terrorism and stop its effects - this is called struggle." She recalls in her memoirs thinking of the risk to children she saw on the plane she was hijacking, and telling herself: "We Palestinians are children too and we are a part of the human race." Would she still die for the Palestinian cause? She draws on her long cigarette, and turns to face me after some silence. "Of course." She shakes her head, smiling, cigarette burning in her hand. "Of course."

fields.headline: The best washed-up scene
fields.standfirst: Cast Away
fields.trailText: Cast Away
fields.body:
The sole survivor of a horrific plane crash, Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks) has found himself marooned on a remote and apparently uninhabited island somewhere in the Pacific.

Standing on the edge of the shore, he bellows in every conceivable direction.

"Hello? Hello?"

Silence.

"Anybody?"

Noland screams at the top of his lungs.

"Help! Help!"

Looking out to sea, Noland picks up a piece of driftwood and begins marking the sand beneath his feet.

At first, it's unclear what Noland is attempting to write. Then, as he painstakingly draws another line in the sand, an H appears. Next, slowly and deliberately, an E. And so on, until we finally pull back to see Noland standing on the beach, dwarfed by the letters around him.

H E L P

Noland retreats to a nearby rock to sit and wait. As he stares ahead, a look of panic spreads across his face. His expression shifting to one of quiet despair, he watches as the incoming tide begins to slowly wash away his handiwork. Trudging back to the beach, he begins collecting wood, shells, and any other detritus that comes to hand. Falling to his knees, he begins methodically placing each article in the sand. Later, he retreats to the rock again, looking back down to the sand to see a single word marked out on the beach.

H E L P

See also: Treasure Island, Robinson Crusoe, The Hell Ship

Don't see also: 6 Days 7 Nights

Pointless trivia: Most of the sound from this scene had to be dubbed by director Robert Zemeckis in LA, as the real tide was found to be "too noisy".

fields.headline: Dead Babies
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Without Martin Amis's prose performance and narrative voice, this callow black comedy of sex and paranoia is just a frantic - and frantically unpleasant - farce.
fields.body:
Now Martin Amis has something else in common with Nabokov: his novels don't seem to make it into the cinema. Because this film, an adaptation of Amis's 1974 novel about a sinister lost weekend of country-house debauchery, is boring, embarrassing, nasty and stupid - and not in a good way. Without Martin Amis's prose performance and narrative voice, this callow black comedy of sex and paranoia is just a frantic - and frantically unpleasant - farce.

Notionally updated to the 21st century with things like websites, PlayStations and Sony Handicams with flip-out screens, Dead Babies is nonetheless saddled with the clunkiest of dated 1970s tat: superannuated hippies saying "far out"; Jaded hedonists evincing an obsolete faith in the exotic and infinitely varied hallucinatory properties of "drugs"; posh people having a bit of rough. It's all from that Very Antonia Fraser, Very Sanderson world of Harold Wilson's final administration.

Whose fault is this film? Well, not the actors'. Dead Babies features the brightest of young British acting talent doing their very considerable best: Paul Bettany, Olivia Williams, and particularly Andy Nyman as the tiny, malevolent Keith Whitehead.

But it all goes for nothing in this leaden, unhappy movie. William Marsh and producer Richard Holmes have already had a spectacular public falling-out over it. Marsh has complained that Holmes cut it behind his back. Did Marsh originally envisage a longer film with more of Amis' narration in voiceover? Perhaps - but I'm not sure that would have helped. I'm afraid this was a misconceived film from the beginning.

fields.headline: The Low Down
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: What a treat to see a zeitgeisty film about London twentysomethings that isn't all about ecstasy, clubbing, and someone getting murdered.
fields.body:
The charm of this spacious and utterly relaxed first feature from Jamie Thraves creeps up on you like a fine summer's day. His film might be rough and ready, but it makes something uniquely difficult look easy - a believable account of ordinary people, who become more engaging as their characters unfold, while they get on with doing not very much.

Aidan Gillen is Frank, a bloke who lives in London and makes props for TV shows: at present he and his colleagues are making a big zany hand for a comedy duo. (My guess was Vic and Bob, but it turns out to be Channel 4's Adam and Joe, who make a smilingly laid-back appearance, utterly in synch with the feel of the film.) In between hanging out with his mates, chatting, or arguing as it might be, Frank falls for Ruby - the excellent Kate Ashfield - who is an estate agent.

And that's about it. Thraves has a novelist's eye for detail and the intelligence to let his characters develop easily and naturally, going for longish takes, and meandering off after them with hand-held shots as his principals slope amiably about. Some might be put off by the rough edges, and the self-conscious bit of A Bout de Souffle that sometimes creeps in. But what a treat to see a zeitgeisty film about London twentysomethings that isn't all about ecstasy, clubbing, and someone getting murdered. Why can't more British films be like this humane and persuasive comedy?

fields.headline: Woman on Top
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Penelope Cruz looks sensational, but gives a performance of purest teak with a hint of mahogany.
fields.body:
In its naffness and cheesiness, this film reminded me of a notorious book of coffee-table eroticism that came out many years ago called Rude Food. It showed naughty-but-nice glimpses of red wine being poured into navels, trifles being smeared on to buttocks etc.

Woman on Top fancies itself as a romantic, sensual fantasy, and is about a lovely young Brazilian woman Isabella (Penelope Cruz) who is a brilliant cook, and equates the pleasures of cuisine with her conjugal satisfactions with Toninho (Murilo Benicio), her husband. But she can only make love on top, so Toninho cheats on her with a woman who will allow him the superior position and, heartbroken, Isabella runs away to America where she stays with her exuberant transvestite friend Monica (Harold Perrineau): a trite mise-en-scène clearly cloned from Cruz's appearance in a far superior film, Almodovar's All About My Mother.

Penelope Cruz looks sensational, but gives a performance of purest teak with a hint of mahogany. She has lots of flaccid speeches about the mysteries of chillies: sensually inhaling their fragrance, while dreamily recollecting Toninho's spicy love-making. But it might as well be a frozen McCain Mini Pizza she's got under her nose, judging by Cruz's performance - which is so outrageously bad that she ends up looking about as sexy as Nora Batty.

fields.headline: Pay It Forward
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: . Little Haley Joel Osment's Princess-Di-cum-Christ-child status will set your teeth a-grinding.
fields.body:
Shouldn't a movie about the practical and moral possibilities of altruism be a refreshing change from the usual brainless Hollywood fare? Yes, but this one turns out to be the yuckiest, gloopiest, most sick-makingly sentimental film imaginable.

Haley Joel Osment, the boy who saw the dead people in The Sixth Sense, puts that tiny little intense voice of his to work as Trevor, the 11-year-old son of alcoholic trailer-park mom Arlene, played inevitably by Helen Hunt, perhaps the most irritatingly over-exposed actor now working. (Hunt is the avatar of credible yet acceptable non-prettiness.)

Captivated by Mr Simonet (Kevin Spacey), the uptight yet inspirational teacher with a mysteriously burned face, Trevor invents the concept of Pay It Forward: you do three people a good turn, requiring each of them in return to do three more people a good turn and so the random acts of kindness proliferate in a kind of pyramid- selling operation.

In the film, Pay It Forward sweeps America. In real life, despite the existence of this film and the original bestselling novel, it hasn't - perhaps Americans think of it as a creepy, coercive and self-congratulatory notion that fails to understand that moral action is a matter of sustained long-term commitment within one's own community, rather than flinging three good turns into the void and sitting back. Anyway...

Under Trevor's cutely covert guidance, Helen Hunt falls in love with Kevin Spacey, natch, and Kevin's big revelation about his face, inevitably saved up for the final reel, is a grisly tear-jerker of titanic proportions. Little Haley Joel Osment's Princess-Di-cum-Christ-child status will set your teeth a-grinding. The music, by Thomas Newman, is exasperatingly similar to the score he composed for American Beauty.
