webTitle: Russian colonel's defection an intelligence coup for Britain

fields.headline: Russian colonel's defection an intelligence coup for Britain
fields.standfirst:
Prized catch: officer gave insight into Soviet ballistic missile tests

Related stories:
Editor 'provided cover for spies'
MI6's lawyers lose spy book appeal
Pen mightier than the sword
fields.trailText: Prized catch: officer gave insight into Soviet ballistic missile tests
fields.body:
A Russian colonel who defected to Britain in 1992 provided vital intelligence on Moscow's strategic command headquarters in the Ural mountains and on Soviet ballistic missiles tests from 1984 to 1990, Richard Tomlinson writes in his banned book, The Big Breach.

The intelligence was so high grade, Mr Tomlinson says he was told, that it went all the way to the White House and Downing Street.

In a separate high risk operation, MI6 spirited the most advanced armoured personnel carrier in the Russian arsenal, the BMP-3, out of Russia to the Polish port of Gdansk and shipped it across, with the help of the Poles, to Southampton where it was taken apart and found to be better than anything Nato had in terms of manoeuvrability, speed, and firepower.

The defector, said to have been a colonel working for Russia's elite strategic missiles forces, approached an English territorial army sergeant, in Russia to run the Moscow marathon in June 1992, with a view to defecting, according to the book.

He showed up in London shortly afterwards and following a series of debriefing sessions at the Admiralty in Whitehall, the debriefing officer, a physicist and missiles expert called Malcolm Knightley - not his real name - announced he had struck it rich. "The guy's a goldmine. We've got to get him residency," Mr Knightley is quoted as telling the author.

The colonel, originally from Kiev, had worked in Soviet missile control for every ballistic missile test done between 1984 and 1990 and the head of the Russian section at MI6 said he was recommending Simakov's acceptance as a full defector to the then foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd.

"'His information would be invaluable to the DIS (defence intelligence service) and, more importantly, to the Americans," Mr Tomlinson writes.

Mr Knightley told Mr Tomlinson that the intelligence went "up to the PM. He later told me it eventually reached President George Bush's office".

"We've hit the jackpot with this guy," Knightley is quoted as saying. "He's just given us the location and layout of a new top secret command bunker set deep inside a mountain in the Urals."

Mr Tomlinson then describes how he travelled to Moscow under cover as a businessman and attended a conference at the the most exclusive hotel in Moscow to "exfiltrate" two notebooks the colonel had secreted in a sewing machine at his mother's flat in a high-rise estate on the city's outskirts.

The notebooks are said to have contained data and statistics describing "perturbations in the flight paths of every ballistic missile fired from the Soviet missile test range in Kamchatka between late 1987 and early 1990."

MI6 would win considerable kudos by sharing the information with the Americans.

Mr Tomlinson describes walking through outer Moscow to visit the colonel's mother, charming his way into the flat with barely a word of Russian, covertly extracting the books, and rushing them to the British embassy from where they were put in the diplomatic bag to London.

He also claims that a millionaire arms dealer working for MI6 managed to get the coveted BMP-3 armoured car to Southampton by negotiating a consignment of lower grade armoured cars for export to the United Arab Emirates in 1991. The dealer, codenamed Battle, is said to have earned £100,000 a year from MI6.

The BMP-3 carries a crew of three plus seven infantrymen. "On one visit [to London] he mentioned he had been shown around the advanced variant of the BMP-3. MI6 persuaded him to try to acquire one. On his next trip, with a £500,000 backhander and forged end-user certificate provided by MI6, Battle persuaded his Russian contact to hide one of the advanced specification BMP-3s among the first batch of 20 export variants."

According to Mr Tomlinson's book, the vehicles were ferried by train to Gdansk. The UAE consignment was offloaded for shipping to Abu Dhabi. "The remaining vehicle, with the assistance of Polish liaison, was loaded into a tramp steamer and shipped to the army port of Marchwood, Southampton."

It was put through field trials in Scotland "disguised under a fibre glass shell to prevent observation by Russian satellites."

fields.headline: Pen mightier than the sword
fields.standfirst:
Related stories:
Editor 'provided cover for spies'
MI6's lawyers lose spy book appeal
Russian colonel's defection an intelligence coup for Britain
fields.trailText: The Pentel rollerball pen is MI6's unique secret weapon. And its value in the Boy's Own world of secret agents is due entirely to accident.
fields.body:
The Pentel rollerball pen is MI6's unique secret weapon. And its value in the Boy's Own world of secret agents is due entirely to accident.

MI5 and MI6 jointly run a three-strong team of experts dedicated only to researching and providing training in secret writing and invisible ink, according to a controversial book by former intelligence agent Richard Tomlinson.

An attempt by the government to delay publication in the British media of the contents of the book, The Big Breach, finally collapsed in the court of appeal yesterday.

The book reveals that British intelligence's favoured "offset" method of secret writing entails jotting down notes with a Pentel, then pressing the writing on to a clean sheet of paper, thereby transferring an invisi ble chemical to the clean sheet - which reproduces the written message when swabbed with the developing fluid that Tomlinson says he carried disguised as a bottle of Ralph Lauren toilet water.

The technique was discovered accidentally in the 1980s when a secret message from Russia was being developed in London and found also to contain Cyrillic script from the surface of a letter it had been pressed against in the post. "The technician realised that the Kiev address must have been written with a commercially available pen. If that pen could be identified, it would be a superbly elegant, simple, and deniable secret writing implement," Tomlinson writes.

"MI6 mounted a systematic worldwide search for the pen and every MI6 station was asked to send a secretary to the local stationery store and buy every make available. It took many weeks to identify the magic pen: the Pentel rollerball. Offset is now used routinely by MI6 officers in the field."

More glamorous accessories are kept in a spy's false-bottomed briefcase, according to the rogue agent. Ordinary cassette recorders are modified to utilise the normally unused parts of the magnetic tape for clandestine recording, and hidden spaces in floppy disks are used to secrete wordprocessing systems in laptop computers.

On his arrival as an agent in Bosnia in 1993, Tomlinson says his predecessor handed him a fountain pen which fired a 7.65mm bullet when the cap was turned. "Here, take a look at this, one of [Bosnian Serb leader Radovan] Karadzic's bodyguards gave it to me," Tomlinson says he was told.

The specialised army, Royal navy, and RAF back-up sec onded to work with MI6 also means the Secret Intelligence Service is equipped with a mini-submarine, a Puma helicopter, a Hercules transport aircraft, and a crack unit of SAS troops based in Hereford known as the "Revolutionary Warfare Wing", Tomlinson writes.

The RAF supplies 10 pilots known as the "SD flight". The army and navy contributions are known as "the increment" and are trained in sabotage, guerrilla warfare, VIP protection, and use of explosives.

The Hercules C-130 transport aircraft is used for ferrying large items of equipment to MI6 stations abroad, while the naval staff, based at Poole in Dorset, operate MI6's mini-submarine - "about the length of two cars. The pilot and navigator sit astride the cylindrical forward hull dressed in dry suits and breathing apparatus. The rear half of the craft flattens into a passenger compartment which is just large enough to carry four persons packed together like sardines."

fields.headline: Taxing time for UK students
fields.trailText: Millions of pounds are unwittingly being paid by the UK's student population in taxes they don't owe, according to a new report.
fields.body:
Millions of pounds are unwittingly being paid by the UK's student population in taxes they don't owe, according to a new report.

'Students: the case for making life easier' has been prepared by the Low Income Tax Reforms Group (LITRG). It says the way students are being treated is shameful and that the tax system is in a complete mess.

It slams various government departments for producing complicated and outdated material. It also says the three departments who students are most likely to deal with continue to "work out of their own silos" and so don't produce a co-ordinated approach. These are the Inland Revenue, the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) and the Benefits Agency.

Mr Andrews also criticises the fact that tax matters are not part of the National Curriculum. His report raps the DfEE for the "lack of thought being given to the tax education of this next generation of workers." And it says Benefits Agency staff do not do enough to make sure students understand their tax position. The current limit that most students can earn to without paying tax is £4,385 a year.

The report adds that many of the UK's employers are ignorant of the student tax position and so make unnecessary deductions from wages, which are often extremely low.

Even though students can claim back tax, many find this a complicated process or are not even aware they area able to. All this just adds to student poverty.

The LITRG has put forward a number of proposals to alleviate the problem. It wants to see the Inland Revenue establish a "students champion" who will address these issues.

It also urges the three departments adopt "a more joined up approach" so that students receive the same messages.

Other recommendations are that a student pack, both in paper and online, should be produced to explain what students are entitled to. It points out the Inland Revenue does not even have a dedicated section for students on its website. It also says literature produced by the Inland Revenue is out of date.

Students who want to work in the holidays must fill in a Form P38(S) if they are to be exempt from tax. The forms should be supplied by the employer, although many, particularly smaller firms, do not know they exist.

Many students also work in the term time to support themselves. But the P38 (S) does not apply to this and so even though the money earned is unlikely to exceed allowances, some students are being taxed. The LITRG is calling for the Inland Revenue to clarify the rules on term time working.

Around 12% of students are from overseas. They are entitled to certain tax breaks but many are unaware of this and don't know how to find out their entitlements.

Mature students, who have worked previously and paid tax, can also find themselves in tax difficulties and need help with sorting out their status.

And there are also complications with students who undertake work placements as part of their courses. They can earn up to £7,000 a year and be exempt from tax. This again is not mentioned in the IR60.

These include leaflets, factsheets, a video and Z cards, which are reference guides that can be folded to credit card size. While the report says some of these are useful, it points out that some staff in Inland Revenue offices are not aware of them and neither are staff in other departments.

A spokeswoman for the Inland Revenue hit back at accusations that they were not doing enough to help students.

"We sent out employers packs and they should all have P38(S) forms to supply to students. If they don't have them, then they can request them from us," she said.

She explained the Inland Revenue planned to step up its outreach programme that involved talking to schools and planned to improve communication with other departments.

"We are looking to build on what we have already done," she added.

Students can also find out more by contacting the National Union of Students. Its Information Sheet 7 provides on areas such as income tax, avoiding tax on bank and building society interest and self-assessment.

A spokeswoman said many students were confused about tax and were not helped by employers who did not understand about exemption. "Some students have told us employers only know about P45s and haven't heard about P 38s," she said.

The sheet can be downloaded from the NUS.

Another website, launched last week, focuses on students' rights at work, although to date does not offer tax advice.

The Unison-backed Trouble at work has information primarily on issues such as health and safety, bullying and work related problems. A spokeswoman said they would be happy to respond to emails from students who needed advice on any issue including tax.

fields.headline: Mitsuko Uchida
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
The ingredients of Mitsuko Uchida's recitals are familiar by now, but the expertise and thoughtfulness of her programme building, and the sense of discovery she brings to everything she plays, ensures there is never a hint of staleness or routine. She chose Schubert, Debussy and Chopin for the Festival Hall, and each was freshly illuminated

The A minor Sonata, D537 that began the evening is the earliest and least well-known of Schubert's three in that key. Uchida attacked it with highly focused intensity, flourishing the arpeggios of its opening theme, picking out the main theme of the andante in haunted relief, and giving the finale the ebullience of something by Scarlatti.

Anyone who believed there was nothing new to say about the Moments Musicaux was in for a wonderful surprise. In a programme note, Uchida described how last year she had returned to the six pieces and found new depths and riches - "as if they are a newly discovered late song-cycle by Schubert". That was exactly how she played them, ever wondering at their mysterious harmonic shifts and nostalgic backward glances, and investing each of these miniatures with a stature and emotional range that most performances never approach. Echoes of the late sonatas were everywhere, and the way she dwelt on the final A flat allegretto, as if unwilling to let go of its spell, silenced even the persistent coughers in the audience.

Then different worlds altogether. Chopin's B flat minor Sonata was preceded by three of Debussy's more aqueous Preludes: Ondine, full of sinuous, suggestive lines; Voiles, a study in perfectly defined pastel shades; La cathedrale engloutie, with every layer lucid yet mysterious.

The poise of those performances was carried over into the Chopin. There was no hell-for-leather drama in the first movement, only classical proportioning. Her musicologically correct decision to include the brief slow introduction in her exposition repeat subtlely shifted its centre of gravity. The scherzo had clarity and deftness; the funeral march was subdued and genuinely sorrowful, not menacing; and the presto finale had point, shape and purpose. No exercise in mindless pyrotechnics this, but something darker, sharper and even more remarkable.

webTitle: MPs slate Brown over Equitable Life crisis

fields.headline: MPs slate Brown over Equitable
fields.trailText: Calls for government compensation to policyholders hit by the Equitable Life crisis were stepped up yesterday as shadow chancellor Michael Portillo demanded Gordon Brown "take responsibility" for his alleged part in the company's misfortunes.
fields.body:
Calls for government compensation to policyholders hit by the Equitable Life crisis were stepped up yesterday as shadow chancellor Michael Portillo demanded Gordon Brown "take responsibility" for his alleged part in the company's misfortunes.

Mr Portillo was one of several MPs who challenged the government in the Commons yesterday. He highlighted a Treasury letter from 1998 which appears to endorse actions taken by the company which led to its present plight.

Equitable is talking to several companies, including Dutch group Aegon, about the sale of all or parts of Equitable after closing its doors to new business early last month.

Up to 1m policyholders have been warned they will face lower investment returns after it lost a legal battle over guaranteed annuities.

Mr Portillo said it was as a result of the Treasury venturing the "wrong" opinion on the law that Equitable had not put itself up for sale earlier. He referred to guidance issued by the Treasury in December 1998, which stated that it believed policyholders with annuity guarantees could be expected to pay a charge towards the cost of the guarantee - which could take the form of a reduction in the terminal bonus.

This guidance was withdrawn after the Lords ruled last summer that Equitable's actions to this effect were illegal.

Mr Portillo claimed millions were "living in anxiety" over the fate of their investments. Tory MP John Butterfill added that as the Treasury and regulators had "failed the public", the government may have responsibility for compensating policyholders.

fields.headline: Rich simplicity from Peter Brook
fields.standfirst:
Le Costume
Young Vic, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Le Costume
Young Vic, London
*****
fields.body:
"Cultivate simplicity," was Lamb's advice to Coleridge. It's also a good precept for a director. Over the years Peter Brook has taken it so to heart that his focus now is on the tale rather than the teller. Yet behind the resonant strangeness of this South African fable, jointly presented by the Young Vic and the London international festival of theatre, you sense Brook's controlling intelligence.

The Suit, by South African writer Can Themba, was first dramatised for the Market Theatre, Johannesburg, by Mothobi Mutloatse and Barney Simon, and it is this version that is now played in French with English surtitles.

Set in the teeming township of Sophiatown in the 1950s, it tells of a young married couple, Philemon and Matilda. One day Philemon is told that his wife is having an affair. He catches her in flagrante and scares off her lover, who leaves behind his suit. Matilda's punishment is to be ever reminded of the suit, which sits with the pair at suppertimes, is taken for Sunday walks and is fatally deployed by Philemon as a humiliating symbol of his wife's sin.

Themba's tale has the spiky potency of a story from the Decameron: it deals with lust, penitence and a tragic failure of forgiveness. Its theatrical power also stems from its vivid evocation of time and place. Sophiatown itself - erased by the brutal apparatchiks of apartheid in 1955 - is as much the protagonist as the suit. It emerges as a place of hardship where privacy is at a premium - hence the knowledge of Matilda's adultery. But it also comes across paradoxically as a source of energy: of gossip, music, dreams and drinking in the ubiquitous shebeens.

The wonder of Brook's production is that it conveys all this with minimal resources. It is staged on a riotously coloured patterned carpet with a pair of coat-racks used as windows, wardrobes, doors and bus-shelters. But Brook, reminding us that Matilda is a frustrated singer, also evokes the extrovert ebullience of township life through music - everything from Miriam Makeba to Ella Fitzgerald. Even with only four actors, he is able to conjure up a bustling party.

Brook's finest touch is unselfconsciously to embrace the audience. When Tanya Moodie's marvellous Matilda joins a community club she turns to individual spectators as if they were her personal benefactors. And the hauntingly lean Sotigui Kouyate addresses us directly in his opening sketch of Sophiatown.

The pain of the story comes across strongly both in Moodie's aching desire for forgiveness and in Hubert Kounde's intransigent severity as her husband. The moment when he finally grasps her lifeless hand packs an Othello-like punch. Without ever straining for effect, Brook's lustrous production affirms the unending richness of theatrical simplicity.

 Until February 3. Box office: 020-7928 6363. Then at Warwick Arts Centre (024-7652 4524), February 6-9. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.headline: Sea change for Divine Comedy
fields.standfirst:
Divine Comedy
Riverside Studios, London
**
fields.trailText:
Divine Comedy
Riverside Studios, London
**
fields.body:
"Tonight, we're going to play all of the new album. After all, you've got to hear it some time," smirks Divine Comedy's leader, Neil Hannon. Since the album, Regeneration, is not released until March 12, it makes for a most peculiar experience, particularly as Hannon and his music have undergone a sea change since they raised eyebrows by signing to Parlophone after a decade in the indie wilderness and two years after their commercial peak.

Gone are the polo necks, the pipe-smoker's haircuts and the overbearing smugness; in are Beck-style flowing locks, grubby T-shirts and canvas trousers, and a new, more heartfelt approach. Musically, the Regeneration material is far superior to previous work; yet for all his intelligence, a mildly self-deprecatory aura and occasionally startling way with a melody, Hannon is not an especially engaging performer. Nor are any of his six band members, who constantly bump into each other on the tiny Riverside stage.

Eleven unheard songs, leavened by just six more familiar ones, is clearly the fast track to audience bemusement. But aside from the dreadful Eye of the Needle, there is much to commend in Hannon's new work. Bad Ambassador is as chunky and muscular of melody as the Divine Comedy have allowed themselves to be, while Lost Property features a xylophone - albeit an almost inaudible one - and is the evening's prettiest melody.

Before the wistful Perfect Lovesong, Hannon declares: "I can see it being our first number one. These words will probably come back to haunt me. When it's number one. Ha ha." There is, of course, more chance of Neil Young having a chart-topping single than Neil Hannon, but at least the coy boy from Londonderry is finally showing his hand. Even if this performance felt more like a showcase than a proper concert, his new direction may yet arrest his decline.

Of the older material, the twee National Express and Becoming More Like Alfie are delivered solo and acoustic as part of the solitary encore. Hannon looks embarrassed, as well he might.

Oddly, the one moment of genuine emotional engagement came much earlier, with the distinctly less heralded Tonight We Fly, from 1994's Promenade. With celestial backing vocals from Bryan Mills, a military drum tattoo and a spiralling keyboard melody closely related to Can's I Want More, for once the Divine Comedy felt like a band rather than a singer and his backing musicians. There is much work to be done here, but the cause is not wholly irretrievable.

fields.headline: Unity's resounding drama of a nobody
fields.standfirst:
Dust to Dust
Unity Theatre, Liverpool
****
fields.trailText:
Dust to Dust
Unity Theatre, Liverpool
****
fields.body:
Nothing became Mick's life, it seems, so much as the manner of his leaving it - in a drunken heap at the bottom of the stairs. He is shabby and unreliable, and the world will get on fine without him. But his passing leaves a Mick-shaped hole in his familiar milieu of the Bull's Head, and Robert Farquhar's elegiac new play steals in to fill the gap.

Farquhar's fizzing, quotidian poetry has been making waves in the north-west for some time, with recent pieces such as God's Official and Kissing Sid James moving on from Liverpool's tiny but funky Unity Theatre to the bigger venues of the Bolton Octagon, Hull Truck and Oldham Coliseum. While the subject matter of his tangy tabloid theatre is mundane to the point of anonymity, his forte is embedding minute detail into general linguistic clutter.

Farquhar's language is not unlike his dead hero's flat. It is in a shocking state - false trails and parentheses all over the place, dramatic threads festering undeveloped beneath accumulated non sequiturs. It sounds horrible, but there's something unusually compelling, not to mention bleakly hilarious, about this reckless untidiness, like waiting for a stack of dirty plates to collapse.

The action involves little more than getting Mick cremated, his flat cleared and his ashes scattered in Scotland. But it becomes more than this: a heavy-lidded, hungover speculation on death presented as a dramatic poem for the three voices of Henry, Kev and Holly, a trio of misfits on the margins of life imperceptibly pulled together by the absence of Mick.

Sarah Thornton's meticulous production makes good use of nothing - just three characters caught in space by crosscurrents of language. Farquhar is adept at creating the impression of everybody talking at once without the sense degenerating into babble, and the performances are miracles of finely nuanced verbosity.

Ron Meadows cuts a louche, distracted figure as Mick's drinking pal Henry, startled that he is the one rung up in the middle of the night to identify a body. The first thought to cross the mind of Mick's estranged wife Holly, touchingly played by Jane Hogarth, is that she once had sex with someone who is now dead. Kev's relationship with the deceased is more ambivalent still: Warren Donnelly delightfully plays him as a neurotic bystander who got roped into someone else's tragedy. At the end, I still had absolutely no idea who Mick was. But I will miss him.

 Ends tomorrow. Box office: 0151-709 4988.

Greenwich Theatre, London
**
fields.trailText:
Greenwich Theatre, London
**
fields.body:
Common Road School is a down-at-heel secondary in the north. It has never won anything, except bottom place in the league tables two years in a row. The kids have given up on the school and the school has given up on the kids. The headmaster likes the place best when they've all gone home. Only the drama teacher believed that "you've got to live each day as if it were your last" - and he has just died of a stress-related heart attack.

His replacement is Mary Clifford, who has been out of teaching for 15 years. Within minutes of her arrival she is reminded why she left. Mary has got the dregs - Stacey, Kerry and Maggie, three 16-year-olds going on 160 who have no self-esteem, no motivation, no hope and no future.

John Godber's latest piece to hit London isn't so much a play as a sparky, passionate piece of propaganda about why we need arts teaching in school. It is quite the most enjoyable piece of propaganda I've ever sat through but, in an evening in which the message is what counts most, theatre plays second fiddle to theatre in education.

It begins extremely well. Mary's frustrating attempts to deal with Stacey, Kerry and Maggie - who blank her out with a mixture of insolence and indifference - ring completely true. But Godber has a sentimental streak a mile wide and it is not long before gritty reality turns to fairy tale as Mary starts hitting it off not just with the kids but also with Stacey's hard-man dad.

A weekend in London watching Pina Bausch and Robbie Williams (not, regrettably, on the same bill) proves that even the most hopeless cases can be redeemed by art. And the pompous old headmaster - an idiot you feel sure would have been relieved of his duties long ago - suddenly decides that dance and drama deserve their place in the curriculum.

Optimism has a place in our thinking about education and fantasy has its place on stage, but here everything is so sugar-coated that the real problems facing girls, teachers and the educational system are merely glossed over in favour of a happy-ever-after ending.

This exceptionally well-acted show is a musical - not of the West End song-and-dance variety, more Bertolt Brecht meets Willy Russell. Composer John Pattison's music is excellent and as a lyricist Godber sometimes hits harder than he does as a dramatist. Kerry's lament of a home life made up solely of snacks in front of the TV is both funny and true.

 Until February 3. Box office: 020-8858 7755.

webTitle: Notebook: Offshore havens must be cleaned up

fields.headline: Offshore havens must be cleaned up
fields.standfirst: Talking shop should not open
fields.trailText: Ambitious plans for a new global tax forum will be discussed in London today. Britain has been at the forefront of the OECD's attempted crackdown on international tax evasion, much of which takes place in outposts of the old colonial empire.
fields.body:
Ambitious plans for a new global tax forum will be discussed in London today at Marlborough House, home of the Commonwealth Secretariat. The venue could not be more appropriate. Britain has been at the forefront of the OECD's attempted crackdown on international tax evasion, much of which takes place in outposts of the old colonial empire.

But the UK's lead on the issue has brought it as many enemies as friends. While the rich industrialised countries are keen to secure their tax bases, off shore financial centres complain that their sovereignty is being infringed by the threat of sanctions unless they lift the cloak of secrecy covering their banking systems. They are particularly irked by the lack of consultation.

To break the deadlock, offshore financial centres are proposing that the OECD initiative should be scrapped in favour of a new process, an ever so grand-sounding Global Forum on International Taxation, which would include both developed and developing countries.

It would not only draw up rules for the operation of offshore centres but also deal with the whole range of cross-border tax issues in a global economy where money can be moved around at the touch of a button.

The offshore centres say the new forum would represent a "truly inclusive approach to developing global tax co-operation" - not just the big guys beating up on the little ones. They say it could have a small secretariat and report to a governing committee consisting of ministers from participating countries. To minimise cost and bureaucracy, meetings could coincide with other international gatherings such as those of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

In fact, the OECD already has a global forum on taxation, but the offshore centres complain that it reports to OECD ministers and the Group of Seven, effectively excluding the rest of the world. Unless it is made more representative, it will have no legitimacy beyond the tight-knit circle of the OECD's 30-strong membership.

Fair enough, perhaps, although there should be no illusions regarding the fact that dragging the world's offshore bolt-holes into some sort of line will be a kicking and screaming affair.

A newly constituted body with better representation is all very well, but the OECD's first priority should be to obtain a prior commitment to reform from the offshore centres. Dropping the OECD initiative now without some sort of blueprint on cleaning up the offshore world would simply leave the new body as an ineffective talking shop.

Game playing

Eidos! You have just lost three quarters of a billion pounds.

Well, in truth, shares in the Wimbledon-based video games design company have been travelling back to earth for much of the past year, despite its Who Wants to be a Millionaire? game sitting at the top of the charts.

And the bottom may not yet have been reached: yesterday saw yet another profits warning, blamed on weak sales in the United States and delays in publishing new titles. There were some bright spots - the previous management's champagne lifestyle has been reigned in, while the Millionaire title was something of a Christmas cracker.

But the overall tone for the company remains downbeat, even if it can pull off the promised £10m cost cuts - without redundancies, note - in the coming year, plug the holes in its management structure, and continue its charm offensive in the City.

The problem is that its current portfolio of games is looking threadbare.

Even the Millionaire success was not unalloyed: Eidos's profit margins are likely to be thin on a product with a high licensing fee and relatively low retail price tag.

The downward pressure on prices in the European games market last year did not help matters, which makes it urgent for the company to come up with a winner for the Playstation2 console, where margins are much higher and early adopters seem happy to buy up full-price software.

That Eidos has chosen to delay releasing its brace of new PlayStation2 titles is surprising, since it will find itself launching titles into a much more congested market later this year.

The alternative - a slimmed-down Eidos making cheap and cheerful Millionaire-style licensed games for the PS1 legacy platform - may be a better bet for the bottom line, at least in the short term. For the longer term it has to be able to prove it still has the creative firepower to grab a share of the market on the more sophisticated platforms.

And, aside from the games themselves, Eidos still has much to do in terms of convincing the City that this is a professionally managed, quoted entity, with proper internal controls - something that has been woefully lacking in the past.

fields.headline: Elton Dean Trio
fields.standfirst:
Elton Dean Trio
Wardrobe, Leeds
***
fields.trailText:
Elton Dean Trio
Wardrobe, Leeds
***
fields.body:
From the distant shores of experimental 1960s British rock to the seething waters of contemporary improvised jazz, Elton Dean's journey has been a long and intriguing one. His understated yet authoritative saxophone has provided a lead voice for such genre-straddling acts as Soft Machine and Ninesense, as well finding a home in musical collaborations with Alexis Korner, Alan Skidmore and Keith Tippett. In Leeds, Dean's current trio continued their leader's dogged 30-year quest by defiantly making a huge racket in front of a handful of people and eliciting a somewhat mixed response.

The first half of the show was hard work, with drummer Mark Sanders and double-bass player John Edwards beating us over the head with death-defying acts of virtuosity. The steamrolling power was relentless, but somehow the band missed its target - if indeed it had one. Improvised music is principally not about melody, rhythm or harmony but about generating and swapping vast amounts of energy, and in this sense the performance was faultless. However, a distressing lack of space and sunshine quickly became evident, with none of the instruments quite managing to tell a story.

Dean is an unassuming figure, and sometimes his tastefully restrained playing was in danger of being overwhelmed by the agitated and impersonal clatter of his rhythm section. The three instruments played non-stop for over half an hour, somehow succeeding in roaring as a whole while simultaneously trying to break away from each other's tangled orbit.

Some members of the audience appeared glum, and most looked pensive. One restless soul at the back of the room did his best to instigate a round of applause whenever the noise thinned out slightly, but no one took his cue, and it was only a matter of time before we were plunged once more into the seething hurricane.

Salvation beckoned in the second half as spaces were finally left open, and one truly thrilling groove was established by Sanders's belated decision to quit his tom-toms and stick to the bare-bone jazz essentials of cymbals and bass drum - played at breakneck speed, of course.

Now we could stop wringing our hands and properly enjoy Edwards's almost comical assault on his double bass, his performance winding up more physical than musical.

Eventually, Dean's vastly accomplished ensemble hit the spot and everyone was happy - apart from the cowards who left at the interval.

fields.headline: Scotia collapses into bickering
fields.standfirst: The arguments get personal as trading in biotech firm's shares is halted
fields.trailText: In the ancient Scottish town of Stirling recriminations have begun over the collapse of Scotia Holdings, one of Britain's oldest biotechnology companies. Trading in Scotia's shares was suspended on Wednesday, after a three-year tailspin in the business's value from £550m to £16m.
fields.body:
In the ancient Scottish town of Stirling recriminations have begun over the collapse of Scotia Holdings, one of Britain's oldest biotechnology companies. Trading in Scotia's shares was suspended on Wednesday, after a three-year tailspin in the business's value from £550m to £16m. Within 24 hours, the firm's founder, David Horrobin, was pointing the finger of blame at his successor, the "ultra-abrasive" chief executive Robert Dow.

Dr Horrobin left Scotia two years ago. He now runs a psychiatric research business, Laxdale, based just a couple of miles from Scotia, on the outskirts of Stirling. He said yesterday: "I've refrained from commenting to the press until now because Dow has basically been going around slagging me off. I felt life was too short to get involved, but now I want people to understand the true story."

A former professor at a Canadian university, Dr Horrobin established Scotia's predecessor, Efamol, with his wife, Sherri Clarkson, in 1979. It initially concentrated on natural products - Dr Horrobin had identified evening primrose oil as a potentially useful treatment for eczema after trying it on the son of a librarian from his college.

Using profits from nutritional products, Dr Horrobin wanted to research lipids - the fatty molecules he suspected were key to the development and treatment of disease. Scotia floated in 1993 and had considerable initial success - several products obtained regulatory approval, including eczema drug Epogam, breast pain treatment Efamast and Efalith, for dandruff.

Things began to go wrong three years ago, when the Medicines Control Agency turned down Tarabetic, a much-hyped medicine for the nerve damage caused by diabetes. The market wiped £190m off Scotia's value in a day, and critics began sniping that Scotia was woolly, sprawling and lacking in focus.

Dr Horrobin was considered too fond of "hippy" projects such as primrose oil. The City questioned why his wife, whose most advanced qualification was a BA in English and women's studies, was in charge of Scotia's drug discovery division.

The couple stepped down in 1998, although whether they were pushed remains in dispute. Robert Dow, a sharp-suited former executive at Swiss drugs firm Roche, became chief executive, and immediately imposed his own style.

Mr Dow maintains that when he arrived, the business was in disarray. The only way he could raise money was through a £50m convertible debt issue - which cast a shadow over the shares - and he was forced to slash 170 jobs.

He axed 23 of the firm's 28 development projects and concentrated on cancer drugs. His best hope was Foscan, a light-activated treatment which showed dramatic effects in trials.

In a catastrophic blow, however, Scotia development partner Boehringer Ingelheim pulled out of a deal to collaborate on Foscan, citing "other priorities".

Dr Horrobin pinpoints this as the moment when Scotia was doomed, claiming the German firm pulled out because Mr Dow had sacked all the scientists working on the project: "The loss of Boehringer was a fundamental blow and he was responsible for it.

"As a result, Foscan has been developed for the last two years by people who don't understand the product."

Dr Horrobin was so incensed that he made an unsuccessful attempt to regain his position in a boardroom coup.

Mr Dow disagrees - he says his personnel changes were irrelevant. "Boehringer were deeply disturbed about the financial position of Scotia. They were very fearful we'd go into liquidation."

Scotia never found an alternative partner. The Scottish company could only afford the bare minimum of clinical trials, which American and European regulators decided were inadequate.

Disastrous decisions

Dr Horrobin claims Scotia's management made other disastrous decisions. He says Mr Dow decided against launching promising new versions of Efamast and Efalith - although Mr Dow maintains that this was in the hands of Searle, the group's development partner.

Dr Horrobin also alleges that Olibra, a weight-loss ingredient for yoghurts and other foods, has been wasted by a decision to put it in the hands of US foods firm General Mills - which, after two years, has launched nothing using Olibra. Mr Dow says the project is still on track.

"For Dow to say Scotia was in a mess when he arrived is simply not credible," says Horrobin. "He had the deep pockets of big pharmaceuticals firms behind him."

Mr Dow expresses fundamental scepticism about the lipid-based technology on which Scotia was based. He also points out that failure is hardly unusual - for every drug launched by the pharmaceuticals industry, thousands fail.

"I wish David Horrobin would stop taking it so personally," he says. "He's a very proud man and he made many useful scientific suggestions. He feels his reputation is damaged if those hypotheses don't generate commercial value, but I don't think that's the case."
